A third approach, subscribed to by Rabbeinu Tam and Rosh, and endorsed by various <i>Aharonim</i>, is that in the event of negligent behavior perpetrated by the sub-agent, the principal may proceed directly against the sub-agent.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 42b, s.v. “<i>kol ha-mafkid</i>”; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 3:23; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:42–43; <i>Levush</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 72:31; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:55.</i> The rationale is that the principal never wanted the sub-agent to be the sole individual responsible for the assets. Had this been the case, the principal would have hired the sub-agent.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sho’el u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura</i> 4, <i>helek</i> 3, no. 143.</i> Or, one may argue that in actuality, the sub-agent was holding the assets for safekeeping for the benefit of the agent rather than the owner of the assets, and therefore the agent continued to remain in the picture such that if negligence ensued, he could be liable.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 36a; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i> 291:8; Kahane, supra n. 25, at p 427–428.</i> Regardless of which rationale serves to explain the aforementioned position, given that the sub-agent acted negligently, he will be liable. Should he be impoverished, the principal may seek redress from the agent.
All of the above three approaches are predicated upon the fact that the responsibility of the agent was defined by <i>hilkhot shelihut</i> and <i>shemira</i>. Moreover, should we be dealing with an agent who is equally a partner with the third party by dint of having the status of a <i>shomer</i>, the parameters of his responsibility will be the same as that of any agent.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Shutafut</i> 2:3. See infra n. 71.</i>
Similarly, in our situation, assuming that the appointment of a second broker was approved by the client, if subsequent evidence indicates that the first broker failed to avert the loss or dissipation of assets due to the negligent behavior of the second broker, the assignment of liability would be subject to debate. According to the first approach, the second broker alone would still be liable. However, pursuant to the two other views, the initial broker would be responsible. Should the second broker be incapable of paying for the loss, the first broker would indemnify the client. However, should an agreement between the parties provide that the initial broker must monitor the results of the second broker’s servicing of the account, if the second broker is incapable of paying for any incurred losses due to his negligence, the first broker would remain liable.
However, how does Halakha address the case of an investment manager who owns partnership interests in a fund, sells some partnership interests to investors, and, pursuant to his agreement with the investors, directs a second manager to invest these assets in other financial securities? Clearly, the investment manager assumes the responsibilities of a <i>shomer</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:11; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:8.</i> therefore, the investment manager, similar to the initial broker in the aforementioned case, will be liable for any negligence committed by the second manager, should he be unable to pay.
What is the definition of negligence in the above case? Regarding entrusted assets, <i>Rema</i> states, “the assets are to be placed in a guarded place, which is a function of the locale and the times.”<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:18. See also, <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:20.</i> In other words, the duty of care required of the <i>shomer</i> is dependent upon the prevailing standards of the community for safekeeping such assets. The assumption of the <i>mafkid</i> is that the <i>shomer</i> will guard the entrusted asset according to communal standards.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 134.</i> Moreover, the <i>shomer</i> may treat the object entrusted to him in the same fashion he treats the same object in his own possession, a standard that is higher than the communal standard.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Mezia</i> 8:6; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:14.</i> However, should the <i>shomer</i>’s standard fail to measure up to minimally the communal standard, he will be liable for any negligence.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 70.</i>
Similarly, in our scenario, a manager or broker is obligated to comply with the standards adopted by the capital markets in servicing investment portfolios.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The scope of responsibility for <i>peshi’a</i>, which is defined by accepted norms of behavior of the marketplace, i.e., <i>nohag mekubal</i>, is not limited to a <i>shomer</i> and equally applies to a broker-qua-<i>shaliah</i>, or manager who is viewed as a both a <i>shaliah</i> and a partner<i>.</i> See <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sheluhin ve-Shutafin</i> 3; <i>PDR</i>, supra n. 3, at 46; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, supra n. 69, at 46, n. 9; <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 2:429. For example, an agent cannot be deemed liable if a few are suspicious of the sub-agent’s investment practices. Consequently, if the sub-agent possessed a good reputation and his fraudulent practices were never detected by the SEC, Wall Street, or the like, the agent will be be exempt from liability. The identical conclusion was reached in J. Ezra Merkin and BDO Seidman Securities Litigation, et al., supra n. 4.<br>Due to the ongoing right of a principal to invoke that his mandate “should be for his benefit rather than his detriment,” R. Tenna demurs and argues that a broker or manager is obligated to consider even infrequent instances of potential problems that are not contemplated by most people. See <i>PDR</i>, supra n. 3, at 31–32.</i> Moreover, should industry standards dictate that a manager who earns a higher fee than a discount broker monitor his client’s portfolio while being managed by a second manager, failure to exercise such due diligence in the wake of a customer’s investment depreciation will result in the first manager being held liable.
A broker or manager may opt to protect his client’s assets in the same fashion he treats his own portfolio. However, should his performance be significantly below the prevailing standard, he would be liable for any loss.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Should his treatment be only marginally below the accepted standard, he would be exempt from liability. See <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 117.<br>Moreover, the manager is obligated to operate according to the agreement with his clients. See supra n. 58. <i>A fortiori</i>, the manager will be liable for any acts of <i>peshi’a</i>. See <i>Beit Meir</i>, supra n. 58; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, supra n. 69.</i> Moreover, if a second manager is managing assets under the assumption that the client acquiesces to his appointment, then according to the second and third approaches we outlined above,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying nn. 62–65 and 66–68.</i> the initial manager’s scope of responsibility to avert the negligence of the second manager would be equally defined by industry standards. For example, if the investment community adopted certain standards relating to the overseeing of a second manager’s accounts, then should the first manager turn a blind eye to red flags indicating a depreciation or dissipation of the client’s assets by the second manager, he would be liable if the second broker is unable to repay the client. Adopting the first approach, on the other hand, would exempt the first manager from liability based on <i>hilkhot shelihut</i>. However, should the initial manager have a partnership interest with his former clients, he would remain liable for failing to respond to warning signs of a depreciation or dissipation of their assets.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">See supra, nn. 59, 76, and 77. Despite the absence of a principal-agent relationship, given that the manager has a financial interest in these assets, he remains liable as a partner. See <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>OH</i> 32:12; Hayyim Zafri, Agency, Section 1, (Hebrew) Ministry of Justice, Yerushalayim: Israel.</i>
Should the agreement explicitly provide for someone to serve as a sub-manager, the first manager would disappear from the picture, and the second manager alone would be liable for any negligence.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:26; <i>Teshuvot Mishpatim Yesharim</i> (Birdugo) 1:65; <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Shomerim</i> 20; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 291:24.</i> The client’s consent to the appointment of the second manager indicates that he considers him trustworthy.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 5:11.</i> However, should the agreement between the parties provide that the initial manager continue to monitor the second one’s asset management, here again the scope of the oversight will be determined by market standards.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Given that the first manager is only a <i>shomer</i>, it might be cogently argued that even R. Tenna would concur that the first manager’s responsibility would be limited to being aware of prevailing trade standards. See supra n. 75.<br>Regarding the responsibilities of the second manager, see <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i>, supra n. 75, at 425–430.</i>
In the last ten years, the financial markets have undergone a boom and bust cycle that has generated a record number of clients’ claims filed at securities arbitration forums, such as the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc. The securities industry has continued to market new financial investment products, and customers have increasingly become susceptible to deceptive promises that offer freedom from financial woes. As members of our Jewish covenant-faith community, it behooves us to address our disputes regarding such matters in a <i>beit din</i>, a binding arbitration panel that may resolve such issues according to Halakha and/or civil law.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">For the halakhic grounds to resolve these matters pursuant to civil law, see <i>The Investment Advisor</i>, supra n. 1, at n. 30.</i>

Chapter 2; The Propriety of a Civil Will

<b>The Propriety of a Civil Will</b><br>During the last twenty-five years, approximately a dozen different formulations of halakhic wills have been disseminated in our community, each new proposal formulated to address problems with the others; nonetheless, to this very day, many segments of our community continue to utilize a civil will as the vehicle for their estate planning.
As we know, in accordance with secular law and the wishes of a testator, an attorney will draft a last will and testament that will distribute assets to a surviving spouse, son(s), and daughter(s) upon demise of the testator. Given the continued use of a secular will in our community, the purpose of this essay is to examine how halakhic authorities deal with such wills. At the conclusion of our presentation, we raise the practical significance of our <i>limud</i> (study) for our community.
<b>1. The Torah’s Order of Hereditary Succession, the <i>Issur</i> of “<i>Avurei Ahsanta</i>” and “There is No <i>Kinyan</i> after Death”</b>
Inheritance occurs by itself. Upon a person’s demise, human ownership ceases and halakhic succession law determines who will inherit his estate. As Rabbeinu Gershom notes, the heir automatically receives his ancestor’s inheritance without anyone giving it to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 141b.</i> There is no transfer of assets between the testator and his heirs via the implementation of a <i>kinyan</i>, i.e., a symbolic act of transfer such as an exchange of money or the writing of a <i>shtar</i> (a halakhic-legal document). As Talmud states,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 55b; <i>Bava Batra</i> 152a. However, a deceased retains ownership of his estate. For further discussion, see J. David Bleich, “Do the Deceased Enjoy Property Rights?” 47, <i>Tradition</i> 71, 82–88 (2014).</i> and as it is restated in Shulhan Arukh,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 250:9.</i> there is no <i>shtar</i> after death.
The signing of a <i>shtar</i> is an example of a <i>kinyan</i> that may serve as a vehicle to transfer assets, provided that the person is alive. Upon death, the person is incapable of transferring assets, or as the <i>Poskim</i> (rabbinical authorities) state, “there is no <i>kinyan</i> after death.”
In the words of the late Dayan Grunfeld of London, England,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Dayan I. Grunfeld, <i>The Jewish Law of Inheritance</i>, New York: Feldheim, 1987, 53–55.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">… In Jewish law we have the rules … There is no gift after death and … There is no effective document after death … The logical consequence of this is that any money in the hands of a beneficiary of a will under the law of the land, which as far as Jewish religious law is concerned, belongs to a different person, namely, the proper heir in accordance with the Jewish law of inheritance, has to be returned to that heir.</span>
Unlike secular law, which permits a transfer of assets upon death, according to Halakha, the moment of death preempts this possibility. The halakhic system, rather than the effectuation of a <i>kinyan</i>, creates the transfer of an inheritance. Pursuant to the Mishnah,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 88b. And a son(s) rather than a daughter(s) inherits his mother’s estate. See <i>Bava Batra</i> 108a, 110b–111a.</i> upon demise of the decedent, i.e., the father, the order of succession is as follows: (1) the sons, (2) their descendants, (3) the daughters, (4) their descendants, (5) the father, (6) the brothers, (7) their descendants, (8) the sisters, (9) their descendants, (10) the grandfather, (11) the brothers of the father, (12) their descendants, (13) the sisters of the father, (14) their descendants, etc.
After presenting the <i>halakhot</i> of succession, the Torah concludes by stating that the order of hereditary succession is “<i>hukat mishpat</i>” (a statute of judgment). The description of <i>hilkhot yerusha</i> as a “<i>hok</i>” implies, among other things, that these <i>halakhot</i>, despite dealing with monetary matters, are immutable.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 12:9; <i>Hilkhot Nahalot</i> 6:1; <i>Yisrael Moshe Hazan</i>, <i>Nahala le-Yisrael</i>, Vienna, 1851, 49.</i> Generally speaking, Halakha allows individuals to determine their own monetary relationships, provided that the arrangement complies with a proper form, i.e., <i>kinyan</i>, and is not violative of any prohibitions, such as theft or the interdict against taking <i>ribbit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 19b; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 38:5; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:17; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 305:4; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 305:4; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 344:1.</i> One of the exceptions to this rule is <i>hilkhot yerusha</i>. As Rambam states,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Nahalot</i> 6:1. See <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i>, <i>HM</i> 6; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>Mahdura Tinyana</i> 83.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">A man cannot cause his estate to descend to someone who is not potentially his heir; nor can he deprive the heir of the inheritance even though this is a money matter. For it says … “And it shall be for the children of Israel a statute of judgment” … that means, this statute cannot be altered and no stipulation can affect it.</span>
In other words, stipulating that assets are to be distributed to a non-halakhic heir falls in the category of “<i>matneh al ma shekatuv ba-Torah, tna’o batel</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i>, supra n. 7. Whereas Rambam argues that an estate distribution at variance with Halakha is a violation of “<i>hukat mishpat</i>,” others contend that the execution of such planning presumes that the assets of the testator during his lifetime can be designated as his <i>yerusha</i>. But, in fact, during the testator’s lifetime these are his assets. It is only upon the testator’s demise that Halakha determines that these assets are now designated as <i>yerusha</i>, are no longer in the testator’s possession, and automatically the Torah heirs receive their rightful distribution. See <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 113b. Alternatively, since the <i>yerusha</i> belongs to the heir only upon the testator’s demise, during his lifetime he cannot execute an arrangement at variance with the Torah order of <i>yerusha</i>. See <i>Ran</i> on <i>Rif</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 41a.<br>Though <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 282:1 states that diverting a share of the estate to a non-Torah heir is characterized as a transaction that merely does “not find pleasure in the eyes of scholars,” decisors construe such conduct as a formal <i>issur</i>. See <i>Teshuvot Maharam me-Padua</i> 60; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 336; <i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 1:118.<br>Clearly, the <i>issur</i> of disinheritance devolves upon the testator. Should a <i>beit din</i> affirm such a distribution, the <i>beit din</i> is not engaging in any <i>issur</i>. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 78; File no. 592010/1, Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Almoni</i>, June 14, 2010. Cf. infra text accompanying n. 171. Furthermore, there is no <i>issur</i> of “<i>avurei ahsanta</i>” (transferring inheritance) to the non-Torah heir who receives a portion of the estate. See <i>Ranah</i>, op. cit.; <i>Teshuvot Maharil</i> 76; <i>Orhot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>Tzva’ah</i> 15; <i>PDR</i> 22:132, 145.<br>In bold contradistinction to the <i>halakhot</i> of hereditary succession that preclude the possibility of devising a testamentary arrangement which stands in variance to these <i>halakhot</i> labeled as “<i>hukat mishpat</i>,” when dealing with a husband’s inheritance of his wife’s <i>yerusha</i>, according to certain authorities one may factor into consideration the testator’s intent in determining whether the husband will inherit her estate. By dint of matrimony, a husband inherits his wife’s estate. See <i>Bava Batra</i> 111b; <i>Bava Metzia</i> 18a. Consequently, some <i>Poskim</i> argue that if the wife dies and at the time of the demise, the husband intended to divorce her, he does not inherit her estate. The implicit assumption is that a husband’s right to inherit from his wife is predicated upon an ongoing marital relationship of <i>ishut</i>, intimacy. See <i>Rashbam</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 146b, s.v. “<i>nafla</i>”; <i>Mordekhai</i> in the name of R. Avraham of Regensburg, <i>Bava Batra</i> 612; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 90:5; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, ad locum 19. Cf. <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 9:16; <i>Yam shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 2:4; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 90:23; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 90:17. However, even those who differ with this ruling may agree that if the couple agreed to divorce or if divorce proceedings have commenced prior to the wife’s demise, the husband would not inherit his wife’s estate. See <i>Teshuvot Bah</i> 24; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Uziel</i> 7:79. Regarding contemporary times, some argue that the husband would inherit his wife’s estate. See <i>Hohkmat Shlomo</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 90:5; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 90:8.</i> and therefore a testator does not have the power to stipulate that a non-Torah heir should inherit him,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:543; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shmuel</i> 103; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 110, <i>HM</i> 304; File no. 8820-41-1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Attorney General</i>, November 23, 2009. Prior to the testator’s demise, whether a Torah heir can waive his right to his share is subject to controversy. See <i>Yad Rama</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 126b; <i>Hidushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 126b; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 50.</i> and it is prohibited to execute such an arrangement.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Bava Batra</i> 8:6; <i>Rashbam</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 133b, s.v. “<i>ma</i>”; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i> 8:37; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 85:3; <i>Maharam me-Padua</i>, supra n. 9; <i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 9; <i>Rema</i>, supra n. 9; <i>Ranah</i>, supra n. 9; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 151; <i>Teshuvot Maharasham</i> 7:12; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 1:29; <i>Teshuvot Zera Emet</i>, 2:110; <i>Mishpat ha-Yerusha</i>, Livorno, 1878, 25a. Cf. others who argue that it is improper rather than a prohibition to engage in disinheritance. See <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 53a; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 2:177; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 282:1; <i>Sema</i>, ad locum. 2;<i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 1:103; <i>Teshuvot Agudat Eizov</i>, <i>HM</i> 15. For further discussion, see infra text accompanying n. 80.</i> Moreover, according to many <i>Poskim</i>, the Torah heirs are entitled to the entire estate and there is an <i>issur</i> to transfer any portion from the Torah heirs to non-Torah heirs.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 8:37; <i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 9; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 1:29, 2, <i>HM</i> 5; <i>Teshuvot Mahari Ibn Lev</i> 3:31,93; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Teshuvot Yashiv Moshe</i> 2:236.</i> For example, if a father is survived by a son and a daughter, the son, the Torah heir, will inherit his entire estate.
Moreover, should a non-Torah heir retain the assets, it would constitute stealing from the rightful heir.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 160; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 142; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> (Ettinger) 2:86; <i>Teshuvot Sha’ar Asher</i> 2, <i>HM</i> 29; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:15; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 282:1; <i>Dinei Mamanot, vol.</i> 3:208. Cf. infra text accompanying n. 80.</i> Consequently, a civil will that provides an estate distribution to a non-Torah heir ought to be null and void.
Barring any halakhically sanctioned arrangement that allows an estate to be distributed to non-Torah heirs,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">For a discussion of various halakhic-sanctioned techniques that allow one to transfer one’s possessions to non-Torah heirs, see Judah Dick, “Halacha and the Conventional Last Will &amp; Testament,” 3, <i>The Journal of Halacha and Contemporary Society</i> 5 (1982); Feivel Cohen, <i>Kuntres me-Dor le-Dor</i>; Mattisyahu Schwartz, <i>Mishpat Hatzava’ah</i>, vols. 1–2;<br>For drafting a halakhic will and the validity of a revocable living trust, see this writer’s <i>Rabbinic Authority: The Vision &amp; the Reality</i>, Yerushalayim: Urim, 2013 (hereafter: <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>), 286–317.<br>Many of the sources found in this chapter have been culled from R. Schwartz’s works, op. cit. as well as a vast array of <i>teshuvot</i> citing <i>Poskim’</i>s rulings.</i> it should be of no surprise to find that many <i>Poskim</i>, both past and present, have invalidated a civil will due to the rule that “there is no gift after death” and because compliance with a secular will would lead to <i>avurei ahsanta</i> (disinheriting a Torah heir).<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Maharashdam</i>, supra nn. 10–11; <i>Maharit</i>, supra n. 12; <i>Mahari ibn Lev</i>, supra n. 12; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Galante</i> 13; <i>Teshuvot Maharshach</i> 146; <i>Teshuvot Lehem Rav</i> 219; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Teshuvot Lev Arye</i> 2:57; <i>Teshuvot Heishiv Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 90, 164; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 2:95, 6:164–165; Cohen, supra n. 14, at 3–7; Zalman N. Goldberg, “Inheritances &amp; Wills,” (Hebrew) 5, <i>Ha-Yashar ve-ha-Tov</i> 3, 7 (5768).</i>
<b>2. The Varying Approaches towards Validating a Civil Will</b>
<b>A. Rabbi Schwadron and Rabbi Feinstein’s View</b>
In reply to the contention that transfer of an estate based upon a secular will flies in the face of the recognized rule “there is no <i>kinyan</i> after death,” R. Moshe Feinstein states the following:<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:104. The translation is culled (with certain modifications) from Grunfeld, supra n. 4, at 72.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Although we are dealing here with a gift to be made after the death of the donor, and there is no such thing as a <i>kinyan</i> after death, as the object no longer belongs to the donor and such a gift is therefore not valid in Jewish law, nevertheless according to the law of the land a person can legally transfer money after death or any other object that at that time no longer belongs to him or her … In essence it is clear, according to my humble opinion, that a testament of this kind, the disposition of which will certainly be put into effect by the authorities of the country, does not need a <i>kinyan</i>, as one could not imagine a more effective <i>gemirat da’at</i> than this. Hence, since a <i>kinyan</i> is not necessary, the legal heirs can uphold their right even against those persons who are the proper heirs by Torah law, although there is no such thing in Jewish law as a gift after the death of the donor.</span>
There are two ingredients required in transferring ownership to another individual: effectuating a <i>kinyan</i> and <i>gemirat da’at</i> (i.e., the parties’ firm resolve to undertake this obligation). In other words, one requires a physical act, such as the execution of a <i>shtar</i>, and the intention of the parties to transfer the assets.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Whether the <i>kinyan</i> is a vehicle for ascertaining that <i>gemirat da’at</i> exists or whether the performance of a <i>kinyan</i> is separate from the requirement of <i>gemirat da’at</i> is subject to debate.</i>
In the absence of a <i>kinyan</i>, can one argue that the intention of the parties suffices to transfer an asset? In reply to this question, R. Shlomo Kluger expounds:<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tuv Ta’am ve-Da’at</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 269. For others who subscribe to this view, see <i>Hiddushei R. Shimon Yehuda ha-Cohen Shkop</i>, <i>Kinyanim</i> 11; Yehezkel Abramsky, “<i>Monetary Laws</i> (<i>A Definition of Types</i>)” (Hebrew), 9–13.<br>The citation of these authorities should in no manner be construed as their endorsement of a civil will.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The essence of the <i>kinyan</i> of the Torah is to resolve in one’s heart to transfer (an asset), as we learnt that, in consideration of the pleasure of our children marrying each other, each father undertakes certain prenuptial obligations. Therefore this proves that in an instance where we can discern that there is was a firm resolution, one does not require an act of <i>kinyan</i>. And in cases where we require a <i>kinyan</i>, it is because we do not know what he resolved in his heart, and possibly he did not resolve to transfer (an asset) … Every act of <i>kinyan</i> is only in order to ascertain what he resolved in his heart. However, if we know what he resolved and it is being transferred with a full heart (clear intention) we do not mandate an act.</span>
Implicitly following in R. Kluger’s footsteps, R. Feinstein argues “that a testament of this kind, the disposition of which will certainly be put into effect by the authorities of the country, does not need a <i>kinyan</i>, as one could not imagine a more effective <i>gemirat da’at</i> than this.”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying n. 16.</i>
In other words, the testator’s execution of a civil will that will be recognized by the civil court corroborates for us that he firmly resolved in his heart to transfer his estate, and consequently a <i>kinyan</i> is not required.
Addressing a will prepared by R. Me’sag that divided up his estate amongst his sons, daughters, and grandchildren, relying upon R. Doniel Tirnai,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, infra n. 31.</i> R. Shalom Schwadron states,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:224 (2). See also <i>Maharsham</i>, supra n. 11. In effect, his view is identical to R. Feinstein’s position. See Yosef Goldberg, “An improperly drafted <i>shtar</i> and at the end a <i>kinyan</i> was executed,” (Hebrew) 1, <i>Shurat ha-Din</i> 319, 323 (5754). See also, <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i> 10:346, 350.<br>According to R. Aharon Lichtenstein, R. Yosef Soloveitchik prepared a civil will. Based upon R. Dr. Dov Frimer’s conversations with Mr. Julius Berman, Esq.,it is R. Frimer’s understanding that R. Soloveitchik endorsed the notion that <i>gemirat da’at</i> could be obtained based upon the testator’s awareness that the provisions of a secular will would be enforced by civil law and therefore no <i>kinyan</i> was necessary.<br>Cf. <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 7:12.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The requirement of a <i>kinyan</i> is to attest to his will and thought, that he resolved in his heart to give with his soul. Wherever there is a presumptive <i>umdana</i> (sound inference/common sense) that demonstrates that he gave with his heart, a <i>kinyan</i> is superfluous.</span>
To claim, in accordance with Rabbis Schwadron and Feinstein, that one can transfer an asset based on <i>gemirat da’at</i> without a <i>kinyan</i> means accepting a well-trodden <i>mesorah</i> that is discussed in various places in the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">(1) <i>Ketuvot</i> 102a–b: “These are the matters that can be acquired via the medium of speech.” See <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 102b, s.v. “<i>a’libai</i>.” (2) <i>Bava Batra</i> 142b, acquiring for the benefit of an embryo; See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 210:1. (3) <i>Bekhorot</i> 18b, transfer ownership of a first-born animal to a <i>kohen</i>. See <i>Teshuvot R. Akiver Eiger</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 37 in the name of <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 18b, s.v. “<i>ak’neuyei</i>.” (5) <i>Bava Kama</i> 102b, someone dedicates his assets to the <i>Beit ha-Mikdash.</i> See <i>Sefer ha-Terumoth</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 1, 1:5 in the name of <i>Ra’avad</i>. (6) <i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a, <i>situmta</i>. <i>Rashash</i>, ibid.; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 194:2. (7) <i>Bava Metzia</i> 94a. A paid <i>shomer</i> (bailee) many change his status to that of a <i>sho’el</i> (borrower) by means of an oral stipulation rather than executing a formal <i>kinyan</i>.<br>(6) <i>Bava Batra</i> 123b. The transfer of priestly gifts to <i>makire kehuna</i> (acquaintances of the <i>kohanim</i>). See <i>Rashash</i>, ad locum. (7) <i>Bava Batra</i> 173b. One may establish that an <i>arevut</i>, a suretyship agreement, undertaken at the time of the creation of a debt can be effectuated orally without a <i>kinyan</i>.</i> and applied <i>Halakha le-ma’aseh</i> (in practice) in varying contexts by many authorities, including Israeli <i>dayanim</i> R. C. Shlomo Sha’anan, R. Domb, and R. Ben Shimon.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Aliyot de-Rabbeinu Yona</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 84b; <i>Rashbam</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 123b, s.v. “<i>hakhi garsinan</i>” (as understood by <i>Rashash</i>, ad locum; R. Engel, <i>Tziyunim la-Torah</i>, <i>kelal</i> 39); <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> ad locum, s.v. “<i>hakha</i>” (as understood by <i>Kovetz Shiurim</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 374); <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Teshuvot Maharshach</i> 1:46, 2:46, 113; <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 36, 135; <i>Teshuvot Tuv Ta’am ve-Da’at</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i>, 265, 269, <i>Mahdura</i> 3, 2:146; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314 (as understood by <i>Teshuvot Shem Arye</i>, <i>YD</i> 48, and <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 4:48:1). Cf. the understanding of <i>Hatam Sofer</i> in <i>Teshuvot Dvar Avraham</i> 1:1; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314 and <i>HM</i> 12; <i>Rashash</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 18b; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Mavin</i> 161; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>pesakim</i> 37; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hakhamim</i>, vol. 1, <i>HM</i> 32; <i>Pnei Yehoshua Gittin</i> 77b; <i>Teshuvot Hemdat Shlomo</i>, <i>YD</i> 33; <i>Avnei Miluim</i> 30:3 (in the name of <i>Ran</i>); <i>Teshuvot Ohel Moshe</i> 2:138.<br>See Ron Kleinman, “<i>Kinyan Situmta</i>,” (Hebrew) 24, <i>Mehkarei Mishpat</i> 243, 257–259 (5768).<br>For validating a civil will, see <i>PDR</i> 20:297, 306–307, 21:28, 37–38; 22:133, 167, 179. Cf. R. Tauber who argues that R. Feinstein’s validation of a civil will was a concession issued decades ago when there were very few Torah-observant American Jews who regularly proceeded to civil court for their estate planning. Therefore, R. Tauber concludes that today, when Torah observance has increased expodentially in the American Jewish community, even R. Feinstein would concur that preparing a civil will is improper. See <i>Kesai Mishpat</i>, 113. A review of R. Feinstein’s <i>teshuva</i> does not indicate that the motivation of his ruling stems from the level of religious observance of the American Jewish community. On the contrary, as R. Feinstein states, “And this is an important reason why in this land they rely upon these civil wills … Nonetheless, they unconsciously intended to the truth. If there aren’t prophets, they are the sons of prophets.” Moreover, as we have shown, his ruling is well grounded in halakhic sources and is but one example of his approach in rendering a <i>psak</i>. See <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, Introduction to <i>OH</i>; <i>YD</i> 1:101 (end).</i>
Nevertheless, many <i>Poskim</i> demur and contend that a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i>, a physical act of transfer, is mandated. For example, Beit Yosef and Rema allow parties to execute an agreement without the prescribed <i>kinyan</i> assuming they use some form of <i>kinyan</i>. For example, both Beit Yosef and Rema will permit <i>metaltelin</i> (chattel) to be transferred with <i>kinyan kesef</i> (an exchange of money), though generally <i>metaltelin</i> cannot be transferred with <i>kesef</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 195; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 195:5. See also, <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 198; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 198:3.</i> In other words, minimally, parties must implement a recognized <i>kinyan</i>, even if it is not the one prescribed for the particular object. Other <i>Poskim</i>, among them Derisha and Shakh, take issue with this position and argue that transfer of ownership requires the prescribed <i>kinyan</i> for the particular matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Derisha</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:3; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 198:10.</i> The consensus is that a recognized <i>kinyan</i> must be used.
Secondly, should a non-Jew adopt Halakha for a particular transaction and purchase with a bona fide <i>kinyan</i> from a Jew, such an agreement would be valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, supra n. 24.</i> Again it is a valid agreement because a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i> was employed.
Moreover, if the recognized forms of <i>kinyan</i> are not effective because of a rabbinic decree, the parties cannot privately stipulate to use these <i>kinyanim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 198:5; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum, 10.</i> Finally, for many <i>Poskim</i>, <i>kinyan situmta</i> (a commercial practice of transferring ownership) is based on either <i>minhag</i> (custom)<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:268, 3:17, 4:125; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 23.</i> or <i>kinyan halifin</i> (barter),<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Dvar Avraham</i> 1:1, <i>anaf</i> 1.</i> or grounded in <i>kinyan meshikha/hazaka</i> (the act of pulling or possession).<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piskei Halakhot im Bi’ur Yad Dovid</i>, <i>Ishut</i> 1, 228–229.</i> In other words, there is a requirement of some “objective” act or at least a mutual understanding that creates the <i>gemirat da’at</i> of the parties.
In short, a civil will is invalid since a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i> is required to transfer an asset and there is no <i>kinyan</i> after death. As such, the view of Rabbis Schwadron and Feinstein is problematic.
<b>B. <i>Maharam of Rothenburg</i>’s View: A Gift in Contemplation of Death</b>
As an alternative possibility, some authorities<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">See decisors cited in <i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, <i>OH</i> 21; <i>Teshuvot Kapei Aharon</i> 12; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 7:197; R. Shlomo Warmash, Rabbi in Fulda, Germany in 5639 cited in 58 <i>Moriah</i> 17 (5741).</i> have recognized a secular will by invoking the position of R. Meir of Rothenberg, who opines,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 254, 602, and <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 591. For our understanding of <i>Maharam</i>, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 95; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:224 (1) in the name of Rabbi Meaglunza.<br>To avoid a challenge to his verbal instructions, the testator would have to memorialize his wishes into writing. See <i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, supra n. 31, at p. 71a.<br>For the antecedents of this testamentary disposition, see <i>Gittin</i> 66a; <i>Bava Batra</i> 151b.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Even a healthy person who says “give this person this and that if I die,” this is designated “commanding because of death” and he [the heir] has acquired [the property].</span>
In effect, despite the absence of a <i>kinyan</i>, the assets have been transferred with the verbal instructions of the testator provided that he mentions the day of death. Whereas a <i>matnat shekhiv mera</i> is a bequest communicated by a person on his deathbed, this is a gift of a healthy person prepared in contemplation of death (<i>metzave mahamat mita</i>). In effect, the testator’s instructions create an <i>umdana de-mukhah</i> (sound inference which is obvious to all) that he is resolute in giving this gift, and therefore no <i>kinyan</i> is required.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, supra n. 31. Many have adopted his approach. See <i>Kapei Aharon</i>, infra n. 42; <i>Mahara Sasson</i> in the name of <i>Rif</i>, <i>Rambam</i>, <i>Ran</i>, and <i>Rabbeinu Tam</i>. See <i>Teshuvot Mahara Sasson</i> 151<i>.</i> In fact some have rejected his approach. See <i>Teshuvot Maharam me-Padua</i> 53; <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 257:4; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 257:7; <i>Teshuvot Har ha-Mor</i> 40; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>YD</i> 203; <i>Mishpat ha-Yerusha</i>, supra n. 11, at 4–6. Cf. <i>Mishpat ha-Yerusha</i>, supra n. 11, at 13a, who claims it is a minority view.</i> Hence, a non-Torah heir may be a beneficiary of an estate without the gifting being a violation of halakhic order of <i>yerusha</i>. Though many decisors reject this approach, it may be considered within the context of the doctrine of <i>muhzak</i> and the <i>kim li</i> argument, as we shall demonstrate.
When a dispute is submitted to a <i>beit din</i>, the court has to determine which claimant retains certain assets. In Halakha, there is a concept whereby one of the claimants is considered the one who is in possession of the disputed item (<i>muhzak</i>), while the other claimant wants to “extract” this item and transfer it to himself. In case of a disputed inheritance, the <i>beit din</i> has to ascertain, first of all, who is the <i>muhzak</i>. Which of the two parties – the Torah heirs or the non-Torah heirs – should be considered “in possession” of the inheritance that the other is trying to take away? Seemingly, one could argue that, inasmuch as the Torah grants the inheritance to certain people, <i>ipso facto</i> they are considered as <i>muhzakim</i>. But, as we explained, in accordance with Maharam’s view, the gifting process is not in violation of the Torah order of succession. If so, the two heirs are on equal footing. Consequently, since there is a <i>safek</i> (doubt) whether we follow Maharam’s posture or not, if the non-Torah heir is <i>muhzak</i>, he will prevail.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:224; <i>PDR</i> 19:1, 4 (Rabbis Elyashiv, Zolti, and Hadas).</i>
The <i>safek</i> whether we follow Maharam’s posture or not is equally relevant with regard to invoking the claim of <i>kim li</i>. Pursuant to halakhic court procedure, a party in a dispute can argue as follows: “I want the court to rule in my favor, which is based on the position of Rabbi X, who affirms my claim.” Under certain prescribed conditions, we will accept his position even if Rabbi X’s view is in the minority, and the majority rule differently.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Hanina Ben Menahem, “Towards a Jurisprudential Analysis of the <i>Kim-li</i> Argument,” (Hebrew) 6–7 <i>Shenaton ha-Mishpat ha-Ivri</i> 45 (5739–5740).</i> Such an argument can be invoked either by a <i>muhzak</i> or by a <i>beit din</i>. Thus, if the non-Torah heir is considered the <i>muhzak</i>, he can request the court to uphold the secular will on the basis of a <i>kim li</i> argument that, “I want the court to rule in accordance with Maharam,” who validates a secular will.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">For those who contend that one can advance such a plea when the non-Torah heir is <i>muhzak</i>, see <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 25, <i>Dinei Tefisa</i> 23, and other <i>Aharonim</i> cited in <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 7, <i>HM</i> 2:6.<br>Others argue that even if the non-Torah heir seizes the assets, one may advance a claim of <i>kim li</i> on his behalf. See <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>HM</i> 25 (end); <i>Yabia Omer</i>, ibid. (end).</i>
Since Maharam may have issued contradictory rulings regarding the effectiveness of <i>metzave mahamat mita</i>, and may have changed his mind regarding its effectiveness as a vehicle to transfer an estate, Maharam’s view possibly may not serve as grounds to recognize a civil will.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">For the self-contradictory rulings that limit the Maharam’s <i>psak</i> to instances of the testator dying, see <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 592; <i>Teshuvot Maharam of Rothenburg</i>, Berlin ed., 46.<br>For attempts to reconcile these rulings, see <i>Maharam me-Padua</i>, supra n. 33; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 94; <i>Teshuvot Maharil</i> 75; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 95; <i>Teshuvot Mahara Sason</i> 151.</i>
<b>C. The Validity of <i>Minhag</i> in Estate Planning</b>
Another approach focuses on whether the existence of a <i>minhag</i> of preparing and executing wills in accordance with secular law ought to be recognized or not. To have binding force, a <i>minhag</i> that is unaccompanied by rabbinic or communal sanction in the form of a legislative enactment<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">For the independent status of a custom involving a monetary matter, see <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:10, 218:19, 229:2, 230:10, 232:6; 330:5, 331:12; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 72:5; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 19–20; <i>Teshuvot Mahara Ashkenazi</i> 33; <i>Mishpat ha-Yerusha</i>, supra n. 11, at 410–411.</i> must be clear and widespread among the majority of members of the community and must have been practiced at least three times.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 79:4; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 475; <i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 342; <i>Teshuvot Lehem Rav</i> 10; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 331:1. Given that other authorities require rabbinic endorsement of the <i>minhag</i> (see infra n. 45), some conclude that this issue is a matter of halakhic doubt and therefore one cannot extract money from the <i>muhzak</i>. See <i>Knesset ha-Gedola SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201, <i>Ha-gahot Beit Yosef</i> 4–5. Consequently, if a contested will is being resolved based on the effectiveness of <i>minhag</i>, a <i>beit din</i> ought to broker a <i>peshara</i> (compromise) amongst the parties. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 4:54; <i>Teshuvot Darkhei Noam</i>, <i>HM</i> 35; File no. 288409/5, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v</i>. <i>Plonit</i>, April 10, 2013.</i> There are some eighteenth- and nineteenth-century authorities (some despite various reservations) who have recognized the use of a civil will that employs the language of “giving” rather than “bequeathing” or “inheriting,”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, supra n. 31, at 76b. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Radakh</i> 26:3 who argues that <i>minhag ha-makom</i> is determinative. Though Radakh’s ruling addresses the case of <i>shekhiv mera</i>, R. Shlomo Sha’anan applies it to a testator who prepares a civil will. See Sha’anan, <i>Shurat ha-Din</i>, infra n. 55, at 319, 329.</i> if this is common practice (even among gentiles<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ra’avad</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Malveh ve-Loveh</i> 25:10; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 132; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>YD</i> 221; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ibn Lev</i> 2:23; <i>Teshuvot Bnei Avraham</i>, <i>HM</i> 13; <i>Teshuvot Makor Barukh</i> 55; <i>Teshuvot Hikekei Lev</i>, vol. 2, 30, vol. 3, <i>HM</i> 2:30; <i>Mahara Ashkenazi</i>, supra n. 38; <i>Teshuvot Kapei Aharon</i> 13; <i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i>, supra n. 14, at 423.</i>) in the community wherein the testator and heirs reside.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, supra n. 31, at 72a–b, 73b, 76b, 77a and citations cited in <i>Teshuvot Kapei Aharon</i>, <i>HM</i> 12–13; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rama</i> (Abulafia) in <i>Ohr Tzadikim</i> (Salonika, 1799), 299; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 2:13; <i>Teshuvot Ta’alumot Lev</i> 1:7; <i>Radakh</i>, supra n. 40; <i>Teshuvot Maharash</i> 2:13; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Tzedek</i> 2:52; <i>Teshuvot Tevuot Shemesh</i>, <i>HM</i> 33–34; <i>Mishpat ha-Yerusha</i>, supra n. 11, at 24; <i>Teshuvot ve-Zot le-Yehuda</i> (Mesalton), <i>HM</i> 9; <i>Teshuvot be-Tzel ha-Hochma</i>, vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 6; <i>Mahara Ashkenazi</i>, supra n. 38.<br>Clearly, there were instances in which authorities sanctioned the use of a civil will based upon <i>minhag</i> or <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> because the civil government would recognize only wills that were prepared in accordance with civil law. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:67; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 75; <i>Teshuvot Rabach</i>, <i>HM</i> 8; <i>Teshuvot Aderet Eliyahu</i> (Riki) 23. As such, these <i>teshuvot</i> fail to serve as grounds to validate a secular will today, when the civil law allows individuals to execute estate-planning arrangements based upon Halakha provided that the will is drafted in a legally acceptable fashion. See text infra accompanying n. 101.</i> According to this view, even if the Torah heirs seize the assets from the non-Torah heirs, the assets would have to be returned to the designated heir(s).<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Kapei Aharon</i>, 13 (159a).</i> As R. Yehiel Epstein rules, in places where the government is insistent that all legal documents be drafted in accordance with civil law, we must comply with their laws. Therefore, he concludes, documents written in accordance with civil law are valid, and <i>a fortiori</i> if the document is in accordance with the local custom.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 68:6. R. Tzvi Yehuda ben Ya’akov concludes that therefore a secular will is valid. See <i>Teshuvot Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 4:7. In light of R. Epstein’s ruling in <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:17, this conclusion seems problematic.</i>
Alternatively, others conclude that to validate a civil will on the basis of <i>minhag</i>, it must be a <i>minhag</i> approved by Torah scholars (<i>minhag vatikin</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mishpat Tzedek</i> (Melamed) 2:52 (end); <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 304; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 102; <i>Teshuvot Admat Kodesh</i>, 1, <i>YD</i> 16; <i>Mishpat ha-Yerusha</i>, supra n. 11, at 25a; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 2:19; <i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, supra n. 31, at 75a; <i>Teshuvot Ramatz</i> 1:92; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Rivot</i> 78; <i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i>, <i>EH</i> 45 citing many <i>Poskim</i> who subscribe to this view. Cf. supra n. 38. For the definition of <i>minhag vatikin</i> as a practice approved by <i>Poskim</i>, see <i>Ohr Zarua</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 280. For a presentation of the diverse views regarding whether the <i>validity</i> of a minhag is contingent upon rabbinic endorsement, see Netanya Beit Din ruling, supra n. 39.</i> According to this view, since there are some <i>Poskim</i> who validate civil wills, distributing assets in accordance with a civil will would be halakhically justified.
Even though there are <i>Poskim</i> who reject the validity of a civil will based upon <i>minhag</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 6:254 cited by <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 26; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:545; <i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 10; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 8; <i>Teshuvot Mishpat Tzedek</i> 1:21; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shmuel</i> (<i>Kal’i</i>) 53; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Ribot</i> 174; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 20:71. Accordingly, a <i>minhag</i> that disinherits a <i>bekhor</i> from his double portion will not be determinative. See <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 281:4; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 281:16.</i> nevertheless neither a <i>kim li</i> plea by the Torah heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying n. 35.<br>In fact, pursuant to <i>Hida</i>, in cases in which there is a clear <i>minhag</i> that distributes estate assets to a daughter based on civil law, one can invoke the <i>kim li</i> argument of those <i>Poskim</i> who endorse the validity of this <i>minhag</i>, such as Rivash and Maharshakh. See <i>Tuv Ayin</i> 17.</i> nor a <i>beit din</i> will trump the <i>minhag</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, supra n. 31, at 31a, 38b; <i>Teshuvot Kapei Aharon</i> 12; <i>Kuntres Yismach Moshe</i> 12; <i>Teshuvot Ba’ei Hayyei</i>, <i>HM</i> 1, 73; Goldberg, supra n. 21, at 322; <i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i> 6, <i>HM</i> 18.</i> Since we have a dispute whether <i>minhag</i> can justify affirming a will, we have a <i>safek</i> what the Halakha is. In cases in which there is doubt regarding a monetary matter, we cannot extract money from the defendant. Consequently, a defendant (in this case, the non-Torah heir) can argue that there are authorities who agree that the <i>minhag</i> ought to be determinative and therefore the will should be validated. Others would contend that the Torah heir, by dint of the Torah law of <i>yerusha</i>, is the <i>muhzak</i> and therefore retains the estate. As the Talmud instructs us, a Torah heir, by virtue of <i>hilkhot yerusha</i>, does not need to plead his right.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 41a.</i> Consequently, the halakhic doubt concerning whether <i>minhag</i> ought to be determinative is irrelevant. The bottom line is that the Torah heir has possession of the estate.
One suggested justification for legitimating secular wills based on <i>minhag</i> dates back to a <i>teshuva</i> penned by Rivash. The <i>teshuva</i> deals with a fourteenth-century Jewish community composed entirely of <i>mumarim</i> (apostates) residing on the island of Majorca who decided to replace Halakha with the governing civil law. Rivash ruled that their decision was to be understood as a practice adopted by the community and was therefore binding.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 52.</i> Lest one assume that this ruling is limited to Jewish apostates,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Mishpat ha-Yerusha</i>, supra n. 11.</i> Rivash clearly states that his decision is applicable to any Jewish enclave that decides to have their matters resolved according to secular law. And, in fact, Rema and R. Aharon ben Azriel understood Rivash in such a fashion.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 248:1; <i>Teshuvot Kapei Aharon</i> 14.</i> Whereas numerous authorities have imparted validity to <i>individuals</i> who decide to resolve their matters in front of a <i>beit din</i> in accordance with secular law,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Giddulei Teruma</i>, <i>Sefer ha-Terumot</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 62, <i>helek</i> 1; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:11, 61:14; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 26:11; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:30; <i>Divrei Gaonim</i> 25:3, 111:3; <i>Bnei Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 26; <i>Maharitz ha-Hadashot</i> 22; <i>Teshuvot Yosef Ometz</i>, 4; <i>Birkei Yosef</i> 26:3,8; <i>Tzedaka u-Mishpat</i>, <i>OH</i> 7; <i>Leket Shikha</i> found in <i>Karnei Re’em</i>, section 4 <i>Dayanim</i>; File no. 1-24-053917464, Haifa Regional Beit Din, October 10, 2003; File no. 1887-24-1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, February 1, 2010; File no. 335906/3. Tel Aviv-Yafo Regional Beit Din, May 26, 2010, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>; File no. 91876-1, Be’er Sheva Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, Octiober 30,2011; File no. 824780/2, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, June 27, 2012; File no. 830099/5, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, June 11, 2012; File no. 873705-1, Supreme Beit Din, November 7, 2012, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>; File no. 838835-8, Tel Aviv-Yafo Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Plonit</i>, January 24, 2013; R. Ezra Batzri, <i>Dinei Mamanot, vol.</i> 3,197; Z. N. Goldberg, <i>Lev ha-Mishpat</i>, vol. 1, 286; Asher Weiss, 6 <i>Darkhei Horo’ah</i> 111 (2007); <i>PDR</i> 18:314, 324; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 9:112; <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 14, 196–198.<br>Cf. <i>Taz</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:3 who strenuously disagreed with this view. In fact, one contemporary <i>Posek</i> notes that had Taz realized that “all of the gedolim” disagreed with him, he would have retracted his view. See <i>Ketunot Yosef</i> (Birdugo) 16:2. Additionally, for a recent discussion of Rabbis Elyashiv and Sherman’s endorsement of <i>Taz</i>’s view, see A. Sherman, “The halakhic principles concerning litigating in civil courts in order to execute inheritance order,” (Hebrew) 12 <i>Sha’arei Tzedek</i> 403, 406–407 (5762).</i> Rivash extends the applicability of civil law to a case of <i>communal</i> adoption. Subsequently, Rivash’s position has been endorsed by Rema, and in contemporary times, has been invoked as one of the grounds for affirming a secular will in Eretz Yisrael.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 248:1; <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i>, supra. n. 21, at 347. To resolve the seemingly self-contradictory ruling of <i>Rema</i>, ibid. with <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:11, see <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:20.</i> In fact, the validity of secular wills executed by some Israeli <i>battei din</i> stems not only from the acceptance of the view of Rabbis Schwadron and Feinstein that there is no need for a <i>kinyan</i> regarding a testamentary disposition, but also from the authority of <i>minhag</i>, the common practice of using a secular will, which exists both in Israel and in other parts of the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i>, supra n. 21; H. Shlomo Sha’anan, “A Will in Halakha,” (Hebrew) 13 <i>Tehumin</i> 317, 324–325 (5751); H. S. Sha’anan, “A Will that was Drafted Improperly,” (Hebrew) 1 <i>Shurat ha-Din</i> 319 (5754), and in his decisions <i>PDR</i> 20:297, 308, 21:28, 37–38. Cf. <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i> 12:329, 331 and <i>Teshuvot Mishpat Shlomo</i> 3:24.</i>
That said, should a Jewish community adopt the practice to arrange their estate planning according to secular law, a position that has been met with trenchant criticism,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 1:61, <i>Maharit</i>, supra n. 8; <i>Teshuvot Mishpat Tzedek</i> 2:68; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 11, <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i>, <i>EH</i> 131; and <i>Dinei Mamonot</i> vol. 3,197.</i> <i>shtarot</i> (documents) of gentiles prepared in accordance with civil law would be binding.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mahara Ashkenazi</i>, supra n. 38; <i>Tevuot Shemesh</i>, supra n. 42.</i>
And as Hazon Ish notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>HM</i>, <i>Likkutim</i> 16:1, 5, 9. Our citation of <i>Hazon Ish</i> is not to be misconstrued as implying that he validated the execution of a civil will.</i> <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> (“the law of the kinship is the law”) determines the expectations of the parties. Hence, if the parties’ expectation is to arrange for a testamentary disposition in accordance with civil law, the provisions of the secular will would be binding. Consequently, if the testator commissioned an attorney to prepare and draft a will in accordance with civil law, he expects to have his estate distributed in accordance with such law.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">See infra text accompanying n. 132. For a discussion of the notion that <i>minhag</i> is a reflection of the governing civil law, see ch. 4.</i>
Implicit in the above approach is the notion advanced by R. Doniel Tirani of nineteenth-century Italy and others that such documents will be effective as a <i>kinyan situmta</i> (a transfer recognized by commercial practice).<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ikrei ha-Da’at</i>, supra n.31, at 70a, 73b; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:224 (30); <i>Erekh Shai</i>, <i>HM</i> 235.</i> To put it differently, just as authorities recognize a modern-day contract as a <i>kinyan situmta</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 23; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 3:8; <i>Teshuvot Zemech Zedek</i> (Lubavitch), <i>YD</i> 233; <i>Kesef ha-Kodshin</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharshag</i> 3:113; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 5:45; <i>PDR</i> 3:363, 4:193, 275; 6:202, 14:43.<br>Implicit in this approach, according to certain <i>Poskim</i>, is that secular law can nullify an individual’s ownership of property, while simultaneously, the execution of the <i>kinyan</i> that is utilized in commercial practice serves to transfer this property to another individual. See <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Kinyanim</i>, 219, note 9 (end).</i> Halakha imparts equal validity to a civil will as another example of a <i>kinyan situmta</i>.
At first glance, invoking <i>kinyan situmta</i> in our situation poses various problems. Firstly, R. Zalman N. Goldberg contends, <i>minhag</i> that is reflective of civil law is not binding. Since obedience to the law entails an element of coercion, and <i>minhag</i> is predicated upon voluntary compliance, a <i>minhag</i> grounded in law is a self-contradiction and therefore unenforceable.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 14:334 (R. Z. N. Goldberg’s opinion); R. Goldberg, 2 <i>ha-Yashar ve-ha-Tov</i> 9 (2006). Subsequent to issuing his <i>psak din</i> and authoring the article, R. Goldberg has emphasized that his position regarding the halakhic ineffectiveness of <i>minhag</i> is limited to matters dealing with commercial modes of undertaking obligations and transferring of assets. See R. Kleinman, “Civil Law in the Nation: <i>Minhag ha-Medina</i>,<i>”</i> (Hebrew), 32 <i>Tehumin</i> 261, 269–271 (5773).</i> As such, since the text of a civil will is drafted and executed according to the norms of secular law, we would deny its validity. Secondly, according to some authorities, notably Bah, one cannot transfer <i>karka</i> (real estate) via a <i>kinyan situmta</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 202:1.</i> And pursuant to other opinions, one cannot transfer assets that are not yet in the testator’s possession at the time the testamentary disposition was prepared and signed (<i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:6, 209:4; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 257:7.</i> Should we subscribe to these views, a testator would be unable to earmark real estate for inheritance purposes or authorize distribution of assets that were not in his possession at the time of the drafting of the will.
Yet, there are numerous authorities who recognize a <i>kinyan situmta</i> based on a <i>minhag</i> that reflects civil law,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Divrei Yosef</i> (Iggeret) 21; <i>Teshuvot Nediv Lev</i> (Dovid Hazan) 12; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 2:111; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72, 75; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yisrael</i> 172; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Halva’ah</i> 2:29.</i> even if it entails the transfer of real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 3:132; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:1; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:1; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:6; <i>Hiddushei R. Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:2; <i>PDR</i> 6:216, 12:292.</i> or assets that are not yet in existence.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 2:278; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 66; <i>Teshuvot Ahiezer</i> 3:79.</i> Generally speaking, assets cannot be transferred if they are not yet in existence at the time the disposition is prepared.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:6, 209:4.</i> Nevertheless, should the prevailing law allow a testator to transfer future assets at the time of drafting the testamentary disposition, many decisors would recognize the power of <i>kinyan situmta</i> to effectuate a transfer not only of current assets, but equally of future assets by dint of commercial custom.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 13:20; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Shabbat</i> 472–473; <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 36; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 201:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Divrei Hayyim</i> 2, <i>HM</i> 26; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:1; <i>Teshuvot Shoeil u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 2:39; <i>Teshuvot Mahariz Enzel</i> 1:37; <i>PDR</i> 3:363, 368–369, 2:193, 198–199.</i> Hence, a civil will that provides for a future disbursement of real estate and/or the future acquisition of assets would be halakhically binding.
The more vexing issue, however, is that the transfer of assets in accordance with a secular will transpires after the testator’s demise, and a <i>kinyan situmta</i>, like other <i>kinyanim</i>, is effective only during the testator’s lifetime. As we noted, there is no <i>kinyan</i> after death. For this very reason, R. Zalman N. Goldberg and R. Judah Dick, Esq. reject the effectiveness of <i>kinyan situmta</i> for halakhic estate planning.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Goldberg, supra n. 62; Dick, supra n.14.</i>
Others, such as Rabbis Eliyahu Hazan, Yehuda Mesalton, and Messas, as well as a <i>psak</i> attributed to R. Yosef Elyashiv, contend that if there is a <i>minhag</i> to execute a civil will, the distribution will be effective based on <i>kinyan situmta</i> without elucidating the grounds for their conclusion.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ta’alumot Lev</i>, supra n. 42; v<i>e-Zot le-Yehuda</i>, supra n. 42; <i>Teshuvot Shemesh u-Magen</i> 1, <i>HM</i> 1; <i>Ma’aseh Beit Din</i> 1: p. 401 (Rabbi Yissachar Hagar in the name of R. Elyashiv); Moshe Toledano, “The Status of a will drafted without a <i>kinyan</i>,” (Hebrew) 5 <i>Kovetz Darkhei Horo’ah</i> 280, 291 (5768).</i>
The grounds for the effectiveness of a civil will as a form of a <i>kinyan situmta</i> can be extrapolated from the position of Rabbeinu Yona of Gerondi, Spain and R. Yeshayahu Blau of Yerushalayim.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Aliyot de-Rabbeinu Yona</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 55a, s.v. “<i>vearisa de-parsai</i>,” s.v. “<i>oleh be-yadeinu</i>”; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i> 8, p. 219.</i> According to this position, the transfer of the assets from the testator to the heirs is subdivided into two stages.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">For this explanation, see Shmuel Shilo, <i>Dina de-Malkhuta Dina</i> (Hebrew) Yerushalayim, 1975, 324–326 and Sinai Deutsch, “The Validity of a Will Drawn in a Foreign Court,” (Hebrew) 12 <i>Dine Israel</i> 193, 223–229 (5754–5755).</i> Invoking the view that the rule of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> (the law of the kingship is the law), secular law divests the testator of the ownership of the assets.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The notion that <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> is based upon “<i>hefker beit din hefker</i>,” loosely translated as “the right of <i>beit din</i> to expropriate a person’s property,” resonates with others such as <i>Teshuvot Mahariz Enzel</i> 4; <i>Dvar Avraham</i>, supra n. 23.</i> Subsequently, based on <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> (commercial practice) and utilizing a <i>kinyan situmta</i>, the assets are transferred from the testator to the heir. The execution of a <i>kinyan situmta</i> is contingent upon the fact that the testator will pass away, and with his demise the beneficiary(/ies) will acquire the assets of the estate (i.e., <i>kinyan al tenai</i>). In actuality, the <i>kinyan situmta</i> is executed during the testator’s lifetime only to be implemented upon his death.
Alternatively, echoing Rabbis Schwadron and Feinstein’s rationale, Rabbi Toledano states that the customary practice demonstrates the <i>gemirat da’at</i> of the donor, and therefore a custom can substitute for a <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Toledano, supra n. 71, at 293, 295.</i> This conclusion ought to equally apply, as R. Toledano claims, to matters of inheritance.
Regardless of which rationale is offered for the effectiveness of <i>minhag</i> relating to a civil will, this approach seemingly undermines the limited scope of the authority of <i>minhag</i>. As we know, the principle of <i>minhag mevatel Halakha</i>, that custom overrides the law, is limited to monetary matters.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 7:1; Mishnah, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 7:1; <i>Bava Metzia</i> 83a–b.</i> In other words, a custom can override an existing Halakha in monetary affairs.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 76.</i> On the other hand, in matters of <i>issura</i> (prohibitions), custom cannot override Halakha.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh Hashana</i> 15b.</i> In our instance, though we are dealing with a monetary matter (inheritance), nevertheless, as we explained, <i>hilkhot yerusha</i> are labeled “<i>hukat mishpat</i>” (immutable) and as <i>issur</i> (prohibition) and therefore <i>minhag</i> should be ineffective in overriding the halakhic order of testamentary succession. And in fact, for the aforesaid reason, some authorities explicitly rule that a <i>minhag</i> cannot override the Torah law of succession.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 46.</i>
Nevertheless, according to many authorities, one may distribute assets to non-Torah heirs if a significant share of the estate (fifty percent or twenty percent) is distributed to Torah heirs, or according to others, if even a nominal amount is distributed to Torah heirs.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ohr Zarua</i> 3, <i>Bava Batra</i> 127; <i>Sefer ha-Ittur</i>, <i>Matnat Shekhiv Mera</i> 59b (p. 118); <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, 3:147; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 168; <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 49; <i>Taz</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 113:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 7:12 in the name of <i>Rema</i>; <i>Teshuvot Beit Dovid</i>, <i>HM</i> 137; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashash</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 133b, s.v. “<i>avurei ahsanta</i>”; <i>Zerah Emet</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Moshe</i> 1:70; <i>Teshuvot Avkat Rokhel</i> 92; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 92 (as understood by <i>Taz</i>, <i>EH</i> 113:1) and <i>Teshuvot Shoeil u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahdura Batra</i>, 1:1 (in the name of <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 92); <i>Nahalat Shiva</i> 21:4, 6; <i>Teshuvot Agudat Eizov</i>, <i>HM</i> 15; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i> 282:2; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 16; <i>Birkei Yosef</i>, <i>YD</i> 249:15; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:110, <i>HM</i> 2:49–50; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 4:216; Rabbi Z. N. Goldberg, 2 <i>Shurat ha-Din</i> 360, n. 11 (5754). Pursuant to one opinion, as long as some of the same property that is distributed to a non-Torah heir(s) is given to the Torah heir, there is no violation of <i>hilkhot yerusha.</i> See <i>Teshuvot Pnei Moshe</i> 1:70.<br>One exception to the rule is that one cannot withhold a portion of the <i>bekhor</i>’s double share. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Geonim</i>, Harkavi ed. 260; <i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 281:4. For an exception to this rule, see infra text accompanying nn. 83–85.<br>The fact that the distribution of a portion to a Torah heir and the balance to a non-Torah heir does not contravene an <i>issur</i>, cannot be taken as proof that a distribution based upon a civil will would be recognized by the above authorities.</i> R. Shmuel Wosner of Bnei Brak, Talmud Yerushalmi, Bava Batra 8:6, and the rulings of <i>Rishonim</i> imply that one engages in an <i>issur</i> only if one transfers the entire estate to non-Torah heirs.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Shevet ha-Levi</i>, supra n. 80.</i> R. Dovid Feldman of London, England argues in his treatise on <i>yerusha</i> that the same conclusion may be drawn from the discussion in Talmud Bavli, Bava Batra 133b.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Otzrot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>Nahalot</i> 228.</i> In effect, there is no commission of the <i>issur</i> of <i>avurei ahsanta</i> since a potential Torah heir receives a portion of the estate.
In other words, if there would be a <i>minhag</i> to divest the Torah heirs from benefiting from any portion of the inheritance, then the custom would be null and void, and would require us to redistribute all the assets to the Torah heirs. However, if a portion of the estate is distributed to the Torah heirs and the balance to non-Torah heirs, then the <i>minhag</i> is not tainted by any element of <i>issura</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 52b (the matter of <i>takanat benin dikhrin</i>); Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Ketuvot</i> 9:1; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 52:4 (end).</i> Consequently, if there is a prevailing custom that divests a <i>bekhor</i> (first-born son) entirely from his double portion of inheritance, such a <i>minhag</i> has no validity. However, if he has been disinherited from only a portion of that share, the <i>minhag</i> will be determinative.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yad Rama</i>, supra n. 42; <i>Maharik</i>, supra n. 46; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 281:4 (in the name of <i>Maharik</i>); <i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 10; <i>Radvaz</i> supra n. 46. The same is applicable when daughters inherit the entire estate and the son(s) receives nothing. See <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 2:19; <i>Maharit</i>, supra n. 8. Other <i>Poskim</i> mandate that a double portion of the decedent’s estate must be given to a <i>bekhor</i> and a partial distribution of his double portion to others is prohibited<i>.</i> See supra n. 80 (end); <i>Mishpat Hatzava’ah</i>, supra n. 14, at 59. Cf. others who contend that a gift while alive or an obligation may be undertaken to others, which in effect will diminish the <i>bekhor</i>’s double portion. See <i>Kerem Shlomo</i>, <i>HM</i> 282; <i>Kesef ha-Kodshin</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 282.</i> Similarly, if a civil will distributes an estate exclusively to the daughter(s) without distribution to the son(s), such a will is not halakhically effective. But if a Torah heir receives at least a portion of the estate, such an arrangement is valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 80.</i>
Even if the basis of the civil will is not grounded in the effectiveness of <i>minhag</i>, one may have to distribute a portion of the estate to the Torah heirs. In other words, if a <i>Posek</i> relies on the positions of Rabbis Meir of Rothenburg, Schwadron, and Feinstein to recognize a civil testamentary disposition, or if the estate has been structured based upon one of the halakhically sanctioned techniques,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 14.</i> according to various <i>Poskim</i>, provisions may have to be made for distribution to the Torah heirs.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Shtaroth le-Rav Hai Gaon</i>, <i>shtar</i> 48; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 168. However, R. Hai Gaon contends that if one utilizes a technique such as a <i>matnat bari</i> (a gift donated by a healthy person) or a <i>matnat shekhiv mera</i> (a deathbed gift), one need not distribute a portion to a Torah heir. See <i>Sefer ha-Shtarot</i>, op. cit., <i>shtar</i> 8–9 and 12. Cf. <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 11.<br>Whether a testator executing a <i>matnat bari</i> must avoid transferring property to a non-Torah heir is subject to debate. See R. Hai Gaon, ibid.; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 25:3; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 113:1; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, ibid.; <i>Teshuvot Mahane Yehuda</i>, <i>HM</i> 282; <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya‘akov</i> 3:28 (3).</i>
Others contend that validating a secular will based upon a secular legal system contravenes the prohibition for Jews to litigate matters in a secular court. In other words, the prohibition is not limited to litigating one’s affairs in secular courts, but extends to adopting practices that follow secular law.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">See infra n. 54. For the <i>issur</i> of litigating one’s matters in civil court, see Simcha Krauss, “Litigation in Secular Courts,” 3 <i>The Journal of Halacha and Contemporary Society</i> 35 (Spring 1982).</i> Others contend that affirmation of such a <i>minhag</i> is a violation of <i>avurei ahsanta</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nahala le-Yisrael</i>, 38, 53; <i>Teshuvot Mishpatei Tishmaru</i> 25.</i>
<b>D. The Scope of <i>Dina de-Malkhuta Dina</i></b>
Under certain prescribed conditions, Halakha is willing to recognize some secular laws based upon the rule “<i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>,” “the law of the kingship is the law.”<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 28a; <i>Gittin</i> 10b; <i>Bava Kama</i> 113a–b; <i>Bava Batra</i> 44b–45a. Many of the sources dealing with <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> have been culled from <i>Shilo</i>, supra n. 73.<br></i> Though the rule addresses a kingship governmental structure, nevertheless the rule is applicable to any polity that has been established with the consent of its citizens, has a legislative body,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:612, 637; <i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i> 6:28; Yosef Henkin, “<i>Dina de-Malkhuta Dina</i>,” (Hebrew) 31 <i>Hapardes</i> 3–5; <i>Yehave Da’at</i> 5:63.</i> and enacts legislation that does not discriminate against its citizenry.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Gezela ve-Aveida</i> 5:14; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:8; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 1:158; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ritva</i> 53; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 3:968; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 126; <i>Teshuvot Torat Emet</i> 153; <i>Teshuvot Hikekei Lev</i>, <i>HM</i> 6.</i>
Seemingly, a civil will drafted in accordance with the governing laws of a democratic order such as the United States ought to be recognized based upon the following <i>psak</i> of Rema:<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:8.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">There are some authorities who state that the law of the kingship is the law in regard to taxes and tariffs dealing with immovable items … but other matters not. And there are others who disagree and argue that the law of the kingship is law regarding any matter that will be beneficial to the citizens of the state.</span>
In accordance with Rema’s commentary on Tur, something beneficial for a state’s citizenry is any matter that relates to interaction between individuals,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i>, 369.</i> such as the execution of a testamentary disposition even if it is in variance with Halakha.
Though Shakh vigorously opposes incorporating a rule of secular law when it is contrary to Halakha,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 73:19.</i> nevertheless, historically, commencing with the time of the <i>Rishonim</i>, the majority of <i>Poskim</i> endorse the position of Rema.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Doveiv Mesharim</i> 1:76. For a list of other <i>Poskim</i>, see Shilo, supra n. 73, at 156.
