In addition, see <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:1; <i>Teshuvot Hakham Tzvi</i> 148; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i>, <i>HM</i> 10; <i>Teshuvot Harei Besamim Tanina</i> 2:41; <i>Teshuvot Avnei Tzedek</i>, <i>HM</i> 9; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Yoel</i> 2:147.</i>
Although in the past most authorities subscribed to Rema<i>’s</i> view, in contemporary times in Eretz Yisrael and elsewhere, normative Halakha endorses the Shakh’s position.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ma’adnei Aretz</i> 18:1; <i>Amud ha-Yemini</i> 1:8; <i>PDR</i> 5:269–270; 8:78, 81. In the most trenchant terms, Israeli <i>Poskim</i> lambast those who argue that <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> can serve as grounds for validating a civil will. See Ben Tzion Uziel, “<i>Mishpat Yerushat ha-Banot</i>,” (Hebrew) 9 <i>Talpiyot</i> 27, 44 (5725); Avraham Tzvi Yehuda Kook, “<i>Dina de-Malkhuta Dina</i> Regarding Inheritance,” (Hebrew) 3 <i>Tehumin</i> 231 (5742); Eliezer Waldenburg, “The Proposed Inheritance Law according to Halakha,” (Hebrew), Jubilee Volume to Shimon Federbush, Yerushalayim, 5721, 221; <i>Teshuvot Yehave Da’at</i> 4:65.</i> Moreover, though Rema invokes <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> regarding matters relating to the benefit of the citizenry of a particular country, nevertheless, following in the footsteps of the Shulhan Arukh,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 369; <i>Teshuvot Rav Pe’alim</i>, vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 15.</i> Rema opposes applying this rule as grounds for validating a civil will.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:11.</i> Similarly, though R. Moshe Feinstein subscribes to Rema’s view regarding the scope of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>, nevertheless, R. Feinstein explicitly rejects the notion that a civil will can be validated based upon that view.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:72.</i>
Furthermore, since American law does not mandate that inheritance matters be resolved in accordance with civil law, there is no reason to invoke <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> as a basis for validating a secular will.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Aliyot de-Rabbeinu Yona</i>, supra n. 72; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:895; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 495 in the name of <i>Rashba</i>; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 55; <i>Kezot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 104:6; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 104:3; <i>Teshuvot Hukot Hayyim</i> 1; <i>Teshuvot Shemesh Tzedaka</i>, <i>HM</i> 33:15; <i>Teshuvot Mahari Assad</i> 2:114; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Uziel</i> 3:28; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Likkutim</i>, <i>HM</i> 16.<br>Therefore, if the validity of a will is based upon <i>situmta</i> (see infra text accompanying nn. 109–113) and the governing civil law does not mandate the implementation of a certain <i>kinyan</i> regarding estate disposition, executing a <i>situmta</i> will be ineffective. See <i>PDR</i> 18:207, 240.</i>
Moreover, as Tashbetz and R. Akiva Eiger note, in cases in which there is an element of <i>issur</i>, one cannot invoke <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tashbetz</i>, supra n. 92; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i> 83.</i> In fact, numerous <i>Poskim</i> reject invoking <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> in order to validate a civil will that provides for an estate distribution to a non-Torah heir, which entails the commission of an <i>issur</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharam me-Padua</i>, supra n. 9; <i>Teshuvot Be‘er ha-Mayyim</i> 120–122; <i>Teshuvot Edut be-Ya’akov</i> 71–72.</i> For example, in the seventeenth century, R. Moshe Benveniste mandated that a daughter return her share in the inheritance to her brother because it was lost property (<i>hashavat aveida</i>), and he records that all scholars of the period rejected the validity of a secular will, based upon <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Pnei Moshe</i> 2:15.</i> In R. Benveniste’s words, “they struck that opinion with a hundred measures against one.” As such, at first glance, one must reject the validity of a secular will based on <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>. Subsequently, addressing a case of inheritance that occurred in 1851 in Ancona, Italy, R. Yisrael Moshe Hazan rails against those who equate the halakhic recognition of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> in estate distribution with the halakhic validity imparted to parties who arrange their monetary affairs in variance with Halakha. R. Hazan explains,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nahala le-Yisrael</i> 9. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Maharitz ha-Hadashot</i> 32.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">What has the maxim of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> to do with the Jewish law of inheritance? For the laws of inheritance are as removed from the laws ruling commercial transactions … as east is from west.</span>
As R. Akiva Eiger notes, these civil matters are monetary in nature, while the laws of a <i>yerusha</i> have the element of <i>issur</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">R. Akiva Eiger, supra n. 102<i>.</i></i> Consequently, it is unsurprising to find numerous <i>Poskim</i> who invalidate a civil will based upon <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 103; <i>Hida</i>, <i>Tuv Ayin</i> 17:4; <i>Yosef Ometz</i>, supra n. 53; <i>Rav Pe’alim</i>, supra n. 98; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 13; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 2:95; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 6:42 (8); <i>Teshuvot Mishneh Halakhot</i> 9:326.</i> Hence, any assets, including but not limited to <i>yerusha</i> awarded by a civil court, halakhically continue to belong to the Torah heir(s), and as such, a non-Torah heir who has won in court cannot enforce the award lest he be labeled a thief.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 145; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 154; R. Z. N. Goldberg, 5 <i>ha-Yashar ve-Hatov</i> 3, 5 (5768).</i>
Notwithstanding what we have presented here, without impinging upon the element of <i>issur</i> of <i>hilkhot yerusha</i>, according to contemporary <i>Poskim</i> such as Rabbis Messas and Sha’anan, one can still invoke the rule of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tevuot Shemesh</i>, supra n. 57; <i>Sha’anan</i>, supra n. 55. See also, R. Yirmeyahu cited in <i>Pnei Moshe</i>, supra n. 104; <i>Teshuvot Aderet Eliyahu</i> 23.</i> A last will and testament is a document that entails gifting an estate to various individuals. Though its provisions and the terminology employed by the document may not be in conformity with the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>shtar matana</i>, a bona fide document that grants a gift, nevertheless, it is a <i>shtar matana</i> that is valid in the eyes of secular law. The question is whether Halakha recognizes a <i>shtar kinyan</i> (a vehicle to transfer an asset) such as a <i>shtar matana</i> that was prepared in accordance with civil law.
According to the majority of <i>Rishonim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ittur</i>, vol. 1, <i>Ma’amar Shemini</i>, <i>Kiyum Tofsim ve-Hotmim</i>; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 325; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 10b; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 10b; <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 10b; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 1:10; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 10b; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Malveh ve-Loveh</i> 27:1; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ran</i> 37; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 203; <i>Tashbetz</i>, supra n. 92; <i>Hiddushei Nimukei Yosef</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 10b.</i> and some <i>Aharonim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:545, 6:1183; <i>Teshuvot Mayyim Amukim</i> 53.<br>However, clearly <i>Radvaz</i> will reject a will as a <i>shtar matana</i> that reflects the <i>minhag</i> of disinheriting Torah heirs.</i> a <i>shtar matana</i> drafted in accordance with secular law is valid. The majority view of <i>Rishonim</i> notwithstanding, Shulhan Arukh and many <i>Aharonim</i> relied upon the minority view of <i>Rishonim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rif</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 1:410; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Malveh ve-Loveh</i> 27:1</i> to invalidate such a <i>shtar matana</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 68:1; <i>Teshuvot Binyamin Ze’ev</i> 2:415; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shmuel</i> 103; <i>Teshuvot Orah le-Tzadik</i>, <i>HM</i> 1; <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 68:1</i> Rabbis Messas and Sha’anan, relying upon the majority of <i>Rishonim</i> and some <i>Aharonim</i> who validate the <i>shtar</i>, argue that a civil will ought to be recognized. Yet, since a <i>shtar matana</i> is a <i>shtar kinyan</i> and there is no <i>kinyan</i> after death, on what grounds can one legitimate such an estate distribution in accordance with a secular will?
Here again, as we mentioned previously in our presentation, the grounds for maintaining the effectiveness of a civil will as a <i>shtar matana</i> is based upon the position of Rabbeinu Yona and R. Blau, in which the will acts as a <i>kinyan situmta</i>. According to this position, the transfer of the assets from the testator to the heirs is subdivided into two stages. Invoking the view that the rule of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>, secular law divests the testator of the ownership of the assets. The assets are subsequently transferred from the testator to the heir as a conditional transfer (<i>kinyan al tenai</i>) that takes effect with the testator’s demise. As we explained previously, the <i>kinyan situmta</i> is executed during the testator’s lifetime, only to be implemented upon his death.
In short, clearly, the need to distribute a portion of the estate to the Torah heirs is not limited to an instance of enforcing a civil will based upon <i>minhag</i> or <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>. As we mentioned earlier, these approaches of Rabbis Rothenburg, Schwadron, and Feinstein are predicated upon the fact that a partial distribution to a Torah heir will suffice to nullify the issue of <i>avurei ahsanta</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 80; <i>Sefer ha-Shtarot le-Rav Hai Gaon</i>, <i>shtar</i> 48; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 168. However, R. Hai Gaon contends that if one utilizes a technique such as a <i>matnat bari</i> (a gift donated by a healthy person) or a <i>matnat shekhiv mera</i> (a deathbed gift) one need not distribute a portion to a Torah heir. See <i>Sefer ha-Shtarot</i>, op. cit., <i>shtar</i> 8–9 and 12; <i>Teshuvot ha-Geonim</i>, supra n. 80. Cf. <i>Halakhot Gedolot</i>, Hildesheimer ed., vol. 2, 511; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 11.<br>Whether a testator executing a <i>matnat bari</i> must avoid transferring property to a non-Torah heir is subject to debate. See R. Hai Gaon, ibid.; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 25:3; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 113:1; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, ibid.; <i>Teshuvot Mahane Yehuda</i>, <i>HM</i> 282; <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 3:28 (3).</i>
Accordingly, the testator’s preparation of a civil will can be grounded in the <i>pesakim</i> of Maharam of Rothenburg, R. Schwadron, and R. Feinstein, and those <i>Poskim</i> who affirm the <i>minhag</i> and the validity of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>.
In the foregoing (section 2, subsections a–d), we presented the positions of Rabbis Rothenburg, Schwadron, and Feinstein, as well as <i>Poskim</i> who endorse the effectiveness of <i>minhag</i> or <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>, which would serve as grounds for drafting a civil will as a means for distributing one’s assets to non-Torah heirs. In fact, R. H. Shlomo Sha’anan, a <i>dayan</i> serving on a Tel Aviv Beit Din, took into account all four approaches in order to validate a civil will.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Sha’anan, supra n. 55; <i>Iyunim be-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 34.</i> It is important to stress that all of these approaches are grounded in a particular halakhic-legal technique that allows for an estate distribution to any individual, regardless of whether the person is a Torah heir or not. In effect, the estate has been effectively transformed from a potential source of inheritance for a Torah heir into an asset that can be acquired by anyone, no different from any article for sale in the marketplace.
As we have discussed, however, others reject these techniques and affirm the Talmudic and Shulhan Arukh rule that “<i>yerusha ein lo hefsek</i>” (the succession of inheritance cannot be interrupted),<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 125b, 129b; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 248:1. See supra n. 15 and infra n. 164.</i> and therefore reject all of these solutions.
<b>E. The Parameters of “<i>Mitzva le-Kayeim Divrei ha-Met</i>”</b>
As we explained, many would argue that the will is ineffective in transferring an estate either because “there is no <i>kinyan</i> after death,”<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">See text accompanying supra nn. 3–4.</i> or because one may not disinherit a Torah heir from his rightful share as dictated by the Torah view of succession. Distributing a partial share to a Torah heir will not obviate the halakhic fact that the Torah view of succession is “<i>hukat mishpat</i>.” According to many <i>Poskim</i>, any distribution of a share to a non-Torah heir entails the contravention of an <i>issur</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 336; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 1:29; <i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 2:164; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 11. Cf. text supra accompanying n. 80.</i> Hence, even <i>be-diavad</i> (<i>ex post facto</i>), one may not rely upon a secular will.
However, according to some <i>Poskim</i>, one can validate a secular will based upon “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>,” the halakhic duty to carry out the wishes of the deceased.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gittin</i> 14b, 15a; <i>Bava Batra</i> 149a. It is subject to debate whether “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” applies to a testator’s instructions unrelated to property. See <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 3:130; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 1:168; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, Tinyana, <i>EH</i> 45. Additionally, whether “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” applies to an asset that is a <i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i> (something which is not yet in existence) or <i>davar she-lo ba lirshuto</i> (something not yet in one’s control) is subject to debate. See <i>Teshuvot Maharbil</i> 3:43; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 212:3, 252:3; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 1:39; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 110; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>YD</i> 2:77.</i> Among the <i>Rishonim</i> there are two primary approaches to understanding the conditions in which this <i>mitzva</i> applies. According to some decisors, should the testator state, “Give such and such to Reuven,” such a clear instruction without transferring the actual asset to a <i>shalish</i> (third party) is enough for there to be a “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 13a, s.v. “<i>ve’od</i>”; <i>Rashi</i>, <i>Gittin</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>be-bari</i>”; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>BB</i> 149a, s.v. “<i>deka</i>”; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 252 who cites <i>Rosh</i>, <i>Ritva</i>, and <i>Ra’ah</i>; <i>Teshuvot Rema</i> 48; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 252 (8); <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 252:4, 7; <i>Teshuvot Binyan Tzion ha-Hadashot</i> 2:24.<br>For discussion of <i>Ritva</i>’s view, which is cited in <i>Shita Mekubetzet</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 69b, see <i>Kesai Mishpat</i> 112.</i> Others require that the assets be deposited for purposes of eventual estate distribution (<i>hashlasha</i>) with a <i>shalish</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rabbeinu Tam</i>, <i>Tosafot Ketuvot</i> 70a, s.v. “<i>veho</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 15:1; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 1:15; <i>Teshuvot Mahari Ibn Lev</i> 2:39; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 95. Others claim that the deposit with a third party must have been executed prior to the verbal directive. See <i>Mahari Ibn Lev</i>, op. cit.<br></i> Normative Halakha mandates that the assets be deposited with a <i>shalish</i> for the express purpose of carrying out the testator’s wishes, and the will should preferably employ the language of <i>matana</i>, gifting (such as “I give”), rather than language of <i>yerusha</i> (such as “I bequeath”).<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 250:23, 252:2; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 48.<br>Whether one can fulfill the wishes of the deceased by employing <i>yerusha</i> terminology in a testamentary disposition rather than the language of gifting is subject to debate. See <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 248:1; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 248:6.<br>Whether “<i>hashlasha</i>” is applicable in regard to real estate is subject to dispute. See the exchange of letters between Helkat Mehokeik and R. Heschel printed at the back of <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i> and cited in <i>Teshuvot Heshev ha-Efod</i>, 2:106. Given that real estate, unlike movable assets, cannot be deposited with a third party, the question is whether control over a given property is sufficient to fulfill the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>hashlasha</i>.</i>
Based upon the foregoing, Maharit contends that a civil will does not conform to the dictates of “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>”:<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharit</i>, supra n. 8.</i> A civil will lacks a clear directive from the testator to the Torah heirs to distribute the assets, which is a precondition for invoking “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 13a; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ran</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 13a; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 252:4; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 252:8; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 252:10; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i>, <i>HM</i> 6; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i> 1:150.</i> and does not satisfy the requirement of disclosing the provisions for distribution of the estate in the presence of the future heirs.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 13a, s.v. “<i>be-mai</i>”; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i> 1:150.</i> That, coupled with the fact that an <i>issur</i> is committed by disinheriting a Torah heir,<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mishpatim Yesharim</i> 44; <i>Teshuvot Avkat Rohel</i> 93.</i> renders it impossible for a civil will to be affirmed. Finally, R. Hayyim Ozer Grodzenzky argues that one cannot find support for the idea that a civil will can constitute valid <i>hashlasha</i> (deposit) in this <i>teshuva</i> of Maharit since this <i>teshuva</i> addresses charity bequests,<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ahiezer</i> 3:34, 4:66.</i> and his ruling therefore may not necessarily extend to private testamentary dispositions.
In one of his rulings, R. Grodzensky writes,<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ahiezer</i> 4:66.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">I have always doubted the propriety of the wills executed in civil courts since there is no <i>shtar</i> after death, yet a Jewish court will affirm their provisions.</span>
As such, though his decision addressed matters of charitable bequests, clearly his ruling regarding the invocation of “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” applies equally to the conventional last will and testament. Contemporary decisors understood Rabbi Grodzensky’s <i>psak</i> in a similar fashion.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Heshev ha-Ephod</i> 2:106, 3:25; <i>Teshuvot Netzah Yisrael</i> 20; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Yerusha</i>, pp. 145–146; <i>Mishpatei Tishmaru</i>, supra n. 89; <i>Kuntres me-Dor le-Dor</i>, supra n. 14, at 2; <i>Mishpat Shlomo</i>, supra n. 55.</i>
To buttress his aforementioned position, R. Grodzensky found precedent in a <i>teshuva</i> of R. Ya’akov Ettlinger dealing with a secular will.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Binyan Tzion</i>, supra n. 120.</i> The facts posed to R. Ettlinger were the following: A healthy individual prepared a testamentary disposition in accordance with civil law, wherein upon his demise, his estate would be distributed among Torah and non-Torah heirs. Since the estate arrangement failed to comply with Halakha, the non-Torah heirs inquired of R. Ettlinger whether this civil will would be halakhically valid. Since the assets were in the hands of the beneficiaries in accordance with secular law, these individuals were <i>muhzakim</i> in these assets. Lest one argue that the assets must be deposited with a third party prior to invoking “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>,” R. Ettlinger argued that since the testator communicated explicit instructions to transfer these assets upon his demise,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">See text accompanying supra n. 130.</i> this suffices to comply with the <i>mitzva</i>. The fact that executors were appointed to ensure that his wishes would be fulfilled, and that the will would be enforced by secular authorities, suffices to comply with the dictates of “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ramban</i>, supra n. 120; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ritva</i> 54 in the name of <i>Ra’ah</i>; <i>Ran</i> on <i>Rif</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 5b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 48 in the name of <i>Rambam</i>.<br>The existence of an executor of a will creates <i>hashlasha</i>. See <i>Teshuvot Heshev ha-Ephod</i> (in the name of <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>) 3:25.</i>
Relying upon R. Ettlinger’s argumentation, R. Grodzensky posits,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ahiezer</i> 3:34. Here again, R. Grodzensky’s argument demonstrates that his decision is not limited to cases of <i>tzedaka</i>. Though in this <i>teshuva</i> he does not definitively resolve that executing a civil will is valid, elsewhere he validates it. See <i>Kovetz Iggerot</i> 25.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">For some time, I have inclined to the view that the beneficiary in a will executed in accordance with the law of the land is to be considered as a <i>muhzak</i>, since the testamentary disposition will be carried out in accordance with the law of the land, and as such we do not need the halakhic requirement of a deposit for the purpose of estate distribution. However, I have not found a source (“<i>gilluyei</i>”) for this Halakha.</span>
In effect, the preparation and execution of a civil will and its subsequent enforcement by civil authorities is tantamount to depositing the assets with a third party for the express purpose of future estate distribution, i.e., <i>hashlasha</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">See text accompanying supra n. 133.</i> His position has been endorsed by some <i>Poskim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Binyan Tzion</i>, supra n. 120; <i>Teshuvot ve-Hanhagot</i> 1:853; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Shai</i> 75. <i>Minhat Shai</i> argues that both <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 13, and <i>Radvaz</i>, supra n. 42, agree with his position.</i>
A similar approach has been espoused by R. Shmuel Shor, who recognizes that <i>hashlasha</i> applies only when one gives a gift to a stranger. However, when one gives a gift to his daughter, and she is considered <i>muhzeket</i> according to civil law, a deposit is not required and therefore such a testamentary disposition is therefore valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Minhat Shai</i>, supra n. 135.</i>
Arguing somewhat differently from Rabbis Shor and Grodzensky, R. Henoch Padwa writes that the initiation of the executor’s action to probate the will is to be viewed as a type of <i>hashlasha</i> and therefore, the condition for “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” at this juncture has been fulfilled. In other words, the preparation of a testamentary disposition in accordance with secular law and its enforceability by the court are insufficient to establish <i>hashlasha</i>. One requires the probating of the will by the executor.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Heshev ha-Ephod</i>, supra n. 129. See also, <i>PDR</i> 17:175, 278.</i> On the other hand, implicit in their approach is that <i>hashlasha</i> suffices and there exists no requirement that the testator communicate instructions to the Torah heirs regarding the estate distribution.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. supra text accompanying n. 124.</i>
The ramifications of Rabbis Grodzensky, Shor, and Padwa’s view that the preparation of a civil will and/or probating it is a form of <i>hashlasha</i> and therefore serves to ascertain <i>gemirat da’at</i>, would be applicable to all segments of our Orthodox Jewish community. Many Jews who identify and affiliate with religious institutions in our Orthodox Jewish community execute such testamentary dispositions. Although many different documents have been suggested as complying with halakhic estate planning, and there are attorneys with the expertise and experience to address the observant Jewish community’s concerns in drafting a halakhic will which will be in legal compliance, it is not unusual to find, amongst families across the Orthodox spectrum, numerous testamentary instructions which continue to be prepared in accordance with civil law. And in fact, many contested <i>yerusha</i> matters addressed in <i>beit din</i> today deal with civil wills executed by members of all segments of our community.
However, R. Yosef Elyashiv seemingly invalidates such testamentary dispositions. He argues in a written <i>teshuva</i> that R. Grodzensky’s view that the preparation and enforcement of a civil will is a form of <i>hashlasha</i> is applicable only to secular Jews who do not exhibit “a deficiency in their <i>gemirat da’at.</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kovetz ha-Teshuvot</i> 3:225.</i> To put it differently, since secular Jews do not comply with Halakha, they firmly intend to have their civil wills probated in secular court. On the other hand, an observant Jew’s allegiance is to Halakha, and should he prepare a civil will, he has no firm commitment to have the document probated civilly. The <i>gemirat da’at</i> of an observant Jew is to follow Halakha, and since in R. Elyashiv’s view a civil will cannot be validated for observant Jews either <i>le-khathila</i> or <i>be-diavad</i>, a testator’s <i>gemirat da’at</i> is recognized only if his estate planning is halakhically compliant. A similar view is espoused by Meishiv be-Halakha, a Torah publication of Machon Lehoro’ah, a <i>beit din</i> in Monsey, New York.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meishiv be-Halakha</i> 211, n. 288</i>
However, as noted by R. Schwartz, R. Elyashiv’s line of reasoning should apply equally to any observant Jew who files a civil divorce, trusting that his testamentary disposition will be executed in accordance with his wishes upon his demise.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i>, vol. 2, 309. In fact, R. Pinchus Rabinowitz, an expert in <i>yerusha</i> matters and a <i>dayan</i> in Monsey, NY who for years was in regular communication with R. Elyashiv, informed me on July 30, 2013 that R. Elyashiv changed his mind and subscribed to R. Grodzensky’s view even with regard to Torah-observant Jews.</i> In fact, according to a <i>mesorah</i> attributed to R. Elyashiv, in situations in which people recognize one mode of estate planning, i.e., executing a civil will and preparing such a testamentary disposition, we assess (<i>umdana</i>) that their intentions were to transfer the estate as a gift in accordance with secular law, and we treat it as <i>hashlasha</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Shlomo Zafrani, 20 <i>Moriah</i>, <i>gilyon</i> 122 (Tevet 5756). See supra n. 140. Cf. R. Turetsky, who attributes a contradictory <i>psak</i> to R. Elyashiv. See <i>Teshuvot Yashiv Moshe</i>, 475.</i> To state it differently, even observant Jews who have their estate wishes executed in accordance with civil law trust that their instructions will be complied with, and therefore a civil will ought to be recognized as a vehicle for <i>hashlasha</i>.
Nonetheless, R. Elyashiv contends based upon “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” that a <i>peshara</i> (compromise) should be executed by the Jewishly observant who utilize secular estate arrangements.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 139.</i> And Meishiv be-Halakha contends that it is <i>midat hassidut</i> to comply with the provisions of a civil will, and invokes the possibility that confirmation of such a testamentary disposition is a fulfillment of <i>kibbud av</i>, a matter we will discuss later in our presentation.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">See infra text accompanying nn. 153–169.</i>
Finally, regarding Maharit’s opposition to invoking “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” when a civil will is in violation of the <i>issur</i> of <i>avurei ahsanta</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 80.</i> this may be based on the view that “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” is a form of <i>kinyan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, if a testator instructs a <i>shalish</i> to transfer ownership of an asset to a third party upon his demise, the beneficiary assumes responsibility for the assets after the testator’s death. See <i>Rashi</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 15b, s.v. “<i>de-amru</i>”; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 630 in the name of <i>R. Tam</i>; <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Zekhiya u-Matana</i> 29; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:224 (10); <i>Sefer Shiurei ha-Rav</i> (Y. B. Soloveitchik) on <i>Gittin</i> 13a.</i> and therefore invoking it as grounds for recognizing a non-Torah heir’s entitlement to estate assets does not mitigate the contravention of an <i>issur</i>. In fact, in another <i>teshuva</i> penned by Maharit, he seems to endorse this understanding of “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 2:95.</i> and we can therefore readily understand his opposition to invoking this notion in cases of disinheritance of Torah heirs.
However, most <i>Poskim</i> contend that “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” is not an act of <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Absent the actual transfer of the asset(s) by the testator during his lifetime to the <i>shalish</i>’s control, it is fulfillment of a <i>mitzva.</i> See <i>Rabbeinu Tam</i>, <i>Tosafot Gittin</i> 13a, s.v. “<i>ve-ho</i>”; <i>Shitot Kadmonim</i> and <i>Hiddushei ha-Rama</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 13a; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 629; <i>Tashbetz</i> 2:53; <i>Rema SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 252:2; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 248:5; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i> (Urbach), <i>YD</i> 48.</i> Rather, as the words denote, this concept informs us that it is a halakhic duty, a <i>mitzva</i>, to fulfill the wishes of the deceased. As R. Shaul Nathanson notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i> 1.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It is a matter of “kindness of truth” [<i>hessed shel emet</i>] that we do with the departed … and it is a duty to comply with the wishes of the deceased.</span>
Yet, as we explained,<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">See text accompanying supra n. 80.</i> should the testamentary disposition provide that Torah heirs, alongside non-Torah heirs, benefit from the estate distribution, the <i>issur</i> of “<i>avurei ahsanta</i>” is nonexistent and the <i>mitzva</i> may be fulfilled and enforceable by a <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 252.</i>
In short, though not explicitly stated, we assume that despite the recognition of a civil will by R. Grodzensky, R. Shor, and the others who recognize a civil will, they will all concur that Torah heirs must receive a distribution from the estate, lest the execution of the will entail a contravention of the <i>issur</i> of “<i>avurei ahsanta</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">See text accompanying supra n. 80.</i> Even if the language employed by the testator is “to bequeath” or “to inherit” rather than “to give” his assets, such language will not invalidate the civil will that reflects the deceased’s wishes.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 248:1. Though <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 248:1 and <i>Teshuvot ve-Hanhagot</i> 1:872 disagree, nonetheless, since there is halakhic doubt as to who ought to possess the assets, we do not extract them from the <i>muhzak</i>. See <i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i> 2:22 (225). However, it is questionable whether such terminology will validate such a disposition based upon the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>kibbud av</i>. See infra text accompanying nn. 154–158.</i>
<b>F. The Parameters of <i>Kibbud Av</i></b>
Finally, in the absence of affirming a civil will as a means to perform the “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>,” there are <i>Poskim</i> who argue that compliance with a parent’s wishes is a fulfillment of the <i>mitzva</i> of either <i>kibbud av</i>, honoring one’s father,<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tashbetz</i>, supra n. 148; <i>Mahari ha-Levi</i>, supra n. 13; <i>Minhat Shai</i>, supra n. 136; <i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 33; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 214; <i>Maharsham</i>, supra n. 21, at 15–18; <i>Kovetz ha-Teshuvot</i>, <i>HM</i> 215; <i>Iyunim be-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 33.<br>Rabbi Ya’akov Reicher argues that in accordance with the dictates of <i>lifnim mi-shurat ha-din</i> (lit. “beyond the limit of the law”), one may invoke <i>kibbud av</i> regarding a testamentary disposition. See <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 1:168. Even though he contends that one cannot coerce the child to respect his parent’s wishes, nevertheless, should such a matter be resolved by a <i>beit din</i>, the signing of an arbitration agreement would be grounds to effectuate his compliance. A <i>beit din</i> can mandate compliance with one’s halakhic-moral obligations. See <i>Teshuvot Mahari Bruna</i> 241; R. Zalman Goldberg, <i>Shivhei ha-Peshara</i> section 5 (letter sent to Kollel Mishpetei Aretz, Ofrah, Israel).<br>Since one is saved from transgressing an <i>issur</i> by performing the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>kibbud av</i>, we may assume that these <i>Poskim</i> hold that as long as the Torah heir(s) receives a portion of the <i>yerusha</i>, there is no nullification of the <i>halakhot</i> of Torah succession.</i> or <i>mora av</i>, filial
reverence.<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>YD</i> 148:8. R. Akiva Eiger is unsure whether to affirm a will based upon these grounds. See <i>Teshuvot Rabbi Akiva Eiger</i> 1:68.</i> The implicit premise of this position is that a <i>beit din</i> can coerce a child to comply with his parent’s wishes<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhosot le-Ramban</i> 88; <i>Sefer ha-Hinukh</i>, <i>mitzva</i> 33; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 97:16; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 1. Alternatively, even if one contends that there is no basis for coercing an individual to honor his parent, by dint of signing on the arbitration agreement, the child is duty-bound to obey a <i>beit din</i> that mandates that the parent be accorded honor and respect. See supra n. 154.</i> and that a child is obligated in <i>kibbud av</i> after his father’s demise.<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Shivat Tzion</i> 58; <i>Birkei Yosef</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 240:17.<br>For example, after his father’s demise the heir is obligated by the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>kibbud av</i> to pay off his father’s debts and restore an object the father stole or <i>ribbit</i> he took. See <i>Ketuvot</i> 91b; <i>Bava Kama</i> 94b, 112a; <i>Bava Batra</i> 157a.</i> Such a conclusion would apply equally to a secular will.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Heshev ha-Ephod</i>, supra n. 129.</i>
Others disagree for one of three reasons. Firstly, one cannot coerce a child to comply with his parent’s wishes.<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 91b, s.v. “<i>mitzva</i>”; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 9:13–14; <i>Maharsham</i>, supra n. 21.</i> Some argue that <i>kibbud av</i> is limited to personal service of a parent, whereas incurring a financial loss does not fall within the ambit of the <i>mitzva</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 240:1.<br>Firstly, though many <i>Poskim</i> argue that there is no <i>mitzva</i> of <i>kibbud av</i> when he does not benefit from the child’s action, there are decisors who disagree. See <i>Havot Yair</i>, supra n. 154; R. Akiva Eiger, supra n. 154; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i>, 2:224 (in the name of <i>Rivash</i> and <i>Tashbetz</i>). Secondly, as R. Schwadron aptly notes, benefit accruing to a parent is not limited to personal service, but encompasses equally his monetary assets. See <i>Maharsham</i>, op. cit., subsection 14. Hence, there should be unanimous agreement that a parent derives benefit, albeit it may be of a psychological nature, from his children’s receiving his assets in accordance with his instructions.<br>Finally, permitting a non-Torah heir to inherit, in effect, creates a situation that the Torah heir has to expend his own money, and seemingly, such an outlay of monies exceeds the scope of <i>kibbud av</i>. See <i>Teshuvot Tehila le-Dovid</i>, <i>HM</i> 252:2.</i> Consequently, since foregoing one’s share in an estate entails an expense to the child without reimbursement by the parent, the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>kibbud av</i> is inapplicable.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Emet le-Ya’akov</i>, <i>HM</i> 282. Cf. <i>Mahari ha-Levi</i>, supra n. 13 and others who argue that the son has not benefited from receiving a <i>yerusha</i>, but rather, by being deprived of it, he incurred a loss.</i> Finally, some argue that since there is no obligation to honor and/or respect a parent after his demise,<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tashbetz</i>, supra n. 148; <i>Shevut Ya‘akov</i>, supra n. 154.</i> the child is exempt from complying with the parent’s testamentary wishes, which will be actualized after his death.
We should be mindful of the words of a well-respected twentieth-century halakhic arbiter. After stressing the importance of complying with the order of succession prescribed in the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 14.</i> R. Tucashinsky concludes with the following:<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gesher ha-Hayyim</i>, vol. 1, 41.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">And if he erred and wrote to his daughter or wife in a language that is ineffective for estate transfer, it is desirable that the sons agree to distribute the estate equally with their sister and mother, and it is a <i>mitzva</i> to fulfill the words of the father … and also to avoid friction and controversy.</span>
The <i>pesika</i> of R. Tucashinsky, which was forged in the crucible of his learning experience and investigation of the halakhic sources, led to him to conclude that various halakhic techniques for drafting a will were the order of the day. And in his writings he suggested various texts of halakhically sanctioned <i>tzavaot</i>. Nevertheless, he concludes his presentation with the point that our Torah is described as “ways of pleasantness and all her paths are peace.”
Though R. Tucashinsky was hard pressed to find grounds to validate a secular will, nonetheless, he clearly experienced personal anguish regarding disrespecting a father and his personal wishes and the potential family strife and instability which ensued by a son who contests a civil will. He therefore directed the son(s) to agree and accept the estate distribution to the non-Torah heirs based upon <i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>, <i>kibbud av</i>, and fostering <i>shalom</i>.
A similar approach, albeit much more subtle in form, resonates in the writings of R. Mattisyahu Schwartz. After his exhaustive treatment of over four hundred pages in volume 1 of <i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i> arguing for the paramount importance of drafting a halakhic will, examining the advantages and disadvantages of the various techniques proposed for drafting a will, and his fifty-five-page review of all the differing views of whether <i>kibbud av</i> is applicable in volume 2, R. Schwartz summarizes his conclusion by stating,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i>, vol. 2, 85.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">In volume 1 of <i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i> we had a lengthy presentation in explaining why the <i>Poskim</i> argue that one must affirm a civil will due to honor of a father [and we discussed the views that rejected <i>kibbud av</i>].</span>
In other words, his aforesaid summary indicates that R. Schwartz is subscribing to the view that <i>ex post facto</i> one should affirm the will based upon <i>kibbud av</i>. A halakhic will is the prescribed method for estate planning, however R. Schwartz affirms a civil will based on <i>kibbud av</i>. In fact, R. Schwartz argues that even <i>Poskim</i> who hold that children are exempt from <i>kibbud av</i> in complying with estate directives agree that if the children fulfill their parent’s wishes, they do fulfill the <i>mitzva</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i>, vol. 1, 501.</i>
His position manifests itself when dealing with the following scenario: A father’s will mandates that portions of his estate be distributed to non-Torah heirs, but upon his demise, his wife demands that the estate be distributed to other non-Torah heirs. Applying rulings emerging from different cases, R. Schwartz finds three approaches to parental precedence and filial responsibility. In a case in which two parents disagreed about the propriety of a match for their child, R. Yehzekel Landau concludes that if only the mother is alive, <i>kibbud em</i> trumps <i>kibbud av</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>EH</i> 45.</i> In a case in which there is a conflict between the deceased mother’s will and the instructions of a living father, and the father’s instructions involve financial loss, R. Akiva Eiger contends that the son can choose whose instructions to follow.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">R. Akiva Eiger, supra n. 155.</i> Should a father oppose his son’s recitation of <i>Kaddish</i> for his deceased mother, some <i>Poskim</i> argue that in such a situation <i>kibbud av</i> and <i>kibbud em</i> are on equal standing and that the <i>avel</i> (mourner) can therefore choose whose instructions he wants to follow.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hayyim She’ol</i>, 1:5; <i>Teshuvot be-Tzel ha-Hokhma</i>, 5:15.</i> In other words, drawing from cases dealing with a prospective marital mate, a child incurring a financial loss through <i>kibbud av</i>, and the <i>Kaddish</i> recitation for a parent despite the other parent’s protestation, R. Schwartz draws three contrasting conclusions regarding how to confront a mother’s desire to modify her husband’s estate disposition and divide the estate among other non-Torah heirs.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i>, 2:82–88.</i> To state it differently, there is no discussion whatsoever about tearing up the will and giving all the assets to the Torah heirs. The question is simply whose <i>kavod</i> will be the determining factor in the estate distribution. And therefore, there are no grounds to distribute the entire <i>yerusha</i> to the Torah heir.
In conclusion, numerous decisors invalidate a civil will either because there is no <i>kinyan</i> after death and/or because affirming the will entails the violation of “<i>avurei ahsanta</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">In addition to the <i>Poskim</i> cited supra n. 15, see <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 172; <i>Rav Pe’alim</i>, supra n. 98; File no. 5528-42-1, Petach Tikva Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, January 20, 2005; File no. 8820-41-1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Attorney General</i>, November 23, 2009; Asher Weiss, “An Improperly Drafted Will,” (Hebrew) 6 <i>Darkhei Horo’ah</i> 130, 133–137 (5767).</i> Should the assets earmarked in a civil will be distributed to non-Torah heirs, many <i>battei din</i> will redistribute the lion’s share of the estate to the Torah heir(s) in accordance with the order of Torah succession.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 259; <i>Kovetz ha-Teshuvot</i> supra n. 139.</i> Other <i>battei din</i> will rely upon the views expressed in our presentation that would validate a civil will.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">See supra nn. 55 and 115.</i>
Should a <i>beit din</i> choose to invalidate the estate distribution in the will, a nominal distribution will be given to the daughter(s). Since legally, the daughter must sign off in order for the son to inherit his share of the estate, the daughter can rely on <i>Poskim</i> who do not obligate a daughter to sign off the estate distribution,<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Whether one can coerce a daughter to sign a waiver is a matter of controversy. See <i>Pnei Moshe</i> supra n. 104; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i> 2, <i>Mahdura Tiltali</i> 1:78, 265, 3:45, 73; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 1:4; <i>Heshev ha-Ephod</i>, supra n. 129; <i>Erekh Shai</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:9; <i>Teshuvot Beit Shlomo</i> (Sklai), <i>OH</i> 85:3, <i>YD</i> 2:79, <i>HM</i> 108–109; <i>Hukot ha-Hayyim</i> 73; <i>Teshuvot Mahariz Enzel</i> 28–29; <i>Nahalat Tzvi HM</i> 276; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim HM</i> 2:3; <i>Teshuvot Rav Pe’alim HM</i> 2:15.<br>However, if this matter is being resolved by a <i>beit din</i> empowered by signed arbitration agreement to address this matter, then even those <i>Poskim</i> who contend that generally one cannot coerce a daughter to sign a waiver document, the <i>beit din</i> does possess such authority.</i> and she therefore has a right to receive a portion of the estate.
In exchange for her signature, there is a <i>minhag</i> to give her either at least ten percent of the value of the estate,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pnei Moshe</i>, supra n. 104 (in the name of Maharit); <i>Hukot Hayyim</i>, supra n. 174; <i>Seder Eliyahu Rabba ve-Zuta</i> 15.</i> or an amount determined by a <i>beit din</i> panel.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 1:4; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:3; <i>Teshuvot Birkat Yosef</i> (Landa), <i>HM</i> 22; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 5:211; <i>Teshuvot Mahaze Avraham</i> (Steinberg) 2:19; <i>PDR</i> 9, 115, 126–131. For a text of a waiver document, see <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 15:60.</i> In effect, offering assets to a daughter is a <i>peshara</i>, a compromise. Generally speaking, in an instance of <i>issur</i>, one cannot implement a <i>peshara</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Avnei Nezer</i>, <i>HM</i> 23; <i>Teshuvot Yad Eliyahu</i> 48; <i>Teshuvot be-Tzel ha-Hokhma</i> 3:36.</i> nevertheless, the <i>issur</i> here may be inoperative. As we earlier noted, though the entire estate belongs to the Torah heirs and consequently, according to certain decisors, a partial distribution to a daughter entails a violation of “<i>avurei ahsanta</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 12.</i> some <i>Poskim</i> permit distribution to a non-Torah heir. Implicit in their allowance of distribution to a daughter is their endorsement of the position that distribution to a non-Torah heir is permissible if he shares in the estate distribution.<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying n. 80.</i> Alternatively, since secular law mandates a daughter’s signature for the son to receive his estate distribution, Halakha allows her to sign off. Consequently, in the absence of an <i>issur</i>, a <i>peshara</i> may be implemented. Finally, to avoid a daughter proceeding to litigate her claim in civil court, which entails the commission of an <i>issur</i>, we allow a <i>peshara</i> to be executed.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Birkat Yosef</i>, supra n. 176<i>.</i></i>
Others, such as Rabbis Maharam of Rothenberg, Schwadron, and Feinstein, sanction the use of a civil will either based upon the <i>gemirat da’at</i> of the testator, “commanding because of death,” <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>, or <i>minhag</i>. Regardless of the grounds for validating a secular will, it may be effective in transferring assets to a non-Torah heir only if there is a partial distribution to a Torah heir.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 80.</i>
On the other hand, some <i>Poskim</i> validate a secular will based upon “<i>mitzva le-kayeim divrei ha-met</i>” or <i>kibbud av</i>. Here again, to avoid the <i>issur</i> of “<i>avurei ahsanta</i>,” such recognition may require that the Torah heir receive a partial distribution of the estate. Others, as we have shown, oppose both approaches.
Deciding between competing arguments regarding the propriety of a civil will is the sole prerogative of the <i>Posek</i> and <i>beit din</i>. The relative strength and plausibility of each argument will continue to be scrutinized within the framework of future <i>pesakim</i> and <i>piskei din</i>.
<b>Conclusion</b>
Since the halakhic propriety of a civil testamentary disposition is subject to debate, it behooves our community to seriously consider that a Torah heir may decide (based upon either his own halakhic convictions, desire for material aggrandizement, hatred of his siblings who are non-Torah heirs, or at the behest of his spouse’s inveighing) to challenge in <i>beit din</i> his father’s civil will that distributes portions of the estate to his siblings who are non-Torah heirs. Such claims have been advanced in <i>battei din</i> in the past and and continue to be submitted to this very day to <i>battei din</i>. One should never assume that fighting regarding <i>yerusha</i> would happen only in somebody else’s family. Since there is no halakhic consensus to affirm a civil will, there is a distinct possibility that the overwhelming majority of the assets will be redistributed and awarded to a Torah heir(s) by a <i>beit din</i>. Optimally, our community ought to seek halakhic and legal counsel regarding halakhic estate-planning techniques that will avoid the potential challenges to the halakhic efficacy of a civil will.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 14.</i>
Should a civil will be contested, and settlement negotiations and mediation fail, it is advisable that a Torah heir as well as a non-Torah heir approach a rabbinic authority who has expertise in Even ha-Ezer and Hoshen Mishpat, and preferably experience in <i>dayanut</i>, for counsel on how to handle this matter.

Chapter 3; Harnessing the Authority of Beit Din to Deal with Cases of Domestic Violence and Child Abuse

<b>Harnessing the Authority of <i>Beit Din</i> to Deal with Cases of Domestic Violence and Child Abuse</b><br>The purpose of our presentation is to educate victims of spousal and child abuse, and the Jewish community in general, about the type of relief that can be provided by a <i>beit din</i>, which has the authority to resolve certain monetary issues relating to such conduct. We hope in this presentation to both demonstrate the nature of these claims and their halakhic underpinnings, so that our <i>battei din</i> will be open to accept such claims and also to serve as an introductory guide to <i>dayanim</i> and <i>to’anim</i> (rabbinical advocates) to deal with such claims.
<b>1.</b>
The first part of our presentation focuses on the right of a Jewish wife to advance various monetary claims against her abusive Jewish husband. Such a right exists equally for a husband who is a victim of abuse,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In fact, our discussion regarding <i>kevod ha-beriyyot</i> and filing for monetary awards for z<i>sa’ar</i> and <i>boshet</i> applies equally in a case of an abusive wife.</i> however, our discussion focuses on the more frequent situation of the abusive husband.
In a hypothetical scenario, a husband and wife are at home with their Jewish maid and suddenly, without any incitement, the husband hits his wife on her hips and back in front of the maid. The husband denies the allegations and argues that the battery was self-inflicted. In reply, the wife counters by arguing that it would have been impossible for her to produce self-inflicted wounds on her back. Moreover, the maid corroborates the wife’s version of the events. Subsequently, the wife files a police report and a restraining order is issued against her husband. Based upon professional findings, it is clear that the husband is a bipolar personality and is violent.
In fact, the wife’s friends are aware of the husband’s abusive relationship with his wife. Fearful for her life, she abandons the marital home and seeks <i>mezonot</i>, i.e., spousal support, compensation for lodging expenses, and monetary damages for physical and emotional abuse. The couple decides to have their issues resolved in <i>beit din</i>. During the proceedings, health care professionals attest to the husband’s proclivity to physical and emotional abuse.
<i>Kevod ha-beriyyot</i> (the dignity of human beings) ought to be one of the governing halakhic norms in our social relations.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berakhot</i> 19b; <i>Shabbat</i> 94b; <i>Bava Kama</i> 79b; <i>Menahot</i> 37b–38a; Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Berakhot</i> 6b; <i>Kilayim</i> 32a. For many of these sources in our presentation, see Eliav Shochetman, “Violence against Women as Grounds for Divorce” (Hebrew), ed. Aviad Hacohen, <i>Volume in Memory of Menachem Elon</i> (forthcoming).</i> Thus, a husband has a duty to respect his wife as a member of the human race. Additionally, as a husband it is incumbent upon him to respect her more than he respects himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 59b; <i>Bava Metzia</i> 59a; <i>Yevamot</i> 62b; <i>Nedarim</i> 51a; <i>Hullin</i> 84b; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 228:3.</i> Whereas various halakhic guidelines have been established relating to the duty of <i>kevod ha-beriyyot</i>, there is a paucity of sources practically detailing how to demonstrate in positive terms one’s respect for one’s wife. Clearly, spousal respect requires intimate and individualistic answers that emerge from the singularity of persons and their relationships to each other, as well as their fused existence. It seems that Halakha has left it up to the husband to determine how to translate into practical terms respect for his spouse.
On the other hand, there are specific acts of dishonor, of demeaning a wife’s persona, such as threatening to assault her or actual battery, which entail a diminution of her honor as a person.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam of Rothenburg</i>, Cremona Edition, 291; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhasot la-Ramban</i>, 102; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 4:113; <i>Teshuvot Binyamin Ze’ev</i>, 88; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 74; <i>Sefer ha-Aguda</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 172; <i>Teshuvot Hayyim ve-Shalom</i> 2:36; <i>Teshuvot Perah Mateh Aharon</i> 1:60.<br>Cf. numerous <i>Poskim</i> who sanction wife-beating in order to prevent the commission of a transgression (<i>le-afrushei me-issura</i>), should a wife be delinquent in fulfilling her marital duties or needlessly curses her husband. See <i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 218; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 888;<i>Mishneh Torah, Hilkhot Ishut</i> 21:10;<i>Rema, SA EH</i> 154:3. Whether such conduct is permissible today is beyond the scope of our presentation. Suffice it to say that there are authorities who prohibit assaulting a wife in these circumstances.</i> Consequently, just as <i>habbala</i> (battery) involves transgressing a negative Torah commandment,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Devarim</i> 25:3; <i>Rambam</i>, <i>Sefer ha-Mitzvot</i>, <i>mitzvat lo ta’aseh</i> 300; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:1.</i> similarly, spousal battery is a violation of <i>habbala</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:3, <i>Rema</i>, ad locum. Moreover, the batterer is invalid to be a witness in a <i>beit din</i> proceeding. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 34:4; <i>Teshuvot Mahari Weil</i>, 28 and 87; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i>, 1:291; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i>, vol. 2, <i>EH</i>, 43.</i> and is subject to criminal sanctions.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 154; <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:20.</i> In short, whereas Halakha has given latitude for a husband to determine how to translate his duty of spousal respect into practical behavior, nonetheless, in situations of violating her persona by means of assault, Halakha sets out guidelines for how to address such behavior.
The seriousness of the <i>issur</i> of battery expresses itself in a husband’s liability for injuring his wife while engaging in <i>onah</i> (conjugal relations).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 63 (end); <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 421:12.</i>
The duty of a husband to engage in <i>onah</i> is <i>mi-dioraita</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shemot</i> 21:10; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 69; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 69:6.</i> Lest one argue that engagement in a <i>mitzva</i> exempts one from responsibility from injury caused during its performance, Halakha states otherwise.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Bava Kama</i> 6:13; <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 340, <i>HM</i> 418:12; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i>, 207; <i>Teshuvot Be’er Sarim</i>, 1:10. For exceptions to the rule, see <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hovel u-Mazik</i> 6:8; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 359:4.</i> Hence, Hazon Ish contends that engagement in the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>onah</i> does not serve as a defense.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 11:21.</i> Even if the husband unintentionally injured his wife due to losing self-control, i.e., <i>ones</i>, nevertheless, regarding any assault against another person, <i>adam mu’ad le-olam</i>, a person is always deemed forewarned.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 378:1; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, supra n. 11. Cf. <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 27a, s.v. “<i>u-Shemuel amar</i>”; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 42a, s.v. “<i>amar Shemuel</i>.”<br>Should a husband unintentionally abstain from conjugal relations and his spouse becomes emotionally distressed regarding the situation, he violates Halakha. See <i>Teshuvot Maharam Alsheich</i> 40; <i>PDR</i> 18:1, 20 (R. Elyashiv); File no. 860977-1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, May 20, 2013. Cf. <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 3:131 in the name of <i>Rambam</i>.</i>
Consequently, it is no surprise that numerous <i>Poskim</i> argue that it is the husband’s responsibility to foresee the possibility of potential injury and therefore, if injury nevertheless transpired, he is negligent.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 2:10.</i> Similarly, a husband who argues that he lost self-control and therefore assaulted his wife will also be held responsible for his behavior. As Shulhan Aruch, Sma, and R. Shlomo Luria note,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 421:12; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 421:20; <i>Yam Shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 3:21.</i> if a husband is liable for any injury caused to his spouse during <i>onah</i>, <i>a fortiori</i>, should he force her to have conjugal relations against her will, he has committed <i>“habbala”</i> and he is therefore liable in <i>nezikin</i> damages.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 19:2; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Yaziv</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:3. Even if the injury was unintentional, he is liable for <i>nezek</i> and <i>tza’ar</i>. See <i>Menahot</i> 49a; Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Gittin</i> 5:5; <i>Kesef Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ma’aholot Asurot</i> 13:28; <i>Teshuvot Hatan Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 24; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 83:1.<br>Though one is exempt from liability for <i>boshet</i> if one unintentionally rapes one’s wife (see <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 421; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 421:12, <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 421:20), nonetheless meting out <i>boshet</i> damages as a punitive measure (<i>migdar milta</i>), is permissible. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:38.<br>For the prohibition against spousal rape, see <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot De’ot</i> 5:4, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 14:8, 15:17, 21:12; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 25, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 240:3, <i>EH</i> 25:2; <i>Magen Avraham</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 240:7; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:4; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Yatziv</i>, <i>EH</i> 77.<br>If a wife is a <i>moredet</i> (i.e., rebellious), who refuses to engage in conjugal relations, it is subject to debate whether coercion is permissible. See <i>Mordekai</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 530; <i>Atzei Arazim</i>, <i>EH</i> 25:1; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 5:34 in the name of <i>Rabbeinu Tam</i>; <i>Tosafot Rid</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 64a; <i>Mabit</i>, <i>Kiryat Sefer</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 14.</i> A husband must control his desires and neither injure his wife nor rape her under any circumstances. Moreover, neither the establishment of marriage nor a mutual agreement between spouses to sanction a husband’s assault of his wife even for her own personal enjoyment may serve as grounds for a husband’s exemption from liability for any ensuing damage.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Revid ha-Zahav</i> 42:3.</i> Any agreement between two individuals to be a subject of battery is prohibited.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Kama</i> 93a; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 68:10; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 421:12. Nonetheless, though there exists a prohibition to agree to be a victim of battery, should battery occur with the consent of the victim, the batterer will be exempt from liability. See <i>Bava Kama</i>, op. cit.; <i>Tosafot Ketuvot</i> 56b, s.v. <i>harei</i> in the name of R. Elhanan,</i> <i>A fortiori</i>, he should not force himself upon his wife.
Given that a husband is responsible for the injury he causes his wife, how would a <i>beit din</i> assess the damages? At first glance, there are seemingly no grounds for awarding monetary damages to a victim of abuse. As we know, there are five types of payment that are to be made in case of assault: permanent injury (<i>nezek</i>), physiological pain (<i>tza’ar</i>), medical expenses (<i>rippui</i>), loss of earnings (<i>shevet</i>), and shame (<i>boshet</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:1; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:3.</i> Following in the footsteps of Rambam,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sanhedrin</i> 5:10.</i> Shulhan Arukh rules that today we can only advance a claim for medical expenses and loss of economic earnings.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:2.</i> However, Rema disagrees and argues that the practice is that even such types of payments cannot be collected.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:2. Cf. <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:7.</i> In short, all five types of damages are not collectible today in a <i>beit din</i>. In the absence of the five payments, pursuant to numerous <i>teshuvot</i> of Geonim, Shulhan Arukh and Rema rule that the parties themselves or a third party such as a <i>beit din</i> ought to attempt to mediate the matter, with the goal of appeasing the victim by offering appropriate compensation for the injury inflicted upon him.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:11; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:5; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:2, 420:38.</i> Should mediation fail, according to Rambam, if a husband assaults his wife, it is incumbent upon <i>beit din</i> to take a portion of the husband’s assets and purchase real estate (<i>karka</i>) and transfer this asset to his wife. All profits from the acquisition accrue to his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hovel u-Mazik</i> 4:17; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:1. Others argue, pursuant to <i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 9:14, that the wife retains title; however, the profits (<i>peirot</i>) belong to the husband. See <i>Ra’avad</i>, ad locum; <i>Semag</i>, positive commandment no. 70; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 65b; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 66a.</i>
Should the couple be unable to settle the matter between themselves, the husband and wife may submit to a <i>beit din</i> to address the wife’s monetary claims relating to spousal abuse. The couple would sign an arbitration agreement (<i>shtar borerut</i>) accompanied by executing a <i>kinyan</i> (i.e., a symbolic act of undertaking this duty), which empowers the panel to halakhically<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 12:7; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 12:18.</i> and legally<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Assuming the decision complies with the rules of civil arbitration procedure, it would be legally enforceable in a competent civil jurisdiction in the United States; see Uniform Arbitration Act, sec. 1.</i> issue a decision. Optimally, the <i>shtar</i> should specifically authorize the panel to resolve claims relating to personal injury, and thus allow the <i>beit din</i> to issue an award of any of the aforementioned payments, should the circumstances dictate such relief. The significance of this arrangement is that although, as we pointed out, normative Halakha precludes a panel from addressing such matters, nevertheless, should the parties obligate themselves to accept a <i>beit din</i>’s decision regarding this matter, such a <i>shtar</i> is valid. In other words, the authority to issue a decision is grounded in the parties’ willingness to fulfill their respective obligations, rather than the judicial authority of a <i>beit din</i> to render a decision.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 114a; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Shekhenim</i> 12:7; <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 334:43; <i>Imre Bina</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; R. Zalman N. Goldberg, “In the Matter of Civil Courts,” (Hebrew), <i>Yeshurun</i> 11 702–703 (2001); Ya’akov Eliazrov, “A Claim for Damages for Bodily Torts,” (Hebrew), 14 <i>Shurat ha-Din</i> 387, 388 (5768).<br>Alternatively, such acceptance is no different than the imparting of validity to litigants’ decision to accept a halakhically invalid individual as an arbiter such as a relative. See <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:13; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yehuda HM</i> 1. For recent applications of this view, see File no. 9326351, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, August 11, 2007 (R. Eliazrov’s opinion); File no. 9326351 (Appeal Decision), Supreme Beit Din, August 25, 2008 (R. Sherman’s opinion); Cf. <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:1, 2:1, who casts doubt upon the validity of such a <i>shtar</i> with regard to punitive damages. However, regarding non-punitive damages such as <i>nezek</i>, <i>rippui</i>, and <i>shevet</i>, Sha’ar Mishpat will validate such a provision in a <i>shtar</i>.</i>
However, even in the absence of a provision in the <i>shtar</i> that allows the panel to render a decision on matters relating to personal injury, a panel may attempt to appease the victim by offering him appropriate compensation for the injury the batterer caused.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Otzar ha-Geonim,</i> ed. B. Lewin, <i>Ketuvot</i>, <i>Teshuvot</i>, 477; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ge’onim</i>, <i>Sha’arei Tzedek</i>, vol. 4, <i>sha’ar</i> 1, 19, in the name of R. Sherira Gaon; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:2–3; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:11; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:5, 420:38, <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:2; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i>, A. Siev ed., 88 (379–380); <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i>, 1:93; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i>, 4:1291; <i>PDR</i> 5:322; File no. 9326-35-1, Supremel Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Almoni</i>, August 25, 2008; File no. 72099, Eretz Hemda-Gazit Beit Din, November 1, 2012.<br>Alternatively, given that the parties empower the <i>beit din</i> to resolve their matters in accordance with <i>peshara</i>, the panel may resolve matters dealing with the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>kenasot</i>. See <i>Mabit</i>, op. cit.; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 12:2; <i>Beit Yehuda</i>, supra n. 26 which is cited authoritatively by <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:3; <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i>, 2:32; Yoezer Ariel, <i>Dinei Borerut</i>, 187; File no. 70029, Eretz Hemdah-Gazit Beit Din, October 31, 2011.</i>
In addition, at the very least, the signing of the <i>shtar borerut</i> will legally empower a <i>beit din</i> to address this <i>nezikin</i> (tort) claim within the context of a divorce proceeding, which addresses all the end-of-marriage issues, or a non-divorce proceeding, which is limited to resolving this claim. However, given that Halakha does not authorize <i>dayanim</i> in contemporary times to award any of the five <i>nezikin</i> payments, on what grounds can a panel issue any potential award? Moreover, what type of <i>nezikin</i> awards can be rendered by a <i>beit din</i> today? Prior to the mid-fourth century CE, arbiters who had received <i>semikha</i> (rabbinic ordination) were authorized to resolve monetary matters, including the assessment of the five aforementioned payments as a form of a compensation for both injurious and non-injurious physical abuse. After the lapse of the ordination process in the fourth century CE, non-ordained arbiters lack authorization to impose these five payments.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">See supra nn. 18–20.</i>
Nevertheless, <i>dayanim</i> today<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">And, for that matter, such empowerment extends to all <i>dayanim</i> who functioned in the earlier periods of Jewish history. See <i>Yevamot</i> 90b; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 46a.</i> are empowered to mete out monetary damages based upon <i>beit din makkin ve-oneshin she-lo min ha-din</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 28.</i> (a court may render punishment not prescribed by the Torah), <i>le-migdar milta</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 90a.</i> (for protective measures) and <i>ha-sha’a tzerikha le-kakh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 28.</i> (the time requires it). Three different views emerge from the works of <i>Aharonim</i> regarding the circumstances under which a <i>dayan</i> can exercise such authority:<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">E. Quint and N. Hecht, <i>Jewish Jurisprudence: Its Sources and Modern Applications</i> (Chur, Switzerland: 1980), 174–175.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Falk,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:2.</i> in his commentary on Karo, attempts to delineate express guidelines. He states that if all the people are not dissolute as to certain matters, an individual may not be punished under this authority unless he is a habitual wrongdoer … Shakh<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:2.</i> views this analysis as an appropriate restatement of the principles as derived from the Talmud and as codified by the Tur. Falk’s approach is cited with approval by … Netivot,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, 2:1.</i> and Beer Hagola<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Be’er ha-Gola</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 2.</i> …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Sha’ar Ephraim<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Sha’ar Ephraim</i>, 72.</i> … held that only if many people in the community are engaging in this type of conduct may an individual be punished.</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">This opinion … is in conflict with the holding of Falk and Maharam.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam me-Lublin</i>, 138.</i> For Falk holds that even where the majority of the people are not dissolute, if the individual is dissolute he may be punished by the court invoking its … power. And Maharam holds that even if the community is not dissolute or the individual is not dissolute, if a court feels that failure to punish this person may cause other people to feel that they might act in a similar fashion with impunity, the court may impose … sanctions.</span>
In short, pursuant to the views of R. Falk, Shakh, Netivot ha-Mishpat, Be’er ha-Gola, and Maharam, if the individual is a habitual wrongdoer with regard to a certain practice or has frequently committed a transgression in public,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i>, 1:136. Following in the Sma and Maharam’s footsteps (see supra nn. 34 and 39), <i>Shevut Ya’akov</i> argues that even if he is not licentious and depraved, but committed an offense that the community may emulate, he ought to be punished.</i> an emergency situation exists in which we cannot allow the individual to continue acting improperly without imposing punishment. In such circumstances, a <i>beit din</i> may mete out punishment as a deterrent, so as to forestall the danger that others will emulate the transgressor’s conduct if it goes unpunished. The imposition of such punitive damages may be handed down by lay arbiters (<i>beit din shel hedyotot</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, 1:161; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i>, 3:385, 393; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i>, 265; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ran</i> 41; <i>Teshuvot Rashbash</i>, 211; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:1; <i>Levush</i>, <i>Ir Shushan</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; <i>Sma</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:9; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, 2:5; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:2; <i>Perisha</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 2. For additional sources, see this writer’s <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, 140–142.<br>Cf. others who require that the authority must be the greatest scholar of the generation. See <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 9:5; <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; <i>Yam Shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 9:7.</i>
Given that a contemporary <i>beit din</i> is empowered to impose such measures, it is our opinion that spousal physical abuse ought to be compensated in situations of repeated abuse, in order that others do not emulate the batterer’s ways.
Moreover, feelings of embarrassment and shame, which are engendered by acts of spousal abuse, may serve as grounds for a monetary award. Halakha recognizes compensation for <i>nezek</i> (bodily injury), <i>tza’ar</i> (emotional stress) which traumatizes the victim in avoiding the engagement in any future conjugal relations, and <i>boshet</i> (shame) engendered by bodily injury,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Regarding the act of rape as an example of <i>hezek</i> despite the absence of a physical act of injury, see supra n. 15. Given that rape engenders emotional stress that traumatizes the victim into avoiding any future sexual intercourse (s<i>ee Ha’amek Davar Bereshit</i> 34:2, <i>Devarim</i> 22:24), there are grounds to sue for <i>tza’ar</i>.<br>Concerning <i>boshet</i>, see Mishnah, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:1; <i>Bava Kama</i> 91a, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:3. Given that <i>habbala</i> causes <i>boshet</i>, therefore one can sue for such behavior. See <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 15 in the name of R. Sherira Gaon; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 101:9. See supra n. 15 for the grounds of a <i>beit din</i>’s authority to impose <i>boshet</i> payments in a situation in which husband unintentionally rapes his wife.</i> where the payment varies from victim to victim, depending upon his social status.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:24.</i> A <i>beit din</i> should factor into the calculation the social status of the person who was humiliated, as well as the circumstances and the intensity of the humiliation.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 425:25.</i> For example, the assessment should take into account whether the bodily injury is in an exposed area and therefore the victim experiences humiliation after the time of injury, and whether the perpetrator continues to humiliate the victim regarding the battery (without ensuing injury).<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:6; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i>, 101:2.</i>
Today, though <i>min ha-din</i> – pursuant to black-letter law – <i>dayanim</i> are not authorized to assess <i>boshet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying nn. 18–20.</i> nonetheless, a contemporary <i>beit din</i> is empowered to impose such measures, <i>le-migdar milta</i>.
