Hence, spousal physical abuse ought to be compensated in situations of repeated abuse, lest others emulate the batterer’s conduct.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying nn. 28–40.</i>
Such <i>le-migdar milta</i> awards are not unusual and in the past have been issued in cases of character defamation and in situations of broken engagements.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">See infra n. 53.</i> In 1965, invoking their power of <i>le-migdar milta</i>, the members of the Supreme Beit Din in Yerushalayim, Rabbis Abudi, Elyashiv, and Goldschmidt marshaled numerous <i>teshuvot</i> to support their position that damages for <i>boshet</i> can be awarded in the case of a broken engagement.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 5:322, 327.</i> Pursuant to the standards outlined above, the assessed damages were based upon the discretion of the <i>dayanim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Zera Emet</i>, <i>YD</i>, 102; <i>Teshuvot Rav Pe’alim</i>, 2, <i>EH</i>, 3; <i>PDR</i> 3:151, 5:322, 328.</i>
Similarly, a claim for <i>tza’ar</i> (emotional stress), even feelings of emotional pain that transpire during the healing process, will be awarded by a <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:17. Cf. <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 6:9.</i> Halakha awards compensation for <i>tza’ar</i> provided that the pain is associated with a blow.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 41.</i> Pursuant to Shulhan Arukh, regardless of whether we are dealing with pain associated with an injury or not, the award is based upon an assessment of how much money one would expend in order to prevent undergoing such <i>tza’ar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:16, <i>Rema</i>, ad locum. Cf. <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hovel u-Mazik</i> 2:6, 9.</i> In the absence of physical contact, <i>le-migdar milta</i> awards for <i>tza’ar</i> may be rendered. In fact, throughout different periods of Jewish history dating back to medieval times and to the present, arbiters have meted out compensatory awards based upon <i>boshet</i> and <i>tza’ar</i> claims.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i>, 101:1, 8, 9; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhasot la-Ramban</i>, 240; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, 3:204; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i>, 3:480; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 207:24, 333:49; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>YD</i>, 146; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i>, 134, <i>HM</i>, 181; <i>Teshuvot Avodat ha-Gershuni</i>, 74; <i>Zera Emet</i>, supra n. 50; <i>Rav Pe’alim</i>, supra n. 50; <i>PDR</i>, supra n. 49.</i>
On the other hand, in the absence of a physical contact, seemingly a <i>beit din</i> cannot hold an offender responsible for a person who feels emotionally abused and demands relief, i.e., <i>boshet devarim</i>. According to the strict law, responsibility for <i>boshet</i> requires that the victim has been physically contacted by the batterer.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 41.</i> Nonetheless, a <i>beit din</i> today is empowered, <i>le-migdar milta</i>, to apply the identical standards employed to assess shame engendered by physical violence to situations of <i>boshet devarim</i>, provided that we are dealing with frequent instances of abuse and want to deter others from emulating a batterer’s behavior.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420: 38–39.</i>
Finally, punitive damages, which may compensate above and beyond any damage incurred, are meant to provide an incentive against repeating the behavior that caused the victim’s injury.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying nn. 28–41.</i> As such, punitive damages differ from compensatory damages, which focus upon “making the victim whole.” Here again, <i>dayanim</i> have meted out punitive damages in cases of spousal abuse.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Otzar ha-Geonim</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i>, <i>Teshuvot</i>, 477; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i>, 62.</i>
Regardless of whether one files a claim for emotional distress due to physical abuse or emotional abuse, marital relations are complex, emotive, and subjective, and therefore difficult to subject to objective scrutiny. Marriages are molded by mutual understandings and interchanges as well as mutual expectations that can evoke different judgments as to whether a particular type of conduct should be labeled as emotional abuse. Nevertheless, given that in the past Halakha has awarded recovery for suits dealing with broken engagements and defamation of character, we see no reason to exempt spousal relations from the ambit of halakhic scrutiny and potential monetary award. Determining what conduct is abusive is a very difficult inquiry in any context, yet this is a <i>beit din</i>’s mandate.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 41, 111–180. For a secular legal perspective, see Ira Ellman &amp; Stephen Sugarman, “Spousal Emotional Abuse as a Tort?” 55 <i>Maryland Law Review</i> 1268 (1996).</i>
Alternatively, in the absence of conditions which may be characterized as <i>le-migdar milta</i> or if one subscribes to the posture that such power may be invoked only by the <i>gadol hador</i> (the greatest scholar of the generation),<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 41.</i> there are three other avenues which would allow for the submission of such claims. Firstly, generally speaking, there is a requirement to maintain a <i>beit din</i> comprised of <i>mumhim</i> (<i>dayanim</i> who received ordination handed down from Moshe Rabbeinu). Such <i>dayanim</i> are empowered to award <i>kenasot</i> (penalties), including but not limited to matters of <i>nezikin</i>. In contemporary times, in the absence of <i>mumhim</i>, the power of <i>beit din</i> stems in part from the parties’ willingness to accept their authority, and the awarding of <i>kenasot</i> is therefore permissible.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shita Mekubezet</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 89b, s.v<i>.</i> “<i>ve-gedolei ha-mehabrim</i>”; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i> 3:1; <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i> 1:1.</i> In effect, through the acceptance of their authority via the execution of a <i>kinyan</i>, the parties agree to obligate themselves to remit such monies should an award be rendered. This obligation is effective even though the parties do not explicitly state in the <i>shtar borerut</i> (the arbitration agreement) that the <i>dayanim</i> may issue a decision regarding a <i>nezikin</i> claim that may entail a <i>kenas</i>.
Secondly, since the parties empower the <i>beit din</i> to resolve matters in accordance with <i>peshara</i> (court-mediated settlement), the panel may resolve matters dealing with the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>kenasot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 12:2; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:93; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yehuda HM</i> 1, cited authoritatively by <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:3; <i>Mishpetekha le-Ya’akov</i> 2:32; Yoezer Ariel, <i>Dinei Borerut</i> 187; File no. 70029/1, Eretz Hemdah-Gazit Beit Din, October 31, 2011.</i>
Finally, usually the couple signs a <i>shtar borerut</i> that authorizes the <i>beit din</i> halakhically and legally to issue a ruling. The <i>shtar</i> should specifically authorize the panel to resolve claims relating to various types of personal injury, namely, physical injury, pain, the incurring of medical expenses, loss of work time, experiencing shame, as well as indirect injuries. Although contemporary arbiters are generally precluded from addressing these <i>nezikin</i> claims, should the parties obligate themselves to accept a <i>beit din</i>’s decision regarding these claims, such a <i>shtar</i> is valid. In other words, the authority to issue a <i>psak din</i> is grounded in the couple’s willingness to fulfill their respective obligations, as in the case of any contractual agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Imrei Bina</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; Z. N. Goldberg, 11 <i>Yeshurun</i> 602–3 (2002).</i> Alternatively, such acceptance is no different than the imparting of validity to the litigants’ decision to accept a halakhically invalid witness (such as a relative) as an arbiter.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Aruk ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:13; <i>Beit Yehuda</i>, supra n. 62. For recent applications of this view, see File no. 9326351, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, 27 Heshvan 5768 (R. Eliezrov’s opinion); File no. 9326351, Supreme Beit Din, 24 Av 5768 (R. Sherman’s opinion).<br>Though <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:1, 2:1 casts doubt upon the validity of such a <i>shtar</i> with regard to awarding punitive damages, however, regarding awarding compensatory damages, <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i> will validate such a provision in a <i>shtar</i>.</i> Whereas invoking the power of <i>le-migdar milta</i> empowers a <i>beit din</i> to mete out punitive damages, these three aforementioned approaches permit a <i>beit din</i> to award compensatory damages. Compensatory damages represent the financial equivalent of the loss or harm suffered by the victim, to restore the injured victim to the position he was in prior to the <i>nezek</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:38; <i>Rema</i>, ad locum.</i>
To award compensatory or punitive damages, the victim of abuse must demonstrate that the act(s) actually transpired. In the absence of a criminal conviction by a court,<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">The assumption is that we can verify that the criminal judge did not accept bribes. Given that Halakha will refrain from accepting a legal document prepared by a civil judge who accepts bribes, <i>a fortiori</i>, we would refrain from accepting a criminal verdict issued by such a judge. Though <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA HM</i> 68:1, argues that we accept their documents unless we discover that the judge accepted a bribe, numerous authorities contend that we must perform our due diligence in ascertaining the judge’s credibility. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 68:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharlbah</i>, 127; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i>, 1: 541; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 350.<br>Should the judge’s credibility be confirmed, a <i>beit din</i> may refrain from investigating whether in fact the alleged abuse actually transpired. However, should the judge’s track record evince a different conclusion, it would be incumbent upon <i>beit din</i> to independently assess the veracity of the allegation of abuse.<br>Others argue either based upon <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> (the law of the kingship is law) or the assumption that a professional will not threaten his own livelihood, we would accept the verdict handed down by a judge without any further inquiry. See <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Hullin</i> 97a; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 324; <i>Tumim</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 114:5, <i>HM</i> 68:2; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 155:3; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 10; <i>Teshuvot Hakham Tzvi</i> 39; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 43; <i>Teshuvot Ein Yitzhak</i>, <i>OH</i> 17; <i>Teshuvot Be’er Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 5 (5).</i> according to most <i>Poskim</i> a victim’s allegation that the spousal abuse or rape transpired is sufficient to establish a spouse’s misconduct as grounds to obligate a husband to give a <i>get</i> provided that the husband refrains from challenging the veracity of this allegation.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">See the vast array of <i>Poskim</i>, <i>Rishonim</i>, and <i>Aharonim</i> cited in <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 4, <i>EH</i> 11 and <i>PDR</i> 4:342. See infra text accompanying n. 78. In order to comply with <i>Ritva</i> who disagrees, a <i>beit din</i> contends that the wife must swear to this occurrence. See File no. 284948/2, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, August 18, 2013.</i> Admission of guilt by the husband serves as adequate proof in order to grant an award.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Terumot</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 21, <i>helek</i> 2, 3, cited by <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 34:36; <i>PDR</i> 15; 119, 122; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shemuel</i> (Werner), 23; File no. 032313884-21-1, archived by <i>ha-Din ve-Hadayan</i>, 8, p. 5. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Mahane Hayyim</i> 2, <i>EH</i> 45; <i>Teshuvot Mishpat Tzedek</i> 1:59.<br>For admissibility of a wife’s testimony regarding her husband as an adulterer, see <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:1.</i> Moreover, even if the husband admits the occurrence, but claims that his wife provoked the assault, we do not necessarily believe the husband’s allegation.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:3.</i> For the purpose of awarding damages, in the absence of a batterer’s admission, optimally there ought to be two male witnesses who can attest to the occurrence of the event.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Devarim</i> 19:15; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 408; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 408:1.</i> In the absence of two male witnesses, ineligible witnesses such as women may testify concerning incidents of infrequent assaults or insults,<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam Mintz</i>, 6; <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 35; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:14; <i>Tumim</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:9; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>HM</i> 58, cited by <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:9; <i>PDR</i> 3:235, 244–245; <i>Teshuvot Mishneh Halakhot</i>, 5: 269; File no. 4564-24-1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, 8 Shevat 5766. Cf. <i>Yam Shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 1:41; <i>PDR</i> 20:126, 21:240. However, according to <i>Yam Shel Shlomo</i>, op. cit<i>.</i>, should their testimony be corroborated by circumstantial evidence, their testimony will be admissible.<br>In Sephardic countries, ineligible witnesses would be unable to testify in <i>nezikin</i> (tort) cases. See <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:14; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 408:1; <i>Erech Lehem</i>, <i>HM</i> 35; <i>Nehfa ba-Kessef</i>, 2, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 12; <i>Teshuvot Hikekei Lev</i>, <i>YD</i> 47.<br>Rema and others distinguish between <i>nezikin</i> matters that regularly occur and those that transpire occasionally. In the latter situation, women’s testimony is admissible. See <i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i>, infra n. 74; <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, op. cit. and <i>Rema</i>, op. cit.; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:30; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 35, <i>Hiddushin</i> 19. Cf. <i>Noda be-Yehuda</i>, op. cit., who contends that such testimony is accepted even in frequent occurrences, provided that the incident suddenly happened and ended. <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 408:2 agrees with Noda be-Yehuda assuming that the <i>beit din</i> determines that the injury actually transpired.</i> and the testimony of the wife may be reliable if the husband’s conduct toward his wife is known generally to be violent or if he exhibited intimidating and demeaning behavior toward his wife during a <i>beit din</i> proceeding.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhasot le-Ramban</i> 198; <i>Beit Yosef</i> (in the name of <i>Ramban</i>), <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 74; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, 5, <i>hashmatot</i> 203; <i>PDR</i> 11:327, 15:119, File no. 289799-1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, January 2, 2013.<br>Alternatively, if we know the assault transpired and the <i>beit din</i> wants to determine who the batterer was, then invalid witnesses will suffice. However, should we be unaware that the conduct actually occurred, even the aforementioned <i>Poskim</i>, supra n. 71, would not find such testimony admissible. See <i>Yam shel Shlomo</i>, supra n. 71; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:11 in the name of <i>Knesset Yehzekel</i> 83.</i> Consequently, in situations in which only an invalid witness was present during the time of the assault,<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, supra n. 71; R. Zalman N. Goldberg, <i>Mishpat Arukh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:14, nn. 20 and 28.</i> such testimony is admissible even if it is contradicted by the alleged batterer and may serve as grounds for a <i>nezikin</i> award.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Even though women are invalid witnesses (see <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:14), nevertheless, should the <i>dayan</i> feel that her words are trustworthy, he may rely upon them. See <i>Ketuvot</i> 85a; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i>, 1:94; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, supra n. 71.<br>In other words, a distinction may be drawn between <i>edut</i> (testimony) and <i>ne’emanut</i> (presumption of credibility). See <i>Urim</i>, <i>HM</i> 36:11; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 36:10; R. Akiva Eiger, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 228:3; <i>Minhat Hinukh</i>, mitzva 75; <i>Sha’arei Yosher</i> 2, <i>sha’ar</i> 6, <i>perek</i> 6. A few <i>Poskim</i> have argued that her acceptability is as an individual who is ineligible to testify (rather than <i>pasul</i>, invalid). See <i>Turei Evain</i>, <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 22a; <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 6, <i>EH</i> 6; <i>Reshimat Shiurim</i> (of R. Y.B. Soloveitchik), <i>Shevuot ve-Nedarim</i>, 1–2, <i>Sukah</i> 108. (Whether one validates her words as testimony or trustiworthiness has halakhic ramifications that are beyond the scope of this presentation.) Alternatively, a woman’s testimony, though inadmissible because <i>of gezerat hakatuv</i>, a scriptual decree, nevertheless, a woman’s words are trustworthy. See <i>Tosafot Zevahim</i> 103a, s.v. “<i>ein le ela</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhosot le-Ramban</i> 128.<br>Nevertheless, many disagree and argue that the truth can only be ascertained on the basis of valid testimony of two adult Jewish males, and hence, the testimony of women would be invalid. See <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 15:4 and <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 15:5, 408:1. But, cf. <i>Noda be-Yehuda</i>, supra n. 71, in the name of <i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i> who argues that according to the <i>din</i>, black-letter law, in the absence of the presence of men, the testimony of two women is admissible regarding matters of <i>nezikin</i>.<br>However, during the time of Rabbeinu Tam, halakhic legislation was introduced that provided that in situations of battery where males are absent, the testimony of one woman would be accepted as trustworthy regarding the veracity of the event. See <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 6:117; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 179; <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, supra n. 71; <i>Rema</i>, supra n. 69; <i>Sma</i>, supra n. 71; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:28; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:366; <i>PDR</i> 20:126, 133 (in the name of R. Z. N. Goldberg). Some contend that the basis of this legislation is found in accepting the veracity of a midwife’s statement regarding <i>yuhasin</i>, familial lineage. See <i>Kiddushin</i> 73b; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Mintz</i> 93; <i>Teshuvot Mahari Mintz</i> 6; <i>Kiddushin</i> 64; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, op. cit.<br>Cf. others who argue that such testimony is acceptable only if the husband does not challenge its veracity. See <i>Yam Shel Shlomo</i>, supra n. 71; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:11 in the name of <i>Knesset Yehezkel</i>; <i>PDR</i> 20:126,134–135; 21:240 (=A. Sherman, 5 <i>Divrei Mishpat</i> 99); <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 1:113.<br>Others argue that in accordance with the legislation, invalid witnesses, such as minors, women, or relatives, are trusted regarding infrequent occurrences. See <i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i>, op. cit.; <i>Sma</i>, op. cit.; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> ibid. Others contend that such testimony is valid even if it is a frequent occurrence. See <i>Noda be-Yehuda</i>, supra n. 71, in the name of <i>Maharik</i>.<br>Some contend in pursuance with the legislation that their trustworthiness is accepted only if an act suddenly happened and finished. See <i>Noda be-Yehuda</i>, supra n. 71.<br>However, regarding instances of <i>davar she-be’erva</i>, matters of intimacy such as marriage and divorce, such evidence is inadmissible by dint of the legislation. See <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, 4, <i>Tur</i> 1, 15; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashbash</i> 211; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>YD</i> 216; <i>Teshuvot (Petah) Beit Dovid</i> (Yosef Dovid, Salonika) 2, <i>HM</i> 6; <i>Teshuvot Avnei Sha’ish</i> 2:29; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:84 (6); <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 2:56; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 3, <i>EH</i> 19; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hezkiah</i> 1, <i>EH</i> 7.<br>Cf. others claim that a ineligible witness’s testimony is even admissible concerning matters of intimacy involving finding grounds to release a wife from an <i>igun</i> situation. See <i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i>, op. cit. <i>Teshuvot Shoeil u-Meishiv</i> 1, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 184; <i>Teshuvot Atzei Hayyim</i> (Teitelbaum) 18. In fact, one trusts a single midwife’s statement regarding <i>yuhasin</i>, which according to certain <i>Poskim</i> is a matter of <i>erva.</i> See <i>Kiddushin</i> 73b, <i>Beit Dovid</i>, op. cit. in the name of <i>Mordekai</i>, <i>Aguda</i>, and <i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i>. Accordingly, testimony of an ineligible witness may encompass not only observing an act of spousal abuse, but equally physical abuse of a child.<br>In fact, the <i>din</i> as well as legislation is understood to encompass matters beyond assault, such as shaming a Torah scholar and accepting a <i>meturgamen</i>, a translator of a witness’s testimony in a <i>beit din</i> proceeding. See <i>Teshuvot Binyamin Zev</i> 249; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 120, 179 (in the name of <i>Mordekai</i>); <i>Rema</i>, supra n. 69; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 334:43; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, ad locum 64; <i>Ha’amek She’ailah</i>, s<i>hei’ltot</i> 55:4. Therefore in light of that position, the admissibility of ineligible witnesses where eligible witnesses are absent should equally apply to matters of <i>erva</i>.<br>In sum, the scope of <i>takanat ha-kadmonim</i> is defined by whether one invokes an <i>umdana</i>, inferential fact-finding that would extend its parameters beyond the actual factual background of the enactment dealing with a woman who witnesses a scuffle in a synagogue’s women’s section, or refrains from invoking an <i>umdana</i>, which results in the halakhic ramifications being limited to the actual facts which the legislation addressed. For varying opinions whether one can employ an <i>umdana</i> regarding a <i>takanah</i>, see <i>Ketonet Yosef</i> (Birdugo), <i>shorshei dinim</i>, <i>anaf</i> 20, “<i>umdana</i>.”<br>Some <i>Poskim</i> who argue that in pursuance to either the <i>din</i> or legislation that an invalid witness’s testimony is admissible to verify spousal rape, contend that on the basis of one individual’s testimony, a <i>beit din</i> can issue a <i>nezikin</i> award, which means that one can extract money from the abuser and give it to the victim. See <i>Kiddushin</i> 73b; <i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i>, op. cit.; <i>Maharik</i>, op. cit. (in the name of <i>Mordekai</i>); <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 35:11; <i>Noda be-Yehuda</i>, supra n. 71; <i>Petah Beit Dovid</i>, op. cit<i>.</i>; <i>Mishpat Arukh</i>, 2, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:14 (20). Our presentation here is premised upon these <i>Poskim</i>’s rulings. But, cf. <i>Yam Shel Shlomo</i> supra n. 71; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:10; <i>Teshuvot Maharash ha-Levi</i> 38.<br>Others argue in principle that we should reject this rabbinic legislation. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:182; <i>Yam Shel Shlomo</i>, supra n. 71; <i>Mishkenot ha-Ro’im</i>, <i>Ma’arekhet Ot Ayin</i>; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 35:20; <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:24; <i>Yeshuot Yisrael</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:11; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:13, 408:2.<br>In sum, assuming that physical abuse happened, a woman’s testimony such as in our case of a Jewish maid is admissible and one can extract money on the basis of her testimony. Consequently, under such circumstances, a wife has grounds for advancing a <i>nezikin</i> claim against her abusive husband. This conclusion presumes that the matrimonial relationship is bereft of strife. However, should there be altercations and quarrels among themselves; the wife’s trustworthiness is undermined. See <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 17:48; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 178:9.</i>
However, there are authorities who reject an ineligible witness testimony in matters of battery between individuals for which nobody else is present to offer valid testimony, or who affirm that extracting money from the batterer requires two Jewish male witnesses who can confirm abuse transpired.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Regarding social violence and spousal abuse respectively, see <i>Petah Beit Dovid</i>, supra n. 74, PDR 21, supra n. 74. For those <i>Poskim</i> who reject extracting money from a batterer relying upon the single testimony of an invalid witness such as the victim of an assault, see <i>Yam shel Shlomo</i>, supra n. 71; <i>Shakh</i>, supra n. 74, <i>Maharash ha-Levi</i>, supra n. 74.</i> Nonetheless, though a woman’s testimony, for example, is invalid as <i>edut</i> (testimony) that a <i>dayan</i> is obliged to accept and follow, nevertheless a <i>dayan</i> may recognize that her words possess veracity and rely upon her testimony as <i>umdana demukhra</i>, circumstantianial evidence<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 58a, 132a (R. Shimon ben Menasiah). See infra n. 80.</i>. In fact, recent <i>beit din</i> rulings ascertained proof of a husband’s assaults and threats through the testimony of invalid wit­nesses.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 022828867-21-1, July 11, 2000, Netanya Regional Beit Din archived by <i>ha-Din ve-ha-Dayan</i>, no. 2, 3; File no. 878656/1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, November 13, 2012; File no. 25449-2, Ashdod Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, November 9, 2013.</i>
For example, in dealing with a case in which the wife claims that her husband assaults her and the husband denies the claim, R. Yitzhak Herzog writes,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Yitzhak Herzog, “In the matter of a <i>get</i> given under duress,” (Hebrew) 1 <i>Ha-Darom</i> 3, 25 (5717). Cf. supra text accompanying n. 67.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">… [I]t depends upon the discernment of the <i>beit din</i>, and I remember that already <i>Rashba</i> writes … that if we follow formal law and comply with the laws of testimony and mandate two witnesses, we will never be able to render a <i>din torah</i> (decision), and we are familiar with what Rambam wrote that essentially everything is dependent upon the perception of the arbiters … and the primary concern is that the <i>beit din</i> … shall hear the parties’ arguments … and if upon examination we find her claim to be truthful … we may conclude that the husband is a batterer.</span>
According to this approach, even invalid witnesses are acceptable if we have reason to believe them.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">For additional <i>Poskim</i> who would validate testimony from invalid witnesses when there is “<i>raglayim la-davar</i>” (credible evidence), see <i>Otzar ha-Poskim</i>, <i>EH</i>, vol. 3, 22–23. Moreover, in situations of <i>le-migdar milta</i> such as abuse, the testimony of incompetent and/or ineligible witnesses is accepted. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i>, 3:393, 4:311; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; <i>Teshuvot Beit Shlomo HM</i>, 2.</i> In addition, a friend’s awareness of the husband’s abusive relationship, police reports, social service findings, or or the existence of health care findings accompanied by an invalid witness testimony, can be used to lend credence in our case to instances of spousal rape or abuse and serve as grounds for a <i>nezikin</i> award.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">For admissibility of circumstantial evidence, see <i>Erekh Shai</i>, <i>HM</i> 421:6; <i>Beit Din</i> Decision, Neve Dekalim-Gush Katif, Sivan 2 5762. For the effectiveness of an <i>umdana de-mukhra</i>, inferential fact finding to extract money, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 69; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 5; <i>Teshuvot Divre Ribot</i> 101, 258; <i>Teshuvot Avodat ha-Gershuni</i> 91; <i>Teshuvot Maharit Zahalon ha-Hadashot</i> 19; 42; <i>Teshuvot Darkei Noam</i>, <i>HM</i> 49, 51–53. Cf. <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:287, 3:561; <i>Teshuvot Mahara Sasson</i> 45, 54; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i>, 3:1, 152.</i> Circumstantial evidence such as a health care professional’s opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">There is an assumption that a professional will proffer an informed and credible opinion rather than threaten his livelihood by offering bad advice. See <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 114:5; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 155:3; <i>Teshuvot Hakham Tzvi</i> 39; <i>Teshuvot Ein Yitzhak</i>, <i>OH</i> 17.</i> and polygraph findings that attempt to determine the veracity of the parties’ claims regarding an alleged abuse, have been admitted in the past.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 11:328; File no. 4564-24-1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, 8 Shevat 5767. For differing opinions regarding the admissibility of polygraph findings in a <i>beit din</i>, see Eliav Shochetman, “The use of a polygraph in a rabbinical court,” (Hebrew), 7 <i>Tehumin</i> 381 (5747); <i>PDR</i> 20:126.</i> Given that health care experts are concerned about their reputation and need to be compensated for their counsel, there is an assumption that they will submit credible findings.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 1:33, 34; 235, 236.</i> Just as we accept a physician’s findings that an expectant woman is in a life-threatening situation that justifies an abortion or a physician’s findings that a sick individual is in danger and therefore one can violate Shabbat or allow him to eat on Yom Kippur, we can also accept the findings of a health care professional, including a gentile.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 425:2; <i>OH</i> 328:31, 618:3. Clearly, there are distinctions that make each instance unique, but nonetheless, the common denominator is that a professional opinion will be trusted and relied upon. For the reliability of a gentile’s professional opinion, see <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 1:324; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 3:66; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i>, 493; <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 20:1; <i>Teshuvot Be’er Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 5, <i>anaf</i> 4; Z. N. Goldberg, 4 <i>Kol Tzvi</i> 14, 28 (5762).</i> Moreover, pursuant to Rema’s position,<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 74:10, 154:3.</i> psychologists and social workers who interview both the husband and the wife can assist in the fact-finding process regarding the stability of the marriage and the alleged incidents of abuse.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 4564-24-1, supra n. 82.</i> Finally, a husband’s intimidating and demeaning behavior towards his neighbors and/or his disruptive conduct towards his wife during a <i>beit din</i> proceeding will lend credence to a wife’s allegations that she is a victim of abuse.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhasot le-Ramban</i>, 198; <i>PDR</i> 11:327, 328, 12:84, 92, 15:119, 122; File no. 168-54, <i>Supreme</i> Beit Din, November 17, 1994, <i>Ha</i>-<i>Din ve-ha-Dayan</i>, <i>gilyon</i> 2, 3.</i>
In short, if the allegation of physical violence can be proven through the batterer’s admission, the testimony of two male witnesses, or circumstantial evidence such as a health care professional’s findings or a husband’s behavior interacting with third parties and with his wife in <i>beit din</i> proceedings,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 9465-21-1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, February 14, 2007.</i> there are grounds for a <i>beit din</i> to award monetary relief to the abused wife. In our scenario, the testimony of the wife and maid that the assault transpired, third-party testimony that attests to the violent character of the husband, and the testimony of a doctor regarding the husband’s proclivity to battery, are sufficient proof for the wife to argue that the events transpired.
In sum, in the absence of two adult Jewish male witnesses, there are two different evidentiary standards which allow a <i>dayan</i> to determine whether in fact the alleged abuse actually transpired. One relies upon the testimony of an invalid witness such as a woman, and the other focuses upon a constellation of factors, which, in addition to invalid witnesses, includes professional findings pertaining to the batterer and his known behavior in social interaction. Regardless of which standard is being invoked, the common denominator is well expressed in the words of Rashba, who states:<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i>, 3:74.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Each <i>beit din</i> [must judge] according to the local matter and time in investigating the matter; If there were witnesses – a man or even a woman … and according to the perception of the <i>beit din</i>, its wisdom and sharpness, [it will] recognize the matter based on the facts. This is why they should search and undertake numerous inquiries, and this is hinted in what has been said, “to judge a true <i>din</i> to the [fullest] truth” …</span>
Likewise, R. Moshe Sofer observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 74. Accordingly, money may be extracted from another individual relying upon a single ineligible witness. See <i>Teshuvot Divrei Yoel</i> 2, <i>EH</i> 117. However, given that in the twentieth century, <i>dayanim</i> are either corrupt or lack Torah scholarship, R. Yoel Teitlebaum concludes that we must rely upon two eligible witnesses.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It seems that the Torah did not require [two witnesses], except when the <i>beit din</i> did not know without the two witnesses. But a matter which is clear to them without having to trust witnesses, is as if they observed it on their own. And just like if the <i>beit din</i> witnessed the event themselves, the Halakha would be handed down without <i>edut</i> … likewise, if at every stage the <i>beit din</i> knows what took place without the trustworthiness of a witness, they are empowered to judge without testimony, and it is not subsumed under the category of “upon two witnesses” …</span>
Regarding cases of spousal abuse, a recent <i>beit din</i> summarizes our conclusion,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 4564-24-1, supra n. 82. See also, File no. 25449-2, Ashdod Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, November 9, 2013 (physical and emotional abuse). For a recent case in which a <i>beit din</i> relied upon a single <i>eid</i>’s testimony, the husband’s face-to-face communications, as well as telephone conversations to him wherein he stated that he battered his wife frequently and regarding spousal assault, “this is the way of the Torah.” See File no. 4927-21-1, Petach Tikva Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, July 7, 2005.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Concerning violence between a couple that occurs in their home, it is almost impossible to bring valid witnesses. Therefore, it is incumbent upon <i>beit din</i> to rely upon ineligible witnesses, circumstantial evidence or documentation.</span>
Upon determination that the incident of spousal abuse transpired, the <i>beit din</i> will determine whether a monetary award for <i>boshet</i>/<i>tza’ar</i> is appropriate. Should a <i>beit din</i> determine that the claim is with merit, the wife would receive monetary relief from her husband.
Finally, in the event the husband refuses to desist from physical and sexual violence, the wife is entitled to leave the marital home.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i> 6, <i>EH</i> 45; <i>PDR</i> 11:327.</i>
Lest one argue that Halakha recognizes only two options (marriage or divorce), and rejects the possibility of marital separation,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">For the halakhic recognition of marital separation, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 43:14; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 4:113; <i>Teshuvot Ta’alumot Lev</i> 3:20 (4); <i>Yaskil Avdi</i>, supra n. 92.</i> Rema teaches us, “We neither coerce him to divorce her nor coerce her to live with him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:3. See also <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 117:11; <i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>EH</i> 70:12.</i>
On the contrary, the purpose of separation is to ease the tensions between the spouses and give each spouse time and breathing room to hopefully resolve their differences.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">See R. Hadayah’s opinion found supra, at n. 92. Additionally, see <i>PDR</i> 1:77, 78; 3:299, 319; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 4:21.</i> Consequently, <i>de facto</i> separation is legitimate.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">For a precedent, see <i>Teshuvot Pnei Moshe</i> 1:55.</i> The grounds for such separation are based upon the Talmudic logic that “a man cannot live in the same basket with a serpent” and “the purpose of our existence is for life not for pain.”<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 61a, 72a.</i>
Whether a wife who abandons the home is entitled to continuing support is dependent upon the reason for her departure from the marital home. Should she vacate the home due to the fact that the husband is delinquent in his marital duties, such as his duty of spousal support, the wife would not be entitled to such remuneration. On the other hand, if the wife separates due to being abused, which is verifiable by invalid witnesses, as is the case in our situation, she is entitled to ongoing support as well as reimbursement for lodging expenses.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 7: 477; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhasot la-Ramban</i> 103; <i>Teshuvot Maharam of Rothenberg</i>, Berlin ed.,11; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 70:12; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:3; <i>Teshuvot Edut be-Ya’akov</i> 36; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 1:113; <i>Teshuvot va-Yomer Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 126; <i>Teshuvot Mor ve-Oholot</i>, <i>EH</i> 10; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Moshe</i>, supra n. 96; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Alsheich</i> 8; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Yehezkiya</i>, <i>EH</i> 1, in the names of Rabbis Kook and Uzziel; <i>PDR</i> 1:7, 238; 15:119, 11:327; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 4:21, 18:58.<br>For the acceptability of invalid testimony in cases of a wife’s abandonment of the marital home, see <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 74:9, 154:3; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:14; <i>PDR</i> 1:201, 2:353.</i>
Procedurally speaking, all of these claims for spousal support and monetary relief for abuse, along with matters such as the <i>get</i>, parenting arrangements, and division of marital assets, are submitted to the <i>beit din</i> panel at the time of the hearing. Pursuant to the view of various decisors,<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 11:1 (in the name of <i>Be’er Sheva</i>); <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 1:143.</i> the overwhelming majority of the <i>battei din</i> in the NY metropolitan area do not require submission of a claim statement to the <i>beit din</i> and the opposing party prior to the hearing. However, there are a few <i>battei din</i> that follow another position<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, supra n. 99; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 11:1.Though these authorities mandate a submission of a claim statement only in response to a defendant’s request, these <i>battei din</i> require the submission regardless of whether the defendant requests it or not.<br>Though pursuant to Shakh’s posture there is no obligation upon the defendant to respond to the plaintiff’s claim statement prior to the hearing, nevertheless, these <i>battei din</i> will mandate a defendant’s written response to the plaintiff’s allegations prior to the convening of the panel.</i> and mandate the submission of a claim statement, as well as a defendant’s reply, prior to the hearing.
The scope of the <i>beit din</i>’s jurisdiction, which is determined by the scope of the arbitration, is crucial. If the arbitration agreement is open-ended and states that “all differences and disputes relating to the end of marriage” are to be resolved, then all matters, including spousal abuse, will be addressed by the panel. If, on the other hand, the husband insists that the allegations of spousal abuse not be adjudicated by the panel, then the wife should seek <i>beit din</i> and rabbinic counsel which, among other things, should allow her to resolve this claim in civil court.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:2. Invariably, claims of abuse are submitted at the same time that a wife requests to be granted a divorce from her husband. In a case in which the husband refuses to deliver a <i>get</i> and a <i>beit din</i> renders a monetary award to the wife, if the husband consents to grant a <i>get</i> provided that his wife waives her right to the award, this does not pose any halakhic dilemma. See <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 41, 111–180.</i>
In conclusion, addressing spousal abuse in eighteenth-century Bulgaria, R. Eliezer Papo writes,<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pele Yo’ets</i>, 1:5, 101.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It is proper for the leaders of the cities to impose sanctions upon violent individuals, in particular decadent people that hit their wives … Their breath should depart — those who treat the daughters of Israel as servants, trampling and assaulting them … and they have no shame in their actions. Anyone who has the ability to impose sanctions ought to apply them … because a woman cannot live in the same place with a snake …</span>
Historically, as we have shown, the <i>beit din</i> and/or rabbinic decisors have assumed this mission. As members of our self-respecting covenantal faith community, we need to follow in their footsteps and continue to bring such claims to our <i>battei din</i> and we need our <i>dayanim</i> to offer monetary relief, if justified.
<b>2.</b>
In a hypothetical scenario, a grown Jewish man of 23 years of age appeared in a <i>beit din</i> proceeding to accuse a former teacher of repeatedly molesting him while attending yeshiva elementary school. “I remember him touching me,” said the man, “He touched my private area.” At age ten, he was raped repeatedly. He stayed quiet for thirteen years, stuffing the pain within himself. He got a job, got married, had kids, and interacted with family and friends with a smile on his face. But every step of the way, he carried with him the suffering of the ten-year-old boy who was betrayed by his mentor. Eventually, the boy’s pain became too much to bear and he demanded that a <i>beit din</i> direct the yeshiva to terminate his teacher’s employment, and advanced a <i>nezikin</i> claim against his teacher for causing him shame and pain. Upon hearing about the alleged abuse scandal and the convening of this <i>beit din</i> proceeding, two other Jewish male adults stepped forward and testified in <i>beit din</i> regarding their own experiences as alleged victims of abuse perpetrated by the same teacher while attending this yeshiva elementary school. Advocating verbal persuasion as the only vehicle for educating children, the teacher admitted during the proceeding, that he did not use corporal punishment.
Rambam states,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hovel u-Mazik</i> 5:1–2.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Anyone who assaults an honest (<i>kasher</i>) individual of Israel whether he is a minor or of majority age … in a disrespectful fashion (<i>derekh nitzayon</i>, such as illicit fondling<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Though this phrase means fighting in certain contexts in <i>Tanakh</i>, here it is understood to mean disrespect.<br>In other words, Halakha not only outlaws genital penetration but equally any illicit touching or fondling. See also, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Issurei Bi’ah</i> 21:1; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 20:1; <i>Teshuvot Seridei Esh</i> 3:29; File no. 917387/1, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Ploni</i>, November 17, 2013.</i>) violates a negative commandment … and one who lifts his hand, even though he has not hit him, is wicked.</span>
Similar rulings were handed down by Shulhan Arukh and others.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:1; <i>Sefer ha-Hinukh</i>, <i>mitzvat lo ta’ase</i> 595; <i>Shulhan Arukh ha-Rav</i>, <i>Hilkhot Nizkei Guf ve-Nefesh</i> 1.</i> Yet, under certain prescribed conditions, a teacher is permitted to hit a child for educational purposes.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 9:11; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 378:8; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 378:9; this writer’s “Corporal punishment in school: a study in the interaction of Halakha and American law with social morality,” 37 <i>Tradition</i> 57 (Fall 2003) accessible at http://www.yutorah.org/lectures/lecture.cfm/744984/Rabbi_Dr_Ronnie_Warburg/Corporal_Punishment_in_School:_A_Study_in_the_Interaction_of_Contemporary_American_Law_with_Social_Morality.<br>Any halakhic dispensation to employ force within the context of a classroom is predicated upon the fact that secular law sanctions such behavior.</i>
Based upon the teacher’s admission that he did not use corporal punishment in the classroom, we are dealing with a case of alleged child abuse rather than an instance of a teacher hitting his student for educational reasons. In the absence of a criminal conviction by a court,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 66.</i> the question is whether we can accept as <i>edut</i> (testimony) the information provided by these three men in order to address the monetary claims advanced by the victim.
A similar question was addressed by a <i>dayan</i> in the mid-nineteenth century. In the year 1850, a teacher who was teaching in a town for a period of eight years was rumored to have engaged in homosexual liaisons with some of his students. A few of them who now had reached the age of thirteen spoke about his improper behavior. The teacher accepted upon himself “with an oath and a vow” that immediately after the close of the school year, he would move and seek employment elsewhere. His desire was to live and teach in Lvov located in the Ukraine. However, rumors of his alleged conduct quickly spread to Lvov and a respected layman of Lvov requested that R. Yosef Shaul Nathansohn, the town’s <i>av beit din</i>, investigate and inquire into this matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meshiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 1:185.</i> Upon deliberation, R. Nathansohn received the testimony of two teenagers who alleged that this teacher had engaged in the aforementioned abusive behavior. The question posed to R. Nathansohn was whether the teacher ought to be disqualified from teaching.
R. Nathansohn’s reply was that such a determination requires the testimony of two male witnesses. Though both alleged victims were presently of majority age, nonetheless, given that their testimony related to incidents that transpired while they were minors, their present testimony is considered to be the testimony of minors.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:3. This ruling applies even if their testimony relates to others or to themselves. See <i>SA ha-Rav</i>, <i>YD</i> 1:42.<br>Though there are certain exceptions wherein we rely upon their testimony pertaining to events that occurred while being minors, our instance is not one of them. See <i>SA</i>, op. cit.</i> Consequently, given that we are dealing with minors, generally speaking their testimony is invalid.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:1.</i> But R. Nathansohn invokes the <i>Rema</i>’s view (and others) according to which their testimony would be admissible and may be relied upon in cases involving battery where no male adults were present.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">See supra, text accompanying nn. 71 and 74. In the absence of two Jewish male witnesses, there are contemporary <i>Poskim</i> who will rely on testimony from minors, recordings, letters, or polygraph findings. See T. Gartner &amp; Y. Silman, “Treatise on ‘your fellow-Jew’s blood’” (Hebrew), 15 <i>Yeshurun</i> 634, 638, 663 (5765).</i> As such, relying upon their testimony, and for the children’s welfare, R. Nathansohn precluded the teacher from accepting a teaching position in Lvov.
Given that various decisors challenge Rema’s posture,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying nn. 71 and 74.</i> is there any other evidentiary basis for a teacher being dismissed or ineligible to teach children due to having been involved in alleged incidents of child abuse? In nineteenth-century Izmir, Turkey, a rumor spread that a teacher had touched a student’s private area. However, the incident could not be verified. Subsequently, another rumor spread that on Purim this teacher entered a home and molested a young boy in the same fashion. According to the rumor mill, this occurrence repeated itself in the same home on Pesach. In response to these rumors, the teacher argued that he never touched these boys. And in fact, in his two visits to this home, the teacher alleged, there were numerous individuals in attendance – how is it possible that they didn’t observe such conduct? The community was divided on whether to dismiss the teacher. Unable to corroborate that any of these incidents actually transpired, R. Hayyim Palache would not mandate the teacher’s dismissal.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hikekei Lev</i>, supra n. 71.</i>
The import of R. Palache’s position is clear. Lest alleged pedophiles lose their jobs and be publicly shamed for conduct that he or she never committed, it is incumbent upon <i>beit din</i> to critically investigate the allegations prior to rendering judgment. Addressing the alleged incident of a teacher molesting a young girl, R. Shmuel de Medina (known by the acronym “Maharashdam”) of sixteenth-century Salonika in the Ottoman Empire states,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>YD</i> 141.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Since all of Israel is presumptively credible (“<i>be-hezkat kashrut</i>”), unless there are proofs or significant justifications (“<i>amatlaot</i>”), one cannot undermine a person’s presumptive credibility.</span>
In fact, a few years ago, within the context of a <i>beit din</i> setting, we addressed an allegation of a series of incidents of a teenager molesting a younger child in an Australian yeshiva dormitory. The <i>tove’a</i> (plaintiff), namely the parent who appeared on behalf of his child who was the victim of the alleged abuse, submitted his claim demanding a remuneration of his costs for the psychological counseling that his child required due to these experiences.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Though generally a <i>ba’al din</i> (litigant) advances his own claims in <i>beit din</i>, nevertheless, a minor who is a litigant may have his claims submitted by a parent or another party of majority age. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 96, 1–2, 108:6; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 108:2; <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 108:7. A parent or grandparent who submits a claim on behalf of his minor child or grandchild, respectively, has the status of an “<i>apotropus</i>” (guardian) appointed by a <i>beit din</i>. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i>, 87–88; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i>, <i>HM</i> 37.<br>The above conclusion is not to be construed as preempting the possibility that a minor may appear either as a plaintiff or defendant in a <i>beit din</i> proceeding. In fact, such a possibility clearly exists. However, the actual advancement of claims will be performed by his guardian or another adult who appears with him at the proceeding. For a <i>beit din</i>’s authority to award recovery of therapy bills, see supra text accompanying nn. 25–41.</i> However, the child neither appeared in front of the <i>beit din</i>, nor was the <i>tove’a</i> able to demonstrate in any shape or form to the panel that these incidents actually transpired. The <i>beit din</i> requested supporting documentation related to these incidents, but never received this evidence from the <i>tove’a</i>. Moreover, the <i>tove’a</i> failed to appear to hear the <i>nitva</i>’s (defendant’s) reply to the <i>tove’a</i>’s allegations. As such, adopting Maharashdam’s approach, the <i>beit din</i> was unable to perform its due diligence regarding this matter and the panel denied the <i>tove’a</i> any monetary relief.
In his extensive <i>teshuva</i>, responsum spanning over twenty pages, R. Palache sets forth, among other matters, the evidentiary standard required in order to terminate a pedophile from employment. Rejecting Rema’s posture, which argues for the admissibility of testimony by minors in cases of <i>nezikin</i>, R. Palache offers another standard. He concludes that, in the absence of two male witnesses who observed the conduct, an abuser could be dismissed from a school’s employment if four conditions are met. First, the child, the victim of abuse, has to be intelligent and of upstanding character. Second, the child must not bear any animosity or hatred for the alleged abuser. Third, the child’s experience has to be corroborated by at least two more children who experienced abuse by this teacher. Finally, the abusive behavior must have happened in a place where people were not present who could testify to the alleged event. Assuming that after intensive inquiry, the <i>beit din</i> arrives at the conclusion that they are dealing with an event which occurred in private with at least three different children who are intelligent and do not harbor any animosity towards the alleged pedophile, there are grounds for the teacher’s dismissal. In R. Palache’s mind, the introduction of these conditions is based upon the <i>beit din</i>’s power to act <i>le-migdar milta</i>, namely the necessity for evidentiary guidelines to address a pressing societal problem.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">See supra, text accompanying nn. 28–40.</i>
Another evidentiary stance suggested by R. Palache is to rely upon the testimony of ineligible witnesses and “<i>kala de-lo pasik</i>” (a persistent rumor). He distinguishes between this type of rumor and a “<i>rinnun be-alma</i>” (a mere rumor), which does not serve to corroborate that the event took place.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">For others who will mandate testimony of two witnesses and not rely upon <i>rinnun be-alma</i>, see <i>Teshuvot Ri Migash</i> 95; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rambam</i>, Blau ed., 111; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 53:4.</i> R. Eliyahu ben Hayyim (known by the acronymn <i>“</i>Ranah<i>”</i>) suggests that there are two conditions that have to be met in order for the rumor to be labeled a “<i>kala de-lo pasik.</i>” First, the rumor must have been heard by many individuals and must not have subsided. Second, one must ascertain the source of the rumor. If, upon discovery, we find that the initiator of the rumor is an enemy of the alleged abuser, the rumor must be discounted.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 2:41. See also <i>Teshuvot Mayyim Amukim</i> 2:52; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>OH</i> 25; <i>Magen Avraham</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 53:7; <i>Bi’ur Halakha</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 53:25.</i>
Alternatively, based upon our foregoing presentation of the evidentiary standards employed to verify instances of spousal abuse, a <i>dayan</i> may rely upon the testimony of an invalid witness such as a minor, when accompanied by other factors, such as circumstantial evidence, including but not limited to professional health care findings and polygraph testing, in order to determine whether child abuse has transpired. In the absence of the testimony of two witnesses, cases of child abuse, like spousal abuse, may be resolved by utilizing alternative evidentiary guidelines.
In our scenario, depending upon which approach a <i>beit din</i> would adopt to determine whether abuse has actually occurred, a <i>beit din</i> is obligated to critically inquire into the credibility of the victims of abuse, their testimony, persistent rumors, and/or the circumstantial evidence which may serve to ascertain the veracity of the alleged event. Should the <i>beit din</i> ascertain that such an event transpired, it can then decide if there is a justification for employment dismissal and/or the rendering of monetary awards based upon claims of <i>boshet</i>/<i>tza’ar</i>, recovery of fees for therapy, etc.
In conclusion, in addressing the relationship between a parent and a child, R. Uziel aptly notes, “Neither the sons nor daughters of a man belong to him in the manner he owns his monetary assets.”<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Uziel</i>, <i>EH</i> 91.</i>
<i>A fortiori</i>, it behooves a parent, sibling, principal, rabbi, teacher, health care professional, and the like to hearken to R. Uziel’s words and protect the bodily and emotional well-being of our children and grandchildren, while simultaneously servicing their educational and psychological needs. We can expect no less. The dismissal of rabbis, teachers, and administrative staff from our synagogues, <i>yeshivot</i>, and youth organizations due to the perpetration of child abuse and the awarding of damages for mental anguish to the victims, serves as an important indication of the seriousness with which we must treat this issue. Ensuring that claims of abuse victims are settled expeditiously and appropriately is a <i>beit din</i>’s mandate.
Similarly, the opportunity to file an action in <i>beit din</i> regarding spousal abuse provides a communal recognition of the intrinsic value of human dignity.
Addressing these issues should be a collaborative effort of <i>dayanim</i>, as well as the health care professionals who will assist the <i>beit din</i> panel. During the past fifteen years, I have witnessed firsthand how child psychologists and experts in child abuse have been “the light at the end of the tunnel” in dealing with parenting arrangements for children of divorced families. We should expect no less in seeking their counsel regarding child and spousal abuse cases.
Some <i>battei din</i> employ a vetting process. In other words, upon receiving a claim, the administrative staff of the <i>beit din</i> will decide whether or not the claim will be heard by a panel of <i>dayanim</i>. For example, though there are grounds for mandating honoring and respecting a parent,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Hinukh</i>, <i>mitzvat aseh</i> 33; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 97:16; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 1; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 107:2.</i> nonetheless, the staff may choose to refrain from accepting a claim initiated by a parent of the victim of abuse for <i>beit din</i> resolution. Or, though there may be grounds for filing <i>lashon hara</i> (defamation) suits against individuals,<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:38; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:56; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 38:2.</i> the <i>beit din</i> policy may limit the acceptance of such claims to cases involving media communications and labor relations. In our opinion, the <i>beit din</i> vetting process regarding alleged abuse should be held to the minimum. Abuse cases, due to halakhic intricacies which we have briefly outlined, varying evidentiary standards and inquiries, and the societal need to address this ongoing issue in the Jewish community, require that a <i>beit din</i>’s administrative staff accept each and every case, provided that the alleged victim submit in writing some supporting documentation corroborating his or her claim.<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Generally, <i>battei din</i> that employ a vetting process require a plaintiff’s claim statement and a defendant’s response, and those <i>battei din</i> without a vetting process do not require a claim statement. See text accompanying nn. 99-100.</i>
Most administrative staffs of <i>battei din</i> accept any and every type of case brought to them, and leave it to the discretion of the <i>dayanim</i> to decide whether a particular matter is justiciable. Consequently, the decision whether to address such claims is in the hands of <i>dayanim</i> rather than administrators.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">For a recent US Supreme Court endorsement of a vetting process pertaining to civil lawsuits in federal courts, see <i>Ashcroft v. Iqbal</i>, 556 US 662, 129 S. Ct. 1937 (2009). Some of the same arguments that support and/or question the merits of this judgment equally apply to whether a <i>beit din</i> should employ a vetting process.</i>
A <i>beit din</i>’s decision to refrain from hearing claims of abuse effectively bestows upon the injurer a form of “halakhic entitlement” to cause the injury. Perceived weakness of the <i>beit din</i> may only lead to increased violation and debasement of Halakha because others have done it with impunity. Unlike other legal systems, in Halakha, there is generally no statute of limitations in advancing such claims. Even if the alleged act of abuse was perpetrated twenty or forty years ago, a <i>beit din</i> is empowered to hear such claims today.<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 98:1; <i>PDR</i> 10:363, 368. Though these sources deal with non-payment of an outstanding debt such as a loan, the continuing right to advance a claim applies equally to a <i>nezikin</i> claim that potentially may translate into an outstanding debt if so determined by a <i>beit din</i>. Even if secular law invokes a statute of limitations regarding such claims, Halakha sanctions the advancement of such claims. See <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Uziel</i>, <i>HM</i> 28:8; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 3:134.<br>For possible exceptions to this rule, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i>, 79:13 (end); <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 98:2; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 104:2 in the name of <i>Rashba</i>; <i>Sma</i>, ad locum 7 in the name of <i>Ramban</i>; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 78. All of these sources that deal with non-payment of conventional monetary debts, such as failure to make a loan repayment, ought to be applied in advancing a <i>nezikin</i> claim.<br>Given that a <i>beit din</i> decision is legally an arbitration decision, in certain states such as Georgia, Illinois, and New York and there are statutes that expressly provide that if a claim is time barred in court, it would also be time barred in an arbitration proceeding. See Official Code of Georgia Section 9-9-5; <i>Peregrine Financial Group Inc. v. Futronix Trading, Ltd.</i> No. 1-09-2293 (Ill. 1st May 21, 2010); New York CPLR Section 7502.<br>However other states, such as California, Connecticut, Florida, Indiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, North Carolina, Ohio, and Washington, rule that statutes of limitations are inapplicable to arbitration proceedings. See <i>Manhattan Loft, LLC v. Mercury Liquors, Inc.,</i> 173 Cal. App. 4th 1040,1051 (Cal. App. 2d Dist. 2009); <i>Owings and Merrill v. Connecticut General Life Insurance Co.</i>, 197 A.2d 83 (1963); <i>Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. v. Phillips</i> (2D10-2144); <i>Lewiston Firefighters Assn. v. City of Lewiston</i>, 354 A. 2d 154, 167 (Maine 1976); <i>Carpenter v. Pomerantz</i>, 634 N.E. 2d 587, 590 (Mass. App. 1994); <i>Ward v. Thomas</i>, 2003 Mich. App. LEXIS 2080 (Mich. Ct. App. 2003); <i>Har-Mar Inc. v. Thorsen and Thorsen, Inc.</i>, 218 N.W. 2d 751 (MN 1974); <i>Price v. New Jersey Manufacturers Insurance Co.</i>, 82 NJ 519, 526 (2005); In the <i>Matter of the Arbitration between Cameron and Griffith</i>, 370 S.E. 2d 704 (N.C. Ct. App. 1988); <i>Cline v. Ohio</i> Bur. <i>of Motor Vehicles</i> (1991), 61 Ohio St. 3d 93, 97, 573 N.E. 2d 77, 80-81; <i>Broom v. Morgan Stanley DW, Inc.</i>, No. 82311-1 (7/22/10).<br>In short, though there is a halakhic basis for filing claims against spousal abuse and child abuse in a <i>beit din</i> setting, nevertheless, depending upon the particular jurisdiction in which the <i>beit din</i> is located, a statute of limitations may apply, which will result in the claim being time barred.</i> Failure to deliberate upon these claims may undermine communal trust in rabbinic authority in general, and in rabbinical courts in particular. We hope that our articulation of these claims will allow <i>battei din</i> to live up to their mission of openly addressing the issues of the Jewish community.
<b>Addendum</b>
Should we be dealing with a <i>beit din</i> which obligated a husband to give a <i>get</i> and he refuses to comply with the <i>beit din</i>’s directive and the wife waives her right to the monetary award for spousal abuse given to her by <i>beit din</i> in exchange for receiving her <i>get</i>, it is our opinion that we are dealing with a situation of “<i>kefiya le-davar aher</i>,” coercion regarding another matter, and therefore the subsequent execution of this <i>get</i> does not produce a <i>get me’useh</i>, a coerced <i>get</i>, which would be invalid.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">In our presentation, we explained the grounds for awarding both punitive damages and compensatory damages for a <i>nezikin</i> claim relating to spousal abuse. In our present discussion as well as in this writer’s earlier presentation in <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 41, 163–175, we assume that the meting out of punitive damages would not run afoul of the strictures of a <i>get me’useh</i>. In fact, such a position of meting out punitive damages is espoused by R. Daichovsky of Yerushalayim, a former <i>dayan</i> of the Supreme Rabbinical Beit Din. See S. Daichovsky, “Monetary Enforcement Steps against Recalcitrant Husbands,” (Hebrew), 26 <i>Tehumin</i>, 173,176–177 (5766), and more recently by an Israeli <i>beit din</i> that obligated a husband to give a <i>get</i>. Upon the wife’s refusal to accept the <i>get</i>, the panel ruled that for every day the wife refuses to accept the <i>get</i>, she would be penalized 300 <i>shekalim</i> a day. The grounds for meting out such damages is<i> the wife’s failure to comply with the beit din</i>’s directive, i.e., <i>bizayon beit ha-din</i>. See File no. 819035/3, Petach Tikva Regional Beit Din, October 21, 2012, which can be accessed at <i>ha-Din ve-ha-Dayan</i> no. 33.Whereas R. Hadaya suggested that financial penalties against a recalcitrant spouse for failing to heed the words of a <i>beit din</i> may possibly be sanctioned, the Petach Tikvah <i>beit din</i> handed down its ruling without offering any reason. See <i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i> 6:96. See also, <i>Teshuvot Heichal Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> vol. 1, 1:5.<br>However, many may disagree with this view and contend that punitive damages are awarded in order that the husband cease and desist from his <i>get</i> recalcitrance. As such, such an award may serve as a threat to the husband and result in a <i>get me’useh</i> should the <i>get</i> be executed in exchange for the wife’s entitlement to her <i>nezikin</i> award.<br>Nonetheless, others, while rejecting the imposition of punitive marriages, may concur that given that compensatory damages is a form of relief for past injury, this debt obligation generated by a <i>beit din</i> is free standing and independent, not linked to the <i>get</i>, and thus will avoid the specter of a <i>get me’useh</i>. See recently, Eliyahu Abergil, “The validity of a <i>get</i> in light of a severe monetary award imposed by civil court,” (Hebrew) 35 <i>Tehumin</i>, 272 (5775).<br>To state it differently, whereas an award for compensatory damages for <i>tza’ar</i> and <i>boshet</i> incurred from spousal rape is an example of “<i>kefiya le-davar aher</i>,” an award for punitive damages is construed as “<i>ones mamon</i>.” For a discussion of this distinction, see <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 41,163–175<i>.</i></i> To state it differently, since the <i>nezikin</i> award was handed down because of abuse rather than as a means to coerce the husband’s granting of a <i>get</i>, if the wife waives her right to the award in exchange for the <i>get</i>, any subsequent divorce avoids the strictures of a coerced <i>get</i>.
However, some <i>Poskim</i> may view this as a <i>get me’useh shelo ke-din</i> (an improperly coerced divorce). The question is whether contemporary <i>Poskim</i> ought to validate such a <i>get be-diavad</i>, <i>ex post facto.</i> It would seem that many, possibly the majority of <i>Poskim</i> would invalidate a <i>get me’useh ex post facto</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 88b, s.v. “<i>mifsal</i>”; <i>Rashbam</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 48a, s.v. “<i>ve’hain</i>”; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 70a, s.v. “<i>yotzi</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 43:6; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 77a; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ran</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 49a, s.v “<i>get me’useh</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 104; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:573, 2:276, 4:40 in the name of <i>Ra’avad</i> and <i>Rabbeinu Hananel</i>; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 50a; <i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 88b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashbash</i> 339 in the name of <i>Rashi</i>; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 14:8; <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 41; <i>Yam shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 12:33; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:5; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 134; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 134:7; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 205:7; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 2:138; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 63; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 134:10, 13; <i>Teshuvot Maharitz</i> 1:40; <i>Teshuvot Mahari bei Rav</i> 41; <i>Gevurot Anashim</i> 38, 48; <i>Meshoveiv Netivot</i> 3; <i>Teshuvot Maharival</i> 2:77; <i>Mikhtav me-Eliyahu</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 7, 19; <i>Teshuvot R. Bezalel Ashkenazi</i> 15; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 41; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>EH</i> 134:10; <i>Teshuvot Beit Ephraim</i>, <i>Mahadura Tanina</i> 73; <i>Mishkenot Ya’akov</i>, <i>EH</i> 38; <i>Teshuvot Ma’set Moshe</i>, vol. 1, <i>EH</i> 17; <i>Teshuvot Mahariz Enzel</i> 88; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 116; <i>Teshuvot Birkat Yosef</i>, <i>EH</i> 83; <i>Teshuvot Kol Eliyahu</i> (Yisrael), <i>EH</i> 22; <i>Teshuvot Be’er Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 10:7; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>EH</i> 99:1; <i>Teshuvot va-Ya’an Dovid</i> (Weiss), 2:202.<br>The <i>Shulhan Arukh</i>’s position is unclear. See <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, op. cit.; <i>Levush Mordekhai</i> 58:2.</i> Seemingly, those contemporary authorities who argue that this is an instance of <i>get me’useh</i> would reject the validity of the executed <i>get.</i> Should either spouse remarry, questions regarding the personal status of a child sired from this relationship.
In my opinion such a conclusion is not necessarily forthcoming. Firstly, even if the majority of decisors consider a <i>get me’useh</i> to be invalid <i>ex post facto</i> that does not mean <i>ipso facto</i> that the Halakha is in accordance with the majority view.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">The fact that possibly the majority of <i>Poskim</i> contend that a <i>get me’useh</i> is null and void does not necessarily mean that we follow this view due to the fact that their position represents a numerical majority. The rule of <i>aharei rabbim le-hatot</i>, following the majority, operates within the confines of a formal <i>beit din</i> proceeding. See <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur HM</i> 13 in the name of <i>Rashba</i>; <i>Get Pashut</i>, <i>Kelalim</i>, <i>kelal</i> 1, 5; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Zeraim</i>, <i>Shevi’it</i> 23; <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 41, 24–25, 50–51. Similiarily, whether normative Halakha ought to align itself with the numerical majority who views a <i>get me’useh</i> as null and void may require the convening of Torah scholars who would exchange their opinions and engage in a give and take regarding the matter and resolve the issue. See <i>Teshuvot Maharlbah</i>, <i>Kuntres ha-Semikha</i>; Rabbinic Authority, supra n. 41, 24–25.</i> Secondly, it is this author’s hope that contemporary authorities, similar to <i>Poskim</i> in the past<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Behag</i>, <i>Hilkhot Gerushin</i>, Machon Yerushalayim ed., 418; <i>Orhot Hayyim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Gittin</i> 80b; <i>Teshuvot Beit Avi</i> 4:143, 169 in the name of <i>Rabbeinu Yeruham</i>; <i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 48b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 4:41; <i>Yam shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 9:27; <i>Teshuvot Agudat Eizov</i>, <i>EH</i> 19:18 in the name of <i>Ra’avad</i>; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:76; <i>Teshuvot Tzemach Tzedek</i>, <i>EH</i> 262 (3, 9); <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:184; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 63, cited by <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>EH</i> 134, <i>Ha-gahot Beit Yosef</i> 21; <i>Teshuvot Ma’aseh Hiya</i> 24; <i>Teshuvot Oneg Yom Tov</i> 167 (238c–d); <i>Teshuvot Beit Avi</i>, <i>EH</i> 169; O. Yosef, “<i>Kol ha-Mekadesh Adata de-Rabbanan Mekasdesh,</i>” (Hebrew), 3 <i>Torah she-Ba’al Peh</i> 96, 99 (5730); <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 6, <i>EH</i> 10.</i> would subscribe to the view of Rambam that a <i>get me’useh shelo- ka-din</i> is <i>pasul mi-derabbanan</i> (rabbinically invalid) but not <i>batel</i> (null and void)<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Gerushin</i> 2:20.</i> and therefore a <i>get</i> delivered under the circumstances mentioned ought to be valid.In effect, though Hazon Ish may be consider Rambam’s view a minority opinion,<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, supra n. 126.</i> there are others who concur with his view. Following in Rambam’s footsteps, these contemporary authorities would be endorsing the view of some well-respected <i>Aharonim</i> including R. O. Yosef that if she remarries, she can remain with her second husband.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 144; <i>Hagahot ha-Tur</i> 21 and <i>Hagahot ha-Beit Yosef</i> 21–22 in the name of <i>Maharshal</i>, <i>Mabit</i>, <i>Maharashdam</i>, and <i>Ranah</i>. Additionally, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:187; <i>Teshuvot Avodat ha-Gershuni</i> 35; O. Yosef, supra n. 128, 99. .<br>A review of notes 126, 128, and 131 show that there exists differing understandings concerning Meiri’s, Ra’avad’s, Rashba’s, Maharal’s, and Mabit’s position whether a <i>get me’useh</i> is rabbinically invalid or null and void. A resolution of their actual views is beyond the scope of this presentation.</i>
Moreover, one may factor into consideration those <i>Poskim</i> who are lenient <i>ex post facto</i> in cases of monetary compulsion.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashbam</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 40b, s.v. “<i>giluyi</i>”; <i>Teshuvot Maharach Ohr Zarua</i> 126; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 1; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:76; <i>Teshuvot Maharbil</i> 1:110, 2:7; <i>Teshuvot Beit Ephraim</i>, <i>EH</i> 125.<br>Said conclusion was attributed by the following <i>Poskim</i> to <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 4:40: <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 1; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:76; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Ribot</i> 291; <i>Teshuvot Maharbil</i> 2:77; <i>Teshuvot Avodat ha-Gershuni</i> 35.</i> Furthermore, Maharashdam, Oneg Yom Tov, and R. Herzog, though admitting that many disagree with Rambam’s view, nevertheless they conclude that <i>Rambam</i>’s <i>psak</i> ought to be controlling and in a case of halakhic doubt, one should rule in accordance with his posture.<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 128; <i>Teshuvot Oneg Yom Tov</i> 168; Notes of R. Herzog, <i>Otzar ha-Poskim</i>, vol. 2, section 4 (pp. 1–2), section 20 (p. 5); <i>Teshuvot Heichal Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:2–3.</i>
Furthermore, Radakh and Hazon Ish contend that the existence of a majority view is to be viewed as “<i>itmar hilkhisa” –</i> the Halakha has been decided and one therefore cannot impart legitimacy to an individual opinion, even in extenuating circumstances.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Radakh</i>, <i>bayit</i> 3, <i>heder</i> 1; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>YD</i> 160:3–4.</i> It appears that in their mind, “abiding by the majority” in halakhic controversy is akin to following the majority in a <i>beit din</i> proceeding. However, R. Ovadiah Yosef <sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Yehave Da’at</i>, vol. 1, 25–29.</i>and others<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 41, 51.</i> contend that debating a halakhic issue when the disputants are in absentia of each other and the emerging controvery is inter-generational, abiding by the majority does not necessarily apply. As such, the issue remains as a <i>safek</i> (doubt) and invoking a <i>sefek sefeka</i>, a double doubt, emerges in our scenario as a distinct possibility. And, in fact, as we mentioned, there are many <i>Poskim</i> who subscribe to the view that a <i>get me’useh</i> is null and void, yet in a case of <i>sefek sefeka</i>, they aligned themselves with Rambam’s view.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mikhtav me-Eliyahu</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 7, 13; <i>Teshuvot Sha’arei Torah</i> 3:63; R. Herzog, supra n. 133.<br>In fact, <i>ex ante</i> Hatam Sofer allowed a <i>beit din</i> to coerce a husband who was incapable of supporting his wife due to an illness by invoking a <i>sefek sefeka</i>.
