Possibly normative Halakha follows Rambam’s view, that in such a case there are grounds for coercion, and even if we accept the views of others that this an instance of a <i>get me’useh</i>, maybe a <i>get</i> mistakenly coerced is biblically valid. See <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:131 (1). Consequently, should a <i>sefek sefeka</i> emerge <i>ex post facto</i> regarding the execution of a <i>get</i> in exchange for a wife’s waiving her <i>nezikin</i> award, Hatam Sofer would <i>a fortiori</i> agree that the <i>get</i> is valid.<br>Disagreeing with Hatam Sofer, <i>Hazon Ish</i>, supra n. 126 contends that given that the <i>beit din</i> overruled the Shulhan Aruch’s <i>psak</i>, which proscribes the meting of coercion in this case, therefore any executed <i>get</i> would be construed as a <i>get me’useh</i>. One may extrapolate from Hazon Ish’s view that a <i>beit din</i> that validates this couple’s exchange based on their perception of Halakha rather than intentionally transgressing it, should result that any executed <i>get</i> is valid <i>ex post facto</i>.<br>The question is whether a <i>sefek sefeka</i> will override a <i>hezkat issur of eishit ish,</i> a wife’s personal status that prohibits her to others. <i>Mikhtav me-Eliyahu</i>, op. cit<i>.</i>; <i>Sha’arei Torah</i>, op. cit.; R. Herzog, op. cit., explicitly follow the <i>Poskim</i> who argue that a <i>sefek sefeka</i> trumps a <i>hezkat issur</i>, endowed with the status of being forbidden such as <i>eishit ish</i> (a married woman). See <i>Ketuvot</i> 22b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:401; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i>, <i>EH</i> 43; <i>Badei ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>YD</i> 110 (277) in the name of <i>Maharit</i>, <i>Kereti u-Pleti</i>, and <i>Torat ha-Shelamin</i>.<br>Others contend that a <i>sefek sefeka</i> cannot override a <i>hezkat issur</i>. See <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 110:27, 29–30 and <i>Poskim</i> cited in <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 6, <i>EH</i> 3:9–15.<br>However, according to some <i>Poskim</i>, a <i>sefek sefeka</i> will neutralize a <i>hezkat issur</i> provided that there are other se<i>nifim</i> (lit. appendages), supporting reasons to be lenient. See <i>Teshuvot Maharshach</i> 1:7, 183; <i>Teshuvot Mahara Sasson</i> 4:9; <i>Teshuvot Maharhash</i> 4:56, 59. In our situation, we have offered additional reasons to validate a <i>get</i> executed under such circumstances <i>ex post facto</i> and consequently, the <i>sefek sefeka</i> should be determinative.<br>Implicit in our application of <i>sefek sefeka</i> to our situation is that it is predicated upon the notion that such a type of doubt may be determinative where there is a halakhic dispute. See <i>Teshuvot Ma’aset Binyamin</i> 56; <i>Pri Hadash</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 110, <i>Kelalei Sefek Sefeka</i>, 17; <i>Darkhei Teshuva</i> on <i>Tur</i>, <i>YD</i> 110:369. Cf. <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1276.<br>Thus, for all the aforesaid reasons, despite the fact that a wife was awarded monetary relief due to her inability to remarry and/or have children, any subsequent execution of a <i>get</i> ought to be recognized <i>ex post facto</i> by all segments of our Torah-observant community.</i> In other words, there may be uncertainties regarding the Halakha that stem from controversies amongst the earlier authorities that create a <i>sefek sefeka</i>, and one may rule leniently in such a situation. In our case, some contemporary <i>Poskim</i> may contend that the executed <i>get</i> is valid ex post facto due to the existence of a <i>sefek sefeka</i>. First, there is a <i>safek</i> whether awarding a <i>nezikin</i> claim for spousal abuse produces a <i>get me’useh shelo ka-din</i> and second, there is a <i>safek</i> whether a <i>get me’useh shelo ka-din</i> is null and void. Consequently, one should follow the lenient opinion of Rambam and others and conclude that the execution of a <i>get</i> under such circumstances is invalid, but not null and void. As R. S. Tzvi Gartner, a well-respected authority on <i>kefiyat get</i> and a veteran <i>dayan</i> of Monsey, NY and Yerushalayim writes,<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kefiya be-Get</i> 207. R. Yehuda Fris, another Yerushalmi <i>dayan</i>, arrives at a similar conclusion. See <i>Yad Yehuda</i>, <i>Hilkhot Gittin</i> 154:1, <i>s.v.</i> “<i>kelalei pesika be kefiyat-get.</i>”<br>Whether Rabbis Gartner and Fris would concur that there is a <i>safek</i> whether such a <i>nezikin</i> claim would produce a <i>get me’useh</i> we leave as an open question.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Some <i>Aharonim</i> have ruled against Rambam but there are those who state Rambam is not a minority opinion, and we should rely upon him for <i>sefek sefeka</i> to act leniently. Consequently, if a woman received <i>kiddushin</i> from another, she requires another <i>get</i>.</span>
Furthermore, the majority opinion that a monetary imposition constitutes <i>ones mamon</i> (monetary duress) and therefore its imposition creates a <i>get me’useh</i> which is null and void, is predicated upon the levying of an exorbitant sum of money by a <i>beit din</i>. However, if the <i>nezikin</i> award is a small amount, it is financially non-threatening and therefore it is permissible avoiding the strictures of a <i>get me’useh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">For further discussion what amount constitutes an <i>ones mamon</i>, see <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 41, 163–165.</i> Consequently, should we be dealing with a small award for spousal abuse, the question of a <i>get me’useh shelo ka-din ex post facto</i> does not come into question.
However, as we explained, even if we are dealing with a substantial monetary award, contemporary <i>Poskim</i> ought to either follow Rambam’s view, as others have done, and/or invoke a <i>sefek sefeka</i> which would validate a <i>get me’useh shelo ke-din be-diavad.</i>
Finally, even when there exists illicit coercion, it may be valid ex post facto if the couple is separated, in that the husband is exempt from providing food, clothing, and lodging, and is free to remarry. Under such circumstances accompanied by other arguments for permitting remarriage, R. Feinstein concludes that she can remarry.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 3:44.</i>
If a wive receives a <i>get</i> in exchange for waiving her right to a <i>nezikin</i> award, it is incumbent upon <i>Poskim</i> to refrain from deciding in a stringent fashion by invalidating the <i>get</i> lest one cast <i>“la-az al ha-Rishonim”</i> (aspersions upon the early Sages), even if Rambam’s view is possibly a minority opinion.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pri Hadash</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 496.</i> Furthermore, should one invalidate the <i>get</i>, it means that one is contesting the propriety of these executed divorces and any future offspring sired by either spouse who remarried would be impacted in terms of his personal status as a member of the Jewish community. Consequently, <i>Poskim</i> who argue that the <i>nezikin</i> award creates a <i>get me’useh</i> and claim that any resultant <i>get</i> is null and void ought to refrain from advancing their views to avoid the child having the halakhic stigma of a “<i>mamzer</i>” (a halakhic bastard).<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mayyim Amukim</i> 12; <i>Batei Knesiyot</i>, infra n. 143; <i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i>, <i>OH</i> 95; <i>Teshuvot Semikha le-Hayyim</i>, <i>OH</i> 1; <i>Sefer Tal Imrati</i>, 275–276.<br>If a <i>get</i> is executed under these conditions, and if subsequently remarriage occurs, it should be no worse than coercing a <i>get</i> based upon a wife’s <i>ma’is alai</i> (“he is repulsive to me”) plea, and if she subsequently remarries, we refrain from casting aspersions upon the <i>get ex post facto</i>. See <i>Teshuvot Rosh</i> 43:6; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 104; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:573; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 2:256; <i>Teshuvot Hut ha-Meshulash</i>, <i>Tur</i> 3, 35; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 154; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 17; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>EH</i> 69:23. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 41; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:5.</i> In effect, the consideration of <i>“la-az al ha-Rishonim”</i> is a relevant consideration regarding <i>ishut</i> (personal status) matters. Implicit in this approach is that in situations of <i>shev ve-al ta’aseh</i> (lit. “sit and do not act”), passive abrogation, a <i>Posek</i> may hand down a decision against the <i>get</i>; however, in a case of <i>kum ve-aseh</i> (lit. “arise and do”), an active abrogration, such as invalidating a <i>get</i>, he should refrain from deciding against it.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Get Pashut</i> 125:3; <i>Teshuvot Ein Mishpat</i> (Malki) 1; <i>Teshuvot Batei Kenesiyot</i> (Avraham ben Ezra) 1, <i>Beit Melo</i> 124; E. Shochetman, “The Concern for Relecting Unfavorably upon Earlier Decisors as a Factor in Halakhic Decision-Making,” (Hebrew), 18–19, 9 <i>Bar Ilan Yearbook</i>, 185–186, (5741).</i> Finally, there are numerous <i>Poskim</i> who contend that in matters of <i>issur ve-heter</i>, ritual law, including but not limited to the issuance of a <i>get</i>, one should refrain from rendering a judgment which would be “<i>la-az al ha-Rishonim</i>” in order to accord <i>kavod</i>, honor, to the early authorities.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Avkat Rohel</i> 212 and <i>Kesef Mishneh</i>, <i>Hilkhot Terumot u-Ma’asarot</i> 1:12; <i>Teshuvot Maharival</i> 3:14; <i>Magen Avraham</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 32:48; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 265; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>YD</i> 139. Cf. <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 43:6; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Pesahim</i> 50a; <i>Mayyim Amukim</i>, supra n. 142.</i> Their view would encompass even a situation of a husband and wife who were divorced subsequent to finalizing a private transaction as described above, and if either one decides to remarry in the future when there is no specter of halakhic stigma such as an impotent husband or an infertile wife, the <i>get</i> would be recognized. In fact, a contemporary <i>beit din</i> headed by R. Avraham Sherman mentioned approvingly a <i>psak</i> of R. Burdigo regarding the need to refrain from casting aspersions upon the propriety of a <i>get</i> that stems from a marriage that may have been a <i>kiddushin al tenai</i>, a conditional marriage and/or may be a <i>get me’useh</i>, letting the children be stigmatized as <i>mamzerim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mishpatim Yesharim</i> 1:117; File no. 9225-64-3, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, August 25, 2008.</i> Consequently, a contemporary <i>Posek</i> should abstain from issuing a <i>psak</i> invalidating a <i>get</i> given under the above conditions.
In sum, for all the aforesaid reasons, even if some <i>Poskim</i> reject the validity of such a <i>nezikin</i> award, any subsequent <i>get</i> rendered by a <i>beit din</i> ought to be recognized by all segments of our community.<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">In the event that the husband refuses to appear in <i>beit din</i> regarding the <i>nezikin</i> claim and the wife receives authorization from the <i>beit din</i> or a rabbinic authority to litigate this claim in civil court, and should the award comply with halakhic guidelines, should a <i>get</i> be executed it should subsequently be <i>pasul</i> rather than <i>batel</i>, even according to <i>Poskim</i> who argue that the <i>nezikin</i> award would create a <i>get me’useh shelo ka-din</i>. See <i>Kefiya be-Get</i>, 233.<br>For the legal-jurisprudential underpinnings for implementing this approach within the context of filing a tort claim against a recalcitrant husband in an American civil court, see Benjamin Shmueli, “Civil Actions for Acts that are Valid according to Religious Family Law but Harm Women’s Rights: Legal pluralism in Cases of Collision Between Two Sets of Laws,” 46 <i>Vanderbilt Journal of Transnational Law</i> 825, 847–852, 893–894 (May 2013).</i> Elsewhere, we arrived at a similar conclusion when dealing with a monetary award given to a wife who was unable to remarry and/or have children due to her husband’s recalcitrance in delivering a <i>get</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 41, 175; this writer’s, “Communications,” 46 <i>Tradition</i> 90–94 (Summer 2013).<br>Similarily, if a husband separates from his wife for a number of years and he fails either to support her or live with her, according to a 1987 ruling authored by a <i>Posek</i> of Antwerp, Beligium, one can coerce him to comply with his marital duties of <i>onah</i> or support or deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife. See <i>va-Ya’an Dovid</i>, supra n. 126 in the name of Rivash, Rosh, Tashbetz, Bezalel Ashkenazi, and Mabit. Here again we are dealing with an independent and free-standing claim to fulfill one’s marital obligations, otherwise a <i>get</i> must be granted. Consequently, <i>get</i> coercion in such an instance avoids the strictures of a <i>get me’useh</i>.</i> In effect, those <i>Poskim</i> who adopted <i>Rambam</i>’s position serve as one of the many examples that imbibes R. Moshe Feinstein’s <i>weltanschauung</i> that a rabbinic authority must render an autonomous judgment based upon his inquiry into the discussions found in the Talmud, commentaries, <i>sifrei psak</i>, and <i>te­shuvot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, Introduction to <i>OH</i>, <i>OH</i> 4:11</i>
In conclusion, an <i>agunah</i> who remarried under such conditions (waiving her right to such an award in exchange for receiving her <i>get</i>) is entitled to adhere to rabbinical guidance that follows the view that she is married.<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 32a, s.v. “<i>ma’tzati</i>”; <i>Sedei Hemed</i>, <i>Ma’arekhet Yud</i>, <i>kelal</i> 35; R. Zalman N. Goldberg, <i>Darkei ha-Psak</i> 21, n. 37.</i>

Chapter 4; An Employer's Vicarious Liability for an Employee's Sexual Misconduct

<b>An Employer’s Vicarious Liability for an Employee’s Sexual Misconduct</b><br>In recent years, some of the rabbis, teachers, administrators, and health care professionals who were employed by our <i>yeshivot</i>, synagogues, and youth organizations of the Orthodox Jewish community have been convicted of child abuse.
How ought Halakha deal today with a yeshiva in New York City that employs a Jewish administrator, principal, or teacher who abuses one of its Jewish students? Though in our presentation, we will be addressing sexual abuse, our conclusions are not limited to sexual abuse, but encompass other forms of harassment, including assault, bullying, hazing, and sexual harassment. In the event that a victim files <i>nezikin</i> (civil damage) claims against the abuser’s employer in <i>beit din</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">For an earlier discussion regarding the types of claims a victim of abuse may advance against his abuser in <i>beit din</i>, see ch. 3 of this monograph.<br>The assumption of our presentation is that either the perpetrator has been criminally convicted by a court, or that the <i>beit din</i> will assess whether in fact he/she is an abuser. Once this determination has been rendered by a civil court or <i>a beit din</i>, the <i>beit din</i> would proceed to address the issue of the employer’s monetary liability for the employee’s sexual misbehavior.</i> the question arises whether the yeshiva is responsible to pay the victim of abuse.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">For earlier treatments of the issue of employer liability relating to <i>nezikin</i> (injury) see Shillem Warhaftig, <i>Jewish Labor Law</i> (Hebrew), Yerushalayim, 1969, 929-951; Haim Hefetz, “Vicarious Liability in Jewish Law,” (Hebrew), 6 <i>Dinei Yisrael</i> 49 (5735); <i>Iyunim be-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 44; Michael Wygoda, <i>Agency Law: Section 11</i>, Yerushalayim: Ministry of Justice. Many of the sources for sections 1–2 of this presentation have been culled from the aforementioned studies.<br>Even if the yeshiva has been incorporated, the corporate entity and its employees may be respectively institutionally and personally liable for any <i>nezikin</i> claims. See this writer’s <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, 65–110.</i> Are there grounds for a victim of abuse to file a claim that he suffered diminished educational opportunities and educational accomplishments, diminished wages and salaries, as well as a non-economic claim for pain and suffering, against the employer of the abuser?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Whether all these particular <i>nezikin</i> claims are valid grounds for monetary damages in Halakha is beyond the scope of our presentation. Alternatively, parties may choose to opt for resolving their matters in accordance with secular law. For the halakhic underpinnings for such an arrangement, see <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 2, 197–199.</i> Should in fact the institution be held responsible, we would in effect be invoking the notion of vicarious liability (or <i>respondeat superior</i>, lit. “the superior must answer”) which means that Halakha would hold an individual responsible for the misconduct of another, even though the individual is free from recklessness, personal blame, or fault, and is, in that sense, “innocent” of any wrongdoing. The modern justification for <i>respondeat superior</i> within the context of labor relations is that the employer chooses the worker, he controls the work and profits, and therefore he should also have to bear the risk, as he is in better position to absorb losses than his employee and therefore will be financially able to compensate for such injuries.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Rochelle R. Weber, “Scope of Employment Redefined: Holding Employers Vicariously Liable for Sexual Assaults Committed by their Employees,” 76 <i>Minnesota Law Rev.</i> 1513, 1519–1520 (1992).</i> Secondly, should a yeshiva or, for that matter, any Jewish institution which services the needs of our children, be halakhically treated in the same fashion in terms of responsibility as an employer who is concerned about a third party’s entrance into the workplace? Finally, is the yeshiva liable for acts of an employee’s abuse even when the yeshiva has exercised reasonable care to correct and prevent any such misconduct?
<b>I. An Employer’s Responsibility for Bodily Injury Caused to his Employee</b>
In the absence of an employer’s negligent behavior causing the injury, the threshold question is whether the employer is responsible for any bodily injury caused to his employee. If in fact, the employer is not liable, then there would be no grounds to even consider whether an employer ought to be responsible for injury caused to a third party, such as a student abused by an administrator or teacher in a school setting.
Addressing the <i>mitzva</i> of erecting a <i>ma’akeh</i>, a parapet on one’s roof, and the prohibition against standing idly by someone’s death, Sefer ha-Hinukh writes,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Hinukh</i>, <i>mitzvat aseh</i> 538.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We realize that the Almighty, in his divine providence, knows exactly what will happen to every man, whether good or bad, decreeing according to his merits … Nevertheless, man must take all necessary precautions in every circumstance, for God created a world which follows the laws of nature: Fire burns and water extinguishes a flame … Likewise, someone falling of a high rooftop will die … Since by divine wisdom, our bodies … are subject to the laws of nature, He has commanded us to take all necessary precautions …</span>
As Rambam states,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Mitzvot</i>, <i>mitzvat aseh</i> 184.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We have been commanded to remove all obstacles and danger from our homes and therefore we have to construct a wall to encircle the roof and around our pits … in order that no one may fall into them.</span>
Strikingly, the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>ma’akeh</i> extends beyond the duty to construct a fence upon one’s roof. As Sefer ha-Hinukh aptly notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Hinukh</i>, supra n. 5.</i> “The fact that Torah mentions ‘your roof’ – the Torah speaking in the usual case.”
In other words, the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>ma’akeh</i> is to serve as a paradigm for dealing with multifarious life situations beyond the actual building of a fence around a roof to avoid risk and danger to human life.
Sensitive to this understanding of the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>ma’akeh</i>, already Rabbi Nathan in the Talmud exhorts us,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Kama</i> 15b.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">One who raises a wild dog or uses a rickety ladder in one’s home transgresses the verse “one should not place blood in one’s home.”</span>
The commandment to provide a safe environment for both occupants of one’s home and third parties is not limited to one’s rooftop, but extends to raising a wild animal or using a rickety ladder in one’s residence. The violation of “one should not place blood in one’s home” (Devarim 22:8) extends beyond the failure to place a fence around one’s roof and encompasses the failure to monitor one’s pets as well as being derelict in maintaining the utility and safety of objects found in one’s home such as a ladder.
Noncompliance with the duty of constructing a <i>ma’akeh</i> entails the nullification of a positive commandment to construct a fence, as well as the negative commandment of “one should not place blood in one’s home.”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rambam</i>, <i>Sefer ha-Mitzvot</i>, <i>mitzvat aseh</i> 184; <i>mitzvat lo ta’seh</i> 298.</i> As such, the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>ma’akeh</i> is a halakhic-moral obligation, which is usually unenforceable by a <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 410:4; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Uziel</i>, <i>HM</i> 44.</i>
Following in the footsteps of R. Nathan and the Sefer ha-Hinukh and realizing that the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>ma’akeh</i> is a halakhic-moral obligation that encompasses multifarious situations, R. Epstein and R. Uziel contend that hazardous materials found in the workplace are to be regulated based upon the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>ma’akeh</i>. In other words, the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>ma’akeh</i> is not limited to protecting an individual in one’s home, but equally extends to one’s place of employment. Moreover, as we noted, it is <i>mitzva</i> with no halakhic-legal consequences. Therefore, in order to be able to hold an employer halakhically-legally accountable for bodily injuries caused to one’s employees by hazardous materials found in the workplace, R. Epstein and R. Uziel suggest that one must invoke the <i>nezikin</i> (injury) claim of <i>bor</i>, a pit.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i> and <i>Mishpetei Uziel</i>, supra n.10</i> The claim of <i>bor</i> covers scenarios in which an obstacle is created by an individual’s negligence, and another person is injured. The classic example is that of a person who digs a pit in a public thoroughfare, leaves it uncovered, and an animal falls into it.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shemot</i> 21:33–34</i> Adopting the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>bor</i> as the avenue for addressing an employer’s liability for the injury caused by potentially hazardous material in the workplace will depend on whether the employer’s permission to allow the worker to enter the workplace <i>ipso facto</i> means that he assumes responsibility for an employer’s claim of <i>nezikin</i>. This issue is a matter of halakhic debate.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 398:5; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 389:10.</i> For those <i>Poskim</i> who argue that the employee’s entry into the workplace means that his employer assumes responsibility for any injury caused to the employee, then based upon <i>hilkhot bor</i>, the employer may be mandated by a <i>beit din</i> to pay for the injury. On the other hand, for those <i>Poskim</i> who contend that a worker’s entry into the work place does not assume an employer’s willingness to compensate the employee for potential injury, a <i>beit din</i> may not obligate him to pay damages. In short, whether an employer is responsible vis-à-vis the employee for exposure to hazardous materials in the workplace is subject to debate.
However, is an employer liable for directing an employee to engage in actual work that entails a danger to him? For example, knowing that an employee worked for their enemy, an employer’s creditors attack the employee, injure him and steal the merchandise. In this case, R. Yosef Trani obligates the employer to compensate his employee for his losses, which were caused by the employer’s negligence.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 2:156.</i> Said conclusion was drawn by R. Trani’s inference from Rashba’s posture,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhasot la-Ramban</i> 20.</i> a view which was subsequently endorsed by R. Moshe Isserles.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:48.</i> And in fact, a few other <i>Poskim</i> concur that in cases of an employer’s negligence, he is responsible to pay for the bodily injury incurred by the employee.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, <i>HM</i> 176; <i>Teshuvot Bnei Binyamin</i> (Navon), <i>HM</i> 35.</i> However, given that the employer did not assume responsibility to protect his employee’s bodily integrity, and given that many decisors reject the notion that an individual may be a <i>shomer</i> of the bodily integrity of another individual, many <i>Poskim</i> demur and contend therefore that he is exempt from liability.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 89:4; <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 96; <i>Taz</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:48; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 176:60; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, s<i>horesh</i> 131; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 435; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i>, <i>OH</i> 34; <i>Teshuvot Tzemach Tzedek</i> 6; <i>Teshuvot Gur Arye Yehuda</i>, <i>HM</i> 18; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 11:21.<br>However, some decisors argue that an employer is liable according to <i>dinei shamayim</i>, the laws of heaven, or <i>midat hassidut</i>, the standard of saintliness. See <i>Noda be-Yehuda</i>, op. cit<i>.</i>; <i>Gur Arye Yehuda</i>, op. cit.; <i>Maharashdam</i>, op. cit.<br>Alternatively, R. Schwadron contends that a <i>peshara</i> should be brokered regarding the matter. See <i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, supra n. 17.<br>Regarding authorities who reject the idea that an individual can be a <i>shomer</i> of someone else’s body, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhasot la-Ramban</i>, 20; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 89:4; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 435; <i>Taz</i>, op. cit.; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, op. cit.</i> In short, in the event that there is no negligence on the part of the employer in the employee’s bodily injury or the injury to the laborer failed to transpire during the time of employment, many <i>Poskim</i> argue that the employer is exempt from responsibility.
Implicit in this conclusion is that liability for one’s behavior rests with the one who causes the injury rather than a third party, even when it is in a position of authority. Dating back to the time of the Second Beit ha-Mikdash (Temple), we encounter that the <i>Perushim</i> (the Pharisees), those who accepted the teachings of our Oral Law, and the <i>Tzedukim</i> (the Sadducees), those who rejected their rulings, already debated whether in fact Judaism accepts the notion of an employer’s vicarious liability for his employee’s actions. Recounting this controversy, the Mishnah in <i>Yadayim</i> informs us,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Yadayim</i> 4:7.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The <i>Tzedukim</i> said: We are protesting against you <i>Perushim</i>. If you argue that my ox and donkey who are exempt from <i>mitzvot</i>, that I am liable for the injury it caused, likewise my bondsman and bondswoman that are obligated in <i>mitzvot</i>, isn’t it clear that I would be obligated to pay for the injury they caused? They replied to them: No – If you say this regarding my ox and donkey who are bereft of intelligence, should we likewise say the same regarding my bondsman and bondswoman who possess intelligence? For if I anger them, they may go out and set on fire someone’s stack and I shall be liable to pay.</span>
In other words, according to the <i>Perushim</i>, the servant’s master is not liable for the damage caused by the servant.
Subscribing to the <i>Perushim</i>’s view, post-Talmudic authorities such as Tosafot and Meiri conclude that even if the slave intended to harm another individual, his master is not responsible for any ensuing damage.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 4a, s.v. “<i>lav</i>”; <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 4a.</i> Similarly, if a servant steals, his master is not duty-bound to pay for the theft.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 349.</i> The concept of individual responsibility is not limited to a master-servant relationship, but extends equally to halakhic marital ties. As Mishnah instructs us, though during her marriage a wife who injures somebody is exempt to pay for the injury caused,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Her nonpayment relates to a wife’s matrimonial property rights, which is a matter beyond the scope of our presentation.</i> nonetheless, upon divorce she is obligated to pay from her assets.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Kama</i> 87a.</i> Or should the wife own assets during the marriage that are not under the husband’s control, she must remit compensation during the marriage.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 424:14.</i> In short, a wife is responsible for the damage she caused to others.
The responsibility of a wife as well as a slave for damages is a reflection of the general rule that if Levi instructs Yehuda to violate Halakha and Yehuda does so, Yehuda is liable and Levi is not. For example, if Levi tells Yehuda to dig a pit, which Yehuda does, and Moshe falls into the pit and is injured, Yehuda is liable.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 410:8.</i> Or, to give another example: An owner of hops entrusted his hops to a <i>shomer</i> (bailee) who has his own hops, and the <i>shomer</i> instructed his servant to put some hops into the beer, pointing to his own hops. However, the servant inadvertently placed the bailor’s hops into the beer instead. Subsequently, the bailor sued to recover the value of his hops. <i>Shulhan Arukh</i> rules that the <i>shomer</i> is exempt from responsibility. The servant is also not obligated to pay since his master, the <i>shomer</i>, did not specifically instruct him to put these hops in and not the others. Since the bailee’s instructions to place “some hops into the beer” were unclear in regard to whose hops, the servant is not liable to pay.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:25.</i> Obviously, had the <i>shomer</i>’s instructions been clear and had the servant failed to comply with them, the servant would have been obligated to pay for the value of the hops. Here again, Halakha recognizes the notion of individual responsibility for one’s behavior. The one exception to the rule of individual responsibility is that a minor who engages in <i>nezikin</i> is exempt from responsibility when he attains majority age.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">However, should the minor benefit from the injury caused, then he must compensate. See <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 1:177.<br>Even though a minor is exempt from payment, nevertheless for educational reasons, a <i>beit din</i> is authorized to monetarily penalize a minor who is a <i>mazik.</i> See <i>Shevut Ya’akov</i>, ibid.; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i>, 1:432.</i> But here again, this exception is understandable and reflects the halakhic affirmation of individual responsibility. Since the act of <i>nezikin</i> was committed during a period when a minor is exempt from <i>mitzvot</i>, and responsibility only commences for actions done when one reaches majority age, therefore a minor is exempt from liability even upon attaining the age of majority.
In short, the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>ma’akeh</i> instructs us that an individual Jew must provide a safe environment that will minimize the exposure to risk. Secondly, the concept of individual responsibility undergirds the interaction between individuals, including but not limited to master-servant ties, spousal relationships, bailment matters, and relationships with minors. In sum, in responding to the question of whether an individual is responsible for the damage caused by someone else, the Talmudic reply is “an individual is obligated to protect his own body.” <sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Kama</i> 4a.</i>
<b>II. An Employer’s Responsibility for Injury Caused by his Employee</b>
A similar conclusion that we found regarding injury caused to the employee may be found in the context of an employer’s responsibility for injury caused <i>by his worker</i>. For example, in a <i>baraita</i> we encounter the following teaching,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 118b.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Our Rabbis taught: Once the quarryman has delivered [the stones for building] to the chiseler [for polishing and smoothing], the latter is responsible [for any damage caused by them]; the chiseler having delivered them to the hauler, the latter is responsible; the hauler having delivered to the porter, the latter is responsible; the porter delivers the stones to the bricklayer, the latter is responsible; the bricklayer delivers them to the foreman (to set the stones in place), the latter is responsible. But if after he had placed the stone properly in place, it caused damage, all are responsible. But has it not been taught: only the last is responsible, while the others are exempt? – There is no difficulty – the second refers to a laborer, the first case to an independent contractor.</span>
Addressing the situation of injury caused to the employer or a third party by a laborer, the <i>baraita</i> directs its attention to whether the other workers who are employed on the same project are responsible to pay for the damages caused. Does it make a difference whether we are dealing with a group of contractors who are being compensated for a project or a group of wage earners who are paid by the hour?<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">For this distinction between a laborer and contractor, see <i>Rashi</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 112b, s.v. “<i>kablanut</i>”; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sekhirut</i> 9:4; <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 333:5. For additional analysis towards defining the relationship between an employer and a laborer, see Berachyahu Lifshitz, <i>Employee and Independent Contractor: Acquisitions and Obligations in Contract</i>, (Hebrew), Yerushalayim 1993.</i> The Tannaitic reply is that if the damage was directly caused by a worker, regardless of whether we are dealing with workers who earn an hourly wage or contractors who are compensated based upon the completion of a project, liability resides solely with the <i>mazik</i>, the tortfeasor. As the aforementioned <i>baraita</i> states,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i>, supra n. 29.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Once the quarryman has delivered [the stones for building] to the chiseler [for polishing and smoothing], the latter is responsible [for any damage caused to a third party].</span>
And such a conclusion is seen as authoritative amongst the authorities.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 118b; <i>Ra’avad</i>, <i>Bava Metzia Shita Mekubetzet</i> 118b.</i> Accordingly, if the actual damage transpired after the worker completed his job, then one must distinguish between a group of laborers and a group of contractors. Concerning the latter group of contractors, given that they all were partners in this enterprise and were jointly responsible for any ensuing damage, they all are jointly responsible to pay for the damages. However, a wage earner is hired to perform a particular job, and therefore only the last one will be liable.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ra’avad</i>, supra n. 32; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 384:4.</i>
On the other hand, in addressing a scenario of a contractor causing damage, the Mishnah in Bava Metzia instructs us,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Kama</i> 98b.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If a builder undertook to remove a wall and broke the stones or damaged someone,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">See textual variant found in <i>Dikdukei Soferim</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 98b; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 9:14; <i>Rashash</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 98b.</i> he would be liable to pay.</span>
Accordingly, if a builder is contracted to demolish the wall, and he breaks the stones during the dismantling or injures a passerby, the builder is liable. The inference drawn from this Mishnaic ruling is that if we are dealing with a builder who has been hired on a per diem basis, if he causes property damage or he himself injures a third party from the dismantling of the stones, the employer as well as the employee would be jointly responsible in paying damages.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Nizkei Mamon</i> 13:18; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 384:4.</i> The rationale is that an employer will supervise his wage earner’s job and therefore he is responsible for any <i>nezek</i> (damage) that was done by his laborer during his employment while working with his employer’s property. On the other hand, an employer has neither control nor the capacity to supervise a contractor’s work; therefore, he is exempt for any <i>nezek</i> committed by his employee. Clearly, should an employer of a group of contractors undertake to accept joint responsibility for damages incurred in the <i>baraita</i> case, he would share in the liability.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nimukei Yosef</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 118b; <i>Ra’avad</i>, supra n. 32.</i> However, should the pain continue to persist after the actual injury, the laborer is solely responsible for the damages.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Nofet Tzufim</i> (Burdugo), vol. 1, <i>HM</i> 395.</i>
As is aptly noted by R. Sha’anan, a <i>dayan</i> who served on Tel Aviv’s <i>beit din</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iyunim be-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 44 (463).</i> the aforementioned Mishnah and subsequent halakhic discussions are silent regarding employer’s liability for other types of <i>nezek</i>, such as the case of an employee who during the performance of work tramples on another person’s property located on the work site. Moreover, there is silence regarding whether employer liability extends to an employee who assaults or sexually abuses a coworker or a third party while on the job. It seems that in these instances, sole responsibility for such misconduct resides with the laborer. Consequently, it would seem a principal or teacher who abuses his student is solely liable for his own misbehavior. In fact, assuming a particular state permits corporal punishment of students by teachers, if a teacher utilizes excessive force in attempting to educate a student, he, rather than the employer, is responsible to pay for damages.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 50a; <i>Gittin</i> 31a; <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 245:9. For further discussion regarding this issue, see this writer’s “Corporal Punishment in School: A Study in the Interaction of Halakha and American Law with Social Morality,” 37 <i>Tradition</i> 57 (Fall 2003).</i> But, is a student in a yeshiva setting to be treated halakhically like a third party in the conventional workplace?
<b>III. The Halakhic Mandate for a Safe Workplace</b>
If in fact, the yeshiva, as the employer, is exempt from responsibility for any monetary claims advanced by the victim of abuse against one of the yeshiva’s employees; does that mean the yeshiva is absolved from introducing policies of hiring, supervision, and training dealing with sexual misconduct, which would hopefully create a safe environment for students? Firstly, Halakha is concerned for the victim of abuse, and ensuring that abuse does not take place must be of primary concern. In addition, the establishment and employment of such policies serve as a concrete articulation of our covenanted responsibility of <i>arevut</i>, guaranteeing that our fellow Jew observes Halakha.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Devarim</i> 9:9–14.<i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 19.</i> Obviously, engaging in child abuse in any shape or form of improper touching or fondling is a halakhic violation.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 20:1; <i>Beit Shmuel</i> and <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, ad locum.</i> Hence, an employer, similar to every individual Jew is duty-bound to ensure that his employees are engaging in proper conduct, and thus must introduce policies with the aim of preventing employees and third parties from working in a sexually hostile environment.
Moreover, our duty to promote a safe worksite is underscored by our mandated love of our fellow man, as Sefer ha-Hinukh observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Hinukh</i>, <i>mitzvat aseh</i> 219.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">One should act with his friend as he is accustomed to behave for himself, to protect his property and to prevent that injuries befall him … If he injures his property or pains him, he has transgressed this positive commandment.</span>
Consequently, the <i>weltanschauung</i> of Halakha based upon the notion of love of our fellowman and <i>arevut</i> would entail that the employer properly screen his potential employees by interviewing them and contacting their references. And once employed, the employee ought to be supervised and receive training in proper sexual behavior.
Furthermore, Halakha is not merely concerned with the prevention of improper sexual misconduct in the workplace. Failure for a yeshiva or any Jewish institution for that matter to deal with actual abusive behavior occurring under their watch entails a violation of “And thou shall restore it to him.” Summarizing the interplay between <i>mitzva</i> of <i>lo ta’amod al dam re’ekha</i>, the obligation to assist somebody in peril, and “And thou shall restore it to him,” the duty to restore a lost object to its owner, R. J. David Bleich writes,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Judaism and Healing</i>, Ktav: NY 1981, 1, 3–4.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The obligation to save the life of an endangered person is derived … from the verse “Nor shall you stand idly by the blood of your fellow …” The Talmud and the various codes of Jewish law offer specific examples of situations in which a moral obligation exists with regard to rendering aid. These include the rescue of a person drowning in a river, assistance to one being mauled by wild beasts, and aid to a person under attack by bandits …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">This obligation is predicated upon the scriptural exhortation with regard to the restoration of lost property, “And you shall restore it to him” … On the basis of a pleonasm in the Hebrew text, the Talmud declares that this verse includes an obligation to restore a fellow-man’s body as well as his property …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">A latter day authority, R. Yehudah Leib Zirelson, in his Teshuvot Atzei ha-Levanon, no. 61 argues cogently that the obligations posited by the Gemara … apply under non-life threatening circumstances no less than in life-threatening situations. The verse “And you shall restore it to him” … mandates not only the return of lost property, but <i>a fortiori</i>, preservation of life as well … Accordingly, declares Atzei ha-Levanon, restoration of health to a person suffering from an illness is assuredly included in the commandment “And you shall restore it to him.”</span>
In short, the divine imperative of “And thou shall restore it to him” is not limited to the recovery of lost objects but equally encompasses the restoration of psychological well being, as well as physical health, of a fellow Jew.
This obligation is enforceable, as is evident from the immunity granted to the rescuer for any injury committed during the saving of the recued party. Additionally, despite the fact that the rescuer has the right to sue the rescued party for any financial expenses incurred during the rescue operation,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 264; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 265; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 267:26, 380:4.</i> nonetheless, the failure to restore health does not result in any legal consequences.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Rotze’ach u-Shemirat ha-Nefesh</i> 1:14, 16.</i> The duty is a halakhic-moral obligation that a Jew must comply with in order to fulfill the requirements of Heaven, i.e., <i>hayav be-dinei shamayim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>din shamayim</i>, which generally cannot be dealt with by an earthly Jewish court, may be addressed in a <i>beit din</i> under certain prescribed conditions. See Yoezer Ariel, <i>Dinei Borerut</i>, 174, 188–190.</i>
To state it differently, a Jewish institution is not only obligated based upon the norms of love of one’s fellowman and <i>arevut</i> to professionally create and implement policies regarding hiring, which entails background checking and fingerprinting, supervising, and training of employees regarding sexual misconduct. Employee training should deal with such matters as meeting alone with students, appropriate physical contact, suitable topics of conversation, and going to students’ homes and having students in their homes. Implicit in such a mandate is that the yeshiva as an employer is duty-bound to serve as a <i>shomer</i> over the bodily integrity of its students.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 359, 461; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:48; <i>Maharik</i>, supra n. 18; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot To’ein ve-Nit’an</i> 5:2. One of the primary objections to this view is that <i>hilkhot shomerim</i> is conventionally understood as limited to the guarding of movable objects rather than human beings. See <i>Shemot</i> 22:6–9; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 227:19; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 176:48. For an employer’s liability as a <i>shomer</i>, see infra nn. 105–107.<br>Whether the institution and the employee serve as an <i>apotropus</i>, a guardian vis-à-vis the children, is beyond the scope of our presentation.</i> Any suspicion of sexual abuse should be recorded and investigated, and the individual should be monitored. As we have seen, whereas the halakhot of labor relations preempt an employer’s responsibility for bodily injury caused by his employee to a third party, here, when dealing with an institution that is servicing children and therefore acting in a custodial, caretaker capacity, they mandate that certain administrative policies be established and implemented.
Moreover, should an actual act of abuse occur, prompt action ought to be taken against the employee by discharge based upon the halakhic imperative of “and you shall restore it to him,” i.e., insuring the psychological health of the victim of abuse. Finally, assuming there is a credible allegation of abuse and there are reasonable grounds that the abuse transpired (“<i>raglayim le-davar</i>”) or actual knowledge of an act of abuse, the employer must comply with the mandated reporting laws of the state where the abuse occurred, and if required by law, ought to notify the civil authorities regarding the incident.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shita Mekubetzet</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 83b in the name of <i>Ritva</i>; R. Sinai Adler, <i>Devar Sinai</i>, (Yerushalayim: 5760), 45–46 (R. Elyashiv’s opinion); “A Treatise Regarding Your Friend’s Blood” (Hebrew), 15 <i>Yeshurun</i> 634, 641 (5765) (R. Elyashiv’s opinion), <i>Nishmat Avraham</i>, vol. 4, 207, 210 (R. Elyashiv’s opinion). See also <i>Nishmat Avraham</i>, vol. 4, 207, 208 (R. Waldenburg’s opinion).<br>However, if the alleged abuse was based upon flimsy evidence, such as a suspicion or rumor, there would be no grounds for contacting the civil authorities.<br>Implicit in the permissibility to contact the civil authorities is that there exists no prohibition of <i>mesirah</i>, of informing to a government, which conducts itself by the rule of law such as a democracy. See <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 388:7; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 19:52.<br>However, there are some <i>Poskim</i> who contend that the interdict against <i>mesira</i> applies when one causes a Jew to be incarcerated and the punishment for the particular offense is more severe than Halakha prescribes. See <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:8, 5:9; <i>Teshuvot Helkat Ya’akov</i>, <i>HM</i> 5 (new edition). Cf. <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 83b.<br>Nonetheless, the prohibition is inapplicable to an individual who is a danger to society, such as a pedophile. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 388:12; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 388:59.</i> The aforementioned policies represent what may be best described as a yeshiva’s zero tolerance policy vis-à-vis employees who may be or who are child predators. These administrative guidelines concretize how to fulfill our obligations of love of one’s fellowman, <i>arevut</i>, rebuke, and active intervention to assist a fellow human being in peril, and thus transform the unconcerned ruggedly individualistic American Jewish bystander into a Jew fulfilling his covenantal imperatives of care for the plight of one’s fellow Jew.
Furthermore, failure to employ a policy of dismissal entails a violation of <i>afrushei me-issura</i>, which minimally is a violation of a rabbinic prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Hiddushei ha-Ran</i>, <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Shabbat</i> 3a.</i> or maximally a transgression of a biblical interdict.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishnah Berura</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i>, <i>Sha’ar ha-Tziyun</i> 347:8.</i> As a member of our covenant-faith community, a Jewish employer, like every Jew, has a duty to prevent the commission of a transgression (<i>le-afrushei me-issura</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sdei Hemed</i>, <i>Ma’arekhet ha-Vav</i>, <i>kelal</i> 26 (3).<br>There is a dispute whether <i>afrushei me-issura</i> is limited to an <i>issur</i> (prohibition) being committed in one’s home and one’s <i>reshut</i> (domain), or whether the obligation to prevent another individual’s transgression extends to a situation in which the <i>issur</i> potentially could be transgressed outside of one’s home and domain. See <i>Imrei Bina</i>, <i>Hilkhot Dayanim</i> 9; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 3:1; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 3:1. Given that the potential for transgression of <i>issur</i> here deals with an employee who is working in an employer’s facility, it would seem that even <i>Imrei Bina</i>, who generally limits invoking the <i>issur</i> beyond one’s home, would argue that such a situation is equivalent to having the potential <i>issur</i> being violated in one’s home and would concur with Ketzot ha-Hoshen and Netivot ha-Mishpat that it is incumbent upon the employer to prevent the occurrence of such <i>issurim</i>.</i> The interdict of <i>afrushei me-issura</i> is grounded either in our covenanted responsibility of <i>arevut</i>, the obligation to guarantee that our fellow Jew observes Halakha,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 19.</i> or based upon in the mitzva of admonishing a neighbor who is straying from the dictates of the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ketav Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 83.</i> To allow an employee who is under suspicion of being an abuser or is actually engaging in pedophilia to roam the workplace without supervision and accountability is a travesty.
In sum, based upon the foregoing presentation, the yeshiva, as an employer, is halakhically obligated to implement certain administrative policies to ensure a safe environment for its students. Yet, should abusive behavior be perpetrated by one of its employees, a yeshiva that has implemented such policies, similar to any employer, would not be vicariously liable for his worker’s sexual misconduct.
<b>IV. “<i>Dina de-Malkhuta Dina</i>” – An Avenue towards the Recognition of an Employer’s Vicarious Liability</b>
The remaining question is whether there are any halakhic grounds to hold an employer who implemented such policies liable for an employee’s sexual misconduct? Clearly, should a labor agreement or an insurance policy deal with an employee’s liability for injury caused by the employee, the agreement dictates the conditions and scope of institutional responsibility for such <i>hezek</i> perpetrated by the employee. However, in the absence of an agreement addressing this issue, is an employer responsible? Will an employer always be held responsible for employee sexual misconduct, or will he be exempt from liability should he demonstrate that hiring, supervisory, and retention policies were in place at the time of the alleged act of abuse?
Given that the abuse transpired in New York City, seemingly the doctrine of “<i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>,” lit. “the law of the kingdom is the law,”<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 28a; <i>Gittin</i> 10b; <i>Bava Kama</i> 113a–b; <i>Bava Batra</i> 54b–55a.</i> may serve as an avenue for a the victim to file suit in <i>beit din</i> against his abuser. In accordance with Rema, which is the accepted view amongst the majority of <i>Poskim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Doveiv Meisharim</i> 1:76.</i> <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> is applicable to all matters that fall under the rubric of “<i>le-takanat bnei ha-medina</i>,” for the benefit of the citizenry.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 73:14, 369:11.</i> As understood by <i>Rema</i> elsewhere,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 369. And, in fact, scattered throughout his <i>Hoshen Mishpat</i> rulings, <i>Rema</i> offers concrete examples of applying civil law to instances involving social interaction. See <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 73:14, 154:18, 356:7, 369:11.</i> any legislation relating to social interaction is to be subsumed in the category of <i>le-takanat bnei ha-medina</i>, and therefore requires Jewish compliance. In contemporary times, legislation relating to labor relations is one of the many examples of a law that is <i>le-takanat bnei ha-medina</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 106/5756, Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit</i> v. <i>Va’ad ha-Hinukh shel Agudath Yisrael</i> (unpublished decision); File no. 5513-35-1, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit</i> v. <i>Ploni</i>, August 11, 2005; File no. 1323-35-1, Ashdod Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni</i> v. <i>Menahel Mosad Almoni</i>, July 13, 2008.</i> Numerous Israeli <i>dayanim</i> including Rabbis Izrirer, Sherman, and Tzadok<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 1323-35-1, supra n. 59; File no. 8085481, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Mosdot Plonim v. Plonit</i>, September 16, 2009.</i> invoke Rema’s approach in halakhically recognizing civil labor law. It is clear in these cases that our desire to foster a sexually safe working environment facilitates proper social interaction. As such, seemingly the doctrine of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> may serve as a vehicle for addressing whether Halakha ought to recognize an employer’s vicarious liability in cases of an employee’s sexual misconduct.
Let’s briefly present how New York courts have dealt with employer’s vicarious liability as it relates to sexual harassment and abuse. A review of the law in New York City will demonstrate how our matter has been resolved differently in the late 1990s in comparison to more recent years. Sexual harassment claims, including but not limited to sexual abuse, have been resolved in New York in pursuance to the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended by the Civil Rights Act of 1991 (“Title VII”) and the New York City Human Rights Law (“NYCHRL”) which is codified in part in the New York City Administrative Code.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">New York City Administrative Code, section 8-107.</i> Various New York courts have noted that claims brought under NYCHRL are to be resolved in the same fashion as claims advanced under Federal Title VII and have been rendered in accordance with two United State Supreme Court decisions.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Fierro v. Saks Fifth Avenue</i>, 13 F. Supp. 2d 481, 487 (SDNY 1998); <i>Moore v. Sam’s Club, et al.</i>, 55 F. Supp. 2d 177 (1999); <i>Wahlstrom v. Metro-North Commuter Railroad Co</i>., 89 F. Supp. 2d 506, 523 (SDNY 2000); <i>Duviella v. Counseling Service of Eastern Dist. Of NY</i>, 52 Fed. Appx. 152, 153 (2d Cir. 2002); <i>Kercado-Clymer v. City of Amsterdam</i>, <i>et al.</i> 608 F. Supp. 203 (2009).</i> In 1998, the United States Supreme Court in two separate decisions, <i>Faragher v. Boca Raton</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">524 US 775 (1998).</i> and <i>Burlington Industries, Inc. v. Ellerth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">524 US 742 (1998).</i> furnishes the guidelines that shield the employer from federal sexual harassment claims. Assuming the plaintiff has proven sexual harassment by an employee who exercised managerial or supervisory responsibility, the employer must prove that (1) he exercised reasonable care to prevent and correct any harassment; (2) action was taken against the offending employee (e.g., discharge, demotion, or undesirable reassignment), and (3) made use of any preventive and corrective mechanisms to avoid the harm. Upon demonstrating compliance with these safeguards, the employer was exempt from responsibility for his employee’s misbehavior. These guidelines were endorsed by NY courts.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Fierro v. Saks Fifth Avenue</i>, 13 F. Supp. 2d 481 (1998); <i>Ehrens v. Lutheran Church</i>, 385 F. 3d 232 (2d Cir. 2004); <i>Vione v. Tewell</i>, 12 Misc. 3d 973, 820 NYS 2d 682 (NY Sup. Ct. 2006)</i>
In effect, these secular legal guidelines are a concretization of the notions <i>of arevut</i>, love of one’s fellow man, <i>afrushei me-issura</i>, and “and you shall restore it to him,” which, if implemented, serve to promote a work environment which is free of sexual harassment and abuse.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">See infra n. 75.</i>
Applying the <i>Farager-Ellerth</i> guidelines to our scenario, should student abuse have occurred in 2008 at the hands of a New York City yeshiva principal or teacher <sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">An individual qualifies as a supervisor if he or she is authorized to hire, fire, promote, demote, and reassign the employee, or if his recommendation is given substantial weight by the final decision maker(s). See <i>Ellerth</i>, 118 S. Ct. at 2269.<br>Furthermore, even if that individual is not empowered to change a person’s employment status, such as to hire and fire, if he is authorized to direct another employee’s day-to-day work activities, he or she qualifies as a supervisor. See <i>Faragher</i>, 118 S. Ct. at 2280. As such, a teacher would qualify as a supervisor.</i> and the school had established and implemented hiring, supervision, and retention polices concerning abuse, the yeshiva would have been exempt from liability. However, if the yeshiva was negligent regarding any one of these policies, in light of New York court decisions, a <i>beit din</i> invoking the doctrine of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> may have imputed responsibility to the yeshiva and the school would be required to pay civil damages. Placing an employee in a position to cause foreseeable harm, harm which the injured party most probably would have been spared had the employer taken reasonable care in supervising or retaining the employee, serves as grounds for imputing employer liability.
Subsequently, over a decade later in 2009–2010, some New York courts abandoned applying the <i>Farager-Ellerth</i> guidelines for addressing lawsuits brought under NYCHRL. In <i>Zakrzewska v. The New School</i>, a federal court in the Southern District of New York concluded that the <i>Farager-Ellerth</i> guidelines for harassment liability do not apply to claims under NYCHRL. Additionally, the court concluded that NYCHRL creates vicarious liability for the acts of managerial and supervisory employees, even when the employer has exercised reasonable care to prevent and correct any such harassment.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zakrzewska v. The New School</i>, 598 F. Supp. 2d 426 (2009).<br></i>
Answering a question certified to it by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the New York Court of Appeals in <i>Zakrzewska v. The New School</i> acknowledges that state and local civil rights law must be interpreted in light of federal law. Moreover, the language of New York City Administrative Code imputes vicarious liability for the employer, even if he complies with the <i>Farager-Ellerth</i> guidelines and has created a safe workplace.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Section 8-107 (1) (a); <i>Zakrzewska v. The New School</i>, 620 F. 3d 168 (2010).</i> And, numerous New York courts have endorsed the <i>Zakrzewska v. The New School</i> ruling mandating an employer’s liability even where the employer implemented hiring, supervision, and retention polices and took immediate and appropriate corrective action.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Edrisse v. Marriot International</i>, 757 F. Supp. 2d 381 (2010); <i>Alexander v. Westbury Union Free School</i>, 829 F. Supp. 2d 89 (2011); <i>Cajamarca v. Regal Entertainment Group</i>, 863 F. Supp. 2d 237 (2012); <i>Mc Redmond, et al. v. Sutton Place Restaurant and Bar, et al.</i>, 95 A.D. 3d 671 (2012); <i>Gandarilla v. Albert Sanchez</i>, <i>et al.</i>, No. 07 Civ. 6909 (LTS) (S.D. New York – August 15, 2012); Joyne<i>r v. The City of NY, et al</i>., No. 11 Civ., 4958 (DLC) (S.D., NY, October 10, 2012).</i> In effect, the courts have precluded the use of the <i>Farager-Ellerth</i> guidelines as an avenue for an exemption of an employer’s vicarious liability rather than rejecting them.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">In this fashion, the New York courts interpreted the cases in a way that did not contradict the established precedent of the US Supreme Ct. decisions.</i> As such, in accordance with New York law, a New York City yeshiva would be liable for child abuse even if it had established and implemented policies that promote a safe work place, such as producing records relating to retention, supervision, discipline, termination, and complaints or investigations regarding an employee accused of sexually abusing a student. To state it differently, concerning abuse, a New York City employer is strictly liable.
However, most <i>Poskim</i> contend that the rule of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> is inapplicable when dealing with judge-made law such as US Supreme Court and New York court decisions, because generally the law, as interpreted by the courts, evolves and is ever changing.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 65a; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 3:109, 6:254; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 26 (end); <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:3, <i>Sma</i>, ad locum. 21; <i>Teshuvot Mahariz Enzel</i> 4; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 2:176; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 5:41; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Moshe</i>, 1:39, 2:116; <i>Teshuvot Shemesh u-Tzedaka</i> 33:1; <i>Teshuvot ve-Hanhagot</i> 3:455; Avraham Sherman, “National Custom in Labor Relations” (Hebrew), 18 <i>Tehumin</i> 245–247 (5758); File no. 335906/3, Tel Aviv-Yafo Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, May 26, 2010; File no. 3448583, Tel Aviv-Yafo Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, June 1, 2011. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 2:86, who argues that judge-made law regarding matters unrelated to taxes ought to mandate compliance based upon <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>; Shlomo Daichovsky, “Partnership Doctrine – Is it <i>Dina de-Malkhuta Dina</i>?” (Hebrew), 18 <i>Tehumin</i> 18, 27–29 (5758); <i>PDR</i> 16, 296, 301; File no. 3369-21-2, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, January 23, 2007; File no. 292687/1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, October 10, 2010; File no. 747359/1, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, October 24, 2011; File no. 830099/5, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, June 11, 2012; File no. 824780/2, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, June 27, 2012. In others, judge-made law similar to legislation requires interpretation (see infra n. 73) and therefore ought to fall under the rubric of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina.</i></i> And, in fact, as we have shown, New York law has evolved from initially absolving an employer from liability in situations in which hiring, supervision polices were operative, and subsequently to mandating responsibility even when said policies were implemented. In the minds of these <i>Poskim</i>, <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> is to be invoked only with regard to a determinate body of law, i.e., statutory law.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">And even though historically, the law of the monarchy required the king’s interpretation, the rule of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> would remain applicable. See <i>Teshuvot Kerem Shlomo</i> 31 (R. Netanel’s opinion). Cf. R. Shimshon Morfogu who claims that any law that requires interpretation, even monarchial interpretation, need not be followed. See <i>Kerem Shlomo</i>, op. cit.; Shmuel Shilo, “<i>Dina de-Malkhuta Dina</i>” (Hebrew), Academic Press: Yerushalayim, 1974, 188-189.</i> And, therefore, New York law which is judge-made law would not be recognized based upon <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Secondly, there are <i>Poskim</i> who subscribe to Shakh’s posture who contend that should secular law contradict Halakha, the latter trumps civil law. See <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA HM</i> 73:39; <i>Teshuvot Avkat Rokhel</i> 81; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 3:69. Consequently, since Halakha rejects the notion that an employer assumes vicarious liability in cases of an employee’s abuse, therefore civil law fails to be binding by dint of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>.</i>
Consequently, secular law memorialized in judge-made law will not provide the grounds for addressing whether an employer ought to be responsible for the abuse committed by his employee. Hence, should a victim of child abuse lodge a monetary claim against the New York City yeshiva in <i>beit din</i>, arguing that <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> should serve as the grounds for justifying his claim, it may be rejected.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">On the other hand, NYC law, which mandates that an employer establish and implement policies regarding hiring, supervision, and retention, would be recognized by many <i>Poskim</i> based upon <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>. This conclusion is based upon R. Moshe Sofer’s teaching, “If the matter would be submitted to us, we would have legislated it!” See <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 44.<br>The background for Hatam Sofer’s ruling relates to the nineteenth-century Eastern European regulation that only licensed wine brokers may sell wine and liquor. Concerned with the monopolistic ramifications of this civil law and its attendant economic harm foisted upon non-licensed wine brokerages, members of a Jewish community ask Hatam Sofer to express his opinion regarding this legal regulation. In reply, Hatam Sofer argues that it is desirable to regulate economic competition, and, in fact, there is precedent in Jewish legal history demonstrating that earlier decisors as well as communities protected the right of people to earn a living, and therefore this civil legislation makes sense. He therefore concluded that had the Jewish community been empowered in his time to pass such legislation, it would have been done without hesitation. As such, the civil legislation ought to be affirmed. This notion of “if the matter would be submitted to us, we would have legislated it!” reverberates in subsequent nineteenth-century and twentieth-century rulings regarding various commercial matters. See <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen HM</i> 259:3; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>YD</i> 2:75, 77; <i>Teshuvot Hit’orerut Teshuva</i> 232; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 44; <i>Teshuvot Doveiv Meisharim</i> 1:76; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Shlomo</i> 1:87; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 12:83; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 10:201; <i>PDR</i> 6:382 (R. Zolty, R. Elyashiv, and R. Nissim’s opinions). Similarly, in our scenario, in contemporary times if <i>Poskim</i> would have been empowered to pass legislation, policies regarding hiring, supervision, and retention would have been promulgated in order to promote a safe working environment as a vehicle for engendering love of one’s fellow man and preventing the commission of transgression. As such, <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> is applicable<i>.</i> Alternatively, it ought to be validated based upon Rema’s view that matters that are legislated relating to social interaction are to be recognized based upon <i>dina de-malkhuta dina.</i> See supra text accompanying nn. 56–60<i>.</i><br>Whether an employer is accountable in a <i>beit din</i> for failure to implement hiring, supervision, and retention policies, or liable for negligent hiring, supervision, and retention of an employee who engages in pedophilia is beyond the scope of this presentation.<br>The implicit assumption of this notion “If the matter would be submitted to us, we would have legislated it!” is that the legislation does not stand in contradiction to any Halakha. See <i>Teshuvot Beit Reuven</i>, vol. 2, 23 (5).<br>In fact, in other situations such as <i>hilkhot apotropsus</i> (laws of guardianship), due to changed conditions, Jewish communities legislated <i>halakhot</i> and in certain instances this legislation became part and parcel of the corpus of Halakha. See <i>Teshuvot Yismach Lev</i>, <i>HM</i> 8; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 290:16; <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 2, 97–99.</i>
<b>V. “<i>Minhag</i>” – An Avenue towards the Recognition of an Employer’s Vicarious Liability</b>
Though the doctrine of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> may not serve to address our situation, nonetheless <i>minhag ha-medina</i>, national or local practice, may be a more halakhically promising approach for dealing with our issue at hand.
Halakha establishes the guidelines for setting up various types of commercial relationships, including but not limited to <i>shutafut</i> (partnership), <i>arevut</i> (surety), and labor relations. At the same time, Halakha recognizes the ability of parties to enter into agreements that may be at variance with the guidelines set down by Halakha.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Parties may determine their own business relationship, provided that the arrangement complies with a proper form, i.e., <i>kinyan</i>, and is not violative of any <i>issurim</i>, prohibitions, such as theft or the interdict against taking <i>ribbit</i>. See <i>Kiddushin</i> 19b; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 305:4; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 38:5, <i>HM</i> 291:17, 305:4; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 344:1.</i> As such, any issues between the parties would be resolved in accordance with the provisions of their mutually agreed-upon arrangement.
If there is a <i>minhag</i> dealing with a certain matter in monetary affairs, even though the <i>minhag</i> does not have the endorsement of a rabbinic authority or communal leadership, and the origin of the <i>minhag</i> is non-Jewish,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Though there is a long-standing halakhic dispute whether a monetary custom practiced by the community on their own is effective without rabbinic or communal endorsement, the classical restatements have either explicitly or implicitly ruled that a monetary custom has an independent status. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:10, 218:19, 229:2, 230:10, 232:6, 330:5, 331:12; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 72:5.<br>Concerning the validity of a monetary <i>minhag</i> that is grounded in non-Jewish practices, see <i>Teshuvot Nediv Lev</i> 12; <i>Teshuvot Mahari Levi</i> (Ettinger) 2:111; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Avraham</i> 1:1; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yisrael</i> 172; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 1:10; <i>Teshuvot Oholei Tam</i> 202; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Yosef</i> 21; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72<i>.</i></i> we presume that whoever signs off on a commercial agreement or obligates himself to an individual intends to obligate himself in accordance with the <i>minhag</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mehira</i> 16:5; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhosot le-Ramban</i> 288; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:662; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ritva</i> 53; <i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 342; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 107,128; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 73; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 72:21.</i> So for example, if a business agreement fails to be finalized in accordance with a <i>shtar</i> (recognized halakhic-legal document), nevertheless, should the <i>minhag</i> validate the transaction based upon commercially accepted modes of undertaking an obligation, the agreement would be halakhically valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 4:125; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Teshuvot Maharshach</i> 2:229; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314.</i> Or if there is a <i>minhag</i> that a partnership undertakes responsibility for a <i>hezek</i> caused by one of its partners, the partnership is liable even though such responsibility was not articulated in the agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:48. For additional examples, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:268, 4:125, 6:254; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ran</i> 54; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 413.</i>
This rule that when one enters into a transaction one is bound by local custom even if the parties fail to mention the practice in their agreement extends equally to labor relations. In the absence of a labor agreement specifying the daily hours of employment, the Mishnah, for example, communicates to us that one follows the prevailing practice, which is to begin work later in the morning and return complete work prior to the evening hours. And upon employment, should the employer insist in pursuance to the <i>din</i> that the laborer begin work early and end late, given that the original agreement does not address this subject, the <i>minhag</i> of beginning work late and finishing early becomes one of the mutually agreed upon terms of the agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 7:1; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 331:1.</i> However, should the parties have mutually agreed prior to the onset of employment that the hours of work would begin early and end late, such an agreement would trump the <i>minhag</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 83a, s.v. “<i>ha’sohair</i>”; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 83a, s.v. “<i>ha-so’hair</i>”; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 331:3.</i>
To understand the effectiveness of <i>minhag</i> in general and in regard to our scenario in particular, let’s briefly present the building blocks for establishing the authority of <i>minhag</i>. For a <i>minhag</i> to be binding, three conditions must be obtained. Firstly, the custom must be clear.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 33; <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i> 413.</i> Secondly, it must be practiced throughout the country or the locale that is practicing the behavior.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 23:12, <i>Hilkhot Sekhirut</i> 9:1, <i>Hilkhot Mehirah</i> 7:8; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 42:2; <i>Teshuvot Maharik ha-Hadashot</i> 65.</i> The presumption that the parties intended <i>minhag</i> to be determinative when entering into the agreement is predicated upon the fact that the custom is “<i>pashut</i>” (widespread), otherwise one cannot assume that this is the parties’ intent. The criteria for ascertaining if a <i>minhag</i> is “<i>pashut</i>,” are subject to debate.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Many of the sources cited infra in nn. 86–101 have been culled from R. Kleinman, “National Laws – Is there an expectation that people contract in accordance with them even if they possess no actual knowledge of them?” (Hebrew), 33 <i>Tehumin</i> 82, 90–91, nn. 31–36 (5773).</i> One approach is that the <i>dayan</i> is the arbiter who will determine the frequency of the <i>minhag</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Y.
