Rosner, <i>Mishpat ha-Poalim</i> 88, n. 43.</i> Some argue that the <i>minhag</i> must be prevalent on a daily basis.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hakham Tzvi</i> 61; <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:81; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Sekhirut</i> 149, n. 17.</i> Others contend that it must have been practiced at least three times.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 342; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 331:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 436; <i>PDR</i> 4:128.</i> Furthermore, according to many <i>Poskim</i>, the parties to a business agreement, including but not limited to a labor agreement, need not possess knowledge of the actual existence of the <i>minhag</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 4:125, 6:254; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Teshuvot Maharashach</i> 2:229; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 338:2; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314; <i>Teshuvot Teshu’ot Hain</i> 55, cited in <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>EH</i> 53:12.<br>Cf. <i>Erekh Shai</i>, who argues that <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 42:36, 61:9, 71:33 disagrees and <i>Aharonim</i> endorse his view. See <i>Erekh Shai</i>, <i>EH</i> 50:7. See also <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 53:20.</i>
The autonomy of <i>minhag</i> and its effectiveness to define commercial ties are not limited to practices that transpire in the business community. According to most <i>Poskim</i>, one can grant halakhic validity to civil legislation by virtue of <i>minhag</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">R. Kleinman, “Civil Law as Custom: Jewish law and Secular Law – Do they Diverge or Converge?” 14 <i>The Review of Rabbinic Judaism</i> 11 (2011).</i> In other words, as contemporary <i>Poskim</i> such as R. Zolty, R. Feinstein, R. Elyashiv, R. Waldenburg, R. Y. Weiss and R. Lavi note, a <i>minhag</i> may emerge from civil legislation.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 2:86 (9), 7:126;<i>Ateret Devora</i> vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 44; <i>PDR</i> 8:162, 12:176, 179, 16:296, 310, 312; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:55; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Sekhirut</i> 4:3; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 5:30.<br>Obviously, some <i>Poskim</i> may restrict the power of a monetary custom and thus refuse to legitimate a piece of civil legislation. For example, even if there is a <i>minhag</i> to accept a civil will, many decisors have rejected this <i>minhag</i>. See ch. 1.</i> The concept of <i>minhag</i> is not limited to a practice in a locale that is frequent, widespread, and clear, but equally extends to any law that is widespread, clear, and exists in statutory form and/or frequently interpreted by the courts. To state it differently, the existence of civil laws regulating labor relations does not mean that ipso facto it is to be recognized as a <i>minhag</i> that ought to govern an employment agreement. For <i>minhag</i> to be determinative, according to certain opinions, it has to have transpired at least three times, which must be attested by two witnesses. However, if the definition of a <i>minhag</i> being “<i>pashut</i>” <i>is</i> that it is a daily occurrence, then the testimony of two witnesses is insufficient. In our scenario, unless the prevailing practice is clear, its existence must be demonstrated by inquiring from numerous individuals whether <i>yeshivot</i> utilize employment contracts prepared by attorneys that provide that disputes be resolved in accordance with secular law.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 13:21; <i>Teshuvot Admat Kodesh</i> 1:31; <i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i>, <i>EH</i> 45:4.<br>If Torah-observant Jews have their contracts prepared by an attorney, it is clear that their intention is to have any differences resolved by civil law. See File no. 1/35/8935, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, <i>Mosdot Plonim v. Kuf &amp; Vav</i>.</i> Then and only then one may contend that <i>minhag</i> as reflected in secular law is “<i>pashut</i>” and therefore determinative, serving to resolve contentious issues.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shmuel</i> 103; <i>Admat Kodesh</i>, supra n. 92; <i>Dinei Mamonot</i>, vol. 2, 14.<br></i>
Just as any <i>minhag</i> may serve to define the terms of a business agreement even though the parties are actually unaware of its existence, so too <i>minhag</i> will establish the choice of law that will govern the commercial arrangement. In other words, even if the yeshiva and the employee in their agreement did not specifically mention that civil law ought to govern any contentious issues by dint of the existence of a <i>minhag</i>, absent any provision to the contrary, their intent is to enter into the agreement on the basis of local law. Furthermore, the <i>umdana</i> (assessed expectation) which we encounter regarding <i>minhag</i> is that the law is applicable – even its details, independent of the fact that the parties are ignorant regarding the details of the applicable law and/or that the law is subject to change.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Dinei Mamonot</i>, vol. 1, 314–315; <i>Mishpat ha-Poalim</i>, supra n. 86, at 92; Kleinman, supra n. 85, at n. 58. For a discussion of this view, see <i>Teshuvot Beit Reuven</i>, vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 172–173.<br>However, R. Sha’anan contends that in situations in which the details of the law are contingent upon judge-made case law, one cannot argue that a <i>minhag</i> has been established. See File no. 3448583, supra n. 72. In other words, <i>minhag</i> must reflect clear-cut law. See text accompanying n. 72.<br>Alternatively, one can invoke the halakhically recognized notion that governing civil law serves to define people’s expectations. For example, a driver injures a pedestrian and the insurance company reimburses the victim for the injury incurred. Subsequently, the driver contacts the victim and argues that, in accordance with Halakha, he is obligated to pay him less than the compensation that he received from the insurance company. Therefore the victim should reimburse him the difference between what he received and what he ought to have been entitled to in pursuance to Halakha.<br>Given that the driver’s right to drive is based upon his possession of a driving license, which is recognized by civil law, and civil authorities have allowed him to drive provided he has insurance, his obligations as a driver are defined by secular law. As such, R. Zvi ben Ya’akov concludes that the amount of compensation is based upon civil law rather than Halakha. See <i>Mishpatekha le Ya’akov</i> 5:26.<br>Similiarly, given that every educational institution is obligated by law to register with the state and comply with certain licensing and approval requirements, therefore the institution’s expectations are that they are governed in all matters with civil law. As such, every educational institution in NYC expects to follow their legal responsibility vis-à-vis pedophiles. Consequently, whether the institution was aware of the governing law regarding vicarious liability is irrelevant. Their expectation was that their multifarious activities would be based upon legal compliance rather than Halakha. Awareness of the details of law does not factor into the expectations of the institution.</i> The assumption is that the parties may avail themselves of the services of an attorney in order to ascertain the state of the law. Therefore, ignorance of the details of the law is no excuse. Moreover, when invoking <i>minhag</i>, we assume that people who accept the authoritativeness of <i>minhag</i> not only assume that the details may be unfamiliar to them but that the content may vary from time to time. Nevertheless, they are ready to manage their commercial ties in accordance with the <i>minhag</i>, namely the law. As such, even if the <i>minhag</i> is “<i>pashut</i>,” that labor relations in the network of New York City <i>yeshivot</i> are being governed by New York City labor law, the fact that there is no awareness regarding a specific labor law or that the New York City law regarding a particular labor law has changed since the date their agreement was consummated, is immaterial.
In a series of <i>teshuvot</i> dealing with bankruptcy law, tenancy law, and labor law, R. Moshe Feinstein endorses the notion that <i>minhag</i> reflects civil legislation and may be invoked as determining a matter even if the parties expressly fail to mention the norm emerging from the <i>minhag</i> in their commercial agreement.
Moreover, in accordance with R. Feinstein’s view, even if the local custom differs from Halakha, the custom will prevail due to the fact that it was the parties’ intent to have their matters resolved in accordance with custom, namely secular law, even in a case of a specific law which generally may be unknown by the populace.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72, 75, 2:55.<br>The rationale is that <i>minhag mevatel Halakha</i>, custom overrides the law. See Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Yevamot</i> 12:1; <i>Bava Metzia</i> 7:1.</i> As Hazon Ish observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Sanhedrin</i>, <i>Likkutim</i> 16:1. For further discussion, <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 2, 189–190.<br>Obviously there is a distinction between Hazon Ish, who is utilizing <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> as a yardstick for determining the content of the <i>umdana</i> and R. Feinstein’s posture, which invokes <i>minhag</i> as the guideline for defining the parties’ expectations. The differing results in whether one adopts the rule of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> or <i>minhag</i> is beyond the scope of our presentation. Suffice it to say that the problems that we encountered attempting to resolve our case via the avenue of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> we will not necessarily confront when we employ the notion of <i>minhag</i> to resolve our case. For example, whereas there are numerous authorities who would limit the invoking of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> to matters of statutory law (see supra text accompanying n. 73), concerning the scope of <i>minhag</i> it may encompass case law.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The law of the kingdom determines the expectation of the people. Since we customarily abide by the law of the kingdom under certain prescribed conditions, the law influences people, who then decide to rely on civil law.</span>
Addressing the question whether an employer can dismiss a worker without cause, R. Feinstein writes, “Any custom that they may stipulate is in actuality Torah law.”<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:75. See also, <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72.</i>
Adopting such a perspective is not limited to the issue of dismissing a worker without cause. As noted hundreds of years earlier by Rashba,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n.15.</i> even though generally Halakha exempts an employer from liability for bodily injury caused to his worker, nevertheless <i>minhag</i> may serve as the grounds for workman’s compensation. Similarly, though generally Halakha exempts an employer from liability for an employee’s act of abuse, <i>minhag</i>, namely the governing law, ought to serve as a basis for obligating a yeshiva to compensate for an employee’s sexual misconduct.
Invoking Rashba and R. Feinstein’s approach,<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Whether Rashba and R. Feinstein would invoke their approach regarding our issue and arrive at this conclusion, we leave as an open question for now.<br>Rashba’s ruling is predicated upon a Tosefta’s discussion of a ship that was sailing at sea and encountered a storm that threatened to sink it, and some of the freight was thrown overboard in order to lighten the ship. Relying upon maritime custom, the Tosefta’s ruling is that the loss be divided according to the weight of the cargo, rather than the property owners’ wealth. See <i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 7:7 which was accepted as normative Halakha. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 272:15, 17.<br>On the basis of this ruling, Rashba concludes that <i>minhag</i> will be determinative regarding an employer’s responsibility for bodily injury caused to his employee while on the job. In other words, despite the fact that Tosefta deals with the halakhic-legal strength of <i>minhag</i> concerning property loss and Rashba is focusing upon an employee’s loss due to bodily injury; nonetheless, in Rashba’s mind the two cases are to be treated alike, i.e., governed by <i>minhag</i>. And therefore, we can argue that though Rashba’s position regarding the effectiveness of <i>minhag</i> deals with an employer’s responsibility for a worker’s bodily injury, his perspective may extend to an employer’s requirement to compensate a victim of abuse that is perpetrated by one of his employees!</i> we can now address our scenario. A child was abused by his principal or teacher in 2012 at a yeshiva located in New York City. In the absence of an insurance policy or an employment agreement that addresses whether a yeshiva is liable for abuses caused by one of its employees, we may invoke that <i>minhag</i> ought to serve to determine the parameters of the yeshiva’s liability.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Should the labor agreement explicitly state that the yeshiva is absolved from any monetary claims in the event of student abuse, it is a subject of debate whether the parties’ agreement trumps a <i>minhag</i> that mandates liability. See <i>Teshuvot Zera Emet</i>, <i>YD</i> 97; <i>Teshuvot Lev Arye</i> 2:37; <i>PDR</i> 8:80; Y.Yifrach, “A Labor Agreement in variance with the National Custom,” (Hebrew), 3 <i>Shurat ha-Din</i> 276 (5755); A.Sherman, “National Custom in Labor Relations,” (Hebrew), 18 <i>Tehumin</i> 245 (5758); Y. Eliazrov, “An Employer who deviates from the National Custom,” (Hebrew), 20 <i>Tehumin</i> 72 (5760); File no. 618660-1, Tzfat Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Mosdot Plonim</i>, February 25, 2008; File no. 808548-1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Mosdot Plonim v. Plonit</i>, September 16, 2009.</i> As such, though the applicable <i>halakhot</i> of <i>Hoshen Mishpat</i> that deal with labor relations do not obligate a yeshiva to compensate a victim of abuse monetarily, nonetheless, <i>minhag</i> as reflected in New York City law may serve as grounds for such monetary relief.
Said conclusion is premised upon three propositions. Firstly, regardless of whether the yeshiva and employee mutually agreed in their labor contract that any disputes that may arise be resolved according to Halakha by a <i>beit din</i>, the <i>umdana</i> is that even God-fearing Jews intend that <i>minhag</i>, namely that governing civil law, ought to be factored into arriving at a decision. Secondly, New York City statutory law as well as the courts’ interpretation of the law is reflective of <i>minhag</i>. In other words, the <i>minhag</i> factors into consideration the fact that details of the law may change due to the varying opinions of court justices even after a yeshiva’s labor agreement has been signed and/or the abuse transpired.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hut Shani</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ribbit</i>, 186–187; R. Tzvi ben Ya’akov (oral communication); Kleinman, supra n. 85 at 89, n. 39, at 93, n. 60. For a discussion of this view, see <i>Beit Reuven</i>, supra n. 94.</i> Moreover, <i>minhag</i> is authoritative even if the law<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">For the validity of <i>minhag</i>, even if an individual is unaware of the <i>minhag</i>, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:1068, 3:17; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 144b, s.v. “<i>ho</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ritva</i> 53; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ran</i> 54; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 413; <i>Teshuvot ha-Tashbetz</i> 1:133; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72, 75.</i> or details of the law, such as an employer’s vicarious liability, are unknown to the parties.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpat ha-Poalim</i>, supra n. 86, at 92. Cf. <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA EH</i> 66:48, who contends that the <i>minhag</i> must be known by everyone in order for it to be construed as the parties’ intention to be bound by it.</i> As such, the content of the <i>minhag</i> is determinative. Finally, even though New York City law as interpreted by the courts differs substantially from Halakha regarding the issue of a yeshiva’s vicarious liability, nonetheless the law as articulated by the courts trumps the <i>halakhot</i> of employment relations. To state it differently, even though the norms of <i>Hoshen Mishpat</i> concerning labor relations would exempt the yeshiva from liability for the teacher’s sexual misconduct, nonetheless <i>minhag</i>, namely applicable New York City law in 2012, would impose liability upon the yeshiva regardless of whether it had proper hiring, supervision, and retention policies in place prior and during the time of incident of abuse. And therefore, should a monetary claim by a victim of abuse be advanced against the yeshiva in 2012, the school ought to be held halakhically responsible based upon the import of <i>minhag.</i>
Finally, a reply to the contention that this <i>minhag</i> is to be a labeled a “<i>minhag garua</i>,” a practice devoid of logic and purpose,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Reuven</i>, supra n. 94, at 100–104 in the name of <i>Ramban</i> and <i>Rabbeinu Tam</i>. See <i>Tosafot Bava Batra</i> 2a, s.v. “<i>be’gvil</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 477.</i> due to the fact that the norms of <i>Hoshen Mishpat</i> do not impute employer liability for an employee’s sexual malfeasance, nevertheless the employer may be responsible for the following reason. If one endorses the minority view that one individual can be a <i>shomer</i> for another person’s bodily integrity,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">See supra text accompanying n. 48. The implication of viewing the yeshiva and its employees as <i>shomerim</i> regarding other matters is beyond the scope of our presentation.</i> then an employer such as a yeshiva may be viewed as a <i>shomer</i> who is protecting his students, and should abuse occur “under his watch,” he ought to be monetarily responsible, like a parent who is construed as a <i>shomer</i> vis-à-vis his/her minor children.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:106; Z. N. Goldberg, “Guarding an Object which does not belong to the Bailor,” (Hebrew), 14 <i>Tehumin</i> 200, 205 (5754) seem to limit <i>shemira</i> to young school children. Whether said conclusion is applicable to children of majority age we leave as an open question. Suffice it to say that if somebody guards an asset and he is hired to perform other work, he becomes a <i>shomer</i> over the asset if the guarding is related to the other work. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 638; <i>Teshuvot Shai le-Moreh</i> 15. Assuming, as we stated, that <i>hilkhot shemira</i> are applicable to human beings, therefore if a teacher is hired for teaching, he becomes a <i>shomer</i>, because the <i>shemira</i> is related to the other job, namely teaching.</i> To state it differently, a yeshiva as a <i>shomer</i> must oversee its employees and ultimately its students “<i>ke-derekh ha-shomerim</i>,” lit. “in accordance with the standard amongst bailees.”<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 42a.</i> “<i>Ke-derekh ha-shomerim</i>” will vary from locale to locale.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 3:21; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 42a; <i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 333; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:18.</i>Absent any institutional guidelines and policies, its scope and parameters may be defined by <i>minhag</i>, namely the governing law. Consequently, even though the yeshiva may have established and implemented a policy of supervising its employees, nevertheless, should an employee engage in abuse, New York City law may find the yeshiva monetarily responsible for such misconduct, even though the yeshiva did not act negligently. In short, <i>minhag</i> trumps <i>hilkhot Hoshen Mishpat</i>, which would have exempted the employer from responsibility.
Various objections may be leveled against implementing <i>minhag</i> as an avenue to resolve whether the yeshiva ought to be vicariously liable for one of its employee’s misconduct. First, as we have seen, given that the application of <i>minhag</i> may vary depending upon the posture of New York law regarding our issue of an employer’s liability, it means that the <i>minhag</i> is unclear and therefore fails to serve as a vehicle for addressing our matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Kleinman, supra n. 85, at 90, at text accompanying n. 48, n. 61 (R. Bareli’s opinion).</i> If the <i>minhag</i> is unclear, how can one presume that the parties intended that it govern their relationship? To state it differently, the applicability of <i>minhag</i>, similar to the invoking of <i>dina demalkhuta dina</i>, requires that the governing law be statutory rather than judge-made law, which may be ever-changing.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 344858/3, Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, June 1, 2011.</i>
Second, unless it is crystal clear that the parties desired that contentious matters be resolved in accordance with <i>minhag</i>, namely civil law rather than <i>hilkhot Hoshen Mishpat</i>, there are no grounds available for invoking the <i>umdana</i> that <i>minhag</i> ought to prevail.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Kleinman, supra n. 85, at 89, text accompanying n. 39 (R. Ben Ya’akov’s opinion).</i> Since American law allows arbitration courts, including <i>battei din</i>, to resolve matters of labor relations according to Halakha,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">The norms of civil law are applicable only if the secular government insists that their laws be followed. See <i>Aliyot de-Rabbeinu Yona Bava Batra</i> 54a; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 10b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:895, 6:149; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 228, 495; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 369 (4) in the name of R. Ya’akov Yisrael; <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 369; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 188.</i> one cannot assume that parties who appear at a <i>beit din</i> implicitly intend to have their differences resolved in conformity with civil law. As Maharashdam notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 327. See also, <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 33; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 13 (end); <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 118:6; <i>PDR</i> 4:126–131.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If we have even a slight doubt, we should not follow a <i>minhag</i> … and when you want to uproot the <i>din torah</i> from its place, you must produce a proof …</span>
In other words, the existence of the <i>minhag</i> must be widespread and clear, namely people’s awareness that secular labor law is governing one’s commercial affairs. Absent such awareness, we invoke Halakha, which would mean that an employer would be exempt from responsibility for his worker’s misbehavior.
Moreover, admittedly, individuals may have the intention to resolve their matters in pursuance of <i>minhag</i>, namely the governing New York City law, but details of the law may be unfamiliar to them. Consequently, <i>minhag</i> may not be determinative.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hut Shani</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ribbit</i>, supra n.101.</i> However, should the practice of legally imposing vicarious liability upon an employer, even in the context of a safe workplace, have been known to have occurred in one jobsite three times, or once in at least three different places, or that many people are aware that the law mandates employer’s vicarious liability, then and only then may we invoke <i>minhag</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">A. Bareli, “The Details of the Law – Are they to be subsumed under <i>Dina de-Malkhuta Dina</i>?” (Hebrew), 26 <i>Tehumin</i> 353 (5766).</i>
Furthermore, given that New York City law has changed since the consummation of the labor agreement between the yeshiva and the employee, the <i>minhag</i> at the time of the execution of the labor agreement (namely, New York law prior to <i>Zakrzewska v. The New School</i>) ought to prevail, and therefore the yeshiva ought to be exempt from responsibility.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hut Shani</i>, supra n. 101.</i> Consequently, for all or any of the foregoing reasons, imposing an employer’s vicarious liability in cases of an employee’s abuse lacks halakhic foundation.
In conclusion, though <i>hilkhot</i> Hoshen Mishpat, including but not limited to labor relations, mandate that a pedophile, regardless of whether he sexually misbehaves during the time of employment or after hours, is personally monetarily liable for his own behavior and his employer is not. Nonetheless, according to Rashba and R. Feinstein’s approach,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 100.</i> one may conclude that should the parties’ expectations be that <i>minhag</i>, namely, secular law, obligate them in their commercial relations and should the law mandate an employer’s liability for his employee’s sexual misconduct, the employer would be monetarily liable. Said conclusion is predicated upon the fact that the parties did not mutually agree in their labor contract that the employer would be exempt from responsibility for any sexual misbehavior that may be perpetrated by his employee in the future.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, should the labor agreement exempt the employer from liability for his employee’s sexual misconduct, the contract is binding, and should a <i>minhag</i> mandate liability, the terms of the contract trump the <i>minhag</i>. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 331:1, <i>Rema</i>, ad locum, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 332:2; <i>Teshuvot Zera Emet</i> 1, <i>YD</i> 97; <i>PDR</i> 8:78, 81; File no. 6186601, Tzfat Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Mosdot Plonim</i>, February 25, 2008. Cf. <i>Radakh</i>, <i>Shitah Mekubetzet</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 83a, s.v. “<i>ha-sohair</i>”; <i>Teshuvot Melamed le-Hoeil</i>, <i>OH</i> 40; Sherman, supra n. 100.<br>However, should the <i>minhag</i>, namely the law, impute an employer’s liability and prohibit parties from agreeing that an employer would be exempt from liability for his employee’s misconduct, then the <i>minhag</i> trumps a labor contract that exempts the employer from responsibility. See <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 61:8; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 61:4, 103:7. Cf. <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 61:8.</i> Others, as we noted, have explicitly or implicitly dissented from this position and argued that <i>minhag</i> fails to serve as an avenue for mandating an employer’s liability.
Unlike New York law, in Halakha, there is generally no statute of limitations in advancing such claims for employer liability.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 98:1 and supra, ch. 3.</i> Even if the alleged act of abuse was perpetrated twenty or forty years ago, a <i>beit din</i> is empowered today to hear claims against an employer, such as a loss of educational opportunities, diminishment of salaries, reimbursement of health care expenses, and noneconomic claims such as pain and suffering.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">For a contemporary <i>beit din</i>’s authority to render a decision regarding <i>nezikin</i> claims and its legal enforceability, see supra, ch. 3.</i> Nevertheless, such a <i>beit din</i> decision would be unenforceable in some states such as in New York.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">In certain states such as NY, given that there is a statute that expressly provides that such a claim is time barred in court, it would be equally time barred in an arbitration such as a <i>beit din</i> proceeding. See NY CPLR, Section 7502. In short, though halakhically there is a basis for a victim of abuse filing a claim against his employer in <i>beit din</i>, nevertheless, in NY a statute of limitations will apply which will result in the claim being time barred, and thus a <i>beit din</i>’s decision imposing employer liability would be legally unenforceable.<br>Many states such as California, Connecticut, Florida, Indiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, North Carolina, Ohio, and Washington rule that statutes of limitations are inapplicable to arbitration proceedings. See <i>Manhattan Loft, LLC v. Mercury Liquors, Inc.</i>, 173 Cal. App. 4th 1040, 1051 (Cal. App. 2d Dist. 2009); <i>Owings and Merrill v. Connecticut General Life Insurance Co.</i>, 197 A.2d 83 (1963); <i>Raymond James Financial Services, Inc. v. Phillips</i> (2D10-2144); <i>Lewiston Firefighters Assn. v. City of Lewiston</i>, 354 A. 2d 154, 167 (Maine 1976); <i>Carpenter v. Pomerantz</i>, 634 N.E. 2d 587, 590 (Mass. App. 1994); <i>Ward v. Thomas</i>, 2003 Mich. App. LEXIS 2080 (Mich. Ct. App. 2003); <i>Har-Mar Inc. v. Thorsen and Thorsen, Inc.</i>, 218 N.W. 2d 751 (MN 1974); <i>Price v. New Jersey Manufacturers Insurance Co.</i>, 82 NJ 519, 526 (2005); <i>In the Matter of the Arbitration between Cameron and Griffith</i>, 370 S.E. 2d 704 (N.C. Ct. App. 1988); <i>Cline v. Ohio Bur. of Motor Vehicles</i> (1991), 61 Ohio St. 3d 93, 97, 573 N.E. 2d 77, 80-81; <i>Broom v. Morgan Stanley DW, Inc.</i>, No. 82311-1 (7/22/10).<br>Therefore, in the aforementioned states, even though there is a statute that expressly provides that the claim is time barred in court, it would not be time barred in an arbitration proceeding such as a <i>beit din</i>.</i>
Deciding between the competing arguments in our case will be the sole prerogative of the <i>Posek</i>. The relative strength of each argument applicable to our case, its effectiveness and plausibility, will hopefully be tested within the framework and constraints of future halakhic decisions.<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">One may very well contend that the abuser in the institutional setting is, in effect, the agent of the employer. The care and safekeeping of children in a yeshiva or youth organization as well as adults in various institutional settings have been entrusted to the employer and he in turn has entrusted their care with the rabbi, administrator, teacher, or health care professional. He was employed to discharge the institution’s mission and responsibility. He abused that special position in which the institution has placed him to discharge certain responsibilities.<br>The question is: assuming the employer establishes and implements the policies against sexual harassment, does Halakha maintain that he remains responsible if abuse transpires “under his watch” as a <i>meshale’ach</i>, as a principal who appointed his employee as an agent to carry out a mandate? We have refrained from examining our issue via the lens of <i>hilkhot shelihut</i> (agency).</i>

Chapter 5; The Status and Role of a To'ein Rabbani in the Beit Din Process

<b>The Status and Role of a <i>To’ein Rabbani</i> in the <i>Beit Din</i> Process</b><br>Generally, a <i>to’ein rabbani</i>, i.e., rabbinical advocate, is an individual who is well versed in the Shulhan Arukh (in particular Hoshen Mishpat and Even ha-Ezer) and <i>Poskim</i>, as well as knowledgeable in civil law. He is hired by a party to represent a litigant who is appearing at a <i>din torah</i> proceeding (case) and will advance claims on behalf of his client and respond to counterclaims of the opposing party. Numerous <i>Poskim</i> invoke the Talmud Yerushalmi’s appellation “<i>anetlar</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 2:1. This source, as well as some others in our presentation, have been culled from Nahum Rakover, “The Jewish Law of Agency in Legal Proceedings” (Hebrew), Yerushalayim: 1972, 192, 308–353; H. Shlomo Sha’anan, “When is <i>Beit Din</i> Permitted or Obligated to Raise Arguments that were not Argued by the Litigant?” (Hebrew), 10 <i>Shurat ha-Din</i>, 215 (5766); Eliav Shochetman, “The Status of an Attorney in the Teachings of <i>Rambam</i>” (Hebrew), 20 <i>Tehumin</i> 38 (5750); idem., <i>Seder ha-Din</i> (Hebrew), Yerushalayim: 1988, 65–75, Yerushalayim: 2011, 167–177.</i> which is the Greek word for an attorney,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Saul Lieberman, “Greek and Hellenism in Eretz Yisrael” (Hebrew), 5723, 10.</i> or designations such as “<i>melitz</i>” (advocate), “<i>to’ein</i>” or “<i>shaliah</i>” (agent) to identify a party’s representative.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 30a, s.v. “<i>ve-od</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i>, 1:743, 2:393; <i>Teshuvot Ba’ei Hayyei</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:75; <i>Teshuvot Orah le-Tzadik</i>, <i>HM</i> 1; <i>Teshuvot Porat Yosef</i>, <i>HM</i> 30.<br>To identify a <i>to’ein</i> as a “<i>murshe</i>” is halakhically incorrect. See infra n. 16.</i>
To fully understand whether a <i>to’ein</i> is to be recognized as a participant in a <i>beit din</i> proceeding dealing with monetary matters, we need to briefly outline various building blocks that define civil <i>beit din</i> procedure. Firstly, though Halakha recognizes the ability of parties to appoint agents to represent them in their daily affairs, nonetheless, there is a mandate that in a <i>beit din</i> proceedings, both parties appear in front of the panel in order for the <i>dayanim</i> to ascertain the truth. Consequently, to avoid inaccuracies in the reconstruction of the facts and the articulation of the arguments by the litigants, there is a prohibition to hear arguments from a <i>meturgamen</i>, i.e., a translator.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Though most <i>Poskim</i> claim that this prohibition applies only to the testimony of witnesses (see <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:331; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:14) others argue that it equally applies to the litigants’ presentations. See <i>Rambam</i>, <i>Teshuvot Pe’er Hador</i> 102; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Makot</i> 6b; <i>Ran</i> on <i>Rif</i> (in the name of <i>Rambam</i>), <i>Shavuot</i> 13a.</i> As such, the parties themselves have to be present to speak to the <i>beit din</i> panel.
Should a party exhibit difficulty in expressing himself, there is an obligation incumbent on the <i>dayan</i> under certain prescribed conditions of “<i>petah pikha le-ilaim</i>” (lit. “open your mouth for the mute”), i.e., to assist the litigant in pleading his case.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shulhan Arukh</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:9; <i>Urim ve-Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:22. Such license equally applies when one litigant is sharp and bright and the other is na•ve and honest. See <i>Hafetz Hayyim</i> (Palache) 102:5.</i> Moreover, though a <i>dayan</i> may not communicate to a party any new arguments,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sanhedrin</i> 21:10; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:8. Cf. <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:14.</i> nevertheless halakhic arguments such as procedural matters (the validity of a woman and/or minor’s testimony), or halakhic shortcomings in an agreement such as <i>asmakhta</i> (the lack of firm resolve to negotiate an agreement), or the inability to obligate oneself or transfer something due to the fact that it is <i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i> (something which is not yet in existence) may be disclosed to a litigant.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Be’er Sheva</i> 71; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:16; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 67:33.</i> Additionally, depending upon the facts of the case, a <i>dayan</i> can articulate arguments on behalf of a recipient of a gift, an heir, or a buyer.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 67:29, 38; 81:3; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 62:16.</i>
On the other hand, there will be instances in which a <i>dayan</i> will be proscribed from invoking a procedural rule or a halakhic argument.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 3:8; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 67:60.</i> In other words, under certain circumstances, a <i>dayan</i> must avoid communicating arguments on behalf of a litigant.
Simultaneously, the <i>dayan</i> “walks a tightrope” and must refrain from becoming an advocate for a particular party.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Avot</i> 1:8; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sanhedrin</i> 21:11, 23:10; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:10.</i> Advocacy of a particular position may teach the party to lie or advance arguments that are false, incorrect, or inaccurate, designed to bring about a miscarriage of justice.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Avot</i> 1:8.</i> Echoing the words of the Rambam,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sanhedrin</i> 21:11.</i> Radvaz aptly notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Radvaz</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, supra n. 12.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">One requires a great degree of focus and incisive perception to distinguish between the one matter [permissible pleading on behalf of a party] and avoiding being an advocate [for a particular party].</span>
As Rashbatz exhorts the <i>dayan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Magen Avot</i>, <i>Avot</i> 1:8.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We do not say in every situation “<i>petah pikha le-ilaim</i>,” it depends upon the opinion of the <i>dayan</i> … and he should not engender suspicion …</span>
Consequently, it is unsurprising to find that <i>Poskim</i> are critical of a <i>dayan</i> who is a member of a <i>zabla</i> panel (acronym for <i>zeh boreir lo achad</i> – each litigant chooses their <i>dayan</i> and the two <i>dayanim</i> then choose a third) who advances arguments of deceit on behalf of the litigant who chose him, rather than serving as an unbiased and disinterested <i>dayan</i>, advocating arguments on behalf of the party who chose him that are halakhically sound.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 3:2; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 13:4; <i>Teshuvot Panim Meirot</i> 2:159; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 8:300, 302; 9:285; <i>Teshuvot Even Yisrael</i> 8:90.</i>
The requirement of integrity and “distancing onself from falsehood” extends itself to everyone, including <i>to’anim</i> as well as <i>dayanim.</i> The prevalence of unethical practices used by some <i>to’anim</i> to win their cases, such as fabricating arguments that are factually and/or halakhically incorrect, training their clients to submit false claims, or misconstruing the facts, have led some <i>Poskim</i>, including Rif, Ri Migash, Rashi, Ramban, Ran in the name of Rambam, possibly Maharam of Rothenburg, Beit Yosef, Darkhei Moshe, Bah, Mabit, R. Shmuel Kali, R. Yair Bachrach, and R. Ovadiah Hadaya to prohibit their appearance and participation at a <i>beit din</i> proceeding.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ri Migash</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 30b, s.v. “<i>matnei</i>”; <i>Rashi</i>, <i>Avot</i> 1:8; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 30a; <i>Ran</i>, supra n. 4; <i>Teshuvot Maharam of Rothenberg</i>, Cremona ed., 175, 246; Lvov ed., 126; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1; <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1; <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 17; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 33; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shmuel</i> 121; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 156; <i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i>, vol. 5, <i>EH</i> 63.<br>Though many <i>Rishonim</i> such as R. Meir Abulafia, Rabbeinu Peretz of Corbeil, and Rivash oppose allowing a <i>nitva</i> (defendant) to appoint a <i>mursheh</i>, nevertheless, the validity of a <i>nitva</i>’s appointment of a <i>mursheh</i> is irrelevant to our issue concerning the legitimacy of employing a <i>to’ein</i>. Similarly, though Rambam opposes the use of a representative for the <i>nitva</i>, his rulings specifically address the institution of a <i>mursheh</i>. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rambam</i>, 372, 411. In fact, Ritva aptly observes that Rambam never expresses a view regarding the propriety of a <i>to’ein</i> in a <i>beit din</i> proceeding. See <i>Ritva</i>, supra n. 3. Cf. <i>Rambam</i>, <i>Avot</i> 1:8, <i>Teshuvot ha-Rambam</i> (Blau edition) 272.<br>As Meiri, Tashbetz, Ritva, and a contemporary <i>beit din</i> are aware or aptly observe, there exists a difference between an <i>anetlar</i> (<i>to’ein</i>) and a <i>mursheh</i>. A <i>tove’a</i> (plaintiff) may transfer to the <i>mursheh</i>, the outstanding debt due from the <i>nitva</i> and in effect the <i>murshe</i>, who has power of attorney, becomes the <i>tove’a</i>. However, given that the <i>nitva</i> is incapable of transferring anything to another individual, it is impossible for him to appoint a <i>mursheh</i>. See <i>Bava Kama</i> 70a; <i>Teshuvot ha-Geonim</i>, Harkavi ed., 180; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rambam</i>, Blau ed., 411; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 439; <i>Mateh Shimon</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:4.<br>On the other hand, an <i>anetlar</i> is authorized to represent either party in the <i>beit din</i> pleading without the issuance of a <i>harsha’a</i>, i.e., a power of attorney. See <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 18a, <i>Shavuot</i> 30a; <i>Tosafot Ri ha-Zaken</i>, <i>Shitat Kadmonim</i>, <i>Avoda Zara</i>, 3:126; <i>Ritva</i>, op. cit.; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 3:206.<br>As aptly pointed out in a recent decision, people tend to use the words “<i>mursheh</i>” and “<i>anetlar</i>” interchangeably without realizing that that there is a halakhic distinction between the two institutions. See File no. 1-13-002793529, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Avraham Greif v. Chaya Greif</i>, April 4, 2005.<br>Based upon the foregoing, given that in situations of <i>harsha’a</i> it is a halakhic impossibility for a <i>nitva</i> to appoint a <i>murshe</i> (see <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 30a; <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 124; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1), therefore, the diverse views regarding whether a <i>nitva</i> may appoint a <i>mursheh</i> in effect would be identical to their views whether a <i>nitva</i> may appoint a <i>anetlar</i>. Consequently, we are able to discern their views regarding the propriety of appointing an <i>anetlar</i> for a <i>nitva</i> from their views regarding the appointment of a <i>mursheh</i> for a <i>nitva.</i> See text accompanying nn. 15–18.<br>The aforesaid rulings regarding <i>harsha’a</i> are therefore irrelevant regarding the propriety of allowing a <i>to’ein</i> in a <i>beit din</i>.<br>Nevertheless, we have been able to extrapolate Rashba and Ritva’s views regarding the status of a <i>to’ein</i> based upon some of the rulings relating to a <i>murshe.</i> See infra text accompanying nn.18–20, 28–29.<br>For the interdict to “distance oneself from falsehood,” see <i>Shemot</i> 23:7; <i>Shavuot</i> 30b–31a; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>YD</i> 402:12; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot To’ein ve</i>-<i>Nitain</i> 16:9; <i>Teshuvot Rama me-Fano</i> 55.</i> And in fact, in the past, some communities passed legislation prohibiting the appearance of any counsel for a proceeding.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 5:288; <i>Kerem Hemed</i> 2, <i>Takanah</i> 170; <i>Teshuvot Ginat Veradim</i>, <i>HM</i> 6:1; <i>Teshuvot Ba’ei Hayyei</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:12.</i> The results of this position are that <i>dayanim</i> address the halakhic issues without availing themselves of outside assistance and are capable of dealing with the litigants and their machinations, as well as offering limited counsel to the parties on a case-by-case basis. Moreover, some decisors assume that a <i>dayan</i> could “walk the tightrope” of assisting a litigant in articulating his claims, without engaging in any behavior where the <i>dayan</i> assumes the role of an advocate for a litigant.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 30b, s.v. “<i>gemara</i>”; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 30b, s.v. “<i>u-leinyan</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i>, 2:393; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, supra n. 12; <i>Radvaz</i>, ad locum; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:9.<br>The same conclusion equally applies to <i>to’anim</i>. See <i>Shabbat</i> 139a; <i>Rambam</i>, <i>Commentary to Mishnah</i>, <i>Avot</i> 1:8; <i>Hafetz Hayyim</i>, supra n. 5.</i> As such, there is no need to have a <i>to’ein</i> in attendance at a <i>beit din</i> proceeding.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">My personal experience of over fifteen years in <i>dayanut</i> has shown that sometimes such expectations of a <i>dayan</i> being able to help a litigant are realized in a particular <i>din torah</i>. However in some complex cases when a <i>to’ein</i> is absent from the proceeding, a <i>dayan</i> is unable to balance assisting a “litigant in need” with maintaining proper procedural safeguards for the proceeding, while simultaneously keeping track of the facts in the case and questioning the parties and witnesses.</i> Some of the beneficial consequences of adopting this posture are that the litigants are not trained to employ deceptive tactics or craft false arguments and will be receptive to forge a <i>peshara</i> (compromise) if the circumstances dictate proceeding in such a fashion.
On the other hand, other <i>Poskim</i>, including Arukh, Rabbeinu Hananel, Ri ha-Zaken, Rashba, Ra’ah, Meiri, Maharik, Urim ve-Tumim, R. Ya’akov Emden, Arukh ha-Shulhan, Hoshen ha-Ephod, Hazon Ish, R. Sternbuch, R. Avraham Horowitz, and R. Zvi Yehuda ben Ya’akov, as well as the overwhelming majority of <i>battei din</i> (established <i>battei din</i> as well as <i>zabla</i> panels) in the New York metropolitan area, <i>allow</i> (rather than obligate) the parties to avail themselves of halakhic counsel.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Arukh</i>, “<i>Antelar</i>”; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 30a; <i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Sanhedrin</i>, supra n. 16; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 90; <i>Urim ve-Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 4:2, 4:7; <i>Etz Avot</i>, <i>Lehem Shamayim</i>, <i>Avot</i> 1:8; <i>Teshuvot Hoshen ha-Ephod</i> (Pipano) 43; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:2; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 4:2, 4:7; <i>Teshuvot ve-Hanhagot</i>, 3:446; <i>Teshuvot Kinyan Torah be-Halakha</i>, 7:121; <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i>, 2:36.<br>Regarding Rashba’s view, there is a contradiction in his rulings. We have concluded in accordance with some <i>Aharonim</i> that Rashba allows the presence of a <i>to’ein</i> for the plaintiff in all circumstances and allows a <i>to’ein</i> to appear on behalf of a defendant provided that the defendant communicates his claims to him. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:743, 2:393, 404; 3:141, 6:210. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i>, 2:753, 4:189; <i>Havot Yair</i>, supra n. 16; <i>Teshuvot Shevet Binyamin</i> 211; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Shalom</i> (Mizrachi), <i>HM</i> 141.<br>Clearly, such dispensation to allow a <i>to’ein</i> to serve a <i>ba’al din</i> presumes that the <i>to’ein</i> refrains from fabricating arguments based upon falsehood. See <i>Tosafot Yom Tov</i>, <i>Avot</i> 1:8.</i> For some <i>Poskim</i>, even if the <i>to’ein</i> received a <i>ketav harsha’a</i> from the litigant authorizing the <i>to’ein</i> to appear in the absence of his client, the litigant must be present at the actual <i>beit din</i> proceeding.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 7b, s.v. “<i>she’moah</i>”; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1, <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1; <i>Teshuvot Ba’ei Hayyei</i>, infra n. 32; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 4:1; <i>PDR</i> 2:142. However, in the absence of a <i>nitva</i>’s denial of the veracity of the <i>tove’a</i>’s claims, some contend that the parties need not appear at the proceeding. See <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1 (end); <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:2.</i> And some <i>Poskim</i> argue that prior to the <i>to’ein</i>’s actual presentation, the litigant should submit his claims and arguments to the <i>beit din</i> panel.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i>, 2:404; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:14.</i>
The role of a <i>to’ein</i> expresses itself in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>edut</i>, i.e., testimony. Generally speaking, a person must refrain from testifying in a matter from which he may benefit, i.e., <i>noge’a ba-davar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 354; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i>, 37:21; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 80.<br>Regarding a <i>mursheh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 123:11 concurs. However, <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 23 concludes that permitting such testimony is disgusting. In contemporary times, Rabbis Roth, Broth and Hadaya sanctioned such a practice. See Shochetman, supra n. 1, at 67, n. 157. Additionally, see supra n. 16.</i> One of the rationales for this Halakha is that we are suspicious that such an individual would submit tainted testimony. Seemingly, one would expect that a <i>to’ein</i> who is a <i>noge’a ba-davar</i> refrain under all circumstances from submitting testimony on behalf of his client. Nevertheless, some <i>Poskim</i> argue that as long as the <i>to’ein</i>’s remuneration is based on his time investment rather than his ability to win the case for his client, he is not construed as a <i>noge’a ba-davar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rif</i>, Leiter ed., 157; <i>Teshuvot Mahari Weil</i> 119; <i>Panim Meirot</i>, supra n. 15; <i>Teshuvot ve-Hanhagot</i> 5:351; Appeal 1/58/711 (Unpublished Decision, The State Archives, Meichal 4796, File no. 99/36) cited by Shochetman, supra n. 1, at 67, n. 152.</i> and therefore his appearance in a <i>beit din</i> under such conditions is permissible. In other words, <i>Poskim</i> who permit halakhic advocacy argue that one cannot summarily assume that all <i>to’anim</i> lack credibility, and therefore deny their appearance in <i>beit din</i>. This is why we do not assume a <i>to’ein</i> who receives compensation for his services based upon his time investment will lie on behalf of his client.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">However, if their compensation were based upon demonstrating positive results for his client, such testimony submitted by the <i>to’ein</i> to the <i>beit din</i> would be inadmissible. See <i>Mispatekha le-Ya’akov</i>, 2:36 (14).</i> Adopting the perspective of the aforesaid <i>Poskim</i>, there is a presumption that a <i>to’ein</i> will vigorously pursue his client’s objectives with integrity and a sense of fairness. In effect, though these <i>Poskim</i> were well aware of the Mishnaic and Midrashic exhortations against rabbinic advocacy due to the potential for corruption,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 1:8; <i>Mekhilta de-Rabbi Yishmael</i>, <i>Mishpatim</i>, <i>Parsha</i> 20; <i>Rabbeinu Yona</i>, <i>Commentary to Avot</i> 1:8.</i> they hold that there is nevertheless a presumption of credibility and that the <i>to’ein</i> possesses the ability “to walk the tightrope.”
However, what if a <i>to’ein</i> undermines his <i>hezkat kashrut</i>, i.e., presumption of credibility, because he received compensation linked to the outcome of a case, or for another reason? Would <i>Poskim</i> prohibit his advocacy in future <i>dinei torah</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Even in the absence of such a provision, a <i>beit din</i> operating under the Israel Chief Rabbinate is empowered to impose monetary penalties against a <i>to’ein</i> who acts improperly. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; File 875507-1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>To’ein Rabbani Almoni v. Ploni</i>, November 7, 2012.</i> For example, even though in general Rashba rejects the possibility of appointing <i>to’anim</i> for various reasons, including issues of credibility,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">See supra nn. 16 and 18.</i> nevertheless under certain circumstances, such as a <i>dayan</i> prone to error or a defendant incapable of articulating his arguments, Rashba permits their appearance.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashba</i>, supra n. 22.</i> Similarly, though Ritva admittedly is aware that an <i>anetlar</i> may advance claims grounded in falsehood, nevertheless he allows his appointment, in part based upon the instructions of his teachers, Ra’ah and Rashba.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 30b, s.v. “<i>ve-khi teima</i>.” Cf. <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 31a, s.v. “<i>to’ein</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ritva</i> 154.</i>
A few hundred years later, R. Hayyim Benveniste of seventeenth-century Izmir, Turkey railed against the deceptive practices of <i>to’anim</i> and contended that it is prohibited for a <i>to’ein</i> to advance arguments that are devoid of truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">A position that was echoed by <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 123:32.</i> but he refrained from outlawing their appearance in <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ba’ei Hayyei</i> 2:90.</i> During the same century in Poland, R. Shmuel ben David ha-Levi, renowned author of <i>Nahalat Shiva</i>, described the rabbinic advocates as those “who search the books for logical argumentation and <i>halakhot</i> which are right in their eyes, and in the majority of instances they ingest the waste and throw out the food when they realize that the Halakha did not agree with them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nahalat Shiva</i> 44.</i> Here again, the <i>Posek</i> does not prohibit the continued use of a <i>to’anim</i>, but advises the <i>dayan</i> to rebuke them for their improper conduct. The renowned seventeenth-century <i>Posek</i>, R. Shabbetai ben Meir ha-Kohen (known by the acronym “Shakh”) of Vilna and later of Holesov, Moravia lambasted <i>to’anim</i> who “are deceptive … even in a matter which is devoid of reality,”<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, supra n. 31.</i> yet he refrained from advocating the abolition of the institution of rabbinic advocacy, as can be seen in the his subsequent ruling.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1.</i>
Subsequently, in one of the lengthiest <i>teshuvot</i> dealing with the prohibition of litigating one’s matters in secular court, R. Avraham Hayyim Rodriguez of eighteenth-century Livorno, Italy criticizes in the most trenchant terms those who proceed to civil court to address their litigious matters in order to avoid appearing in a <i>beit din</i> serviced by <i>to’anim</i>, whom he describes as those who “distanced themselves from truth and justice and drew closer to falsehood … and communicated to the <i>dayanim</i> matters that never came into the mind of the litigant.”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Orah le-Tzadik</i>, supra n. 3. See <i>Teshuvot Hukat Mishpat</i> 2:3.</i> Yet, here again, the <i>Posek</i> continues to proscribe a Jew from litigating his case in civil court, and does not ban the practice of rabbinic advocacy in <i>beit din</i>. To state it differently, despite the <i>to’anim</i>’s deceptive tactics, R. Rodriguez refrains from issuing a <i>heter arkaot</i>, permission to litigate their case in civil court.
This posture continues to persevere to this very day among various contemporary <i>Poskim</i>. Addressing a twentieth-century situation of a crafty and conniving <i>to’ein</i>, an opposing party exclaims that he is unable to defend himself against such an individual and demands that R. Shmuel Gaimazian of Yerushalayim prohibit the <i>to’ein</i>’s appearance at the <i>din torah</i>. In a succinct <i>teshuva</i> comprising nine lines, R. Gaimazian denies the questioner relief and concludes with the following words,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Tzedek</i> 139.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">In a place where it is customary that a defendant has a <i>murshe</i> (loosely translated as a <i>to’ein</i>), he must stand with the opposing party for resolution of the case and he cannot argue in such a manner.</span>
Though criticizing <i>to’anim</i> who manipulate the system to promote their client’s best interests, R. Yosef Elyashiv and R. Yehezkel Roth, the Karlsberg Rebbe, do not raise the possibility of abolishing the institution.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>He’arot le-Masekhet Ketuvot</i> 52b; <i>Teshuvot Emek ha-Teshuva</i> 6:542.</i> Finally, a few years ago, in possibly one the most scathing and detailed critiques of the tactics of <i>to’anim</i> who display the art of deception and obfuscation recorded in our <i>sifrei teshuvot</i> (responsa literature), R. Yehuda Bracha in his <i>teshuva</i> concludes based on his experience that one is permitted to be a <i>to’ein</i> provided one serves with a sense of fairness and integrity. Here again, the <i>Posek</i> refrains from banning the institution of <i>to’anim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Birkat Yehuda</i> 3:3.</i> In 2009, R. Avraham Drabermediker, a Yerushalmi <i>dayan</i> and an author of a treatise on <i>beit din</i> procedure concurred with R. Bracha.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Seder ha-Din</i>, 515–516.</i>
Optimally, as we mentioned, there is a need for a <i>to’ein</i> to abide by the prohibition against advancing arguments of falsehood and fabricating evidence,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Supra text accompanying n. 20.</i> yet as we have shown, the views of <i>Rashba</i>, <i>Ritva</i>, R. Hayyim Benveniste, R. Shmuel ben Dovid ha-Levi, <i>Shakh</i>, and Rabbis Rodriguez, Elyashiv, Roth, Gaimazian, Bracha, and Drabermediker direct us to the conclusion that a <i>beit din</i> hearing may be conducted where a litigant is utilizing the services of an unscrupulous <i>to’ein.</i> The expectation is that the <i>to’ein</i> will exhibit credibility.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam of Rotenburg</i>, Levov ed., 127.</i> But, should he display tactics of deception, as halakhically objectionable as such behavior may be, the aforementioned <i>Poskim</i> do not seek to outlaw the institution of rabbinic advocacy.
A review of some of the <i>teshuvot</i> reveals various reasons for permitting a litigant to avail himself of the services of a <i>to’ein.</i> First, attuned to the varying capabilities of a <i>ba’al din</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 14a (bottom).</i> some <i>Rishonim</i> observe that “there are some people who are clever and know how to contradict the words of their antagonists.”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 14a, s.v. “<i>dina</i>”; <i>Shita Mekubetzet</i> in the name of <i>Gilyon Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 14a; <i>Tosafot ha-Rosh</i>, ad locum in the name of <i>Rivam</i>; <i>Ran</i> on <i>Rif</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 51a. See also, <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 31a, s.v. “<i>zeh</i>.”</i> The inference to be drawn from this statement is that some individuals are unable to articulate their arguments. Hence, one may avail himself of the services of a <i>to’ein</i> if he is incapable of pleading his case due to the lack of requisite skills in articulating his claims, incapable of formulating questions aimed at evoking the opposing party’s reply, or bereft of the talent to read and understand legal documents and financial records. Sometimes, a party is incapable of responding to the opposing party’s questioning and/or is high-strung and emotionally irate, which stymies the party’s self-expression.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Geonim</i>, Harkavi ed., No. 206; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 123:17; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Shavuot</i> 31a; <i>Hoshen ha-Ephod</i>, supra n. 20; <i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i>, <i>pesakim</i> 217; <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 122:1; Shlomo Shapiro, 13 <i>Shurat ha-Din</i> 343, 348 (5768). Cf. <i>Teshuvot Temim De’im</i> 62; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 13:32; 123:32.</i> Hence, the presence of an intermediary such as a <i>to’ein</i> who is well-informed regarding the facts and claims of the contentious matter may serve to “moderate the atmosphere” and articulate his client’s position based on his scrutiny of the facts and review of the documentation.
Second, as we mentioned, a <i>dayan</i> must be very careful in maintaining his role of independence, being “above the fray.” Consequently, to preempt the possibility of transforming a <i>dayan</i> into an attorney advocating the claims for one party, the role of assisting the litigant in articulating his claims should be the province of the <i>to’ein</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Yahel Yisrael</i> 102.</i> Clearly, the <i>to’ein</i> must foster the promotion of justice rather than serve as an advocate fabricating lies.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mekhilta</i>, <i>Parshat Mishpatim</i>, <i>parsha</i> 20. See supra n. 18.</i> Lest one argue that in the presence of a <i>to’ein</i>, a <i>dayan</i> may be relieved of his duty to assist a party in articulating his claims,<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i> 5, <i>EH</i> 58.</i> over sixty years of halakhic practice of the Israeli Rabbinical Courts clearly tells us a different story. A cursory glance of their <i>piskei din</i> reveals that the <i>dayanim</i>, while in the presence of <i>to’anim</i>, may nevertheless serve in an advisory capacity to the litigants.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:404; <i>PDR</i> 1:5, 9; 4:175; 10:273; 14:71.</i>
Third, R. Yosef Alfandri offers a historical reason for the value of having <i>to’anim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Porat Yosef</i>, supra n. 3.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It is nice and pleasant that Torah scholars be <i>murshim</i>, because they can search the sources of the <i>Poskim</i> … and show it to the <i>beit din</i>.</span>
Clearly, in this community of nineteenth-century Constantinople, the Torah scholarship of the <i>to’anim</i> contributed to fill the gaps of knowledge found among the local <i>dayanim</i>. In fact, today, there are some <i>to’anim</i> who are more proficient in Halakha than some individual <i>dayanim</i> and/or some <i>beit din</i> panels in some major cities around the United States. As such, the expertise of the <i>dayanim</i> remains a factor in retaining <i>to’anim</i>. Implicit in such an argument is that the <i>dayan</i>, who albeit is less knowledgeable than a particular deceptive <i>to’ein</i>, has the learning skills to scrutinize the merits of the <i>to’ein</i>’s halakhic presentation, and if need be, to seek halakhic counsel<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">In fact, even if the <i>dayan</i> is halakhically proficient, some <i>Poskim</i> mandate that under certain prescribed conditions one seek advice from another arbiter prior to rendering a <i>psak din</i>. See <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 35; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:280; <i>Birkei Yosef</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 10:3; <i>Mishpetei Shmuel</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:3 in the name of <i>Sefer Hukot ha-Dayanim</i> 3:3; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 10:2.</i> and arrive at an informed and credible <i>psak din</i>.
Fourth, despite Sma and Shakh’s<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Text accompanying nn.15, 23, 31, and 35.</i> repeated reservations regarding the appointment of a translator or a <i>to’ein</i> because of his lack of credibility,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 13:12, 17:14, 123:1, 124:1.</i> nevertheless since both litigants have voluntarily accepted the jurisdiction of the <i>beit din</i> and implicit in such acceptance is that <i>to’anim</i> will participate in the <i>beit din</i> process, Sma and Shakh conclude that the practice should be permitted.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:14; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:1. For a different understanding of <i>Sma</i> and <i>Shakh</i>, see <i>Radvaz</i> and <i>Hazon Ish</i>, see infra text accompanying n. 58.</i>
Finally, other <i>Poskim</i> validate the appearance of a <i>to’ein</i> based upon <i>minhag</i> (custom) either construing it as if the litigants have consented to this institution or without grounding it in the consent of both litigants.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari Weil</i> 119; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 104; <i>Sma</i>, supra n. 54; <i>Shakh</i>, supra n. 54; <i>Urim ve-Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 124; <i>Tumim</i>, ad locum 1; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shmuel</i> (Kali) 121; <i>Teshuvot Ba’ei Hayyei</i> 75; <i>Teshuvot She’al Ha’ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 17; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:2; Yoezer Ariel, <i>Dinei Borerut</i>, 120; <i>Sefer Seder ha-Din</i>, supra n. 40, 512.</i> Consequently, echoing the words of Aruch ha-Shulhan and Tumim, R. Eliav Shochetman of Yerushalayim, an internationally renowned expert on <i>beit din</i> procedure communicated to this author the following:<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">In a written communication dated April 26, 2012 to this author (on file with this author). This <i>minhag</i> predates the twenty-first century. See <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:14; <i>Tumim</i>, <i>HM</i> 124; <i>Aruch ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 124:2; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 4:7–8; File no. 113002793529, infra n. 74.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">I do not know on what basis a <i>beit din</i> has the authority to prohibit the appearance of <i>to’anim</i> given that the <i>minhag</i> that developed is that both the plaintiff and the defendant can have representation in <i>beit din</i>.</span>
Attesting to this ongoing <i>minhag</i>, recently handed down <i>piskei din</i> appear on the web on a weekly basis from <i>battei din</i> under the aegis of Israel’s Chief Rabbinate and/or from Eretz Hemdah-Gazit network, in which litigants are represented by <i>to’anim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">One should not draw a conclusion that other Israeli <i>battei din</i> follow suit. For example, in Yerushalayim, a <i>beit din</i> in Ma’alei Adumim, which serves a <i>dati leumi</i> populace, and the <i>beit din</i> ha-Yashar ve-ha-Tov, which attends to the needs of the yeshiva community, both prohibit the use of a <i>to’ein</i>.</i>
Whether the <i>minhag</i> of having <i>to’anim</i> depends on the decision of the litigants remains an open question. Implementing Radvaz and Hazon Ish’s view that the consent of both litigants is required in order to permit <i>to’anim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 2:753; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 4:7–8. Additionally see, <i>Dinei Mamonot</i> vol. 1, 263.</i> to the best of my knowledge there is at least one standing <i>beit din</i> in the New York metropolitan area which insists that both parties must demand the services of a <i>to’ein</i> in order to permit their appearance and participation at a <i>beit din</i> proceeding.
Consequently, absent the mutual agreement of the litigants to have <i>to’anim</i>, if one party requests a <i>to’ein</i> and the opposing party refuses to have one, the pending <i>din torah</i> will be resolved without the services of a <i>to’ein.</i> However, echoing the words of Sma, Hazon Ish, and the Beit <i>Din ha-Gadol</i> in Yerushalayim,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:14; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 4:7; File no. 113002793529, infra n. 74. See also, <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:404; <i>Tur SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 9:7.</i> the overwhelming majority of <i>battei din</i> in the New York metropolitan area will allow the appearance of a <i>to’ein</i> by one party even if the opposing party decides to proceed without the services of a <i>to’ein</i>, or if the opposing party requests that the <i>beit din</i> hearing take place without the presence and/or participation of <i>to’anim</i>.
In sum, explicit or implicit in the position espoused by Rashba, Ritva, R. Benveniste, R. Shmuel ben Dovid ha-Levi, Shakh, and Rabbis Rodriguez, Elyashiv, Gaimazian, Bracha, and Drabermediker is the recognition of all or some of the aforesaid reasons for why litigants as well as a <i>beit din</i> panel would want to avail themselves of the services of a <i>to’ein</i>. To state it differently, though there is a consensus that a <i>to’ein</i> is <i>not required</i> at a <i>beit din</i> proceeding, nevertheless, even if the <i>to’ein</i> may be of dubious credentials, there may be a redeeming value in retaining him. And in fact, generally speaking the <i>minhag</i> today is to allow <i>to’anim</i> to participate in <i>beit din</i> hearings. In effect, the ramifications of their posture is that while in certain instances the <i>dayan</i> may have to assume the daunting challenge of traversing a minefield of lies attuning himself to the deceptive tactics of a <i>to’ein</i>, the redeeming qualities of a <i>to’ein</i> together with discernment and halakhic acumen will help him arrive at a coherent and persuasive decision based on the halakhic cogency of the claims. If one is permitted to continue a <i>beit din</i> proceeding which entails a <i>din merume</i>, a proceeding marked by a fraudulent monetary claims contrived by a <i>to’ein</i>, this means that under such circumstances it is incumbent upon a <i>dayan</i> to persevere, carry forward the <i>din torah</i>, and arrive at a <i>psak din shel emet</i>, a ruling reflective of the truth.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">For the various guidelines how to deal with deceit and fraud including under what conditions a <i>dayan</i> ought to recuse himself from continuing to adjudicate a case, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rambam</i>, Blau ed., 58; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 68:20, 77:4, 107:6; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:1209, 2:148, 283; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ran</i> 34; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 108; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 2:881; <i>Radvaz</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sanhedrin</i> 24:3; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 232, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 710; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 108; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Alsheikh</i> 40; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Alshakar</i> 119; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 15:3; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 15:12–13; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 15:5; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 75:1; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 15:9 in the name of <i>Shevut Ya’akov</i> 3:142 and <i>Avodat ha-Gershuni</i> 91; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 76; <i>PDR</i> 9:331, 349–351.<br>Though the rulings emerging from these aforementioned <i>sifrei psak</i> and <i>sifrei teshuvot</i> deal with a fabricated claim advanced by a litigant, nonetheless these rulings ought to be applicable to a <i>to’ein</i>’s argumentation which is marked by manipulation.</i>
Well aware of the machinations of the “<i>yetzer ha’ra</i>” (the evil impulse) and the existence of deception in the human persona, the late R. Eliyahu Dessler, <i>mashgiach ruhani</i> (spiritual supervisor and advisor) of the Ponevezeh Yeshiva in Eretz Yisrael observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mikhtav me-Eliyahu</i>, Yerushalayim, 1987, 60. A similar idea was echoed approximately two hundred years earlier by R. M. Luzzatto. See <i>Mesilat Yesharim</i>, <i>perek</i> 3.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Since bribery blinds the learned and man cannot discern his own faults, how can we ever arrive at the truth? … The answer is that bias never completely conceals the truth … the inability of the <i>yetzer</i> to obscure the truth entirely is the direct result of the Creator’s ever abiding kindness to his creatures. Every individual has the capacity of determining in his own heart where the actual truth lies.</span>
As Vilna Gaon observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Perush ha-Gra</i>, <i>Mishlei</i> 6:4.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The <i>dayanim</i> have to be proficient also in the way of the world in order to avoid a fraudulent judgment. If they will fail to have expertise in these matters even if they are well versed in Torah scholarship, the judgment will not be true.</span>
A Jew’s mission to discern between truth and manipulation equally extends to a Jew who assumes the mantle of <i>dayanut</i> who must deal with litigants and <i>to’anim</i> who may exhibit duplicity and deceit. Even if a litigant fabricates an argument in order to instill fear in the opposing part’s mind and heart, it is a <i>dayan</i>’s mandate to inform him “you are speaking a lie.”<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:12. Cf. others who contend that one can advance arguments (rather than claims) that entail deception. See. <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 2:17; <i>Sefer ha-Terumot</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 38, <i>helek</i> 1 (end) in the name of <i>Ra’avad</i>; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 75:57.</i> In other words, a <i>dayan</i> must be capable of discerning truth from falsehood regarding a litigant’s argumentation. We can expect no less from a <i>dayan</i> confronting a <i>to’ein</i>’s pleadings.
On the other hand, there are <i>battei din</i> today that prohibit the appearance of a <i>to’ein</i> at a <i>beit din</i> proceeding. For example, in Yerushalayim there is at least one <i>beit din</i> that will outlaw <i>to’anim</i> due to their deceptive tactics and another <i>beit din</i> that will ban them because the panel wants to hear from the litigants directly rather than through an intermediary.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Seder ha-Din</i>, supra n. 40, 516; Y. Freis, <i>av beit din</i> (presiding <i>dayan</i>) for a <i>beit din</i> in Ma’alei Adumin, Yerushalayim, in a written communication dated August 16, 2013 to this author.</i>
In conclusion, the propriety of allowing a <i>to’ein</i> to participate in a <i>beit din</i> proceeding is subject to controversy. Should a <i>to’ein</i>’s behavior be marked by deceit and manipulation, it is a matter of halakhic debate whether it then becomes the <i>dayan</i>’s responsibility to recuse him from this <i>din torah</i>. It is the prerogative of the <i>Posek</i> and/or <i>beit din</i> to decide what policy it ought to pursue regarding these matters.
<b>Addendum</b>
The foregoing presentation shows that there is a divergency of halakhic opinion regarding the propriety of retaining a <i>to’ein</i> of dubious credentials for a <i>beit din</i> proceeding. Despite the highly objectionable presence at a proceeding of a <i>to’ein</i> that is crafty and deceptive, nonetheless as we have shown, there are <i>Poskim</i> who fail to ban the institution and nonetheless trust that a <i>dayan</i> will have the ability to distinguish between truth and falsehood and arrive at a credible decision. And there are others who prohibit a <i>to’ein</i>’s appearance and are unwilling to rely upon the <i>dayan</i>’s ability to persevere and attain the <i>emet</i>, the truth, for the parties involved.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, there are other reasons for these differing positions regarding the retaining of a <i>to’ein</i>.</i>
This halakhic debate is not limited to our issue regarding the propriety of having a <i>to’ein</i> present at a <i>din torah</i>. In fact, there are numerous instances regarding <i>beit din</i> procedure where we encounter a controversy regarding the parameters of halakhic judicial ethics in general and the willingness to trust a <i>dayan</i> to render a proper <i>psak din</i> in particular. For example, prior to knowing that he would serve on a case, a <i>dayan</i> hears <i>ex parte</i> the arguments from one party and communicates to the party his opinion regarding the merits of the <i>tove’a</i>’s pleadings. Is that rabbi permitted to serve as a <i>dayan</i> for that pending matter? If a rabbi hears the arguments of only one side and offers his view concerning the matter, some <i>Poskim</i> are concerned that he has crystallized his position and therefore will not be receptive to weighing the evidence and arguments of the opposing party submitted at the time of the <i>din torah</i>. As such, he would be invalidated from serving as a <i>dayan</i> for the <i>din torah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; <i>Teshuvot Mishneh Halakhot</i> 17:120.</i> However, others would permit him to be retained as a <i>dayan</i> for the proceeding.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharbil</i> 3:97; <i>Teshuvot Maharlbach</i>, <i>Kuntres ha-Semikha</i> 147; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i>, <i>HM</i> 79; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:9. In such a situation, <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:5 and <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 17:11 require that the rabbi disclose to the opposing party that he heard the arguments of the opposing side prior to the proceeding. And should the party consent to the rabbi’s participation, he is permitted to serve on the <i>din torah</i>.</i> Here again, the question is: Can we trust the <i>dayan</i> to issue a credible <i>psak</i> or not after having heard the arguments <i>ex parte</i> from one party?
Another example of a debate that centers around our willingness to trust a <i>dayan</i> that he will hand down a credible decision deals with the procedures implemented in a <i>zabla</i> proceeding.
