Many <i>Poskim</i> will allow a <i>boreir</i> to speak prior to and during the proceeding with the party who has selected him.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kesef ha-Kodshin</i>, <i>HM</i> 17; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 2:143; <i>Teshuvot Mahari of Pozen</i> (Rav of Magen Avraham) 77; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 13:3–4; <i>Teshuvot Maharash Engel</i> 7:88; <i>Teshuvot Hemdat Shlomo</i> 22; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 9:136; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 8:302; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Shalom</i> (Krauss) 1:83; File no. 1158-68, Beit Din Yerushalayim 11:20, 23 (in the name of R. Elyashiv).</i> Nonetheless, others will prohibit such conduct.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 1:4;<i>Panim Meirot</i>, supra n. 15.</i> Whether the parties must remit equal compensation to their respective <i>boreir</i> is equally subject to debate. Some decisors insist that their renumeration must be identical<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Urim ve-Tumim</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 9; <i>Teshuvot Kerem Shlomo</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:26 (4).</i> while others permit that a <i>boreir</i>’s compensation may exceed that of the opposing <i>boreir</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Erekh Shai</i>, <i>HM</i> 9; <i>Mahari of Pozen</i>, supra n. 68; 8 <i>Kovetz Mashiv B’Halocha</i> 78–79 (Av–Elul 5752) in the name of <i>Mahari of Pozen</i>. See also, <i>Kesei Mishpat</i> 13.</i> In fact, some <i>shtarei borerut</i>, arbitration agreements, explicitly state that the <i>boreirim</i> may receive unequal compensation. In other words, parties may explicitly agree that a <i>dayan</i> may be a <i>noge’a ba-davar</i>, an interested party.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharitz</i> 218; <i>PDR</i> 7:225, 259 (R. Goldschmidt’s opinion). However if, for example, one party refuses to accept such an arrangement regarding unequal compensation, the compensation for the two <i>borerim</i> must be equal. See <i>Kesei Mishpat</i>, supra n. 71.</i> Here again, some authorities place their trust in <i>borerim</i> who conduct <i>ex parte</i> communications with their party and receive compensation for their services in an amount that exceeds the renumeration received by the opposing <i>boreir</i> from his party and still trust that they will retain their integrity and issue a proper ruling.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">In the event that a <i>boreir</i> is delinquent in his responsibility, the <i>shalish</i>, who is the third <i>dayan</i> chosen by the <i>boreirim</i> with the consent of the litigants, is prohibited from conducting <i>ex parte</i> communications with the parties, and receives the same renumeration for his services from both litigants, will render a credible <i>psak din</i>. See <i>Maharash Engel</i>, supra n. 68; <i>Panim Meirot</i>, supra n. 15.</i> In short, despite the disparity between the various judicial practices, the common thread that underlies all of these practices is that some <i>Poskim</i> are ready and prepared to trust in a <i>dayan</i>’s integrity to render a credible judgment under extenuating circumstances. As such, just like a <i>dayan</i> prior to a hearing who heard the arguments from one party in the absence of the opposing party, we trust in his ability to reach a just decision. Similarily, we trust that a <i>boreir</i> can advance sound and credible halakhic arguments for his client despite the fact that he may be engaging in <i>ex parte</i> communications with his client and may be receiving more compensation than the opposing <i>boreir</i>. Given such a posture, one can readily understand that many contemporary American and Israeli <i>Poskim</i> entrust a <i>dayan</i> with being able to deal with a <i>to’ein</i> of dubious credentials rather than advocating the abolishment of the institution.
Such conclusions will raise the eyebrows of individuals such as attorneys who have been imbued with a code of professional judicial ethics that looks askance at such practices. As noted by the <i>Beit Din ha-Gadol</i> in Yerushalayim, the halakhic guidelines for judicial responsibility may be markedly different than that of a civil code of judicial ethics.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">See File no. 113002793529, <i>Beit din ha-Gadol</i>, April 4, 2005; File no. 8123782, <i>Beit Din ha-Gadol</i>, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, September 27, 2011. In fact, in situations in which Halakha is divided over the propriety of a particular judicial practice, some decisors who may personally ascribe to the view which is in variance with the prevailing professional code of judicial ethics may opt to align their posture with the view of the legal code rather than be subjected to the aspersions cast upon them by attorneys! For such concerns, see File no. 8123782, op. cit.<br>If there would have existed halakhic unanimity that a rabbi who hears <i>ex parte</i> the arguments of one party may serve on the case as a <i>dayan</i> and that a <i>boreir</i> is allowed to engage in <i>ex parte</i> conversations with the party who chose him and receive from him compensation exceeding the amount remitted to the opposing <i>boreir</i>, there would still be a basis for outlawing such practices based upon <i>Hatam Sofer</i>’s teaching, “If the matter had been submitted to us, we would have legislated it.” In other words, even if the halakhic consensus would be to sanction such judicial practices, given that civil legislation in the format of professional codes of judicial ethics proscribes this conduct, invoking Hatam Sofer’s <i>sevara</i> (halakhic logic) decisors would choose to prohibit these practices. See infra ch. 8, “Dual Real Estate Commission, Illegal Contracts, and Civil Law.”</i> Obviously, in the United States, a <i>beit din</i> ruling is viewed as a binding arbitration decision provided the panel complies with the rules of civil arbitration. As such, the propriety of the particular judicial practice adopted by the panel, as well as requirements of proper disclosure to the parties of the potential prejudice of a <i>dayan</i>, must pass muster with the provisions of arbitration law. Failure in compliance with civil law requirements may result in a civil court vacating, nullifying the <i>beit din psak din</i>. As such, even if a particular judicial practice has halakhic approval, should it stand in variance with the rules of civil code of judicial ethics, a <i>beit din</i> ought to refrain from adopting such a practice based upon <i>dina demalkhuta dina</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Given that civil arbitration law mandates that an arbitration panel, including but not limited to a <i>beit din</i>, is required to comply with certain rules of civil procedure, Halakha recognizes such a mandate based upon the doctrine of <i>dina demalkhuta dina</i>. Whether this rule is valid biblically or rabbinically is a matter of debate. See <i>Avnei Miluim</i>, <i>EH</i> 28:2; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA EH</i> 28:3; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314; <i>Teshuvot Binyan Tzion</i> 2:15. Failure for a <i>beit din</i> to comply with a particular arbitration procedure entails the violation of an <i>issur</i>, a prohibition. See <i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Nedarim</i> 28a, <i>Bava Kama</i> 113a; <i>Teshuvot Maharshach</i> 2:219.</i> the law of the kingdom is the law, as well as avoid running the risk that its decision will be vacated by a civil court.

Part II; Rabbinic Authority; The Reality

Chapter 6; Decisions in Even haEzer

a) Spousal Rape, the Grounds for Divorcing an Adulterer, Retrieving Electronically Stored Information Incident to Divorce, and Nezikin Claims

<b>A. Spousal Rape, the Grounds for Divorcing an Adulterer, Retrieving Electronically Stored Information Incident to Divorce, and <i>Nezikin</i> Claims</b>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Rochel Rabinowitz v. Ya’akov Rabinowitz</i></span>
Ya’akov Rabinowitz (hereafter: <i>Nitva</i>) and Rochel Rabinowitz (hereafter: <i>Tova’at</i>) have been married in accordance with Halakha for ten years and reside in New Jersey. Rochel begins to suspect that her husband is having an affair. Rather than hire a private detective to observe her husband’s activities, she decides to engage in some “self-help discovery.” The <i>tova’at</i> boots up the family computer, which both the husband and wife use without passwords, and logs into the <i>Nitva</i>’s e-mails that had already been read and were in “post-transmission storage.” Among the e-mails she finds are numerous communications to and from a woman, one of the <i>Nitva</i>’s co-workers; the e-mails are intimate and of a romantic nature. After her discovery of these e-mails pointing to her husband’s engagement in an extra-marital affair and hearing rumors of his behavior, the <i>Tova’at</i> offered them as evidence during divorce proceeding for consideration by the <i>beit din</i> as grounds for obligating her spouse to deliver a <i>get</i> to her. Additionally, people observed him interacting with this woman.
Two years ago, the <i>Nitva</i> moved out of the marital home and he continues to refuse to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.
The above parties signed a <i>shtar borerut</i>, an arbitration agreement empowering this <i>beit din</i> panel to resolve this matter according to the applicable portions of the Shulhan Arukh and <i>Poskim</i>.
<b><i>Tova’at</i>’s Claims</b>
Based upon the production of the <i>Nitva</i>’s e-mails which reveal that over a period of a few months he has been engaging in an extra-marital affair, which exposes him to sexually transmitted diseases (STD) such as AIDS, as well as the fact that various individuals have submitted testimony that the <i>Nitva</i> has been seen in the company of this woman, the <i>Tova’at</i> is requesting that the <i>beit din</i> obligate the <i>Nitva</i> to deliver a <i>get</i> to the <i>Tova’at</i>.
Moreover, in the few times that the <i>Nitva</i> engages in conjugal relations, <i>Tova’at</i> claims that <i>Nitva</i> came to her incessantly during the night, insisted on repeated intercourse, forced her to engage in unnatural cohabitation, leaving her intolerably sleepless and exhausted.
<b><i>Nitva</i>’s Reply</b>
Though <i>Nitva</i> admitted that these e-mails were from his computer, nevertheless <i>Nitva</i> argues that he never wrote them. In addition, he argues that even if he is the author of these e-mails, it is a violation of Federal and NJ law as well as Halakha to submit evidence in marital disputes that has been unlawfully retrieved from electronically stored information. Furthermore, even if this improper conduct happened, <i>Nitva</i> claims he continuously protected his spouse by using a condom. Since a condom is highly effective in preventing HIV (the virus that causes AIDS), herpes simplex, hepatitis B, and gonorrhea, <i>Nitva</i> claims that he is not endangering his wife’s health and therefore a <i>get</i> should not be granted. Finally, the fact that he has been in the company of this woman does not mean that he is engaging in an illicit relationship with her. In the absence of definitive proof that he committed adultery, there are no grounds for a <i>beit din</i> to direct him to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.
<i>Nitva</i> admits to <i>Tova’at</i>’s claim of spousal rape, but argues that Rambam writes that a wife must be attentive to all his wishes.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 14:7, 15:18.</i> In fact, unnatural conjugal relations without his wife’s consent is seemingly sanctioned in a Talmudic dictum that states, “A husband may do whatever he wishes to his wife.”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 20b.</i>
In short, alleges <i>Nitva</i> unconditional intercourse is what a Jewish marriage is all about, and therefore, there are no grounds for giving his wife a <i>get.</i>
<b>Discussion</b>
<b>1. The Retrieval of Electronically Stored Data: New Jersey Privacy Law and the Halakha</b>
In pursuance to the terms of the <i>shtar borerut</i>, this matter is to be resolved in accordance with Halakha, and the norms of <i>minhag</i>, custom, do not dictate that this issue be addressed through the lens of NJ law. Nonetheless, since the <i>Nitva</i>’s defense in part relies upon New Jersey law, we have chosen to address the state of NJ law regarding this matter.
In reply to <i>Nitva</i>’s contention that the retrieval of electronically stored information incident to divorce is a violation of both Halakha as well as secular law, we beg to differ.
The passage of Federal Wiretap Act and NJ Wiretap Act in 1968 recognized a right to privacy in communications by prohibiting recording conversations through wiretaps on phones or hidden microphones. In 1986, due to technological advances, Congress amended the Wiretap Act with the passage of the Electronic Communications and Privacy Act (ECPA), and a few years later New Jersey amended the NJ Wiretap Act with provisions identical to the ECPA, prohibiting intentional interception of electronic communications such as cell phone conversations and e-mails.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">18 USC Sections 2701–2711 (2000); NJSA 2A: 156A-27 (a) (West 2000).</i>
The leading case regarding the accessing of a spouse’s e-mail in New Jersey is <i>White v. White.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">344 NJ Super. 211 (Ch. Div. 2001).</i> This case dealt with a husband filing a motion to suppress e-mails stored on a family computer hard drive which had been submitted to the court in order to buttress his wife’s divorce action alleging marital infidelity. Firstly, the court held that the language of the NJ Wiretap Act contains no explicit exemption for any wiretapping or any electronic communication by an aggrieved spouse. As noted by the court, it is already settled law in New Jersey that an inter-spousal exception does not exist.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Scott v. Scott</i>, 277 NJ Super. 601, 649 A. 2d 1372 (Ch. Div. 1994); <i>M.G. v. J.C.</i>, 254 NJ Super. 470, 603 A. 2d 990 (Ch. Div. 1991).</i> In fact, NJ is among the majority of states that does not provide for interspousal immunity in such a situation.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Glazner v. Glazner</i>, 347 F. 3d 1212 (11th Cir. 2003); P<i>eople v. Otto</i>, 831 P. 2d 1178, 1190 (Cal. 1992); <i>Kempf v. Kempf</i>, 868 F. 2d 970 (8th Cir. 1989); <i>US V. Jones</i>, 542 F. 2d 661 (6th Cir. 1976).</i>
Consequently, the court addressed the legality of the wife’s interception of her spouse’s e-mails. Following in the footsteps of <i>Steve Jackson Games, Inc. v. US Secret Service</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">36 F. 3d 457, 461–464 (5th Cir. 1994).</i> the court held that since the e-mail was accessed while in electronic storage, i.e., saved in the husband’s file cabinet rather than acquired during electronic transmission, such interception does not run afoul of the NJ Wiretap Act.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 4, at 220.</i> Messages read and saved are not within the scope of the NJ Wiretap Act. This understanding of federal and state legislation protected the right of a spouse to access e-mail stored on the hard drive of a family computer which could be accessed by all.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Had the husband failed to give consent to access the computer, such interception would not have been authorized. See supra n. 4, at 221.</i> Neither the system nor the files accessed were password protected. In other words, whether a spouse has a password-protected e-mail account will be the determinative factor in deciding whether access to e-mail stored on a hard drive of a family computer is unauthorized. When access is available to both spouses, as in <i>White v. White</i>, access is not considered to be without authorization.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Subsequent to the <i>White</i> decision, there has been NJ legislation enacted that would have considered intercepting e-mails post-transmission without authorization as a criminal offense. See NJSA, Section 2C:20–23 (q). See infra n. 13.</i> Other state jurisdictions have also endorsed this approach.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazard v. Hazard</i>, 833 SW 2d 911 (Tenn. Ct. App. 1991); <i>Trulock v. Freeh</i>, 275 F. 3d 391 (4th Cir. 2001); <i>State v. Appleby</i>, 2002 WL 1613716 (Del. Super. 2002).</i>
Finally, cyber-snooping may entail the invasion of privacy. Relying upon the seminal article authored by Dean Prosser,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">William L. Prosser, “Privacy,” 48 <i>Cal. L. Rev</i>. 383 (1960).</i> the authors of Section 652B of the Restatement (Second) of Torts recognize intrusion as grounds for invasion of privacy. To establish this tort there must have been an invasion of someone’s physical space. In accordance with the aforementioned section of the Restatement, a claim for an alleged intrusion obtains when the individual exhibited an “objectively reasonable expectation of seclusion or solitude in the place, conversation or data source.” Clearly, marriage does not deprive one of individual autonomy, but at the same time, each spouse does relinquish a certain degree of privacy. In <i>White v. White</i>, the court concludes that given that both spouses, albeit separated, had access to the computer (i.e., without password protection) and used it, there never existed an expectation of privacy. Hence, the wife’s access to her husband’s e-mails is not to be construed as an intrusion upon his privacy.
Based upon the foregoing, given that the <i>Nitva</i> consented to his wife’s access to the computer and given that her access was limited to the e-mails stored on the hard drive, therefore from a legal standpoint, we are at liberty of assessing the import of these e-mails in arriving at our conclusion over whether there are grounds for divorce or not.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Accessing e-mails from a computer’s hard drive may run afoul of the NJSA Section 2C:20–31, which was passed in 2003. Yet, as we explained, such actions will not violate the Wiretap Act. In other words, whereas <i>White v. White</i>, which was handed down in 2001, drew a distinction between the different types of storage in a computer, no such distinction is found in the above-cited legislation. Given that there is no case law dealing with this question and its impact on divorce matters, we continue to assume that the <i>Tova’at</i> would be exempt from criminal liability.</i>
Now, let us turn to how Halakha addresses these issues. Addressing whether there is exists a “marital home” exception to the <i>halakhot</i> of privacy, R. Shlomo Daichovsky states,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 14:321, 331.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">There are grounds that between a husband and wife one cannot speak about an “invasion of privacy,” since in the <i>ktav tena’im</i> [the agreement which memorializes the conditions of the engagement] that are prepared prior to the marriage it states: “They will refrain from any fraudulent conveyance or hiding anything from each other but they should live together with love and affection …” … This is a personal obligation to refrain from hiding or disclosing matters.</span>
Years later, R. Daichovsky elucidates the parameters of this notion of marital privacy,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 1217661, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Almonit</i>, June 29, 2004.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">In respectful families, it occurs frequently that either the husband or the wife read letters which are designated for their spouse or listen to telephone conversations which are for the other spouse, without receiving permission. Also, it happens that a spouse inspects the personal items of his spouse … Ought we consider them transgressors of the law? In my opinion, in matters between a couple there is no concept of individual privacy, their common zone of privacy is one unit … in the sphere of emotions and asset acquisition. How can one speak of an invasion of a spouse’s privacy, when the essence of marriage is the expansion of personal privacy into common privacy? Even if the couple is quarreling, as long as the marital tie persists or as long as there is no <i>beit din</i> divorce judgment, there continues to exist collective privacy …</span>
Recently, R. Avraham Meisels of Netanya Regional Beit Din reiterates R. Daichovsky’s line of argumentation.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 851788-2, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, May 7, 2012. See an earlier Netanya decision, file no. 3680-21-3, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, May 4, 2008.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Given that the prospective couple at the time of the wedding do not sign off on the <i>tena’im</i> and given that the <i>tena’im</i> is not drafted as a <i>bona fide shtar</i>, a halakhic-legal document, mutually obligating the couple to recognize a “marital exception” to the halakhic guidelines of individual privacy, the inclusion of such a phrase has been described as “<i>shufra d’shtara</i>” (lit. “the grace of an agreement”), a clause added for stylistic purposes, and has no halakhic import.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tuv Ta’am ve-Da’at</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, 18; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:110. See this writer’s <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, 187–189.</i> Furthermore, the assumption of marital privacy is that the couple is living “together with love and affection.” However, clearly in cases of domestic instability, a spouse may very well have no reluctance to disclose her spouse’s secrets.</span>
However, seemingly such a notion of a marital exclusion regarding privacy emerges from the <i>halakhot</i> of bailment. When an owner entrusts a <i>shomer</i>, i.e., a bailee, with an item to be guarded in the home of the bailee, it is assumed that the wife and sons, who are financially dependent upon the father,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:20.</i> and other members of the household of the bailee, will be involved in guarding the object.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:20–21.</i> There is a presumption that a family member who resides with the <i>shomer</i> is treated as an extension of the <i>shomer</i> and assumes the same responsibilities as the <i>shomer</i>. Similarly, we should conclude that all members of the household who reside in the same place may open the letter sent to the husband/father. Consequently, it is understandable to find that the rabbinic legislation which was passed in the eleventh century during the time of R. Gershon prohibiting an individual from opening up another’s letter only encompasses non-family members.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Da’at Kodshin</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 334.</i>
Such a position is seemingly open to challenge due to the difference between the matter of <i>pikadon</i> (i.e., bailment) and opening up another person’s letter without his permission. Whereas, the grounds for proscribing against the opening of a letter entail the commission of an <i>issur</i> (prohibition) such as theft, <i>geneivat da’at</i> (lit. “stealing of the mind”) or borrowing without consent,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Halakhot Ketanot</i> 1:276; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 3:47; <i>Teshuvot Hikekei Lev</i> 1, <i>YD</i> 49.</i> the case of <i>pikadon</i> entails expanding the scope of monetary liability of the <i>shomer</i> to apply to members of his household. But it seems that drawing an analogy between two such different <i>halakhot</i> as <i>pikadon</i> and opening up a friend’s letter is permissible.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 130b.</i> Though in certain places the Talmud states, “We don’t derive rulings in monetary matters from matters of <i>issur</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berakhot</i> 19b.</i> nevertheless, in other cases the Talmud does draw such analogies.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 6b; <i>Bava Batra</i> 47b. See <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 17, 53–57.</i> Consequently, there is a basis for the conclusion that Halakha recognizes spousal immunity in cases of privacy intrusions in the marital home akin to the extension of bailment responsibilities to all members of the family household.
Nonetheless, R. Asher ben Yehiel (known by the acronym “Rosh”), argues that one cannot assume that a husband desires to have his secrets disclosed to his wife by invoking the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>pikadon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Orhot Hayyim</i>, Klein ed., NY 5745, p. 47.</i> Stated differently, there is a zone of privacy even in the context of a husband and wife according to Rosh.
Subscribing to Rosh’s approach to marital privacy, are there grounds for a <i>beit din</i> to accept as evidence the e-mails that were opened up by the wife? If the conduct is prohibited, on what basis can a <i>beit din</i> accept evidence that was obtained improperly? In fact, R. Shlomo Goren prohibited any disclosure of contents of a letter without having the permission of the sender and receiver of the letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Shlomo Goren, “<i>Seder Nashim”</i> (Hebrew), 25 <i>Tehumin</i> 369 (5765).</i>
Notwithstanding this view, our position embodies the view well articulated many years ago by the renowned Israeli Supreme Court Justice Professor Silberg:<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Moshe Silberg, Talmudic Law and the Modern State, New York: Burning Bush, 1973, 82.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We see clearly that Jewish law does not establish a causal connection between the commission of an offense and the voiding of a civil contract … The violation of the law or morality is one thing, and the legal validity of the contract is another – to the extent that the fulfilling of the contract itself does not activate the offense … Precisely because Jewish law does not distinguish between law and morality, and that practically every performance of an obligation is at the same time a fulfillment of a religio-moral commandment – as in “the commandment” of repaying a debt of monetary obligation – the non-fulfillment of a contract entered into through a violation of law will only turn out to be an additional offense to supplement the original one committed by the transgressor.</span>
In other words, the universe of Halakha encompasses varying matters; some of them are identified as “<i>issur</i>” and other as “<i>mamon.</i>” As R. Avraham Sherman aptly observes, there are numerous occasions in which committing an <i>issur</i> does not have halakhic consequences for a related monetary issue. For example, even though the execution of a sale is prohibited on Shabbat, should it transpire, the sale is valid, and therefore both the seller and buyer have to abide by the consequences of the sale.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i>, supra n. 14, 293–294.</i> Similarly, though the <i>Tova’at</i> may have engaged in an <i>issur</i> by opening her husband’s e-mail, nevertheless the electronic communication is admissible in <i>beit din</i> in order to ascertain whether in fact there are grounds for the couple becoming divorced.
Addressing the nature of marriage, R. Malkiel Tenenbaum notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 4:144.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The matter of engagement and marriage between a husband and wife are no different than other <i>kinyanim</i>.</span>
Alongside the matters of personal status – namely <i>ishut</i>, which prohibits each spouse from living with a third party – the essence of marriage deals with the civil obligations between spouses, such as spousal support and medical care. Lest one conclude that R. Daichovsky’s advocacy of the notion of marital privacy inexorably leads to the inability of a <i>beit din</i> to “pierce the veil” of a couple’s privacy in order to cull information for the determination of various personal status and halakhic-legal consequences of divorce, he concludes,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Text accompanying n. 13. See also, <i>Hikekei Lev</i>, supra n. 21.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">A <i>beit din</i> has been chosen to inquire into the problems of the marriage and draw its conclusions. The status of a <i>beit din</i> is akin to a doctor, and it is incumbent upon each party to present the problems relating to the marital life, even if in the process he exposes the inappropriate conduct of his spouse.</span>
Notwithstanding the Rosh’s view about marital privacy, in our scenario, as we will demonstrate, no infringement of the husband’s privacy transpired due to the wife’s decision to read his e-mails. To arrive at this conclusion, we need to examine the prohibition of opening up somebody else’s letter. Our assumption is that R. Gershon’s legislation would have not been limited to the opening letters of others but would have also included our scenario, opening e-mail messages. Both entail a disclosure of information and therefore would be equally prohibited.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Tzvi Spitz, “Eavesdropping” (Hebrew), 3 <i>Divrei Mishpat</i> 338, 339 (5758).</i> As R. Sherman states,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i>, supra n. 14, at 292.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Clearly, there is no principled difference between communication of matters between two people via a letter or transfer of information via a technological device … and all the reasons offered by the authorities to prohibit viewing a letter sent by one person to a friend apply …</span>
The language of the legislation regarding opening another individual’s letter is the following:<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kol Bo</i>, 116; <i>Torat Hayyim</i>, supra n. 21.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">One should refrain from reading a letter sent by a man to his friend without his knowledge and without his permission.</span>
Seemingly, both the knowledge and permission of the sender are required for a third party to read the letter. In another text of the legislation, it states,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam of Rothenburg</i>, Prague ed., 1222; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Mintz</i> 102.</i> “And if he disposed of it, one is permitted [to read it].”
That being said, let’s examine how Halakha treats the requirement of obtaining permission prior to reading somebody else’s letter. Regarding a letter that has been thrown out, R. Moshe ben Haviv concludes that a third party may read it in accordance with the provision of the legislation.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Kol Gadol</i> 1:102. However, if a sealed letter were thrown away, there would be grounds to argue that one may not open it. See <i>Teshuvot Halakhot Ketanot</i> 1:59.</i> Even though the legislation requires knowledge that the author consents to its reading, the fact that it has been disposed of by the recipient of the letter is sufficient to allow a third party to read it.
Applying these guidelines to our case: Electronic communication read and/or downloaded from a family computer that is not password protected are analogous a letter that was discarded by an individual who was unconcerned whether his message would be read or not. Hence, a wife’s foray into her husband’s computer that is not password protected is not to be construed as an invasion of her husband’s privacy. In addition, the fact that the husband was unaware that his wife read his personal e-mail would still not demonstrate an infringement of privacy. Once the computer is not password protected, there is an implicit assumption that the husband has waived his right to know whether in fact his e-mail communications have been opened.
Alternatively, the avoidance of the commission of <i>issurim</i> trumps privacy concerns. As R. Daichovsky writes,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 15.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The obligation of <i>beit din</i> is to prevent a man from being in a marriage of <i>issur</i> … and where we are dealing with a biblical prohibition, there is no deference of respect accorded to human dignity and we are not concerned about his privacy.</span>
Without delving into the difference between human dignity and privacy,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, the two terms are not interchangeable. An instance may entail a violation of human dignity and not privacy infringement. Conversely, another situation may involve an infringement of privacy, but human dignity is not at stake.</i> neither halakhic notion will override a negative commandment of the Torah. Applying this conclusion to our scenario of the alleged adultery, there are two <i>issurim</i> which impact upon the halakhic integrity of the marriage. Firstly, as we know, it is incumbent upon the husband to engage in <i>onah</i>, i.e., conjugal relations. As the Torah teaches us, “<i>she’era kesuta ve-onatah lo yigra</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shemot</i> 21:10. Whether the <i>mitzva</i> is derived from the word “<i>she’era</i>” or “<i>ve-onata</i>” is subject to debate. See <i>Mekhilta de Rabbi Yishmael</i>, <i>Mishpatim</i> 3, ed. Horowiz-Rabin, 258–259.</i> – “her food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights, he shall not diminish.” The abstention from engaging in this <i>mitzva</i> generates a transgression of a negative precept.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Hinukh</i>, <i>mitzvat lo ta’aseh</i> 59, Chavel ed.; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 69.</i> Should there be a fear that a husband will travel away from the marital home against his wife’s will and thereby result in an inability for the wife to live with him, a <i>beit din</i> will issue a restraining order against his right to travel.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 76:5.</i> Given that the husband finds satisfaction from his illicit relationship, he may choose to abstain from fulfilling his <i>onah</i> obligations with his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:16; File no. 2109-13-1, Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, July 18, 1999. The citation of these sources is simply to corroborate that <i>Poskim</i> were aware of the consequences of a husband engaging in an illicit relationship.</i> Should the husband be deemed a <i>moreid</i> (lit. “rebellious”) due to his failure to comply with the dictates of the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>onah</i>, he is obligated to divorce her.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Derisha</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:2; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:2; <i>PDR</i> 7:75, 78.</i> Secondly, the actual commission of adultery entails the transgressing of an <i>issur</i>.
On the other hand, though there is no halakhic duty upon the wife to have conjugal relations with her husband, a wife is bound to her husband (<i>meshu’abedet</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The utilization of <i>shi’abud</i>, i.e., servitude, is not to be construed as ownership. See J. David Bleich, “<i>Kiddushei Ta’ut</i>: Annulment as a Solution to the <i>Agunah</i> Problem,” 33 <i>Tradition</i> 90, 116 (1998).</i> as an incident of the establishment of the marriage,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 6b; <i>Nedarim</i> 15b; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:20; <i>Teshuvot Tzit Eliezer</i> 1:42 (4).</i> provided that he remains faithful to his wife. In our scenario, in light of her husband’s conduct she is repulsed by having to live with him,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 77 (end).</i> engendering mental anguish and stress<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">S<i>ee Ha’amek Davar Bereshit</i> 34:2, <i>Devarim</i> 22:24; <i>PDR</i> 8:124, 141.</i> leading to abstaining from engaging in conjugal relations. Her obligation ceases to exist in such a situation and she may separate from him, leave the marital home, and/or request a <i>get</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:3; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:1.</i> As one contemporary <i>Posek</i> notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Mordechai Gross, “The Obligation of <i>Onah</i> when the Wife is Suspicious of her Husband” (Hebrew), 5 <i>Divrei Mishpat</i> 90–91 (5758).</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">On this condition she didn’t bind herself in marriage, since the duty of <i>onah</i> mandates a meeting of the minds between them.</span>
In addition, the husband’s adultery has certain detrimental financial results to the marriage. As Aguda rules (cited authoritatively by
Rema),<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Aguda</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 65b, <i>siman</i> 77; <i>SA</i>, <i>Rema</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:1.</i> one of the grounds for divorce from an adulterer is based upon the fact that such conduct has a financial impact upon the marriage. The illicit relationship creates financial havoc as well as a breach of love and trust in the marriage. “An adulterer wastes money,”<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Aguda</i>, supra n. 49.</i> as assets that could have been expended for maintaining the domestic household are being earmarked for illicit conduct.
In short, the husband and woman who engage in an adulterous relationship destroy the family unit both halakhically, by the married couple’s mutual refusal to live with each other, as well as by unconsciously diverting funds that were destined for the husband’s family. Focusing upon the rationale for outlawing adultery, a <i>beit din</i> observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 1:5, 13.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It is not because of the sin that was committed … but rather because of the destruction of marital life resulting from the husband’s behavior.</span>
Applying these guidelines to our case, which deals with electronic communications read and/or downloaded from a family computer that is not password protected, clearly the exposure of an act of adultery that entails the potential breakup of family living serves as grounds for infringing upon the husband’s privacy. Even the potential loss of money trumps protecting the privacy of electronic communications. As R. Yosef Kolon points out, the mitzva of <i>hashavat aveida</i>, restoring lost property to its owner, trumps Rabbeinu Gershon’s edict against opening up somebody else’s communications.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 110.</i> In other words, recovery of lost assets under any circumstances trumps privacy considerations.
Even if the case had dealt with a password-protected computer, similar conclusions would have been drawn. The halakhic legislation enacted during the life of R. Gershon was to facilitate the continued observance of Halakha rather than allow the committed to falter due to the commission of prohibitions.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:557.</i> Moreover, should the wife’s reading of her husband’s e-mails be deemed an infringement of his privacy as well as inadmissible as evidence in <i>beit din</i>, this would prevent the <i>beit din</i> from being able to determine the facts on the ground, namely, whether in fact there is a basis for divorce. In concluding his essay, R. Spitz states,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 31, at 328. See also Netanya Beit Din, supra n. 16.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">There are instances where reading personal communications … is for the purpose of sustaining the Torah and establishing religion in place. In these situations and the like, we are allowed to look … at confidential materials, and the edict of <i>R. Gershon</i> is inapplicable.</span>
Finally, as pointed out by Aguda, and subsequently by Rema and others, the primary reason for a wife’s right to divorce her husband is grounded in the potential medical danger to herself.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 48. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 42:1; <i>Teshuvot Ma’aset Moshe</i>, vol. 1, <i>EH</i> 17; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 115; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 3:30; <i>Taz</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 39:5; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 39:9; <i>Teshuvot Nish’al Dovid</i>, <i>EH</i> 46; <i>PDR</i> 5:280; Tel Aviv Beit Din, infra n. 101.</i> There is the clear possibility that due to the husband’s illicit affairs, he has been exposed to the contraction of AIDS and other STDs and is therefore a potential danger to his spouse’s health and life. Lest one argue that the husband’s use of a condom eliminates the potential of contracting any of these STDs, condoms, like all contraceptives, are not 100% foolproof. Frequently, condom failure is due to human factors, such as the failure to use a condom consistently or incorrect use of the prophylactic. Sometimes, condoms stored in excessive heat for an extended period of time may also fail. Though the use of a condom is highly effective in preventing AIDS, and a study has shown that even among individuals with repeated sexual contact, 98–100% of those who used latex condoms correctly and consistently did not become infected,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">“How Effective are Latex Condoms in Preventing HIV?” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, www.cdc.gov/hiv/pubs/faq/faq23.htm.</i> nevertheless, their use does not eliminate the risk entirely.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Prevention message in response to Pl 106–554, CDC, July 5, 2001.</i>
Based upon the foregoing, given that many times condom failure is due to human factors, the question is whether Halakha would sanction a wife’s exposure to the distinct possibility that she may contract AIDS. In addition, we should consider the mental stress the wife may experience as the result of the potential risk. The question is whether such concerns of being infected by STDs by one’s spouse and mental stress generated by such endangerment serve as grounds for dissolving a marriage.
Dealing with a case of a husband diagnosed with AIDS and whether the wife must continue to remain in the home, a Tel Aviv <i>beit din</i> rules,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 2109131,Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, July 18, 2009.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">In our times, regretfully the AIDS disease has spread and we cannot comfort the wife that she should continue to live with her husband and rely upon him that he will be vigilant in complying with proper protocol …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We know many men who have died from this disease even though they followed proper protocol and due to the fact that once they engaged in sex with no protection, they were infected by this disease …</span>
Though this case deals with a husband who already is a victim of AIDS, the halakhic recognition of the human factor in condom failure, which increases the risk of infection to a wife, would equally apply to our scenario in which the husband has yet to contract HIV.
Even though the aforesaid study found that the contraction of AIDS is a minimal risk by those who use a condom, the possibility of condom failure still looms and therefore such a situation would be labeled a “<i>safek sakana</i>,” lit. “a doubt of danger,” and therefore under such circumstances, a wife’s right to divorce exists.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ra’vyah</i>, <i>Teshuvot of Rabbi Rothenburg</i>, Cremona ed., 165; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, supra n. 41; <i>Teshuvot Be’er Mayyim Hayyim</i> 7; Eliav Shochetman, “The Disease of AIDS as Grounds for Divorce” (Hebrew) 25, <i>Mishpatim</i> 19, 34–35 (5755).<br>It should be no different if spousal assault occurs and there is a danger to the victim’s life; there would be grounds for delivery of a <i>get</i>. See <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:9; <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 69; <i>Teshuvot Mateh Lehem</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:8.</i>
Moreover, should the husband have actually contracted HIV or any other STD and the wife agrees to continue living with him, there is no Halakha that states that should the wife suddenly experience emotional stress regarding the potential danger, that she cannot change her mind and demand a divorce.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 53.</i>
In short, should a wife suspect that her husband is a womanizer, the concerns of potential or possible infection, as well the engendering of stress due to her spouse’s engagement in extramarital affairs, serves to justify invading her husband’s personal communications, even those found on a password protected computer.
In sum, reading e-mail communications of one’s spouse from a computer with password protection and discovering that one’s husband is an adulterer is not construed as an invasion of privacy. The potential medical endangerment to the wife’s life, coupled with the likelihood of family breakdown, both in terms of the absence of conjugal relations and possibly undermining the fiscal stability of the home, justify opening up a husband’s personal communications. Such grounds trump the legislation during the time of R. Gershom that one cannot open up a person’s letters without his permission. Moreover, as we have shown, given that we are dealing with a home computer without password protection, even in the absence of the aforesaid extenuating circumstances, a wife would be allowed to access her husband’s e-mails without his express permission.
<b>2. The <i>Nitva</i>’s Admission of Adultery</b>
Given the admissibility of an e-mail communication as evidence, seemingly we can corroborate the wife’s allegation that her husband is an adulterer, and therefore, there would arguably be grounds for having him deliver a <i>get</i> to her.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 1; <i>PDR</i> 1:139, 141; 8:124,126, 216, 225; 14:300, 311. For another case regarding adultery, see <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 17, 212–213.</i> In effect, the e-mails should be construed as the husband’s admission that he in fact committed the adultery.
This conclusion can be justified based upon the principle of “<i>hoda’at ba’al din kemay’ah edim dami</i>” (lit. “the admission [of liability] by a litigant is akin to one hundred witnesses”). However, one might protest that this rule applies only to monetary matters,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 1:10; <i>Bava Metzia</i> 3b.</i> but in <i>dinei nefashot</i>, criminal matters, we invoke the doctrine “one cannot render oneself a wicked person”<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 9b.</i> as per the well-known ruling of Rambam,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sanhedrin</i> 18:6.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It is a scriptural decree that the court shall not put a man to death … on his own admission … For it is possible that he was confused in mind when he made the confession …</span>
We nevertheless contend that the rule of <i>hoda’at ba’al din</i> is applicable here. Self-incriminating statements are inadmissible regarding criminal matters; however an admission of liability regarding an adulterous relationship, which can destroy a family, is a dispute between two individuals in which admission is acceptable evidence.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 34:36 in the name of <i>Sefer ha-Terumot</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 21, 2:3; <i>PDR</i> 1:5, 13; 14:300, 311. Cf. <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>EH</i> 154, <i>ha-gaha</i> 45 in the name of <i>Mishpat Zedek</i>; <i>Teshuvot Mahane Hayyim</i> 2, <i>EH</i> 45.<br>In fact, a wife’s testimony of her husband being an adulterer is admissible. See <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:1.<br>Recently, a <i>beit din</i> awarded monetary damages based upon a husband’s admission that he was physically abusive towards his wife. See File no. 25449-2, Ashdod Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, November 9, 2013.</i>
In lieu of two witnesses testifying that the act of adultery transpired, an adulterer’s admission will suffice. Seemingly, such an admission occurred. In a recent case of the Be’er Sheva Regional Beit Din, the panel concluded that a husband’s placement of an ad on the internet looking for a wife, accompanied by his personal information along with his picture, would be admissible as evidence to prove that he was a womanizer.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 040135832211, Be’er Sheva Regional Beit Din, February 26, 2007, cited in <i>ha-Din ve-ha-Dayan</i>, <i>gilyon</i> 15, 3.</i> However, with all due respect, we disagree that such evidence may serve as an admission regarding his actions. There is no demonstrable proof that the husband placed these materials on the internet. In fact, the same lack of proof is equally applicable to our scenario. The “admission” was extrapolated from a series of e-mails, rather than having been heard from the adulterer himself. Addressing e-mails found on a cell phone a recent Netanya <i>beit din</i> decision states,<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, supra n. 16.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We cannot rely upon what is written there since the writing is electronic writing, and clearly we cannot identify who wrote these words. Unlike a handwritten note in which we can ascertain its veracity based upon witnesses’ corroboration or comparing it with other documents written by the same individual,<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 69:12; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen HM</i> 46:5; <i>Sefer ha-Terumot</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 13, vol. 1, <i>Halakha</i> 4; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 69:8.<br>Whether one can prohibit a husband from continuing to live with his wife based upon document comparison is subject to debate. See <i>Teshuvot Emek She’ela</i> 17 and <i>Teshuvot Avnei Nezer</i>, <i>EH</i> 34.</i> in the case of an e-mail, absent the presence of witnesses at the time of writing, there is no possibility for ascertaining whether the husband wrote the e-mail, in particular given that the computer was not password protected.</span>
<b>3. The Evidentiary Standards to Corroborate the <i>Nitva</i>’s Adultery</b>
In the absence of a husband’s admission, R. Alexander Zuslin concludes<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Aguda</i>, supra n. 49.</i> that we require “<i>eidim</i>, witnesses, who observed him with the woman in the manner of adulterers.”
The question is whether R. Zuslin’s ruling mandates that the actual fornication be observed. Based upon Hagahot Maimoniyot, which has been authoritatively cited by R. Feinstein,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hagahot Maimoniyot</i>, <i>Teshuvot ha-Shayahot le-Sefer Nashim</i> 1; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh Yevamot</i> 2:8; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 178:16; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>YD</i> 1:47, <i>EH</i> 1:22, 24, 82.</i> we find the following:
<span class="poetry indentAll">It is in particular with regard to the conjugal act that we construe that witnesses to a couple’s seclusion are considered witnesses that the couple engaged in sex. The reason is because we say, “Can fire touch straw and not ignite it?” Furthermore, he is not ashamed in her presence. Moreover, we cannot observe “the paint stick in the tube” as that would be abhorrent.</span>
In effect, Hagahot Maimoniyot is suggesting two different justifications why witnesses are not required to observe the act itself. Firstly, there is an <i>umdana</i>, i.e., a logical inference based upon the facts that when individuals are isolated and secluded from the outside world, they are unable to control their drives, and the sex act will transpire. Secondly, even though there does not exist absolute certainty that the act occurred, nevertheless due to the difficulty of such an observation and the fact that it is an embarrassment, Halakha suffices with mere contact of body parts rather than mandating observation of the act itself.
However, in the absence of a husband’s admission or the actual observation of the act by <i>eidim</i>, normative Halakha, as codified by Rema, states,<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:1.</i> “If witnesses saw him with adulterers, some say that he can be coerced to give a <i>get.</i>”
In other words, whereas R. Zuslin requires actual testimony of the event and Hagahot Maimoniyot maintains that contact between bodies is required to label him an adulterer, some argue we can coerce him to give a <i>get</i><sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">For the type of coercion and whether in actuality Rema concurs with this opinion is subject to debate and beyond the scope of our presentation.</i> provided only that he was seen amongst other adulterers. This approach has been subscribed to by various Israeli <i>battei din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 1212720, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, March, 7, 2001 cited by <i>ha-Din ve-Ha-Dayan</i>, <i>gilyon</i> 6; File No. 8501062, File no. 059835603211, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, May 5, 2002 cited by <i>ha-Din ve-ha-Dayan</i>, <i>gilyon</i> 2.</i> This conclusion is not limited to situations in which the husband is in physical proximity to other adulterers. Even if he converses with women on the internet on websites that are pornographic, that will serve as grounds for labeling him an adulterer.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 1215162, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, Tammuz 13, 5766.</i>
Furthermore, a Netanya <i>beit din</i> relied upon “<i>kala de-lo pasik</i>” (a persistent rumor), which in the eyes of the panel creates virtual certainty (<i>umdena mukhahat</i>) that the conduct has happened.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 067596809211, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, April 26, 2004.</i> The <i>beit din</i> is distinguishing between a firmly established rumor and <i>a</i> “<i>rinnun be-alma</i>” (a mere rumor), which does not serve as evidence that the alleged incident took place. R. Eliyahu ben Hayyim (known by the acronym: Ranah) suggests that there are two conditions that have to be obtained in order for the rumor to be labeled a “<i>kala de-lo pasik</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 2:41. See also <i>Teshuvot Mayyim Hayyim</i> 2:52; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>OH</i> 25; <i>Magen Avraham</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 53:7.</i> First, the rumor must have been heard by many individuals and not have subsided. Second, one must ascertain the source of the rumor. If one finds that the initiator of the rumor is an enemy of the alleged abuser, the rumor will be discounted. Based upon the foregoing, in our case, we are dealing with a persistent rumor and we therefore have grounds to direct the husband to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.
In short, in the absence of a husband’s admission or the presence of a two <i>eidim</i> who observed the act, other forms of evidence, such as contact between the two bodies who allegedly are engaging in an illicit affair, the association of the husband with a circle of adulterers, and persistent rumors, all serve as evidentiary standards to determine whether the husband is in actuality an adulterer. As R. Moshe Sofer aptly notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:94.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It seems that the Torah did not require [two <i>eidim</i>] except when the <i>beit din</i> did not know without the two witnesses. But a matter that is clear to them without having to trust witnesses is as if they observed it on their own. And just like if the <i>beit din</i> witnessed the event themselves, the Halakha would be handed down without <i>edut</i> … Similarly, if at every stage the <i>beit din</i> knows clearly the matter without the trustworthiness of a witness, they are empowered to judge without testimony, and it is not subsumed under the category of “upon two witnesses.”</span>
Given that the parties signed off on an arbitration agreement, this panel is empowered to resolve whether there are grounds for a divorce judgment based upon <i>umdana</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i>, 3:142; <i>Teshuvot Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 3:32:3.</i>
Finally, in accordance with Rema and other <i>Poskim</i>, given that the adulterer has continued in his illicit affair, engages in conjugal relations with his wife on a sporadic basis, exposes his wife to the possibility of contracting STDs, and is contributing by his behavior to the breakdown of his family, we would seek rabbinical counsel, and had this case transpired in Eretz Yisrael we would have discussed the possibility of coercing the husband to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, supra n. 65; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, supra n. 41; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:67; <i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i> 6, <i>EH</i> 106; <i>PDR</i> 12:26. Given that coercive measures are only possible in Eretz Yisrael, such a possibility would not materialize in the Diaspora.</i> However, even though the <i>Nitva</i> was not forewarned regarding the impropriety and consequences of his conduct,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 17, 205–206.</i> we will now <i>obligate</i> him to give a <i>get</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hakham Tzvi</i> 133; <i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i> 2, <i>EH</i> 45; <i>PDR</i> 8:257. Cf. others who argue that if the husband has frequently been engaged in illicit affairs, there is no need to forewarn him. See <i>Teshuvot Havot Binyamin</i> 2:48.</i>
<b>4. The <i>Mitzva</i> of <i>Onah</i> and Spousal Rape</b>
In <i>Bereshit</i>, we encounter a description of the first marriage between a man and a woman,
<span class="poetry indentAll">And therefore man shall leave his father and mother, cling to his wife and they will become one flesh.</span>
A literal interpretation of this verse has led English and American jurists from the eighteenth century through the early twentieth century to subscribe to Blackstone’s legal depiction of marriage,<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">William Blackstone, <i>Commentaries on the Law of England</i>, Oxford, 1768, 1:422,430–431</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">By marriage, the husband and wife are one person in law, that is, the very being or legal existence of the woman is suspended during the marriage, or at least is incorporated and consolidated into that of the husband; under whose wing, protection, and cover she performs everything … Upon this principle of a union of person in husband and wife, depend almost all the legal rights, duties, and disabilities, that either of them acquire by the marriage.</span>
More recently, the idea was well captured by law professor Lawrence Friedman,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Lawrence Friedman, <i>A History of American Law</i>, NY 1974, 184. See this writer’s, “A Comparative Analysis of a Wife’s Capacity to Pledge her Husband’s Credit for Domestic Necessaries in Anglo-American Law and Jewish Law,” (hereafter: Domestic Necessaries) 13, <i>The Jewish Law Annual</i> 213,215–220 (2000).</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Essentially, husband and wife were one flesh; but the man was the owner of the flesh.</span>
Accepting such a position has led Lord Matthew Hale to conclude that a husband cannot be guilty of spousal rape because,
<span class="poetry indentAll">By their mutual matrimonial consent and contract the wife hath given up herself in this kind unto her husband, which she cannot retract.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">M. Hale, “The History of the Pleas of the Crown,” 629, S. Emlyn ed., 1778.</i></span>
As recently as the year 2000, the majority of American states continue to invoke this marital exemption rule, which is rooted in the outdated notion that a wife is the property of her husband<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Jill Hasday, “Contest and Consent: A Legal History of Marital Rape,” 88 <i>California L. Rev.</i> 1375 (2000).</i> and preempts prosecuting a husband for marital rape.
Seemingly, the halakhic recognition of “<i>ishto ke-gufo</i>” (lit. “his wife is like himself”) embodies the same notion propounded by common law jurists. But in fact, a cursory glance of its use in the Talmud leads us to a different conclusion. Due to “<i>ishto ke-gufo</i>,” a husband lying near his wife may recite <i>keriat shema</i> and would not be distracted from the prayer, a wife of a priest cannot submit testimony regarding a blemish of a first-born animal, and a portion of damages awarded to a wife are payable to her husband. On the other hand, a wife may not lay her hands on an animal sacrifice as an agent on behalf of her husband even though “<i>ishto ke-gufo</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berakhot</i> 24a; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 76b; <i>Bekhorot</i> 35b; <i>Menahot</i> 93b.</i> In all these instances, the concept of “<i>ishto ke-gufo</i>” is invoked to demonstrate the psychological unity of the marriage rather than as an impingement of the wife’s legal rights, such as executing contracts or acquiring property.
In addressing the notion of marital privacy, R. Daichovsky elaborates on this psychological dimension as defining the marital ties:<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 15</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">In respectful families it occurs frequently that either the husband or the wife read letters that are designated for their spouse or listen to telephone conversations that are for the other spouse, without receiving permission. Also, it happens that a spouse inspects the personal items of his spouse … Ought we consider them transgressors of the law? In my opinion, in matters between a couple, there is no concept of individual privacy, their common zone of privacy is one unit … in the sphere of emotions and asset acquisition. How can one speak of an invasion of a spouse’s privacy, when the essence of marriage is the expansion of personal privacy into common privacy? Even if the couple is quarreling, as long as the marital tie persists or as long as there is no <i>beit din</i> divorce judgment, there continues to exist collective privacy.</span>
Halakha does not deny legal capacity to a wife, as it does to a minor or mentally deficient individual. In fact, “<i>ishto ke-gufo</i>” has been invoked to demonstrate that a wife has legal capacity. For example, generally speaking, should an employer fail to pay his employee in a timely fashion, he violates a prohibition. If an employee is hired by a man’s wife, and does not receive his salary on time, the husband has violated the prohibition based on the rule of “<i>ishto ke-gufo.</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 339:7.</i> Likewise, although a father cannot redeem his first-born son (<i>pidyon ha-ben</i>) via an agent, nevertheless a husband may appoint his wife to perform this <i>mitzva</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 305:10. On the other hand, Halakha invokes “<i>ishto ke-gufo</i>” to serve as basis for a husband’s obligation to redeem his wife from captivity<i>.</i> See <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 78:2.</i> Finally, regarding transactions executed by a wife relating to her husband’s properties, Ravan states,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Ravan</i> 115; <i>Domestic Necessaries</i>, supra 83, 221–235.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">All wives now are guardians of their husband’s properties and a guardian is an agent … therefore, her transactions are by virtue of her agency …</span>
According to numerous <i>Poskim</i> who adopt Ravan’s position,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yam shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:29; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 96:9; <i>Urim ve-Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 96:17; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 96:11; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i> 2:18; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Alsheikh</i> 19; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 96:8; <i>PDR</i> 2:289, 292.</i> there is a <i>hazaka</i> (presumption) that creates a wife’s implied agency, provided that the wife is engaging in a business-like undertaking.
This notion of a wife’s capacity and autonomy fully expresses itself in the context of conjugal relations, which is the matter of contention in this case. The essence of matrimony is the establishment of a personal tie, i.e., <i>ishut</i>, whereby each spouse is permitted to live with one another and simultaneously prohibited to live with a third party. <i>Onah</i>, as we mentioned earlier in our <i>psak din</i>, entails the engagement in conjugal relations, and its scope and parameters define the halakhic expression of <i>ishut</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Ittur</i>, <i>Ot Mered</i> 68a; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 38:12 in the name of <i>Drisha</i>.</i> Though there is no halakhic duty upon the wife to have conjugal relations with her husband, a wife is bound to him (<i>meshu’abedet</i>) as an incident of the establishment of the marriage.
Being <i>meshu’abedet</i> to her husband does not inexorably lead to the conclusion that a wife loses her autonomy and emotional integrity regarding the governance of her intimate relations. Generally speaking, there are <i>halakhot</i> governing the relationship between parties. Nevertheless, in accordance with normative Halakha, the rules relating to monetary matters may be subject to change by mutual agreement of the parties. Consequently, with regard to <i>halakhot</i> that deal with spousal support and maintenance, if the couple decides to modify the rules, such an agreement would be valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 19b.</i> However, according to many <i>Poskim</i>, regarding <i>onah</i>, which entails a non-financial matter, one is prohibited to modify its requirements.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">See authorities cited by <i>Mishneh la-Melekh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 6:10.</i> The inability to modify conditions in a non-financial matter stems either from the halakhic denial of an individual’s right to modify the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>onah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 6:8–10.</i> or from a lack of <i>gemirat da’at</i> (firm resolve) on the part of the individual in stipulating a condition in variance with Halakha.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 94a, s.v. “<i>ve-amar</i>.”</i> One of the rationales offered for this conclusion is that releasing a husband from his duty will only lead to emotional distress for the wife, who will be unable to engage in conjugal relations.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 56a; Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Kiddushin</i> 1:2.</i>
However, in accordance with the Talmud Yerushalmi, there are other <i>Poskim</i> who argue that if the wife explicitly waives her right to conjugal relations, such a waiver would be valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>BB</i> 7:7; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 56a, s.v. “<i>harei zu</i>”; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 213 in the name of <i>Ritva</i>.</i> Once she requests a return to a life of intimacy, he becomes obligated again in the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>onah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh la-Melekh</i>, supra n. 94; <i>Lehem Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 15:1.</i> Moreover, even those authorities who prohibit a husband from contracting out of <i>onah</i>, nevertheless will permit him to abstain temporarily from <i>onah</i> when his wife permits him, such as while he is traveling and away from their home for an extended period of time.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 62b; <i>SA</i>, <i>Rema</i>, <i>EH</i> 76:5.</i> Here again, she may withdraw her permission at any time.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 6:10; <i>Mishneh la-Melekh</i>, supra n. 94; File no. 3426-21-3, Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, January 28, 2008.</i> On an ongoing basis, though a couple may engage in unnatural form of intercourse, a husband cannot force himself upon his wife against her wishes. As <i>Poskim</i> rule, a husband cannot compel conjugal relations, much less insist upon engaging in unnatural intercourse with his spouse.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 25 in the name of <i>Ra’avad</i>; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 25:2.</i> These <i>halakhot</i> are a reflection of the overarching need that intercourse must be consummated in joyful circumstances rather than in situations of wrath and tensions.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 15:17; <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 240:3.</i>
One of the unforeseeable and unintended consequences of spousal rape is that the wife may be physically injured by the husband’s conduct. The fact that <i>onah</i> is a <i>mitzva</i> does not create an exemption for injury.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Bava Kama</i> 6:13; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 418:12; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 207.</i> Hence, Hazon Ish contends that engagement in the <i>mitzva</i> of <i>onah</i> does not serve as a defense.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 11:21.</i> Even if the husband unintentionally injured his wife due to losing his self-control, i.e., <i>ones</i>, a situation that can occur through engaging in conjugal relations in general and spousal rape in particular, we nevertheless have the rule “<i>adam mu’ad le-olam</i>,” a person is always deemed forewarned.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 378:1.</i> Based on this reasoning, numerous <i>Poskim</i> argue that it is the husband’s responsibility to foresee the possibility of potential injury, and therefore if injury transpired, he is responsible.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 11:21.</i>
The foregoing presentation demonstrates that the husband’s <i>onah</i> obligation under certain prescribed conditions can be circumscribed, and the wife’s <i>shi’abud</i> to conjugal relations does not translate into coerced cohabitation. In fact, as we have shown, a concern for the wife’s physical and emotional integrity expresses itself in the <i>halakhot</i> governing <i>onah</i>.
That said, if a wife wants to refrain from <i>onah</i> then she must demonstrate the reason(s) for her refusal to cohabit. Should her claim(s) be corroborated, the <i>beit din</i> will issue a judgment that the husband ought to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.
In advancing the claim that the husband is despicable,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The claim is characterized as “despicable” in terms of her distaste in engaging in <i>onah</i> with him. Whether “<i>ma’is alai</i>” is applicable to an instance of hatred unrelated to <i>onah</i>, see <i>PDR</i> 9:171, 181–184.</i> the <i>Tova’at</i> is in effect articulating the Talmudic plea of “<i>ma’is alai</i>” (“he is repulsive to me”).<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 63a.</i> Such a claim finds resonance in Rambam’s ruling:<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 14:8.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">A wife who denies her husband conjugal relations is called a <i>moredet</i> (a rebellious wife). If upon being asked why she has rebelled, she responds that her husband has become repulsive to her and she cannot voluntarily live with him, the husband will be compelled to release her since she is not like a captive woman who has sexual relations with one whom she despises.</span>
Regarding the list of cases of “compelled” divorce in the Mishnah and the Talmud as closed, and concerned that the wife may have “cast her eye on another man,” certain <i>Poskim</i>, notably Rabbeinu Tam and Rosh, reject a wife’s right to receive a <i>get</i> on the grounds of such a plea.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 63b, s.v. “<i>aval</i>” in the name of <i>R. Tam</i>; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 43:3, 8; <i>Tosafot Ketuvot</i> 64a, s.v. “<i>avel</i>” in the name of <i>Rabbeinu Hananel</i> and <i>Rashi</i>; <i>Sefer Meisharim</i>, <i>netiv</i> 23:8; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 14:8; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ran</i> 62; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhosot le-Ramban</i> 138; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, 2:256; <i>Teshuvot Mahari Bruna</i> 211; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 77; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:2; <i>Teshuvot Zekan Aharon</i> 149.<br>Despite their position, there were <i>Poskim</i> such as Rosh who coerced a <i>get</i> in situations in which the plea was at least as repulsive and/or infectious or similar to the grounds of divorce recorded in the Mishnah and Talmud. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 42:1; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:693; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 2:8; <i>Sefer ha-Aguda</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 77; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 9; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, ad locum; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 154; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:1, 3.</i> Nevertheless, there are numerous <i>Poskim</i> who endorse Rambam’s position.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 63b, s.v. “<i>aval</i>”; <i>Semag</i> 1, <i>mitzva lo ta’aseh</i> 81; <i>Teshuvot Maharam ben Barukh</i>, Prague ed., 946 in the name of <i>Rashi</i>; <i>Shiltei ha-Gibborim</i> on <i>Rif</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 63b in the name of <i>Rashi</i>; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 77 in the name of <i>Rashbam</i>; <i>Sefer ha-Ittur</i>, under <i>Mered</i>, vol. 1, 58d; <i>Teshuvot Maharach Ohr Zarua</i> 155; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 2:40; <i>Teshuvot Mekor Barukh</i> 17; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 72:7; <i>Teshuvot Ma’sat Binyamin</i> 44; <i>Mishkenot Ya’akov</i>, <i>EH</i> 17 (compare with his <i>teshuva</i> 38:24); <i>Teshuvot Zemach Zedek</i>, <i>EH</i> 132; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 3:93;<i>Teshuvot Hikkei Lev</i>, <i>EH</i> 56; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 5:26.<br>Regarding the position of <i>Rashba</i>, there are contradictory rulings, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i>, 1:573, 1192, 1235; 7:414; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhosot le-Ramban</i> 138; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 49b.<br>However, there are many <i>Poskim</i> who reject the <i>ma’is alai</i> plea as a grounds for divorce. See Y. Goldberg, <i>Elu shei-Kofin le-Hotzi</i> 144, n. 1.</i> After surveying the halakhic landscape regarding our issue, R. Avraham Gatinyo of nineteenth-century Salonika concludes,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tzail ha-Kessef</i> 13 (86b). See the list of <i>Rishonim</i> who subscribe to Rambam’s view that can be found in <i>Teshuvot Hut ha-Meshulash</i> 35.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">There are more <i>Rishonim</i> (early authorities) who hold that we compel him to get divorced based upon the plea of “<i>ma’is alai</i>” than <i>Rishonim</i> who argue that we do not compel a divorce …</span>
R. Gatinyo therefore subscribes to this view.
Finally, many <i>Poskim</i> will compel a <i>get</i> if the wife has a clear pretext (<i>amatlaot berurot</i>) that in fact her husband is “<i>ma’is alai</i>,” a repulsive husband due to his inappropriate behavior,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 43:6; <i>Tosafot Rid</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 63b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashbash</i> 93; <i>Hut ha-Meshulash</i>, <i>ha-Tur ha-Shlishi</i> 35; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 77; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 77 in the name of <i>Tosafot</i> and <i>Maharam</i>; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:2; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:27; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:25; <i>Teshuvot Dvar ha-Mishpat</i> (Hayyim ben Shlomo), <i>EH</i> 47; <i>PDR</i> 8:124, 126; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>YD</i> 140; <i>Teshuvot Ezrat Kohen</i> 55–56; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 4:21, 5:26; <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 3, <i>EH</i> 18; <i>PDR</i> 9:183; Appeal 5754/168, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Tzur v. Tzur</i>, 14 Kislev 5755; File no. 056128952-21-1, Ashkelon Regional Beit Din, April 14, 2005 in 29 <i>ha-Din ve-ha-Dayan</i> 8. For an overview, see H. Izrirer, “The Obligation of the <i>Get</i> and Maintenance for A <i>Moredet</i> Who Despises her Husband” (Hebrew), 2 <i>Shurat ha-Din</i> 64, 73–97 (5754). Cf. <i>Hut ha-Meshulash</i>, vol. 4 of <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, <i>ha-Tur ha-Shlishi</i> 2 and 35 who contend that the wife who advances such a plea does not require corroboration provided she is acting with integrity rather than advancing her own agenda.<br>According to many <i>Poskim</i>, in places where the <i>minhag</i> is to coerce when there is a wife’s plea of <i>ma’is alai</i>, such as in certain Sefardic communities which generally followed Rambam’s rulings, or in situations where there exist unique circumstances in a particular case, some <i>Poskim</i> would require the claim to be substantiated and others other would accept the plea without proof prior to issuing a compulsion order.
