See <i>Teshuvot Mekor Baruch</i> 17; <i>Yabia Omer</i>, op. cit.; <i>Teshuvot Ma’asat Binyamin</i> 44.<br>However, given that the <i>ma’is alai</i> plea is not mentioned in the Mishnah, others reject the claim even if it is corroborated. See <i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 63a; <i>Mahari Bruna</i>, supra n. 111; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 77:3; <i>Teshuvot Ateret Shlomo</i> (Karelitz) 1:33.</i> contingent upon the fact that a <i>beit din</i> heard the couple’s claims and deemed that the facts dictate that there are grounds for compulsion,<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, a <i>beit din</i>, rather than an individual Jew, is required in order to determine whether there are grounds for coercing the giving of a <i>get</i>. See <i>Sefer ha-Yeraim</i> 164; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 63; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 3; <i>Meshoveiv Netivot</i> 3; <i>Minhat Hinukh</i>, <i>mitzva</i> 8; <i>Teshuvot Oneg Yom Tov</i> 168; <i>Ohr Sameach</i>, <i>Hilkhot Gerushin</i> 2:20; <i>Hilkhot Mamrim</i> 4:3; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Ta’am</i> (Heft) 128; <i>Teshuvot Kol Eliyahu</i> (Yisrael), <i>EH</i> 22; <i>Teshuvot Tzmach Tzedek</i> (Lubavitch), <i>EH</i> 262:9; <i>Teshuvot Avnei Nezer</i>, <i>EH</i> 178:20; <i>Teshuvot Heichal Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 1; <i>Teshuvot Beit ha-Levi</i>, end.<br>Cf. <i>Meshoveiv Netivot</i> who contends that <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 3 allows an individual Jew to decide whether there are grounds for <i>get</i> compulsion. A review of Netivot’s actual words indicates that only with regard to compelling mitzva observance one permits an individual to determine whether coercion is permissible. However, Rabbis Sofer, Rofe, and Gordon rule that a Jew is sufficient to determine whether <i>kefiya</i> is proper. See <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 2:64, <i>Teshuvot Ma’aseh Hiya</i> 24 cited by <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>EH</i> 134:32; <i>Teshuvot Yehuda</i> (Gordon), <i>EH</i> 51:2; <i>Yad Aharon</i> (Alfandri), <i>EH</i> 134:20–21.</i> and provided that the civil law permits <i>get</i> compulsion.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Shem Aryeh</i> 2, <i>EH</i> 43; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 3:43 (end); <i>Teshuvot Heichal Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:5; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 3, <i>EH</i> 31; <i>Teshuvot Har Tzvi</i>, <i>EH</i> 2:181; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Eliyahu</i> 45; <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 3, <i>EH</i> 20; File no. 8455-64-1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, September 17, 2008.<br><i>Maharam Schick</i> of sixteenth-century Poland concurs that the custom is to refrain from physical coercion except for instances of prohibited marriages such as a <i>kohen</i> who is married to a divorcee. See <i>Teshuvot Maharam Lublin</i> 1.</i>
Given that secular law in the United States does not empower a <i>beit din</i> to impose criminal sanctions upon a recalcitrant husband, we may abstain from addressing whether or not we should compel the husband to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife. In other words, though under certain conditions the Mishnah, Talmud, and <i>Poskim</i> mandate <i>kefiya be-shotim</i>, physical coercion by using sticks<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Consequently, the physical coercion should not be tolerated by the majority of people. See <i>Teshuvot Beit Ephraim</i>, <i>Mahadura Tanina</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:70–71.</i> or by any other means,<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:1187; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 348. In certain instances, only verbal persuasion may be utilized. See <i>Tosafot Ketuvot</i> 70a, s.v. “<i>yotzi</i>”; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 4:157; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 2:8.</i> against a recalcitrant husband and that it should be meted out until he states “I want to (give a <i>get</i>),”<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Gittin</i> 9:8; <i>Ketuvot</i> 77a; <i>Gittin</i> 88b; <i>Bava Batra</i> 48a; <i>Sefer ha-Yashar</i>, <i>Teshuvot</i> 24; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Ketubot</i> 204; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Gerushin</i> 2:20; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashbash</i> 339; <i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:21. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Bigdei Yesha</i> 36 (8-9); File no. 861974/2, Tzfat Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, May 20, 2014, 68-73. Some <i>Poskim</i> note if he delivered a <i>get</i> silently without stating “I want to,” the <i>get</i> would be valid <i>ex post facto</i>. See <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 55.</i> <i>Poskim</i> have ruled given that the secular authorities legally proscribe the use of force, such coercion regarding <i>get</i> compliance is halakhically prohibited.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 116.</i> Implicit in their conclusion is that regarding criminal matters, Jews are duty-bound to comply with “the law of the land.”<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:612; <i>Drashot ha-Ran</i>, <i>drasha</i> 11; <i>Tur</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 369; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:7–8.</i> Based on the above, as well as contemporary <i>Poskim</i> and three recently issued <i>beit din</i> decisions handed down in Yerushalayim and Tel Aviv, respectively dealing with a wife who advanced a plea of “<i>ma’is alai</i>” based upon supporting proof regarding her spouse who was engaging in adultery and the fact that <i>Nitva</i> abandoned the marital home and continues to refuse to give his wife a <i>get</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 4:21 (12); <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 3:18 (13); File no. 059835603211, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, February 5, 2002; File no. 027471085211, Tel Aviv-Yafo Regional Beit Din, December 15, 2003; File no. 32555-1, Ashdod Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, May 9, 2011; File no. 190175/15, Tel Aviv-Yafo Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, April 22, 2012.<br>Even though the <i>ma’is alai</i> plea is not mentioned in the Mishnah and there are numerous <i>Poskim</i> who argue that such a claim does not serve as grounds to coerce a <i>get</i>, nonetheless in our case, in which the husband has abandoned the home and refuses to give a <i>get</i>, a <i>beit din</i> can coerce a <i>get</i>. See <i>Teshuvot Zekan Aharon</i> 149; <i>Teshuvot Haham Tzvi</i> 1. Given that our panel is not legally empowered to issue a compulsion order, nevertheless we can obligate him to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.</i> we obligate the <i>Nitva</i> to give a <i>get</i> to the <i>Tova’at</i>.
<b>Decision</b>
1.<i>Nitva</i> is hereby obligated to give <i>Tova’at</i> a <i>get</i>.
2.<i> Nitva</i> is hereby obligated to pay <i>Tova’at</i> $50,000.
3. Should <i>Tova’at</i> receive her <i>get</i> in exchange for waiving the foresaid monetary award, a <i>seder ha-get</i>, an arrangement of a <i>get</i>, may be executed and the parties are then permitted to remarry.
<b>Final Thoughts: The Awarding of <i>Nezikin</i> Claims against the Abuser</b>
Given her husband’s ravishment and coercive tactics and the <i>beit din</i>’s ruling to obligate the giving of a <i>get</i> and the husband’s continued refusal to give one, had <i>Tova’at</i> argued for a monetary award for <i>tza’ar</i> (psychological pain) and for <i>boshet</i> (embarassment) due to <i>Nitva</i>’s improper conduct during conjugal relations, would there be grounds for such monetary relief?
<b>A. The Authority of <i>Beit din</i> to Award a <i>Nezikin</i> Claim</b>
Generally speaking, there is a requirement of having a <i>beit din</i> composed of <i>mumhim</i> (i.e., <i>dayanim</i> who have received classical ordination handed down from Moshe Rabbeinu) who are empowered to award <i>kenasot</i> (i.e., penalties) including but not limited to <i>nezikin</i> (damages such as recovery for bodily harm and medical care). However, in contemporary times in the absence of <i>mumhim</i>, the power of <i>beit din</i> stems in part from the parties’ willingness to accept the <i>beit din</i>’s authority, and therefore the awarding of <i>kenasot</i> is permissible.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shita Mekubezet</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 89b, s.v. “<i>ve-gedolei ha-mehabrim</i>”; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i> 3:1; <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:1;</i> In effect, by the acceptance of the <i>beit din</i>’s authority via the execution of a <i>kinyan</i> (i.e., a symbolic act of undertaking the duty to abide by the <i>psak</i> of the <i>beit din</i>), the parties agree to obligate themselves to remit such monies should an award be rendered. This obligation is effective even though the parties do not explicitly state in the <i>shtar borerut</i> (arbitration agreement) that the <i>dayanim</i> may issue a decision regarding a <i>nezikin</i> claim that may entail a <i>kenas</i>. Secondly, since the parties empower the <i>beit din</i> to resolve their matters in accordance with <i>peshara</i>, the panel may resolve matters dealing with the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>kenasot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 12:2; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yehuda</i>, <i>HM</i> 1 which is cited authoritatively by <i>Pit’hei Teshuva</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:3; <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 2:32; Yoezer Ariel, <i>Dinei Borerut</i> 187.</i>
Alternatively, in accordance with a <i>takanah</i> (legislation) enacted by the <i>Geonim</i> and “the <i>minhag</i> of <i>battei din</i>” (the practice of rabbinical courts), a panel is empowered to employ their discretion in determining the amount of the monetary award and inform the batterer that this amount will appease the victim. This amount will be final even if the figure arrived at by the panel is unacceptable to the victim. As elucidated by the <i>Poskim</i>, the grounds for this award are to deter others in the community from emulating the batterer’s conduct.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Otzar ha-Geonim</i>, B. Lewin ed., <i>Ketuvot</i>, <i>Teshuvot</i> 477; <i>Teshuvot ha-Geonim</i>, <i>Sha’arei Tzedek</i>, vol. 4, <i>sha’ar</i> 1, 19 in the name of R. Sherira Gaon; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:2–3; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:11; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:5, 420:38, <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:2; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i>, A. Siev ed., 88 (379–380); <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:93; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i>, 4:1291; <i>PDR</i> 5: 322; <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i>, <i>Dinei Mamonot v’Berurei Yahadut</i> 3:205; Supreme Beit Din, supra n. 4.</i>
In short, though the <i>shtar borerut</i> in our case does not state that <i>nezikin</i> matters will be resolved by this panel, nevertheless this panel is empowered to address these issues for one or more of the following reasons: (1) by accepting the panel’s authority via the signing of the <i>shtar</i> accompanied by a <i>kinyan</i>, a panel may address these matters; (2) since the <i>beit din</i> is authorized to implement a <i>peshara</i>, they have such empowerment to resolve these issues; and (3) in accordance with rabbinic legislation and <i>“</i>the <i>minhag</i> of <i>battei din”</i> such matters may be addressed.
<b>B. Evidentiary Standard for Determining Spousal Rape</b>
To award damages, the victim of the alleged abuse must demonstrate that the actual event(s) transpired. In the absence of a criminal conviction by a civil court,<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Regarding the veracity of a court’s findings, see ch. 3, n. 66.</i> the admission of guilt by the perpetrator<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Generally speaking, regarding <i>dinei nefashot</i>, criminal matters, the rule is “no man may render himself a <i>rasha</i>, a wicked person.” See <i>Sanhedrin</i> 9b. However, concerning claims dealing with monetary matters, we invoke the rule that “a man’s own admission of guilt has the power of one hundred witnesses.” See <i>Bava Metzia</i> 3b; <i>Sefer ha-Terumot</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 21, 2:3; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur HM</i> 34:36; <i>PDR</i> 1:5, 12–13; 15:119, 122.<br>For acceptance of a husband’s admissibility of his improper conduct as grounds for divorce, see <i>Sefer ha-Aguda</i> in the name of <i>Maharam</i> 77; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:1.</i> or two adult Jewish male witnesses attesting to the occurrence<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Devarim</i> 19:15; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 408; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 408:1.</i> is adequate proof for <i>beit din</i> to render an award. In the absence of a husband’s admission or two male witnesses corroborating the event, in situations of assault where males were absent, the testimony of the victim of abuse, who generally speaking is ineligible to submit testimony, would be admissible.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam Mintz</i> 5; <i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 353; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:14; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>HM</i> 58, cited by <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 35:9.</i> To state it differently, though a woman’s testimony is not viewed as <i>edut</i> (testimony) that a <i>dayan</i> is obliged to accept and follow, a <i>dayan</i> may nevertheless recognize that her words possess veracity and rely upon her words, i.e., <i>ne’emanut.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Urim ve-Tumim</i>, <i>HM</i> 36:11; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 36:10; R. Akiva Eiger, <i>YD</i> 228:3.</i>
The acceptability of a woman’s testimony is not limited to events that she observed as an outsider that transpired with other individuals, but extends equally to events in which she was a participant.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 129; <i>Osaf Piskei Din shel ha-Rabbanut ha-Rashit le-Eretz Yisrael</i>, vol. 2, 11, 13–14 (5745). Cf. A. Sherman, “Accepting Invalid Witnesses for a Divorce Claim, Monetary Matters, and Battery” (Hebrew), 5 <i>Divrei Mishpat</i> 101 (5758).</i> Therefore, in the absence of any other claims leveled against her husband, if a wife claims that her husband is impotent, according to the majority of <i>Poskim</i> we may believe her, and we do not need to identify any other reason for the tensions and marital breakdown.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gevurat Anashim</i> 57; <i>Get Pashut</i>, <i>Kelalim</i>, <i>kelal</i> 2; <i>PDR</i> 1:81, 85, 12:96, 102.</i> In our scenario, seemingly we must question whether we can trust the veracity of the wife’s contention that her husband assaulted and raped her. However, since he admitted to his actions, we have no need to cast any doubt upon the veracity of her account.
Once said evidence has been submitted to the <i>beit din</i>, it is incumbent upon the <i>dayanim</i> to examine the information, in the same fashion that any other testimony is analyzed. For example, regarding instances of battery of a spouse for which it is unclear who provoked the behavior, the husband is not believed over his wife that his wife is the provocateur of the conduct, because women have a <i>hezkat kashrut</i> (presumption of credibility).<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:3.</i> Here again, in our case, the husband’s admission absolves <i>beit din</i> from the need for further inquiry.
<b>C. A <i>Nezikin</i> Award for <i>Boshet</i> and <i>Tza’ar</i></b>
<i>Tova’at</i> is experiencing feelings of embarrassment regarding the incidents, as well as knowing that members of her community are aware of this occurrence. In a case in which an individual intended to embarrass another person,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hovel u-Mazik</i> 1:10–12</i> Halakha awards compensation for <i>boshet</i> (shame). The amount of the award will vary regarding the type of shaming. For example, slapping someone in the face will incur a higher award than yelling at someone.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:6.</i>
In our scenario, the spousal rape did not generate any bodily injury, but there is nevertheless a concept of <i>boshet devarim</i>, lit. “shame in words,” which would encompass any feelings of embarrassment associated with this conduct. This may simply be emotional anguish unrelated to a third party’s awareness of the occurrence,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 65b, s.v. “<i>bezman</i>”; <i>Nedarim</i> 27b, s.v. “<i>asmakhta</i>”; <i>Kiddushin</i> 8b, s.v. “<i>maneh</i>”; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, 4:69; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 207:7.</i> or shame which comes from the cognizance of others regarding what transpired. In the Mishnah and Talmud, such an incident of shame does not have a fixed compensation rate. The standard suggested by Rashi, Shulhan Arukh, and Sma is that the estimate is determined according to the character and social status of the two parties, as well as the circumstances that generated the shame.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 90a; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:24; <i>Sma</i>, ad locum 25.</i> As noted by various <i>battei din</i>, the award will be vary from case to case.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 3:131, 151, 5:322, 327.</i> And, in fact, in the last few hundred years, <i>boshet devarim</i> has been awarded.<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 134; <i>Teshuvot Avodat ha-Gershuni</i> 74; <i>Teshuvot Zera Emet</i>, <i>YD</i> 112; <i>Teshuvot Givat Pinhas</i> 74. For a contemporary <i>beit din</i>’s empowerment to render <i>nezikin</i>, injury awards, see <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 17, at 111–138.</i>
Additionally, as we explained, although there is a <i>mitzva</i> of <i>onah</i> and a wife has a duty to be intimate with her husband, nevertheless forcible sexual relations are prohibited. Given that coerced cohabitation entails physical contact, one can advance a claim for <i>tza’ar</i>, physiological pain.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:1; <i>Bava Kama</i> 85a; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hoveil u-Mazik</i> 2:9; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:1; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 420:16.</i> Additionally, spousal rape, similar to any rape, is a traumatic experience engendering feeling of emotional stress that prevents the victim from engaging in sexual relations in the future.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">S<i>ee Ha’amek Davar</i>, <i>Bereshit</i> 34:2, <i>Devarim</i> 22:24.</i>
Although the formal <i>halakhot</i> of <i>nezikin</i> do not recognize psychological pain,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Nezikin</i>, ch. 11, n. 32.</i> by dint of the parties’ voluntarily accepting the authority of the <i>beit din</i>, and given that the matter will be resolved in accordance with <i>peshara</i> and that it is the <i>minhag</i> of <i>battei din</i> to mete out damages to appease the victim, therefore there would have been grounds to award the <i>Tova’at</i> damages for physiological and psychological pain and <i>boshet devarim</i>.
<b>D. <i>Tova’at</i> Waiver of Her <i>Nezikin</i> Award in Exchange for Receiving Her <i>Get</i></b>
In the event that a <i>beit din</i> obligated a husband to give a <i>get</i> and the husband’s continued refusal to give one, should the <i>beit din</i> have awarded her <i>nezikin</i> claim, had the <i>Nitva</i> argued he would be willing to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife in exchange for his wife waiving her right to this monetary award, would such an exchange result in a <i>get me’useh</i>, a coerced <i>get</i>? Generally, a <i>get</i> must be given voluntarily by the husband, and the wife must accept it voluntarily, without any coercion. In our scenario, should the husband be coerced into delivering the <i>get</i>, the subsequent execution of the <i>get</i> creates a “<i>get me’useh</i>,” a situation that means that the <i>get</i> procedure is invalid and the couple remains married. The threshold question is the following: Does a husband’s willingness to deliver a <i>get</i> in exchange for waiving a monetary debt mandated by the <i>beit din</i> constitute financial coercion which would create a <i>get me’useh</i>?
According to numerous authorities, should monetary fines be leveled against a recalcitrant husband, any subsequent execution of a <i>get</i> will be unlawful.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 4:40; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 50a; <i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, Mishnah, <i>Gittin</i> 8:1; <i>Bava Batra</i> 40b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 127; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 134:5; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 63; <i>Teshuvot R. Bezalel Ashkenazi</i> 15; <i>Teshuvot Bigdei Kehuna</i> 56; <i>Mishkenot Ya’akov</i> 38; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Emet</i>, <i>kuntres</i> 11, 4; <i>PDR</i> 15:145, 16:260.</i>
Consequently, the advancement of a monetary claim to compensate for damages due to a husband’s recalcitrance in delivering a <i>get</i> is without halakhic foundation. If such an award is forthcoming, and the husband decides to give the <i>get</i> in exchange for being released from paying this debt, the subsequent execution of the <i>get</i> will create a <i>get me’useh</i>.
Despite the foregoing, there are authorities who do not consider monetary compulsion as <i>ones</i>, duress.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Meisharim</i> 1, <i>netiv</i> 24; <i>Teshuvot Ohr Zarua</i> 1:754; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 1:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 63; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:76; <i>Teshuvot Divre Ribot</i> 291; <i>Teshuvot Maharbil</i> 2:77; <i>Teshuvot Avodat ha-Gershuni</i> 35; <i>Mikhtav me-Eliyahu</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 7, 22; <i>Yad Aharon</i> 134; <i>Teshuvot Tzemach Tzedek</i> (Lubavitch) 62:3.</i> However, there are <i>Poskim</i> who distinguish between different types of monetary and non-monetary types of coercion. Certain forms of duress will taint the subsequent execution of a <i>get</i> while others will be free from any compulsion. There is a type of damage claim that can be advanced by a divorcing wife in a <i>beit din</i> and it is labeled “<i>kefiya ke-din</i>” (legitimate coercion) and therefore avoids the strictures of a <i>get me’useh</i>. Numerous authorities have argued that certain kinds of pressure are not sufficiently coercive to result in an invalid divorce, provided that the coercive element emerges from circumstances unrelated to the divorce. For example, describing the following scenario, Rivash of fourteenth-century Spain and North Africa rules,<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 232 (translation excerpted from Yehiel Kaplan, “Enforcement of Divorce Judgments by Imprisonment Principles of Jewish Law,” 15 <i>The Jewish Law Annual</i> 57, 102 (2004).) See also <i>Rivash</i>, supra n. 143.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The case … involved a person cast into debtor’s prison for nonpayment of a debt. His wife’s relatives offered to satisfy the debt on his behalf and thereby obtain his release from prison on the condition that he divorce his wife.</span>
Rivash finds no objection to execution of a <i>get</i> under such circumstances “for he was not seized in order to [compel] him to divorce [his wife] but on account of his debt; the <i>get</i> is not coerced but [the product] of free will.”
Since the husband was imprisoned for defaulting on a debt rather than as a means to coerce to give a <i>get</i>, his release in exchange for executing a <i>get</i> is not to be viewed as duress, and therefore the strictures of <i>get me’useh</i> are inapplicable. Numerous authorities such as Tashbetz, Ranah, Rema, R. Feinstein, and while serving on the Israel Rabbinical Court Rabbis Elyashiv, Daichovsky, and Shilo Rafael, endorsed the notion that coercion relating to another matter (<i>kefiya le-davar aher</i>) is permissible.<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tashbetz</i>, supra n. 144; <i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 1:63; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 154:21; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:137; <i>PDR</i> 11:300, 302–307, 16:271, 272–279, 275–276. For extensive treatment, see <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 17, at 142–152.</i>
In short, these authorities concur with the view expressed hundreds of years ago by R. Moshe of Trani,<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha</i>-<i>Mabit</i> 1:22 (translation from Kaplan, supra n. 145, 104–105). See further <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 17, 147, n. 147.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">A <i>get</i> is only considered unlawfully enforced when [the husband] is coerced with regard to the divorce. But if he is coerced with regard to a different matter, and in order to free himself from that coercion he divorces his wife, [the <i>get</i>] is not regarded as unlawfully enforced.</span>
In our scenario, we may invoke the concept of <i>kefiya le-davar aher</i>, i.e., advancing a <i>nezikin</i> claim unrelated to divorce,<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">This notion of “<i>kefiya le-davar aher</i>” is to be distinguished from “<i>kefiya derech bereira</i>,” which means coercing a husband to comply with his marital duties, such as spousal support, and exempting him from his obligation by delivering a <i>get</i> to his wife. See <i>Gevurat Anashim</i> 48 and ch. 3, addendum.</i> since the <i>kefiya</i> relates to spousal rape, an act unrelated to the divorce. A <i>beit din</i> is empowered to hand down a monetary award regarding emotional stress caused due to such conduct. As such, our case represents another example of <i>kefiya le-davar aher</i>, no different than that of Rivash’s debt repayment, and it is therefore permissible and avoids the strictures of a <i>get me’useh</i>.
Finally, even if we were not dealing with an instance of <i>kefiya le-davar aher</i>, in various Israeli <i>piskei din</i> and <i>teshuvot</i> “obligating a divorce,” R. Elyashiv and others permit a husband whose wife does wish to accept a <i>get</i> to appease his recalcitrant wife by offering money in exchange for her accepting a <i>get</i>; the ensuing divorce is not deemed to be unlawfully coerced.<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 7:11, 8:36, 9:65; File no. 2337, Supreme Beit Din, December 27, 2004; <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i>, vol. 6, <i>EH</i> 10. See further <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 2:68; <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, supra n. 17,150–152.</i> Similarly, if the wife absconded with her recalcitrant husband’s assets and will release them only upon receiving her <i>get</i>, such a financial inducement is permissible.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 4:35; <i>Torat Gittin</i> 134:4; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-She’arim</i> 6.</i> Hence, in our scenario, a wife’s waiver of her monetary award in exchange for her <i>get</i> would have been permissible.

b) "A Dead Marriage" and its Halakhic Aftermath

<b>B. “A Dead Marriage” and its Halakhic Aftermath</b>
<b>Facts</b>
In Hassidic circles, <i>shiddukhin</i> is a system of matchmaking in which Torah-observant singles are introduced to one another for the purpose of marriage. Whereas in other Orthodox communities, singles may meet in different ways, in Hassidic circles, a <i>shiddukh</i> usually begins with a recommendation from a family member or friend.
Whereas in other circles, dating usually takes place in a public setting such as a restaurant, an airport, or a social/educational event, in Hassidic communities, once a match has been proposed, the prospective partners proceed to a “<i>bashow</i>,” meaning a sit-in. In a conventional <i>bashow</i>, the young man is accompanied by his parents to see the young woman in her house to see if the prospective couple is compatible. Both sets of parents converse with each other, and eventually they walk into another room, leaving the man and woman to speak privately. Some may use the opportunity to ask relevant questions, while others want to gain a sense of whether they like each other, relying on the information that they received from the <i>shadkhan</i>. As the couple sees more of each other and the couple is satisfied that the proposed marriage will be successful, their decision is communicated to the <i>shadkhan</i>, and the engagement is announced, followed by marriage.
We are dealing here with a young couple that met each other in three <i>bashows</i>, and subsequently got engaged and married. In this particular circumstance, there was no <i>shadkhan</i>, but upon the initiative of the two families of the couple, the ensuing courting, engagement, and eventual marriage took place. After being married for four years, the couple had a baby girl. Two years later, they decided to get divorced. During their marriage, the couple had been residing in northern New Jersey in a non-Hassidic community where the <i>Tove’a</i> was employed as a financial analyst and the <i>Nitva’at</i> was a social worker, while simultaneously managing the household and engaging in child rearing, cooking, and washing.
For two years the couple had not been engaging in conjugal relations, and a year ago the husband moved out of the marital home.
<b><i>Tove’a</i>’s Claims</b>
<i>Tove’a</i> argues that the <i>Nitva’at</i> was the first to request a <i>get</i> and subsequently, he agreed that he did not want to remain with her. However, he refuses to deliver a <i>get</i> to her. He admitted that he was not interested in having children.
Given that the <i>Nitva’at</i> asked for the <i>get</i>, she is not entitled to receive the value of her <i>ketuba</i>. Additionally, given that the <i>Tove’a</i>’s father-in-law gave the rent money as a gift to the couple, the <i>Tove’a</i> is exempt from repaying this money to his father-in-law. Finally, the <i>Nitva’at</i> has withdrawn all the funds from their joint account, funds that have not been expended for the domestic household, and therefore the <i>Tove’a</i> is demanding recovery of half the funds.
<i>Tove’a</i> is willing to pay child support, but he argues that the calculation of payment should be based upon the customary practice in the Hassidic community rather than civil law. Moreover, though <i>Tove’a</i> agrees that the <i>Nitva’at</i> should be the custodial parent, <i>Tove’a</i> contends that the panel should decline her request for child relocation because the <i>Nitva’at</i>’s “need” to move is really the product of her own lifestyle choice, and that consequently, he should not be the parent who is “punished” with the loss of proximity and weekday contact. Moreover, her desire to relocate is prompted by the wish to distance herself from her ex-husband, and she seeks to escape the perceived humiliation of remaining in “the father’s community.” In reply to <i>Nitva’at</i>’s contention that she requires emotional support from her parents and therefore the move is required, <i>Tove’a</i> argues his wife’s two sisters and some friends live in New Jersey and/or in close proximity to her, who would be able to provide assistance and emotional support.
Should the <i>beit din</i> determine that the <i>Tove’a</i> is obligated to give a <i>get</i> to the <i>Nitva’at</i>, <i>Tove’a</i> wants the financial claims to be resolved prior to giving her the <i>get</i>.
<b><i>Nitva’at</i>’s Claims</b>
From the onset of the marriage, <i>Nitva’at</i> never felt emotionally attached to the <i>Tove’a</i>. Though the couple met each other at <i>bashows</i>, in actuality there was never any emotional and physical attraction between them. It was a marriage orchestrated by their respective families. In fact, the <i>Nitva’at</i> contends that the <i>Tove’a</i> never wanted to have children and the child that they had was a concession to the <i>Nitva’at</i>. On numerous occasions, <i>Tove’a</i> refused to have relations with the <i>Nitva’at</i>. In the final analysis, <i>Tove’a</i> was upset that they were married, and therefore he ought to give her a <i>get</i> and pay her the value of her <i>ketuba</i>. In reply to <i>Tove’a</i>’s willingness to pay $250 a month for support for one child, allegedly the practice in Hassidic communities, <i>Nitva’at</i> is requesting that child support payments be calculated based upon NJ child support standards.
<i>Nitva’at</i> is petitioning this panel to allow her to relocate from New Jersey to Chicago, Illinois where her parents live. The move is necessary to accommodate a new job being offered to her in social work in Chicago, as well to provide her with parental assistance and support in raising her daughter. Such a move would be in the child’s best interests.
Moreover, <i>Nitva’at</i> claims that the $80,000 that she withdrew from their joint account represents her salary for the last six years working as a secretary, and argues based on “<i>kim li</i>,” i.e., that she adopts the opinion of the decisor who would support her claim that the salary belongs to her. Alternatively, she argues that since a year prior to the divorce proceedings <i>Tove’a</i> withdrew $200,000 from their joint account and <i>Tove’a</i> can only demonstrate that $50,000 was used in order to pay domestic expenses, and therefore, she is entitled to $75,000, which represents fifty percent of the remaining funds, as a joint account holder. Moreover, though formally speaking <i>Nitva’at</i> admits that she was the first to request the <i>get</i>, it is clear that the above withdrawal indicates that for a year prior to their decision to appear in front of this panel, the <i>Tove’a</i> was already contemplating divorce. In fact, at that time, <i>Tove’a</i> consulted with a rabbi regarding end-of-marriage matters.
Finally, <i>Nitva’at</i> is requesting $100,000, which represents the money lent to the couple by the <i>Nitva’at</i>’s father in order to pay for the first five years of rent. In reply to <i>Tove’a</i>’s contention that the aforesaid monies were remitted as a gift, <i>Nitva’at</i> argues that her father never said that these funds were a gift, and therefore should be viewed as a loan that must be repaid.
Should <i>beit din</i> determine that she has a right to receive a <i>get</i>, <i>Nitva’at</i> demands that it should be executed prior to the <i>beit din</i>’s resolution of the outstanding financial claims.
<b>Discussion</b>
<b>1. Husband’s Obligation to Deliver a <i>Get</i></b>
Generally, the right of a wife to demand a divorce is based upon the following grounds: (1) physical defects of her spouse, such as impotence or a contagious disease such as AIDS; and (2) conduct of her husband, such as his unwillingness to support her or live with her. Halakha recognizes similar grounds for a husband to demand that his wife accept the <i>get</i> from him.
However, Rabbeinu Yeruham introduces a different ground for divorce. He rules the following:<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Meisharim</i>, <i>helek</i> 8, <i>netiv</i> 23.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">And my teacher Avraham ben Ashmael writes that it seems to him that a wife who says she does not find her husband pleasing and that he should give her a <i>get</i> and <i>ketuba</i>, and the husband says and that he likewise does not find her pleasing, but does not want to give a <i>get</i>, it is logical that we do not consider her a rebellious wife to lose her <i>ketuba</i> and <i>nedunya</i> (dowry). Rather, we wait twelve months regarding the <i>get</i>, because possibly she will reconcile. After the year, we force him to divorce her and she loses her <i>tosefet</i> (<i>tosefet ketuba</i>) and everything she received from him, because we assume that he didn’t let her take (his property) and then leave (the marriage).</span>
According to one understanding, R. Yeruham is extending the case of <i>ma’is alai</i> to a new situation. In the conventional situation of <i>ma’is alai</i>, if a husband refuses to engage in conjugal relations with his wife, the wife can say “I find him repulsive” (“<i>ma’is alai</i>”), and in accordance with some <i>Poskim</i> we coerce him to deliver a <i>get</i>. R. Yeruham argues that even if she states “<i>ma’is alai</i> and I don’t want to live with him,” after a year we coerce him to deliver a <i>get</i> lest she become an <i>agunah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 19:57, 62.</i> Another perspective on R. Yeruham’s position is offered by the Netivot ha-<i>Mishpat</i> who contends that according to R. Yeruham (as well as his teacher, Rashba), given that each spouse is a “<i>moreid</i>” (lit. “rebellious” – unwilling to engage in conjugal relations), the wife loses only her <i>tosefet ketuba</i>, and after a year we coerce the husband to deliver a <i>get</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> on <i>Sefer Meisharim</i> 218b.</i>
According to an alternative interpretation,<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Our reconstruction of R. Yeruham’s position is drawn from Nahum Prover, “The obligation of a <i>get</i>, return of gifts, a justified claim: regarding a couple who are not interested in each other,” (Hebrew), <i>Kenas ha-Dayanim</i>, ed. Sheinfeld and Ya’akobi, Yerushalayim: 5768, 109, 110–116<i>;Ateret Devora</i> 2:89.</i> we are dealing with a case in which there are no mutual obligations between the spouses, since one cannot speak of a sense of duty devolving upon one side if the other side equally refuses to undertake an obligation. For this reason, the issue of failing to engage in conjugal relations is a non-issue. The matter of <i>merida</i> (rebelliousness) emerges within the context of ongoing and functional marriage when one party is derelict in his or her duty in living with his spouse.<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 183; <i>Teshuvot Ohr ha-Gadol</i> 4.</i> In this case, refraining from conjugal relations is due to mutual incompatability and/or hatred. One cannot view the husband as a <i>moreid</i> when the wife has no interest in her marriage and therefore refrains from living with her husband. And similarly, one cannot view the wife as a <i>moredet</i> when the husband has no interest in living with her. The meaning of a “<i>moredet</i>” is a wife who is rebellious toward her husband who desires to live with her. And in fact, there is a procedure dating back to Geonic times that mandates synagogue announcements as a means to indirectly compel a wife to return to her spouse. In short, if the husband doesn’t want to remain married, but nevertheless wants his wife to be an <i>agunah</i>, R. Yeruham rules that we compel him to give her a <i>get</i>.
On the other hand, if the wife has no interest in remaining married and the husband wants to remain married (and there are no grounds for obligating a <i>get</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">According to <i>Mateh Yosef</i>, in order to apply <i>R.</i> Yeruham’s <i>psak</i> the husband must have acted improperly to his wife. See <i>Teshuvot Mateh Yosef</i> 2, <i>EH</i> 5.</i> the wife cannot claim she is an <i>agunah</i>. On the contrary, the wife is creating her “<i>igun</i>” situation, and therefore we do not obligate the husband to deliver a <i>get</i>.
In our situation, adopting the alternative understanding of of R. Yeruham, since each spouse does not want to remain married and have been separated for a year, we are dealing with a situation of <i>igun</i>. Even if the wife would have been interested in remaining married, attempts at promoting <i>shalom bayit</i> (lit. “domestic tranquility”), matrimonial reconciliation, would be impossible since the husband no longer wants the marriage to work and succeed.<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">However, if the husband sincerely wants <i>shalom bayit</i> and only is willing to give a <i>get</i> because this is his wife’s wish, the ruling of R. Yeruham would be inapplicable. See <i>PDR</i> 13:268, 271; <i>Ateret Devora</i>, supra n. 4.</i> In our case, given that the <i>Tove’a</i> wants to neither engage in conjugal relations nor have children, the <i>Nitva’at</i> has no desire to remain married. In accordance with R. Yeruham’s position, one would therefore compel the husband to divorce her. This case is no different than an instance of a wife who commits adultery – the halakhic result is that she cannot live with her spouse. In such a situation, despite her improper behavior, which undermined the marriage, we do not sanction recalcitrance regarding the delivery of a <i>get</i>. On the contrary, we coerce the husband to give a <i>get</i>, as in R. Yeruham’s case.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 13: 64, 267–271.</i>
R. Yeruham’s <i>psak</i> also implies that the issuance of such a divorce judgment will occur regardless of which spouse desired to leave the marriage. Had the <i>psak</i> been contingent on the fact that the husband wanted to leave the marriage first, R. Yeruham would have said so. <i>Argumentum ex silentio</i> supports our conclusion.<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 14:183, 193.</i> Consequently, in R. Yeruham’s situation, the wife was the first one who wanted to get divorced, while the husband wanted to stay married. Yet, the husband’s refusal to engage in conjugal relations and have children derives from his personal determination that the marriage is “dead” rather than his wife’s demand to receive her <i>get</i>, and therefore there are grounds for coercing a husband to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i>, supra n. 8, at 271.<br>In other words, “a dead marriage” <i>per se</i> will not serve as grounds for obligating the husband to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife. Additionally, there has to be grounds for the divorce, such as what transpired in our case, i.e., the husband refusing to engage in conjugal relations and to sire children. See <i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 3:144–145; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Shmuel</i> 3:145; <i>Teshuvot ha-Gaon Avraham Herzog</i>, <i>EH</i> 154; R. Y. Herzog, <i>Pesakim u-Ketavim</i> 7:133–134; <i>Teshuvot Shema Shlomo</i> 3, <i>EH</i> 19; <i>PDR</i> 1:162, 4:112, 7:108–109, 112–113, 9:211, 10:173, 11:362, 364; 12:206, 13:360; File no. 698719/15, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, July 26, 2015.<br>In 2005, there was a debate between R. I’zirer and R. Daichovsky regarding this matter. See File no. 4827-21-2, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, July 3, 2005 (R. Izirer’s opinion). Dissenting from R. Izirer’s view and the above view, R. Daichovsky argues in said decision that “a dead marriage” <i>per se</i> where there is no possibility for <i>shalom bayit</i> (domestic tranquility) and there has been marital separation for at least a year and a half there is a <i>“mitzva”</i> for the husband to deliver a <i>get</i> under such circumstances. For the basis for this approach, see <i>Teshuvot Hayyim ve-Shalom</i> 2:112; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i> 4, <i>YD</i> 15 (2); A.Z. Sheinfeld, “Prenuptial Agreement” (Hebrew), 24 <i>Tehumin</i>, 148, 154, n. 15 (R. Daichovsky’s opinion) (5762). R. Lavi argues that R. Yeruham would concur that the absence of <i>shalom bayit</i> may serve as a grounds for obligating a <i>get</i>. Whereas, for R. Yeruham, one would wait a year prior to coercing a <i>get</i>, according to R. Daichovsky and others, one must wait eighteen months before obligating a <i>get</i>. See also <i>PDR</i> 11: 89-95,14:183,194(R. Sha’anan’s opinion),19:52; File no. 4276-63, Supreme Beit Din, November 11, 2003; File no. 3599-22-1, Tiberias Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, November 24, 2004 (R. Yoezer Ariel’s opinion); File no. 8801-21-1, Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, June 24, 2009; File no. 289477/1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, December 28, 2010; File no. 842462/1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, January 16, 2012; File no. 2487693, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, May 16, 2012; File no. 289799-1, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, January 2, 2013; File no. 862233-1, Tiberias Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, January 8, 2013; File no. 8426111, Ashdod Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, June 10, 2013 (R. Avraham Atiyah’s opinion); File no. 901912/1, Haifa Regional Beit Din, May 7, 2013;File no. 284462-9, Netanya Regional Beit Din, May 14, 2014; File no. 764231-6, Haifa Regional Beit Din, May 25, 2014; File no. 869531/2, Netanya Regional Beit Din, July 31, 2014; <i>Yabia Omer</i> 3, <i>EH</i> 18 (13).<br>There is an intermediate position that allows <i>shalom bayit</i> to serve as grounds for divorce in situations in which the <i>beit din</i> discerns that marital separation may lead to the commission of sin. See <i>Hayyim ve-Shalom</i>, op. cit.; File no. 810538/2, op. cit. (R. A. Sherman’s opinion). See A. Sherman, “Extended separation as grounds for obligating a <i>get</i>” (Hebrew), <i>Kenas ha-Dayanim</i> 5767, 102, 108–110 where he emphasizes that a couple’s monetary rights remain intact, such as a wife’s right to the value of the <i>ketuba</i> or support. To state it differently, R. Sherman contends that a spouse’s decision to leave the marital home serves to undercut <i>shalom bayit</i>. Nonetheless, it is the potential of engaging in sin in a situation of marital separation that propels R. Sherman to mandate the rendering of a divorce judgment. See File no. 810538-2, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, April 28, 2011.<br>In R. Lavi’s understanding, R. Palache’s position is that separation does not serve as grounds for a divorce, but rather marital separation may lead to inappropriate conduct. See File no. 3599221, Tiberias Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, November 11, 2004. As such, he agrees with R. Daichovsky that the absence of <i>shalom bayit</i> may serve as grounds for a divorce.<br>Given that in our case, the <i>beit din</i> was not fearful of improper behavior occuring during the marital separation, we did not decide to invoke <i>shalom bayit</i> as grounds for divorce, and we followed the majority opinion that contends that one needs to ascertain that that there must be grounds to issue a divorce judgment in a situation of “a dead marriage”.</i> And even if the wife suddenly has a change of heart and wants to remain married, the husband has no interest in <i>shalom bayit</i>. Consequently, to prevent an <i>igun</i> situation, after a year R. Yeruham would coerce the husband to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Coercion of the <i>get</i> would equally apply if the wife would refuse to accept the <i>get</i>. See <i>PDR</i>, supra n. 8, at 271. If there would be in actuality an <i>igun</i> situation, according to numerous <i>Poskim</i>, a <i>beit din</i> may obligate a <i>get</i>. See <i>PDR</i> 13:267, 273; File no. 764231/6, supra n. 10.</i>
In the wake of “a dead marriage,” each side having no interest in the continuance of the marital ties, R. Yeruham’s position is to avoid <i>igun</i>, and therefore, <i>dayanim</i> in the United States would <i>obligate</i> the husband to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">For a contemporary understanding of Rabbeinu Yeruham’s position that the existence of <i>igun</i> serves as grounds to obligate the granting of a <i>get</i>, see File no. 470386-20, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, June 26, 2014.<br>Unlike the situation in Eretz Yisrael, in the Diaspora we are bereft of legal and institutional mechanisms that would facilitate coercion, such as physical coercion and imprisonment, and therefore under certain conditions we obligate him to give a <i>get</i>. Should physical coercion be meted out, it is subject to debate whether any subsequent <i>get</i> executed is valid <i>ex post facto</i> or if a second <i>get</i> is required. See S. Messas, “<i>Safek be-Kefiyat ha-Get</i>” (Hebrew), 23 <i>Tehumin</i> 120 (2004).</i> Whereas in many instances, the grounds for divorce are based upon the conduct and/or physical defects of a spouse, here a <i>get</i> is to be given in order to avoid <i>igun</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hakham Tzvi</i> 1.</i>
As noted already by others, there are no <i>Poskim</i> who explicitly disagree with R. Yeruham’s position regarding the husband’s obligation to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i>, supra n. 9.</i> On the other hand, the fact that his view is not memorialized in Shulhan Arukh and Rema has been understood to mean that <i>Poskim</i> do not ascribe to his position.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tumim</i>, <i>Kitzur Takfo Kohen</i> 48b</i> And as such, R. Rosenthal, a sitting <i>dayan</i> on Netanya’s Regional Beit Din, discounted R. Yeruham’s position.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i>, supra n. 2, at 61.</i> Nonetheless, R. H. Shlomo Sha’anan, a <i>dayan</i> who served on the Tel Aviv Beit Din and Supreme Beit Din, has adduced various proofs that both Shulhan Arukh and Rema, as well as others, implicitly have adopted his posture.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iyunim be-Mishpat</i>, <i>EH</i> 262–266.</i> Numerous <i>battei din</i> in contemporary times have endorsed his view.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 6:13, 8:323, 11:95, 255, 13:264, 14:183, 19:57; <i>Iyunim be-Mishpat</i>, <i>EH</i> 237–240; File no. 7479-21-1, Tel Aviv-Jaffa Regional Beit Din, November 18, 2007; File no. 26259-21-2, Tiberias Regional Beit Din, March 17, 2008; File no. 854682-1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, June 28, 2012; File no. 587739-6, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni.</i> July 17, 2012.<br>In another decision, a <i>beit din</i> endorsed his <i>psak</i> without invoking any corroboration of it by others. See File no. 747359/1, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, Octber 24, 2011.</i>
Addressing this situation in which <i>shalom bayit</i> has not existed for years and there is no real possibility for reconciliation, R. Yeruham concludes that the wife is entitled to the value of her <i>ketuba</i>. A brief review here of the various rules dealing with recovery of <i>ketuba</i> monies will serve to explain the cogency of his ruling. There are three basic rules governing whether such entitlement exists: (1) If the husband demands the divorce and the wife wants to remain married, then she is entitled to the value of the <i>ketuba</i> upon divorce.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 48b; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh Makot</i> 1:1; <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 118, and for numerous <i>Aharonim</i> who authoritatively cite <i>Tur</i>’s ruling.</i> (2) If the wife did not demand a divorce and was prepared to remain married despite quarreling, and the ensuing divorce was due to the husband’s request, the monies of <i>ketuba</i> are remitted to her.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid.</i> (3) If the wife demands the divorce without any grounds to obligate the husband in the divorce, she is not entitled to the <i>ketuba</i> even if the <i>get</i> was arranged with the husband’s consent.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., <i>Tur</i> 154:7. However, if it is clear to the <i>beit din</i> that there are grounds for the wife to divorce her husband, then she receives the value of the <i>ketuba</i>. See File no. 854682/1, supra at n. 18; File no. 849079/2, Haifa Regional Beit Din, October 17, 2012; File no. 588903/1, Haifa Regional Beit Din, April 10, 2013.</i> In other words, if the husband demonstrates that there are grounds to divorce her, she is not entitled to her <i>ketuba</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 117:1–2, 4, 11; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 115:16; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 115:17,19; <i>PDR</i> 8:254, 259.</i> Based upon the foregoing, if the couple wants to mutually end their marriage, regardless of who may have requested the divorce initially, given that there is an outstanding obligation undertaken by the husband at the inception of marriage, according to R. Yeruham she is therefore entitled to her <i>ketuba</i>.
<b>2. The Recovery of <i>Tosefet Ketuba</i> according to R. Yeruham</b>
The standard amount of money in the <i>ketuba</i> is 200 <i>zuz</i> for a first marriage.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 66:6.</i> Additionally, in many instances, a husband obligates himself to add to the value of the standard <i>ketuba</i> amount, and this is called <i>tosefet ketuba</i>. In Ashkenazic <i>ketubot</i>, the standard amount is 200 <i>zekukim</i> of pure silver.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">For the valuation of the <i>ketuba</i>, see M. Broyde and Y. Reiss, “The Value and the Significance of the <i>Ketuba</i>,” 47 <i>The Journal of Halacha and Contemporary Society</i> 101 (Spring 2004).</i> Usually one hundred <i>zuzim</i> are earmarked for the <i>ikar ketuba</i> and another one hundred <i>zuzim</i> are earmarked for <i>tosefet ketuba</i>.
R. Yeruham holds that with regard to delivering a <i>get</i>, the only relevant factor is the problem of <i>igun</i>. Therefore, regardless of whether the wife is at fault, when neither party is interested in continuing the marriage, the husband must give a <i>get</i>. However, concerning whether a wife receives her <i>tosefet ketuba</i> R. Yeruham’s informs us,
<span class="poetry indentAll">Upon the assumption that she would take it and leave him, he would not have given it to her.</span>
To state it differently, regarding <i>tosefet ketuba</i>, we focus on the husband’s intent at the time that he undertook the obligation to pay <i>tosefet ketuba</i> to his prospective spouse, namely, did he intend to pay her <i>tosefet ketuba</i> upon divorce? Whereas, <i>ikar ketuba</i> is a debt which is <i>ex lege</i>, created at the inception of marriage, and paid off at the time of divorce,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 16:10. Consequently, since it belongs to her, a wife can sell her <i>ketuba</i> to her husband. However, the husband has to give her a new <i>ketuba</i>. See <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 66:5, 105:1. For a list of additional <i>Poskim</i> who argue that the wife is “<i>muhzeket</i>” in her <i>ketuba</i>, see <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 3:353. Cf. <i>Hiddushei ha-Granat</i> (Trop), <i>Ketuvot</i> 44 who contends that the debt is created at the time of divorce or the husband’s death. See also <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i> 3, <i>EH</i> 21.<br>For a contemporary application in Eretz Yisrael of the distinction between <i>ikar ketuba</i> and <i>tosefet ketuba</i>, see File no. 593163-2, Tiberias Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, January 5, 2014.</i> <i>tosefet ketuba</i> is dependent upon the intent of the husband who undertook the obligation prior to <i>nissuin</i> (marriage) during the time of the writing of the <i>ketuba</i>.
One proposed yardstick to gauge whether the wife is entitled to receive said monies is to assess who is responsible for the fact (eventually acknowledged mutually) that the marriage is dead. One approach, taken by R. Eliezer Goldschmidt, a <i>dayan</i> who served on various <i>battei din</i> of Eretz Yisrael’s Chief Rabbinate, contends that if a husband refuses to support his wife or engages in illicit affairs, he is responsible for the downfall of the marriage and therefore, the husband is obligated to remit <i>tosefet ketuba</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 1:201, 221. For earlier <i>Poskim</i> who invoke this view, see <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 195; <i>Teshuvot Torat Emet</i> (Sasson) 64.</i> On the other hand, should divorce ensue because of the wife’s demands and despite the husband’s desire to continue being married, the husband is exempt from paying such monies. The rationale for this exemption is that he voluntarily obligated himself to pay these monies provided that she is willing to be married to him. Since she does not want to remain married, he no longer is obligated to pay her these monies.
However, if he is responsible for the “dead marriage” rather than his spouse, he remains obligated to pay <i>tosefet ketuba</i> (as well as <i>ikar ketuba</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 8:321, 324; File no. 849079-2, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, October 17, 2012; File no. 380065-5 B, Tel Aviv-Yafo Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, May 13, 2013.</i> For example, if the husband is either incapable of finding a livelihood or is sexually impotent, even though these situations are characterized halakhically as “<i>ones</i>” (duress), he is exempt to remit such monies. On the other hand, if the husband is responsible for the divorce, for example if he fails in finding a job to support his wife, he is obligated in <i>tosefet ketuba</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i>, supra n. 26 at 219–221. Cf. <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 65b in the name of <i>Rabbeinu Tam</i>; <i>PDR</i> 8:275, 279–282 (R. Yisraeli’s opinion).</i> Eretz Yisrael’s <i>dayanim</i>, Rabbis Elyashiv, Horowitz, Ben Shimon, Sheinfeld, Sha’anan, Probar, and Ushinski, have endorsed this approach.<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 7:275, 278; 8:321, 323–324; 13:264, 274; 14:183, 194; Provar, supra n. 4, at 115; File no. 854682-1, supra n. 18; File no. 587739-6, supra n. 18.<br>For an excellent explanation of their stance, see File no. 380065-5, supra n. 27, R. Cohen’s opinion.<br>On the other hand, if the wife demands to be divorced because of a matter that is beyond her husband’s control, she is not entitled to <i>tosefet ketuba</i>. See <i>Tosafot</i>, op. cit.; <i>PDR</i> 8:277 (R. Elyashiv’s opinion).</i>
Based upon the foregoing, given that the <i>Tove’a</i> refuses to engage in <i>onah</i> (the mitzva of engaging in conjugal relations periodically) and does not desire children, the marriage has <i>de facto</i> dissolved, a situation created by his personal choice, and therefore, he is obligated to pay <i>tosefet ketuba</i>. In accordance with R. Yeruham, she is “bolting the marriage” because of what her husband voluntarily did or refrained from doing, and therefore she is entitled to <i>tosefet ketuba</i>.
<b>3. A Husband’s Justifiable Claim</b>
Generally, upon a <i>beit din</i>’s determination that a <i>get</i> ought to be executed, the question arises whether the <i>seder ha-get</i> (the arrangement involved in the giving of the <i>get</i> by the husband to the wife) should be performed prior to the convening of a <i>beit din</i> or whether the panel should first resolve the outstanding end-of-marriage issues which are in dispute. This question is matter of controversy<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">R. Menashe Klein and R. Shimon Ya’akobi, “The Giving of a <i>Get</i> and Financial Arrangements: Which Precedes the Other?” (Hebrew), 22 <i>Tehumin</i> 157 (5762); File no. 8811-64-1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, September 6, 2009.</i> and in the NY metropolitan area, the policy of the majority of <i>battei din</i> is to address the parenting and financial issues relating to the marriage prior to the <i>seder ha-get</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Even the few <i>battei din</i> in New York City that have a policy to execute a <i>seder ha-get</i> prior to addressing the other matters will invariably deal with the end-of-marriage issues prior to the <i>seder ha-get</i> in a situation in which the husband insists on resolving the outstanding matters before giving a <i>get</i>, lest he become recalcitrant and refrain from delivering a <i>get</i> to his wife.</i>
In our scenario, the <i>beit din</i> panel had issued a judgment that the husband is obligated to deliver a <i>get</i> to his wife. Given that the husband is obligated to give a <i>get</i> in order to avoid an <i>igun</i> situation, the question is: Can the <i>Tove’a</i> insist that the <i>beit din</i> panel address and resolve his financial claims prior to the actual delivery of a <i>get</i>? Seemingly, since his wife is refusing to accept her husband’s stance regarding these claims, she is in effect creating an <i>igun</i> situation, and the obligation to give a <i>get</i> disappears. Consequently, these financial matters may be resolved prior to the issuance of a <i>get</i>. Given that the the wife’s claims are only being advanced due to “the dead marriage,” which in retrospect is the result of the husband’s behavior, therefore it seems that most <i>Poskim</i> conclude that the <i>get</i> ought to be given up front, and any outstanding claims should be resolved in <i>beit din</i> afterwards.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Dovid Bass, “The Establishment of Conditions by the Husband who is Obligated to Give a <i>Get</i>” (Hebrew), 25 <i>Tehumin</i> 149, 149–151 (5765); <i>Teshuvot Ateret Devora</i>, vol. 2, 646,650–657.</i>
Nevertheless, the minority view of Maharashdam,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 41.</i> which validates a husband’s right to stipulate that his claims must be resolved prior to giving a <i>get</i>, has found support in some <i>piskei din</i> of Eretz Yisrael’s Chief Rabbinate.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 5:68, 79 (R. Elyashiv’s opinion); N. Probar, Y. Goldberg, and S. Bibi, “<i>Psak Din</i>: A Husband who is obligated to give a <i>Get</i>, Can He Delay It Due to a Financial Claim?” (Hebrew), 2 <i>Divrei Mishpat</i> 153 (5756); File no. 1-05902427321, Supreme Beit Din, 21 Kislev 5761; File no. 4273-21-1, Supreme Beit Din, December 18, 2000; File no. 0027-21-1, Supreme Beit Din, August 29, 2004; File no. 7041-21-1, Supreme Beit Din, March 11, 2008; File no. 043387083-21-1, Tiberias Regional Beit Din, <i>ha-Din ve-ha-Dayan</i> 7, 28 Iyar, 5764; File no. 022290027-21-1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>ha-Din ve-ha-Dayan</i> 6, Heshvan 5765.</i> The scope of his ruling has been open to wide and varying interpretations. Some authorities have argued that his position embraces a husband’s right to stipulate claims that are unrelated to the <i>get</i>. Others have understood his position more narrowly, as referring to conditions related to the <i>get</i> itself. Hence, conditioning the delivery of a <i>get</i> upon first resolving matters of child support and parenting arrangements would be unjustified.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">S. Landesman, “A Husband Who is Obligated to Give a <i>Get</i>, Can He Establish Conditions?” (Hebrew), 2 <i>Divrei Mishpat</i> (5756), 145, 151–152; S. Daichovsky, “A Husband Who Stipulates the Giving of a <i>Get</i> after a Nullification of Prior Obligations” (Hebrew), 26 <i>Tehumin</i> 156, 157 (5766); this writer’s, “The Propriety of a Conditional Divorce,” 47 <i>Tradition</i> 31, 37,44-45 (2014).Cf. File no. 002721-1, supra n. 34.</i> Many have contended that only conditions which can be easily fulfilled by the wife fall under the ambit of Maharashdam’s <i>psak</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 1-21-022290027, Supreme Beit Din, 12 Elul 5764.</i> For example, if a wife could afford to pay X amount of money in exchange for the <i>get</i>, such a condition would be valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">R. Elyashiv, see supra n. 34.</i> In other words, whether a wife may easily comply with a condition is determined based upon “her social status, her personality, and her lifestyle,”<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 35.</i> Consequently, one cannot expect that a secular Jewess who was educated with the expectation that civil law would determine her marital issues would easily comply with her husband’s request to have these claims resolved by a <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">File 61-82, Supreme Beit Din, 18 Sivan 5762.</i> Likewise, one cannot expect an Orthodox Jewish woman to heed the demands of her husband to have <i>beit din</i> resolve their claims when he is someone who would ordinarily resolve his disputes in a secular court, and has no regard for <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Daichovsky, supra n. 35, at 158. Consequently, a husband is precluded from pleading that his wife is “transgressing religion” when he is violating the identical infractions. See <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 115:3; <i>Helkat Mehokeik and Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 115:7.</i> In addition, a husband’s demand that his wife relocate to another city would be an unjustified condition.<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ein Yitzhak</i> (Spector) 2, <i>EH</i> 40.</i> Others understood Maharashdam’s position to allow for unjustifiable claims contrary to Halakha to be resolved in <i>beit din</i> prior to the issuance of a <i>get</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">R. Landesman, supra n. 35.</i> Some decisors limit the validity of non-halakhic claims to those that can easily be resolved and fulfilled.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 35.</i> Others understood Maharashdam’s posture to be limited to halakhically justifiable claims only.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 5:60.</i>
In our case, since the husband’s monetary claim regarding the funds from the joint account is “a condition which is easily to comply with,” and there is a risk that failing to accede to his request may lead him to become intransigent regarding the <i>get</i>, the <i>Tove’a</i> does not have to deliver the <i>get</i> prior to this matter being resolved by the panel.
<b>4. Standard for Calculating <i>Mezonot ha-Yalda</i> (Daughter’s Support): In Accordance with the Child’s Social Standing, His Needs, or <i>Minhag ha-Medina</i>?</b>
As we know, a wife’s maintenance is assessed based upon her husband’s financial position and social status, provided that it is not lower than the standard of living she was accustomed to when living with her parents. If the husband’s standard of living is lower, he is obligated to support her according to the higher standard.<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 70:3, 73:3.</i> In fact, Pnei Moshe notes that a woman’s standard of living should be maintained in accordance with the standard of living in her father’s home.<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pnei Moshe</i>, Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Ketuvot</i> 5:6, s.v. “<i>ha-bat</i>.”</i> However, others argue that if the husband cannot afford his father-in-law’s standard of living, he is not obligated to provide it.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 8:309.</i>
In accordance with Talmud Bavli,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 68a.</i> a man must provide for his daughter in accordance with “<i>kevodo</i>,” i.e., his level of dignity. In other words, if the father is wealthy, then the standard will be that of a wealthy individual, and if he is poor, it will be the standard of a poor person. As R. Nahum Gertler, a <i>dayan</i> serving on a Rehovot <i>beit din</i>, aptly noted, the majority of <i>Rishonim</i> subscribed to this approach, a view which resonates amongst contemporary <i>Poskim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 68a, s.v. “<i>ha be-akhila</i>”; <i>Tosafot</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>mai lav</i>”; <i>Tosafot Shantz</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>mai lav</i>”; <i>Tosafot ha-Rosh</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>mai lav</i>”; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 190; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 6:12; <i>Shiltei Gibborim</i> on <i>Rif</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 4; <i>Piskei Riaz</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 4:4; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 112:15 (compare with <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 73:5); <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 114:7 in the name of <i>Rosh</i>.<br>For contemporary <i>Poskim</i> who subscribe to this position, see <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:106 (end); <i>PDR</i> 2:3, 8.</i>
Nonetheless, implicitly relying upon a passage in Talmud Yerushalmi,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 5:6. See <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 112:6.</i> as well as Rambam and Shulhan Arukh’s rulings,<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 13:6, 19:11; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 112:6.</i> most <i>Aharonim</i> contend that a daughter’s level of support is calculated according to her needs, not her father’s means.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 13:6; <i>Teshuvot Rashbash</i> 502; <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 73; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 70:1, 73:6,112:6, 114:6; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 71:1, 73:5; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 73:6; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 112:15; <i>Pnei Moshe</i> and <i>Korban ha-Eidah</i>, Talmud Yerushalmi, supra n. 46; <i>PDR</i> 1:119, 4:3, 8 (Rabbis Hadaya, Herzog, and Elyashiv), 9:251, 255.<br>There is a position that seemingly mandates a lower support standard, akin to the amount of basic subsistence for a poverty-stricken individual. See <i>Teshuvot Hina ve-Hisda</i> 3, 45:1; <i>Teshuvot Lev Mavin</i>, <i>EH</i> 138 (end); <i>Teshuvot Lev Hayyim</i>, <i>EH</i> 71:1; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, op. cit.; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:106, <i>YD</i> 1:143. Yet, it has been suggested by others that this approach is synonymous with the view that a daughter’s needs ought to be satisfied. See <i>Teshuvot Havot Binyamin</i> 2:42.</i> Elaborating upon the standard, R. Yehoshua Maman observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Emek Yehoshua</i> 2, <i>EH</i> 19:3.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">One is obliged to support them according to their needs … and their social station and how they were customarily supported prior to the divorce.</span>
R. Refael Moshe Elbaz of twentieth-century Yerushalayim writes,<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tehuvot Halakha le-Moshe</i>, <i>EH</i> 15.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Necessities are not measured by what is necessary in another city, but what is sufficient for them accordance to the practice of their city.</span>
In other words, upon divorce, the basic needs of child support are defined by the local practice,<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 9:255–258; <i>Havot Binyamin</i>, supra n. 52.</i> or by what the woman was accustomed to receive as basic needs, rather than by any additional support provided by her father due to his financial means.
There is a third yardstick for calculating a daughter’s support, a standard that was established at the inception of the marriage of the now-divorcing couple. According to certain <i>Poskim</i>, a father’s duty of child support is grounded in his obligation to support his wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 65b, s.v. “<i>yotzei</i>”; <i>Ran</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i>, end of <i>perek af al pi</i>; <i>Mishneh le-Melekh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 12:14; <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 71; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 91:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharam of Lublin</i> 79; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, supra n. 52, <i>YD</i> 1:143, 4:43<br>For <i>Poskim</i> who validate a <i>minhag</i> in monetary matters without receiving rabbinical approval (“<i>minhag vatikin</i>”), see this writer’s <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, 234, n. 20. For additional authorities, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:268; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ritva</i> 180; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 102; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i> 193; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shemuel</i> 103; <i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i>, <i>EH</i> 45, citing a list of <i>Rishonim</i> who concur with this view.<br>Even those <i>Poskim</i> who generally require rabbinical approval to legitimate a <i>minhag</i> dealing with a monetary matter, a prevailing practice regarding a marital dowry and <i>ketuba</i> may be an exception. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 102, 341; <i>Teshuvot Maharival</i> 1:70. Whether these <i>Poskim</i> would extend their position to a <i>minhag</i> dealing with child support we leave as an open question.</i> This duty is recorded in the <i>ketuba</i>, in which the husband obligates himself to provide for his family – “<i>ana eflach ve’okir</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Taz</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 71:2.</i> Given that <i>mezonot yeladim</i> (child support) is one of the <i>tena’im</i> (conditions) in the <i>ketuba</i>, its calculation is determined in the same fashion as some of the other <i>tena’im</i> of the <i>ketuba</i>. As already noted by Rambam, Shulhan Arukh, and Gra, matters relating to the <i>ketuba</i> are determined in light of national <i>minhag</i>, which has not been approved by rabbis, provided that the <i>minhag</i> is widespread throughout the country.<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 23:11, 12, 14; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 105, 345; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 66:11; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 66:48.</i> The legal guidelines regarding the standard of child support, a condition of the <i>ketuba</i>, are based upon the <i>minhag ha-medina</i>, similar to other issues that are governed by the prevailing practice.<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Divrei Yosef</i> 21; <i>Teshuvot Nediv Lev</i> 13; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 2:111; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Avraham</i> 1:1; <i>Teshuvot Ateret Shlomo</i> 1:85 (5) in the name of <i>Hazon Ish</i>; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 2:86 (9); <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72, 2:55; <i>PDR</i> 12:179.</i> Even if Jews are unaware of the <i>minhag</i><sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 3:932; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 228:2; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72, 75; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Sekhirut</i>, <i>perek</i> 7, n. 99; Batzri, <i>Dinei Mamonot</i> 2:316; <i>PDR</i> 19:9.</i> and/or fail to practice it,<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72.</i> Halakha obligates them to comply with it.<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Had the couple lived in a Hassidic community, assuming there was a <i>minhag</i> regarding the amount of child support, we would have to weigh whether such a <i>minhag</i> ought to prevail.</i>
Based upon the foregoing presentation, it is our opinion that <i>minhag ha-medina</i>, namely the law governing child support in the state of New Jersey where the couple resides, ought to be applied.
<b>5. Relocation of Child after Divorce</b>
Upon divorce, should there be any differences regarding with which parent a child ought to live, Halakha argues that custody contests ought to be resolved in accordance with <i>tovat hayeled</i>, namely, the child’s best interests.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 82:2; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhasot le-Ramban</i> 38; <i>Teshuvot Maharam me-Padua</i> 53; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 2:62; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:123, 360; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 82:7; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 123; <i>Teshuvot Perakh Mateh Aharon</i> 2:110; <i>Teshuvot Darkhei Noam</i>, <i>EH</i> 26; <i>PDR</i> 1:65, 145; 7:3. See further, this writer’s, “Child Custody: A Comparative Analysis,” 14 <i>Israel Law Review</i> 480 (1979).</i>
Such considerations should equally be factored into whether to approve a custodial parent’s request for relocation. As we know, the divorce of parents undermines the child’s sense of attachment and stability. Optimally, a child would want his divorcing parents to be amicable, communicative with each other and live close enough to each other. When a custodial parent seeks to move to a different geographical location, the best possible post-divorce situation for the child is threatened.
Given that following divorce, as few changes as possible should be made in the life of a child, in arriving at “a best interests” determination, a <i>beit din</i> must consider the following factors: each parent’s reasons for seeking or opposing the move, the quality of the relationships between the child and the parents, the impact of the move on the quality of the child’s future contact with the noncustodial parent, and whether the child’s life may be enhanced economically, emotionally, and educationally by the relocation.
Halakhically, in the wake of a custody battle, a daughter remains with her mother in order to be instructed in the ways of <i>tzniut</i>, modesty, and <i>midot</i>, halakhic-moral propriety.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashba</i>, supra n. 63; <i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 63; <i>Darkhei Noam</i>, supra n. 63; <i>Teshuvot Maharival</i> 1:55.</i> Given that this is a <i>hazakah</i>, a presumption that may be rebutted if the facts dictate that child placement with the mother may undermine the child’s best interests,<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:263; <i>Teshuvot Yaskil Avdi</i>, vol. 2, <i>EH</i> 10; <i>PDR</i> 1:173, 176.</i> how does Halakha address the case of a mother who wants to relocate to another geographical region, which will prevent the father from regularly spending time with his daughter?
In reply to this question, R. Yosef ben Lev contends that the daughter may move to another country in order to be with her mother. Firstly, when the Talmud states, “The daughter is forever with the mother,”<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 102b.</i> it means barring certain exceptions,<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">And moving away from her father is not one of these exceptions.</i> a daughter always remains with her mother. For example, an older daughter’s welfare does not mean that she must be with a mother who is licentious or a prostitute.<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharival</i>, supra n. 64.</i>
Strongly disagreeing with this position, R.
