Shmuel de Medina contends that should the move expose a daughter to interactions with people of immoral character, then such relocation is impermissible.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 63.</i> In other words, relocation must serve the child’s best interests. Since the child’s welfare should be a priority in any relocation decision, the larger family unit cannot be neglected. The goal is to <i>preserve</i> what is sound and successful. Hence, if during the marriage, there existed a healthy relationship between the noncustodial parent and the child, absent any extenuating circumstances, the ties should continue upon divorce of the parents.<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 21:17; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 82; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 82:7; <i>PDR</i> 1:114, 118, 158, 176.</i> Consequently, optimally the postdivorce family is “binuclear,” where a child is living in two households. As R. Shmuel de Medina exclaims,
<span class="poetry indentAll">Is it possible that a man has only one son … who lives with him and his being is emotionally tied to his son and when he sees that the young man no longer is here, he dies and his father is anguished … one cannot fathom this …</span>
In other words, relocation must be justified based on the child’s best interests, which entails assessing whether the child’s detachment from his noncustodial parent may psychologically impact upon him and leave long-term effects upon his personality development.
Following in the footsteps of Rabbis S. de Medina and D. ben Zimra, numerous <i>Poskim</i> will evaluate child relocation through the lens of the child’s best interests.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Shufrei de-Ya’akov</i>, <i>EH</i> 60; <i>Teshuvot Lev Mavin</i>, <i>EH</i> 139; <i>PDR</i> 1:158; File no. 7529-23-2, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, March 29, 2007; File no. 3750-64-2, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, January 6, 2008; File no. 586034/4, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, Haifa Regional Beit Din, January 16, 2011; File no. 84273/1, Tel Aviv Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, September 6, 2011; File no. 290277/7, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>, May 29, 2013.</i> Such a position flows inexorably from the notion that visitation rights for a noncustodial parent who lives in proximity to the custodial parent is granted based upon a determination that such privileges are in the child’s best interests, regardless whether we are dealing with a son<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Such visitation privileges will allow a father to educate his son in Torah. See <i>Mishneh le-Melekh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 21:17; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 82:7.</i> or a daughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 586034/4, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, January 16, 2011; File no. 586034/4, Haifa Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, July 25, 2012. Implicit in said conclusion is that the father has certain educational responsibilities vis-à-vis his daughter. See <i>Tosafot Shanz</i>, <i>Yoma</i> 82a; <i>Tosafot Yeshanim</i>, <i>Yoma</i> 82a; <i>Magen Avraham</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 343:1, 615:2, 640:3; <i>Shemirat Shabbat ke-Hilkhata</i> (1st ed.), <i>perek</i> 32.</i>
Based upon the parties’ argument, this panel finds that relocation would undermine the halakhic recognition of the binuclear family. <i>Nitva’at</i>’s contention that a job opportunity and parental support would lend credence to her petition for the move lacks foundation. Unlike other professions, there are numerous employment opportunities in the area of social work in northern New Jersey. Moreover, the <i>Nitva’at</i> has the emotional support of her siblings who reside in close proximity. The impact on the quantity and quality of the child’s future contact with the noncustodial parent must be provided for, even at the expense of the redeeming value of the <i>Nitva’at</i>’s parental emotional support her in the post-divorce situation. Consequently, we decline the <i>Nitva’at</i>’s request to relocate to another state that is far away from the daughter’s father.
<b>6. A Father-in-Law’s Claim to Recover Support Monies Provided to his Children: Are the Monies a Loan or a Gift?</b>
For the first three years of their marriage, <i>Nitva’at</i>’s father-in-law paid the couple’s rent. In effect, although halakhically a husband is obligated to support his wife including providing “a roof over her head,” here the wife’s father was paying his son-in-law’s outstanding obligation. Realizing that the <i>Tove’a</i> was not earning sufficient money to cover the rent, the father-in-law decided to pay the rent. At the time as well as later, there was no mention that said monies were a gift to the couple. Consequently, on behalf of her father,<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Since the father did not sign the <i>shtar borerut</i>, a <i>shtar harsha’a</i>, an authorization document, was prepared and signed by the father authorizing his daughter to advance a claim on his behalf. Upon the signing of the document, the <i>shtar borerut</i> (which was signed by both the husband and the wife) was amended to include the father-in-law as a <i>tove’a</i> against his son-in-law.</i> <i>Nitva’at</i> argues that her father is demanding that said monies be returned to him. <i>Nitva’at</i> contends that even if one would view these monies as gifts, such distributions would have not been forthcoming had <i>Nitva’at</i>’s father, the donor, realized that the couple would eventually become divorced. Buttressing her posture, she invokes Mordekhai’s ruling that deals with a testator who earmarked a portion of his estate to <i>tzedaka</i>. Subsequently, the testator’s relatives lost their assets and third parties claimed that the earmarked assets for <i>tzedaka</i> should be given to the testator’s relatives. Given that one can invoke the <i>umdana</i> (inferential fact finding) that had the testator known that his relatives would be in need of funds, he would not have designated said monies for <i>tzedaka</i>, Mordekhai rules that the monies ought to be distributed to his needy relatives.<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 493.</i> A similar conclusion was reached by Maharam of Lublin.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam of Lublin</i> 105.</i>
Countering the <i>Nitva’at</i>, <i>Tove’a</i> unravels the logical weakness of opposing party’s view. If one accepts <i>Nitva’at</i>’s argument, then in any situation in which relations deteriorate between a donor and recipient, the gift should be returned, because had the donor known that relations would sour, he would never have gifted the item to the recipient. Comparing this case to that discussed by R. Yom Tov Zahalon, <i>Tove’a</i> argues that this is impossible:<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharitz ha-Hadashot</i> 117.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If a <i>sefer Torah</i> was donated to a synagogue, and subsequently relations soured [between synagogue and the donor], can one allow him to take the Torah and sell it based upon an <i>umdana</i>!</span>
Consequently, <i>Tove’a</i> contends that although the relations have radically changed between the father-in-law and the <i>Tove’a</i>, one cannot therefore utilize an <i>umdana</i> regarding a future development as grounds to recover these assets. To ascertain whether <i>Tove’a</i> must repay the rent, we must look at the time that the gift was given, rather than at what would occur in the future. When the gift was given there were harmonious relations between the couple, and therefore the gifting did not entail any contingencies. Had the father-in-law stipulated that his giving of the gift was predicated upon continuing marital ties between the couple, then there would be grounds for rescinding the gift. However, in our scenario, no such stipulation was ever advanced.
In our opinion, <i>Tove’a</i>’s arguments demonstrate the correct understanding of the contours of an <i>umdana</i>. As Tosefta and Talmud observe, if a man’s son travels abroad and the father hears that his son passed away and therefore gives away his assets to a third party, if his son subsequently appears, the gifting is null and void.<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 4:14; <i>Bava Batra</i> 132a.</i> Clearly, the gift was predicated upon a fact that never transpired, i.e., his son’s death. In our situation, however, we cannot revoke the father-in-law’s gift by invoking an <i>umdana</i> because the gift was not based on an error. At the time of the gift, the couple was actually married. The fact that in the future, circumstances would change and the couple would divorce, does not serve as a grounds for invoking an <i>umdana</i>.
The remaining issue is whether the rent money ought to be returned to the father-in-law due to the fact that one cannot enrich oneself at the expense of others.
If an individual supports his friend, his friend is obliged to compensate him<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ran</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 107b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 3:615; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i> 1:147;</i> because he derived benefit from his friend’s assets.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh le-Melekh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Malveh ve-Loveh</i> 16:11; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i> and <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 246.</i> The requirement to provide compensation is not limited to sustaining somebody, but equally extends to any services provided to another individual, even in the absence of an oral or written request for these services.<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">See list of <i>Rishonim</i> cited in <i>Teshuvot Alsheikh</i> 70; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 70:8, <i>HM</i> 246:17, 286:3.</i> In rabbinic nomenclature, conferring benefit for another is known as “<i>yoreid le-nikhsei haveiro</i>,” or “one who goes down to another person’s field.”<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 67:7, 185:3.</i> Compensation in such situations is not limited to friends or strangers, but applies equally to relatives.<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 317, 348; <i>Rema</i>, supra n.81; <i>Levush Mordekhai</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 286; <i>Teshuvot Parakh Mateh Aharon</i> 1:62.</i> Though some <i>Poskim</i> demur, and therefore some decisors conclude that it is a legal doubt, i.e., <i>safek le-dina</i><sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 363; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 246:9, 363:13; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 363:9; <i>Teshuvot Agudat Eizov</i>, <i>HM</i> 20; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 119; <i>Teshuvot Ktav Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 21; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>HM</i> 363:7; File no. 1643159, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, January 16, 2006; File no. 256859/7, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, Netanya Regional Beit Din, July 22, 2012.</i> and therefore one cannot extract money under such circumstances, nevertheless, many others mandate compensation.<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh le-Melekh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkot Gezela ve-Aveida</i> 3:9; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 12:19; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 70:28; <i>Taz</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 246:17, <i>YD</i> 166:3; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 264:7 (Cf. 246:17); <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 134; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 345, 373; <i>Teshuvot Ktav Sofer</i>, supra n. 84, <i>HM</i> 21; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 246:19.</i>
Assuming both parties concur that it was not specified whether the money was a loan or a gift, seemingly the <i>Tove’a</i> who argues that his intent was to lend the money is <i>bari</i> (certain), whereas the <i>Nitva</i> is in doubt whether in fact it was a loan. Shulhan Arukh rules that in such a case one is exempt from paying.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 75:19.</i> <i>Poskim</i> nevertheless maintain that one is obligated to pay, not because we believe the <i>ta’anat bari</i>, claim of certainty, but rather because we invoke an <i>umdana</i> that it was the person’s intention to give a loan. The <i>Nitva</i> is therefore obligated to compensate him regardless of whether he is a stranger, friend, or relative.<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Nizkei Mamon</i> 3.</i>
Based upon the foregoing, in the absence of the donor’s articulating his intent regarding the nature of the monies distributed, and in the absence of a <i>minhag</i> in the community to give such monies to young couples,<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Terumat ha-Deshen</i> 317; <i>Alsheikh</i>, supra n. 81; <i>Yam shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 8:69; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 373; R. Akiva Eiger, supra n. 79; <i>Teshuvot Mishpat Tzedek</i> 2:7.</i>and in pursuance to Hatam Sofer that a <i>peshara</i> is proper due to uncertainty regarding the Halakha,<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 84.</i> <i>Tove’a</i> is hereby obligated to return two years of rent to his father-in-law.
<b>7. <i>Tova’at</i>’s Claim for <i>Ma’aseh Yadeha</i> (Handiwork)</b>
In exchange for being supported by her husband, a wife is obliged to do domestic work that is normally performed by wives enjoying a certain standard of living. In Mishnaic and Talmudic times, wives engaged in domestic chores such as cooking, baking, and washing, and contributed economically to the family by engaging in weaving wool in the marital home. Such work became an obligation upon a wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 59b.</i> Subsequently, in certain places during the Middle Ages, wives embarking on other “career choices” chose to embroider and spin linen. These “female occupations” became obligatory upon a wife, and as such, income earned from this work belongs to the husband in exchange for his financial support of his spouse.<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 21:1.</i>
As the centuries progressed, almost all vocations became “gender neutral,” women began working outside the home, and consequently, occupations such as working in a factory, teaching, and secretarial work are not activities that a wife must perform.<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 1:82, 2:223, 3:208, 8:307.</i> In other words, in exchange for spousal support, a wife engages in certain domestic chores and economic activities in her household. However, a wife’s employment in the marketplace is not to be understood as reciprocation for her husband’s support.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Meir</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 80:1; File no. 833474/12, Ashkelon Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, September 2, 2013.</i> As such, if a wife manages a household and exerts additional time effort to earn money in the marketplace, such work may be labeled <i>ha’adafah al yedei ha-dehak</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 7:290, 8:275, 304.</i> If a wife exerts herself more than usual (<i>ha’adafah al yedei ha-dehak</i>), it is a matter of debate whether this “surplus” belongs to her or to her husband. Consequently, a husband who contends that his wife’s earnings should belong to him may very well lose in advancing such a claim in <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 80; <i>PDR</i> 1:91, 94, 2:223, 226, 6:32, 8:275, 278, 279. Cf. <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>EH</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ketuvot</i> 70:5.</i>
Some authorities will argue that since there are <i>Poskim</i> who contend that a wife’s income belongs to her,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 59b, s.v. “<i>R. Eliezer</i>”; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Mintz</i> 17; <i>Mishneh le-Melekh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ishut</i> 21:1 in the name of <i>Ra’avad</i>; <i>Beit Yosef</i> (in the name of <i>Rashba</i>); <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 95; <i>Dagul me-Revava</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 80; <i>PDR</i> 1:81, 90, 19:287–288; R. Reuven Feinstein (in the name of R. M. Feinstein), <i>Sefer Zikaron Eitz Erez</i>, 799–801.</i> a wife is entitled to retain her earnings by invoking “<i>kim li</i>” (lit. “I hold the opinion”). The invocation of this rule rests on the assumption that when a dispute is submitted to a <i>beit din</i>, the panel has to determine which claimant is entitled to retain certain assets. In Halakha, there is a concept whereby one of the claimants is considered as the one who is in possession of the disputed item (the <i>muhzak</i>), while the other claimant wants to “extract” this asset and transfer it to himself. As R. Elyashiv notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 8:275, 278</i> pursuant to halakhic court procedure, the wife who engages in her domestic chores while working as a social worker can argue: “I want the <i>beit din</i> to rule in my favor, based upon the position of Rabbis so and so who affirm my claim.”<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bah</i>, supra n. 95; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 80:2; <i>Helkat Mehokeik</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 80:2; <i>Dagul me-Revava</i>, supra n. 96; <i>PDR</i> 1:81, 92, 2:220, 226; 8:275, 278.</i> This argument is halakhically admissible provided that the wife is in possession of her income – if it is in her bank account (under her own name or jointly held with her husband), still in her employer’s possession, or invested in her property.<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 1:81, 94, 2:220, 227; File no. 577277/2, Haifa Regional Beit Din, June 24, 2010 cited in <i>ha-Din ve-Hadayan</i> 25.</i> However, if the earnings have been deposited in her husband’s financial accounts or have been invested in his property, she would not be <i>muhzeket</i> and therefore would be unable to receive her earnings by invoking the “<i>kim li</i>” argument.
Based on the cumulative evidence in our case, given that a year prior to the divorce proceedings <i>Tove’a</i> withdrew $200,000 from the couple’s joint account, and <i>Tove’a</i> can only demonstrate that $50,000 was used in order to pay for domestic expenses including income tax obligations, <i>Nitva’at</i> is entitled to $75,000, which represents fifty percent of those funds, as a joint account holder. <i>Nitva’at</i> is entitled to those funds for two reasons: (1) Based upon the <i>kim li</i> argument, she is entitled to her earnings, but she is only entitled to half of these assets, since by signing on to a joint account, she implicitly agreed that her assets would be jointly owned by her spouse and herself. (2) Even if one rejects the merits of employing the <i>kim li</i> argument, nevertheless her husband’s agreement to have his assets jointly held with hers in the same account entitles her as a partner to half those assets. However, she would not recover income from earlier years of employment that was deposited in this account and already spent for the domestic household.
<b>Decision</b>
1. <i>Tove’a</i> is hereby obligated to give the <i>Nitva’at</i> a <i>get</i> after the rendering of our decision.
2. <i>Tove’a</i> is hereby obligated to pay her $50,000, the value of her <i>ketuba</i> and <i>tosefet ketuba</i>.
3. <i>Tove’a</i> is hereby obligated to pay the <i>Nitva’at</i> $75,000.
4. Based upon NJ Child Support guidelines, <i>Tove’a</i> is obligated to pay $1600 monthly child support for his child.
5. <i>Nitva’at</i>’s petition to relocate to another state is hereby denied.
6. <i>Tove’a</i> is hereby obligated to pay two years of rent to his father-in-law.

Chapter 7; Decisions in Hoshen Mishpat

a) The Scope of an Investment Broker's Responsibility

<b>A. The Scope of an Investment Broker’s Responsibility</b>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Menachem Levy vs. People’s Bank, Levi Cohen</i></span>
On June 1, 2011, the above parties signed an arbitration agreement empowering this panel to resolve their dispute according to applicable portions of Shulhan Arukh and <i>Poskim</i>. As noted above, Menahem Levy is filing suit against Mr. Cohen personally, as well as against People’s Bank, Inc. Both parties submitted their differences and disputes in reference to Cohen’s services provided to Menahem Levy to this <i>beit din</i>. Having given said matters due consideration and having heard all parties testify as to the facts of said disputes and differences, this panel does decide and agree as follows:
<b>Facts</b>
Menachem Levy (hereafter: <i>Tove’a</i>), a long-time banking client of People’s Bank in New York, NY, a bank owned and managed by Torah-observant Jews (hereafter: <i>Nitva</i>), met with Levi Cohen (hereafter: Cohen), an Orthodox Jewish broker at the bank’s newly created brokerage firm (which inadvertently failed to file incorporation papers at the time) to discuss investing. In his forties at the time, Cohen had previously placed his money in insured certificates of deposit. At the meeting, Cohen prepared a comprehensive financial analysis, which included evaluations of <i>Tove’a</i>’s financial portfolio, his net worth, debt management, retirement finances, estate planning, and insurance coverage.
Prior to investing with the brokerage firm of the bank, <i>Tove’a</i> received certain written materials to read regarding the risks associated with the stock investments and signed off on paperwork to open up his account. Cohen signed off in his capacity as an employee of People’s Bank, Inc. Among the provisions of the customer agreement relating to the discretionary account are the following:
<span class="poetry indentAll">The client agrees that he has read and understood the risks involved in trading on a securities exchange … The broker shall conduct its business, as it relates to the services defined herein, in a commercially reasonable, legal and ethical manner … and that the broker’s affairs with client have been conducted in a professional manner. All investments involve risk, and unless you provide individualized recommendation to me, I or my agent are responsible for determining the suitability of any trade, investment, investment strategy and risk associated with my investments.</span>
With the consent of the <i>Tove’a</i>, Cohen was empowered to determine whether to buy or sell stock funds without any prior instructions from the <i>Tove’a</i>. To state it differently, Cohen was managing a discretionary account on behalf of the <i>Tove’a</i>. Cohen invested half his money in these stocks. The other half, which was to be invested in conservative bonds, was placed in a discretionary account wherein there is a duty to execute an order promptly in accordance with the <i>Tove’a</i>’s instructions and best interests. Prior to the economic meltdown of 2008, Cohen abstained from following the <i>Tove’a</i>’s instructions to purchase a bond. Subsequently, the market plunged and the product subsequently declined in value.
Though Cohen held a professional liability insurance policy, and therefore commercial practice is that parties proceed directly against the insurance company, nevertheless, at the time of the convening of this <i>beit din</i> panel, <i>Tove’a</i> had not and was inclined not to commence a suit in civil court against the insurance company.
<b><i>Tove’a</i>’s Claims</b>
<i>Tove’a</i> claims that a special relationship existed between Cohen and himself, which imposed a duty on the defendant to convey sound financial advice to him. Additionally, it appeared that Cohen held or appeared to hold special expertise relating to investment planning, and therefore <i>Tove’a</i> relied on him that the information provided to him was financially sound.
Cohen induced the <i>Tove’a</i> to buy securities by misrepresenting the level of risk, such as illiquidity, deferred contingent sales charges, and unusual political and economic risks. In reply to Cohen’s argument that written disclosure and signing off on the potential risk of such investments precludes a claim for negligent misrepresentation, <i>Tove’a</i> claims that he had no prior investment experience regarding stocks, the written materials were difficult to comprehend, and he didn’t understand what he was signing. In reply to Cohen’s argument that no special relationship had been established between the parties, <i>Tove’a</i> argues that Cohen’s credentials as an investment planner, his preparation of a comprehensive financial analysis of <i>Tov’ea</i>’s holdings, and his receipt of compensation for his services <i>ipso facto</i> creates a relationship of trust and confidence rather than an expression of “curbside advice.” Like others, Cohen is a licensed broker, who passed examinations and had passed certain education requirements. His conduct is subject to regulation by the government and industry self-regulatory organizations.
Admittedly, Cohen informed himself of his client’s investment objectives and general financial situation, so as to ensure that each security would be suitable to his client’s investment objectives and financial situation. On the basis of his due diligence, he recommended setting up a discretionary account for the purchase and sale of stocks and a non-discretionary account for the purchase and sale of conservative bonds.
Regarding the stock investments, though Cohen was authorized to buy and sell without the <i>Tove’a</i>’s prior authorization, nevertheless, Cohen failed to heed red flags that indicated a potential depreciation of his stock investments and the <i>Tove’a</i>’s stocks decreased in value, resulting in a loss of $300,000.
<i>Tove’a</i> is suing People’s Bank and Cohen personally. Though Cohen is employed by a corporate entity, nevertheless, he is not a shareholder in the bank, and therefore, he allegedly is personally liable for his conduct.
<b>Cohen’s Claims</b>
Given that the <i>Tove’a</i>, as an investor, was provided with written materials disclosing the risks, and signed off on his accounts, which indicated that that the investment involved a degree of risk, <i>Tove’a</i> has no claim for negligent misrepresentation. Moreover, <i>Tove’a</i>’s contention that there was a special relationship between them implies a relationship that extended beyond the typical arm’s length business transaction, but such ties did not exist. Nobody from the bank initiated such contact with <i>Tove’a</i>, no one induced the <i>Tove’a</i> to forego performing his own due diligence, and no individual repeatedly vouched for the veracity of the allegedly deceptive information. The requisite relationship of trust and confidence did not exist, and therefore, Cohen argues that he is exempt from responsibility for any losses from both the stock investments and the potential bond purchase. Finally, given that Cohen served in the capacity of an employee of the bank, any award handed down by the <i>beit din</i> must be paid by the bank, which is incorporated, rather than by him.
Given that <i>Tove’a</i> may proceed against the insurance company, which protects Cohen’s professional activity as a broker, <i>Tove’a</i> has no right to “double dip” should he decide to file a civil suit and recover monetary damages from the insurance company. Consequently, in the event that there would be a <i>beit din</i> award, it should be contingent upon the fact that <i>Tove’a</i> shall refrain from filing suit in court against the insurance company.
<b>Discussion</b>
Generally speaking, given that we are dealing with monetary matters, Halakha allows the parties to determine their own business relationship, provided that the agreement complies with proper form, i.e., a <i>kinyan</i> (a symbolic act of undertaking an obligation), and that it does not violate any prohibitions.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 19b; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur HM</i> 305:4; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 344:1.</i> Consequently, if the written memorandum between the broker and client varies from the <i>halakhot</i> of Hoshen Mishpat (halakhic civil law), the agreement will be valid and binding upon the parties.
In our case, among the terms of the brokerage agreement was the following: a presentation of the financial services to be provided, the rate of compensation, and the broker’s obligations. Prior to signing the agreement, Cohen brought the contents of a risk disclosure letter to the notice of the <i>Tove’a</i>, and in the written agreement it states that he has read and understood the risks involved in trading on a stock exchange. When one invests in securities and becomes aware of the attendant risks, it means that he has accepted that his investments may decline in value.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot Ketuvot</i> 47b, s.v. “<i>shela</i>.”</i> In the agreement, there was no standard “no reliance” disclaimer that neither party was relying on any advice, statements, or recommendations (whether written or oral) of the other party regarding any transaction. Absent any agreement to the contrary, such an arrangement will exempt the broker from responsibility for any negligent behavior.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 94a; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 2, <i>HM</i> 116; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 344:1. Cf. R. Barukh of Regensburg, <i>Ohr Zarua</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 297.</i> Finally, the agreement contains a pre-dispute arbitration clause whereby any differences will be resolved by a <i>beit din</i>. As such, this panel has been empowered by the parties to address the matters in dispute in accordance with the provisions of the signed written agreement.
At the initial hearing, the question arose whether the matters in dispute would be resolved according to the canons of Hoshen Mishpat or according to <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> (commercial practice) as expressed in federal and state law as well the broker-dealer selling practice rules promulgated by self-regulatory organizations such as the National Association of Securities Dealers and the New York Stock Exchange. The <i>Tove’a</i> contends that the <i>halakhot</i> of Hoshen Mishpat should govern the proceeding, and Cohen advanced pleadings for <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> to be the basis for resolving their issues. Without having to address the halakhic propriety of invoking <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, given that the parties were in disagreement regarding how to have their differences resolved, this panel decided to render a <i>psak din</i> (decision) grounded in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>Hoshen Mishpat</i>.
At first glance, such a decision runs counter to an oft-cited <i>teshuva</i> (responsum) authored by R. Shlomo ben Avraham ha-Kohen (known by the acronym <i>“</i>Maharshakh”)<i>,</i> a sixteenth-century authority in Salonika, Turkey, who addressed a similar scenario.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 2:229.</i> There was a dispute relating to a civil contract. One party wanted the matter resolved in a <i>beit din</i> and the opposing party wanted the matter resolved by a merchants’ panel that was located in Venice, Italy where the transaction took place. Maharshakh ruled that since both parties were relying upon commercial custom to govern their affairs, the matter ought to be resolved by the civil panel of businessmen. Seemingly, in our instance, the engagement of the <i>Tove’a</i> and Cohen was premised upon the fact that commercial practice would prevail. Consequently, we should opt to render a decision based upon civil law.
However, a closer reading of the <i>teshuva</i> reveals that the <i>psak</i> was contingent upon two facts. Firstly, there must be evidence that the parties relied upon commercial custom to govern their relationship. Secondly, in Venice, the <i>minhag</i> was to resolve commercial issues in front of laymen of professionals rather than a <i>beit din</i>. In our situation, the provisions of the brokerage agreement do not attest to any intention that their affairs be determined by <i>minhag ha-soharim.</i> On the contrary, the pre-dispute arbitration clause in their agreement designates the forum for resolution to be a <i>beit din</i>. Our decision to resolve this matter according to the canons of Hoshen Mishpat is thus not contradicted by the aforementioned <i>teshuva</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">It would seem that if both parties were operating with the expectation that their disputes would be resolved by <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, then Maharshakh would rule that the <i>beit din</i> would determine the claims based upon <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>.</i>
In reply to <i>Tove’a’s</i> claim that he failed to understand what he was signing, once the client reads a prospectus, a risk disclosure statement, and signs off on a brokerage agreement, he cannot subsequently claim that he did not understand what he signed or that he failed to read all the provisions of the agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 61:13; <i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA HM</i> 45:3. For a contemporary application of this rule regarding a brokerage agreement, see <i>PDR</i> 9:16, 25.</i> In effect, by failing to find others who would explain the agreement to him, he is in effect relying upon his broker and is obligated to the terms of the agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 45 in the name of <i>Ramban</i>.</i> Hence, <i>Tove’a</i>’s contention that he did not understand what he read when he signed the bank’s customer agreement lacks foundation.
<b>1. Reliance Factors That Establish a Broker’s Responsibility</b>
A claim for negligent misrepresentation entails a communication, in the course of one’s employment or profession, of an unintentional false representation of information for the guidance of others in their commercial transactions. In our situation, a broker advises a client and misrepresents certain information regarding securities investments. Relying upon this advice, a purchase or sale of securities is executed and losses are incurred.
Addressing which factor(s) engender responsibility for negligent misrepresentation, there is a debate whether a “<i>mumheh</i>” – in our case, a licensed investment broker – who performed his due diligence by proffering advice and erred, is exempt under all circumstances. Unable to resolve the controversy, R. Yosef ibn Lev, a sixteenth-century authority therefore rules, “In cases of doubt we do not extract money.”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari ibn Lev</i> 3:30</i>
Implicit in his position is that if an arbiter feels he cannot resolve the situation, he should abstain from deciding the merits of a claim for negligent misrepresentation. Adopting such a view inexorably leads to the conclusion that one cannot find any monetary relief in filing such a suit against an investment broker who was paid for his services and acted negligently.
However, the more widely accepted position is that receipt of payment, “the pecuniary interest,” serves as the foundation for the expert’s responsiblity for lack of due diligence in communicating advice. As Shulhan Arukh states,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>HM</i> 306:6</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If he charged for his services, he is obligated to pay even though he is an expert and does not require further training.</span>
Relying upon the venerable views of Rambam and Rosh, Shakh concurs with Shulhan Arukh’s decision.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 306:11.</i> This position is reflective of normative Halakha.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Sekhirut</i> 328–329, <i>Nezikin</i> 170, n. 57.</i>
Assuming that such a claim will be heard in <i>beit din</i>, pursuant to Shulhan Arukh and Rema, the prerequisite for liability is that the professional advisor is remunerated for his services and that the client has relied upon his advice, either by an actual statement communicated to the investment advisor or because the circumstances indicate an apparent reliance upon the advisor.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 106:6. For further discussion, see this writer’s, “The tort of negligent misrepresentation in investment planning: a comparative analysis,” 19 <i>The Jewish Law Annual</i> 141 (2011) which can be accessed at www.yutorah.org.</i>
Even though we are dealing with a <i>Tove’a</i> who invested conservatively, depositing his monies in bank CDs, and who is relatively na•ve regarding the securities market, clearly we are dealing with a broker who performed his due diligence in communicating to his client the risk of such investments. Furthermore, by opening up these various accounts and signing off on the customer’s written memorandum, the <i>Tove’a</i> accepted or understood the nature of the risk and voluntarily chose to subject himself to that risk.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 301:10; 380:1.</i> Given that Cohen forwarded materials for the <i>Tove’a</i> relating to securities, and also explained “the market risk” to him and that “past performance does not guarantee future results,” there was an implicit assumption of risk which exempts the broker from responsibility for ensuing losses. Clearly, <i>Tove’a</i>’s assumption of risk was limited to receiving sound investment advice.
<b>2. The Halakhic Consequences of Securities Investment Losses due to a Broker’s Inaction in Selling</b>
Given that the <i>Tove’a</i> was informed regarding the risks of his investment, is there a basis for concluding that the <i>Nitva</i> remains liable? A broker handling a discretionary account decides whether to sell or buy without receiving any instructions from his client. To execute transactions in a professional fashion, the broker must be duly informed of market fluctuations that affect his client’s interests and objectives, and must provide ongoing counsel regarding the risks entailed in purchasing or selling securities. Granted a power of attorney, the broker is authorized to execute transactions without the client’s prior approval.
Despite the existence of red flags that indicated a potential depreciation of the <i>Tove’a</i>’s investments, Cohen refrained from selling, and losses were incurred. This matter must be examined within the context of <i>hilkhot shemira</i> (bailment), <i>hilkhot shelihut</i> (agency), and <i>hilkhot nezikin</i> (damages). Absent terms of the customer agreement stating otherwise,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, if the customer agreement would state that the broker is liable for all damages, then he would be responsible even for indirect damages. See <i>Teshuvot Imrei Bina</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; Z. N. Goldberg, 11 <i>Yeshurun</i> 602–603 (2002).</i> generally speaking, given that the damage was only indirect (<i>grama</i>) and “one who causes indirect damage is exempt from responsibility” (“<i>grama be-nezikin patur</i>”),<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Kama</i> 60a; <i>Bava Batra</i> 22b.</i> one might at first glance assume that Cohen is exempt from compensating the <i>Tove’a</i> for his losses. According to most authorities, an action is a direct cause of the ensuing damage (“<i>garmi</i>”) if the damage is instantaneous and inevitable (“<i>bari hezeka</i>”), such as destroying someone’s note of indebtedness. However, if the damage is not inevitable or instantaneous, the damage is labeled <i>grama</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 22b; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 9:17. Such a conclusion may be inferred from <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i> 140; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 4, <i>HM</i> 3; <i>Teshuvot le-Horot Natan</i> 3:99.</i> However, given that Cohen is a professional broker and is paid for his services, he is liable for his negligence in failing to sell the securities in a timely fashion.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i> and <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 306:6; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Yitzhak</i> (Abulafia) 24.</i> This conclusion is predicated upon construing a broker as incurring responsibility based on the norms of <i>hilkhot nezikin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:53, 3:107; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 2:114; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 234:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 179; <i>Teshuvot Maritz Yeshanot</i> 156; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:16; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 10:294; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 5:102.</i>
Alternatively, for those who argue that one cannot advance a claim for negligence based on <i>hilkhot nezikin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Alternatively, arguably one may contend that the broker’s inaction did not cause losses that were “<i>bari hezeka</i>,” and therefore, he is exempt from paying for the damages. See <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 386:3; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 21; <i>Pnei Yitzhak</i>, supra n. 17.</i> or espouse the view that a professional broker who is paid and erred is in the category of an <i>ones</i>, i.e., an unpreventable accident, and is therefore exempt from any errors that might have been committed or omitted,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 99b, s.v. “<i>eima</i>”; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 99, s.v. “<i>amar</i>”; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sekhirut</i> 10:5.</i> Cohen may be nevertheless responsible by virtue of his status as a <i>shomer sakhar</i>, i.e., paid bailee, who is liable for negligence including loss<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 94a; Talmud Yerushalmi, <i>Kil’ayyim</i> 7:3; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 306:12; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 131; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 3:142. Though no <i>kinyan</i> was executed, once the client entrusts his assets to a broker, <i>hilkhot shemira</i> are applicable. See <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 99a, s.v. “<i>tiknu</i>”; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 8:15; <i>Teshuvot Beit Ephraim</i> 34; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:359. Others learn that pursuant to <i>Tosafot</i> and <i>Rosh</i>, the commencement of work generates <i>hilkhot shemira</i>. See <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 307:1.</i> and therefore subject to <i>hilkhot shemira</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i>, supra n. 6; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:16; <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 2:34.</i> Though Cohen never explicitly accepted the responsibility to safeguard the assets, nonetheless, in this respect he is no different than any employee who receives compensation, who is obligated to safeguard the material he works with,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 293:1.</i> and if he causes a loss, he is responsible.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 74:1, 307:1; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 291:12.</i> Alternatively, in light of the client’s reliance upon Cohen, as a professional broker compensated for his expertise, he is responsible for any negligence and ensuing loss, even if the loss was not <i>bari hezeka</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Avnei Nezer</i>, <i>HM</i> 19.</i> Finally, the circumstances indicate, i.e., there is a <i>giluy da’at</i>, that the monies have been transferred from the client to the broker, and therefore, <i>ipso facto</i>, the planner is entrusted with them.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 291 (in the name of <i>Rosh</i>); <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Shomerim</i> 1; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:291; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 291:2.<br></i>
Regardless of the rationale that establishes the ties of <i>shemira</i>, one of the consequences of Cohen’s status as a <i>shomer</i> is that he is responsible for his inaction. Addressing this point, R. Yosef Trani deals with an agent who was remunerated and empowered to sell merchandise but failed to finalize the sale. In the interim, the goods declined in value. Though in terms of <i>hilkhot nezikin</i>, he would be exempt from responsibility (since the situation would be labeled as <i>grama</i>), however given that the <i>shaliach</i> is also a <i>shomer</i>, he is liable for acts of <i>grama</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharit</i>, <i>HM</i> 110.</i> Similarly, one may conclude that if a broker is aware of the potential decline of securities, he would be responsible for ensuing losses.
Implicit in invoking <i>hilkhot shemira</i> as defining one of the identities of an investment planner,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Our presentation explicitly assumes that a broker’s identity is governed by various realms of Halakha, such as <i>nezikin</i> and <i>shemira.</i></i> is that a broker’s duty of care encompasses protecting the market value of the securities. If a Jew deposits <i>hametz</i> with a fellow Jew on the eve of Pesach and the Jewish bailee neglects to sell the <i>hametz</i> to a gentile before the onset of Pesach, the owner of the <i>hametz</i> is forbidden to derive benefit from it after Pesach. Moreover, according to most authorities, the s<i>homer</i>’s responsibility is limited to ensuring the preservation of the actual physical state of the <i>hametz</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 38a; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 30a, s.v. “<i>le-tzorkho</i>”; <i>Taz</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 443:4; <i>Teshuvot Meishiv Davar</i> 3:18; <i>Mishnah Berura</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>OH</i> 443:16; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:16.</i> The fact that the owner of the <i>hametz</i> will be unable to benefit from the foodstuffs after Pesach is not the <i>shomer</i>’s responsibility. Similarly, it would seem that the safeguarding of the value of securities from market fluctuations is beyond a s<i>homer</i>’s mandate.
However, there are <i>Poskim</i> who note that in cases of potential devaluation of currency or depreciation of documents such as a lottery ticket, a <i>shomer</i> is duty-bound to redeem this currency or be liable for failing to be aware of the lottery ticket’s expiration date.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Zekan Aharon</i> 1:112; <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i> 1:593; <i>Teshuvot Tarshish Shoham</i> 105; <i>She’elat Ya’avetz</i> 1:85; Barukh Kahane, <i>Shomerim</i>, 351–354.</i> Similarly, we may conclude that an investment planner, by dint of being a <i>shomer</i>, is obligated to keep abreast of market fluctuations, and if he fails to sell an investment that demonstrates the potential to decline in value, he is liable for the loss.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">This conclusion is predicated upon the fact that the lost value of an investment, albeit is an example of <i>hezek she’ane nikar</i>, indiscernible damage; nonetheless one is liable for the loss. See <i>Tevuot Shor</i> 18; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Schick</i>, <i>YD</i> 284; <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i> 66:34.<br>A broker’s liability for such damage extends even in a situation in which the broker fails to explicitly assume responsibility for such a loss. See <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i> 66:34; <i>Teshuvot Helkat Yo’av</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i>, <i>HM</i> 12.</i> In other words, even if one would contend that a professionally paid broker’s inaction in selling investments that would potentially lose their value is not “<i>bari hezeka</i>” and therefore should be viewed as <i>grama</i>, nevertheless, as a <i>shomer</i>, he would be responsible for the loss.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshurat Shai</i>, supra n. 30; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 140.</i>
To assess whether, in fact, there are grounds to view Cohen’s inaction as an act of negligence, we inquired with two experts in securities investments as to whether the decline in the value of the securities was due to the financial integrity of the companies or “the halo effect” of the financial markets. Depending on its source, the decline ought to have propelled Cohen to either sell or refrain from selling these securities. Addressing an insurance agent who failed to collect an award from an insurance company and subsequently went bankrupt, Maharshakh states,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 2:46. For the hiring of experts in other matters such as appraising the value of property or movables, see <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 73:15; 103.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It appears that this matter should be clarified by expert merchants, and if they feel he has been negligent according to the custom of the merchants, he is … obligated to pay.</span>
In our scenario, the expert testimony of both financial planners was that Cohen’s inaction was due to his failure to keep abreast of the market fluctuations and therefore he is obligated to pay <i>Tove’a</i> for his losses.
<b>3. Corporate Liability or Broker’s Personal Liability?</b>
Generally speaking, directors, officers, and shareholders of a corporation are not personally liable for the financial obligations of the corporation. One of the reasons for accepting this rule, known as the limited liability rule, is because there is an assumption that when individuals engage in transactions with corporations, everyone will abide by civil law, which validates this rule. Implicit in this position is that regarding monetary matters, “<i>matneh al ma she-katuv ba-torah, tena’o kayam</i>,” i.e., we can stipulate contrary to what is written in the Torah and establish our own agreements regarding our commercial transactions. In other words, though Halakha imputes personal liability to these individuals, Halakha permits us to adopt the norms of civil law, which precludes them from being personally responsible for any debts. In effect, individuals have not only agreed to comply with secular law but also with “<i>minhag ha-soharim</i>,” i.e., commercial practice. Alternatively, others contend that pursuant to “<i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>,” i.e., the law of the kingship is the law, Halakha imparts validity to limiting liability of shareholders, directors, and officers.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Batzri, <i>Dinei Mamonot</i>, vol. 2, 315; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Halva’a</i> 7:17, <i>Shutafut</i> 1:33; <i>Brit Yehuda</i> 7:25–26; <i>Moadim u-Zmanim</i> 3:269; <i>PDR</i> 6:322, 10:278.</i> However, given that Cohen was an employee for People’s Bank, Inc., rather than a shareholder, director, or officer, the limited liability rule cannot shield him from personal liability for his improper behavior.
The question is, given the fact that Cohen signed off on the customer agreement as an employee of People’s Bank, will Cohen’s employer be responsible for his actions, or will he be personally liable for his failure to sell the securities in a timely fashion? As we explained, the identity of a broker is molded by the <i>halakhot</i> governing <i>nezikin</i> and <i>shemira.</i> However, there is another realm of Halakha which impacts a planner’s identity, namely <i>hilkhot shelihut</i>, i.e., the laws of agency, and <i>hilkhot sekhirut</i>, i.e., labor relations law, which replies to our question. Generally speaking, agency is formed on the basis of a verbal commitment, a written agreement, or the conduct of the parties.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 35:5; <i>HM</i> 182:1.</i> In our scenario, in the absence of an oral or written agreement explicitly stating that Cohen is the <i>shaliach</i> of the <i>Tove’a</i>, <i>Tove’a</i>’s authorization to have Cohen open a discretionary account is nevertheless equivalent to appointing Cohen as his agent. Numerous <i>Poskim</i> have construed a broker as a <i>shaliach</i>, either due to the services he provides,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, supra n. 22; <i>PDR</i>, supra n. 6; <i>Sefer Meishiv be-Halakha</i>, 138–140, 170.</i> or because he is employed by the <i>Nitva</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tarshish Shoham</i>, <i>YD</i> 34; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Shick</i> 157.</i> To put it differently, Cohen’s responsibilities are defined not only by <i>hilkhot nezikin</i> and <i>shemira</i> but also by <i>hilkhot shelihut</i> and <i>sekhirut po’alim</i>. As a <i>shaliach</i>, the broker is to manage the account in his client’s best interests. If the broker undermines his client’s best interests, such as by failing to address potential loss of investment, the client can raise an objection,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 85a, 99b.</i> “<i>le-tikunei shedartikh ve-lo le-avutei</i>,” i.e., “You were commissioned to act for my benefit, not to my detriment!”
The question that remains is whether the <i>Nitva</i> or Cohen is liable to pay for the losses. There is a proscription against damaging another person’s property.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The nature of the <i>issur</i> is subject to debate. See <i>Yad Rama</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 26a; <i>R. Tam</i>, <i>Sefer ha-Yashar</i> 522; <i>Rabbeinu Yona</i>, <i>Masekhet Avot</i> 1:1; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 108:10; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 378; R. Yosef Trani, <i>Kiryat Sefer</i>, <i>Shekhenim</i> 9; Zalman N. Goldberg, 1 <i>ha-Yashar ve-Hatov</i> 5 (5766).</i> In addressing the case of a <i>shomer</i>, Rambam writes, “Anyone who acts negligently is a <i>mazik</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sekhirut</i> 2:3</i>
The moment that a person obligates himself to be a <i>shomer</i>, in acting negligently he becomes a <i>mazik</i>, even in situations of <i>grama</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Revid ha-Zahav</i> 42.</i>
Consequently, once the <i>issur</i> of causing damage occurs, the <i>mazik</i> must pay for losses caused even indirectly. As we have demonstrated, Cohen is liable for damages due to the harm that he perpetrated. In effect, Cohen’s inaction caused damage, and although it may have been indirect,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n.15.</i> since the damage involved violation of an <i>issur</i>, at first glance, one would conclude that Cohen is responsible for his conduct. But as a <i>po’eil</i>, his behavior is merely an extension of the work of the employer, “<i>yad po’eil ke-yad ba’al ha-bayit</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 10a; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 105:1; <i>Ohr Sameach</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sekhirut</i> 9:11; <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sheluhin ve-Shutafin</i> 11.</i> And although we generally invoke the rule that “one cannot be an agent for a prohibited act,” and therefore one would conclude that the employer (<i>meshaleiach</i>) ought to be exempt from responsibility, here, the status of the broker as a <i>po’eil</i> trumps his status as a <i>shaliach</i>, and therefore <i>Nitva</i> ought to be responsible.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, supra n. 43, as understood by <i>Teshuvot Sh’oeil u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 2:110; <i>PDR</i> 16:205, 208 in the name of <i>Imrei Tzvi</i>.</i> However, most authorities contend that the rule “one cannot be an agent for a prohibited act” applies to a <i>po’eil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mahrit Algazi le-Hilkhot Bekhorot le-Ramban</i> 4:50; <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i> 182:1; <i>Teshuvot Shivat Tzion</i> 53; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 1:20.</i> and therefore, given that Cohen committed an <i>issur</i> by harming the <i>Tove’a</i>’s assets, he is responsible.
<b>4. The Scope of the Monetary Award</b>
Reuven, a landlord, leases his house to Shimon contingent upon Shimon taking out fire insurance. Shimon fails to insure the property and the house burns down. Since Shimon agreed to assume the responsibility of a <i>shomer</i> by dint of agreeing to take out insurance, R. Hayyim Segelovich concludes that Shimon acted negligently and therefore Reuven is entitled to full compensation for his home.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mekor Hayyim</i> 22.</i> Other authorities have concurred with his view.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Lehem Rav</i> 183; <i>Teshuvot Shnei ha-Meorot ha-Gedolim</i> 12; <i>Teshuvot Torat Emet</i> 108; <i>Maharshakh</i>, supra n. 33; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 333:3.</i> Analogously in our case, Cohen, by virtue of the fact that he is a <i>shomer</i> and <i>shaliach</i>, is obligated to fully compensate the <i>Tove’a</i> for his losses.
<b>5. A <i>Beit Din</i> Award and an Insurance Award – “Double Dipping”</b>
Based upon the foregoing, <i>Tove’a</i> is entitled to receive full compensation for his losses. Given that <i>Tove’a</i> may proceed against the insurance company that protects Cohen’s professional activity as a broker, Cohen argues that he has no right to “double dip,” should he recover monetary damages from the insurance company. Consequently, any <i>beit din</i> award should be contingent on the fact that <i>Tove’a</i> fails to recover monetary damages from the insurance company.
Addressing the case of a tenant who assumed liability for a loss due to fire, and subsequently, the landlord bought fire insurance, Ohr Sameach rules that even though the insurance company will reimburse the landlord for the loss, nevertheless, the tenant still remains bound to pay the landlord for the identical loss.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sekhirut</i> 6:7.</i> Since the tenant assumed an unconditional obligation to pay for fire damage, the tenant must pay the landlord even if the landlord will not suffer a loss (due to insurance compensation). Most authorities subscribe to this position of double indemnity.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 4:7; <i>Teshuvot Helkat Yo’av</i> 2:50; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meshiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i> 3:129; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 21:58; <i>Teshuvot Mishneh Halakhot</i> 2:10.</i> Consequently, as long as the insurance company allows the landlord to benefit from double compensation, such benefit will be halakhically valid. Similarly, in our case, as long as the terms of the insurance policy will allow for <i>Tove’a</i> to recoup his losses twice, Halakha will validate both the <i>beit din</i> award and insurance award.
<b>Decision</b>
1. Menahem Cohen is hereby obligated to pay <i>Tove’a</i> $300,000.
2. <i>Tove’a</i> is permitted to file suit in court against the insurance company.
3. All other claims and applications are hereby denied.

b) Piercing the Corporate Veil

<b>B. Piercing the Corporate Veil</b>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Century Affiliates vs. Rabinowitz Properties</i></span>
On February 1, 2011, the above parties signed an arbitration agreement empowering this panel to resolve their dispute according to applicable portions of Shulhan Arukh and <i>Poskim</i>. Both parties submitted their disputes in reference to various claims advanced by Century Affiliates (hereafter: <i>Tove’a</i>) against Mr. Dine of Rabinowitz Properties of Bethesda, Maryland (hereafter: <i>Nitva</i>).
<b>Facts</b>
Pursuant to a contract, dated July 1, 2010, <i>Tove’a</i> was represented by Levi Fried and <i>Nitva</i> was represented by Moshe Dine. According to the agreement, <i>Tove’a</i> performed certain environmental protection work on behalf of the <i>Nitva</i>. Nine months after the work was completed, some outstanding invoices remained unpaid. At the time, Mr. Dine was the CEO of Rabinowitz Properties, a corporate business whose partners, directors, and mangers were Jewish, and <i>Nitva</i> held the controlling interest in this business entity.
<b><i>Tove’a</i>’s Claims</b>
The <i>Tove’a</i> argues that it was his understanding, based upon the trust relationship developed over years in business dealings with <i>Nitva</i>, that if Rabinowitz Properties would fail to pay the outstanding debt, Dine would serve as a guarantor and personally pay it. In fact, the <i>Nitva</i> said to the <i>Tove’a</i>, “You need not worry. Our assets are secure.”
<b><i>Nitva</i>’s Reply</b>
Given that <i>Nitva</i>, as CEO of Rabinowitz Properties, acted at all times as a representative of the corporation, <i>Nitva</i> argues that, in accordance with the accepted doctrine of the limited liability rule, he is not personally liable to pay a corporate debt. All of the <i>Tove’a</i>’s invoices were paid from corporate accounts rather than from <i>Nitva</i>’s personal financial accounts. Moreover, <i>Nitva</i> claims that at no time did he communicate to <i>Tove’a</i> that he construed these outstanding monies as a personal debt. Though <i>Nitva</i> admits that he communicated to <i>Tove’a</i> that “You need not worry, our assets are secure,” nevertheless <i>Nitva</i> meant that our company assets are now secure and therefore bills will be paid. In fact, <i>Nitva</i> subsequently realized that some of the <i>Tove’a</i>’s work was below industry standards, and as a result, refused to pay the unpaid invoices. To put it differently, <i>Tove’a</i>’s work and <i>Nitva</i>’s interaction with the <i>Tove’a</i> was inextricably linked to corporate past, present, and future rather than connected to <i>Nitva’s</i> “personal piggy bank.”
<b>Discussion</b>
The threshold question is how Halakha views a corporation. Dating back to the English case <i>Salomon v. Salomon &amp; Co.</i> (1897), common law views a corporation as an artificial person. It is a legal fiction recognized by civil law.
As explained,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Menachem Elon ed., <i>The Principles of Jewish Law</i>, Yerushalayim, 1975, 160.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Legal person [is] a body of men or of property which the law, in imitation of the personality of human beings, treats artificially as subject of rights and duties … The classic example of a legal person is the corporation … The corporation has usually … the following characteristics: a name common to the aggregate of its component individuals … ; a life independent of the lives of its components; the possession of privileges or rights, liabilities or duties, which do not inhere in its membership as individuals …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Jewish law did not recognize the type of ownership implied in the idea of a corporation. Common ownership is ordinarily expressed in terms of partnership [<i>shutafut</i>] … The salient differences whereby partnership may be distinguished from the corporation are: the continued existence of the partnership is dependent upon the lives of the partners; the rights, liabilities and duties associated with a partnership inhere almost directly in the individuals members of the association …</span>
<b>1. The Nature of a Corporation: <i>Tzibur</i> v. <i>Shutafut</i></b>
Consequently, it is unsurprising to find that most authorities view the corporation as a <i>shutafut</i>, i.e., a joint effort of partners.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Shoeil u-Meishiv</i>, vol. 1, 3:31; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Schick</i>, <i>YD</i> 158; <i>Teshuvot ha-Elef Lekha Shlomo</i>, <i>OH</i> 238; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 3:1, 7:26; <i>Mishneh Halakhot</i> 6:277, <i>Teshuvot Maharshag</i>, <i>YD</i> 3; <i>Pnei Mavin</i>, <i>YD</i> 119; <i>Teshuvot Melamed le-Hoeil</i>, vol. 1, <i>OH</i> 91, vol. 2, <i>YD</i> 3, 9; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 1:20; <i>Minhat Elozor</i> 2:22; <i>Minhat Petim</i>, <i>YD</i> 160; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 189; <i>Teshuvot Har Tzvi</i>, <i>YD</i> 126; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Shlomo</i> 28; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>OH</i> 1:90, 4:54.</i>
However, a minority of authorities construed the corporation as an independent entity. To buttress their conclusion that the corporation is an artificial person, authorities look for parallels of associations dating back to the time of the Mishnah and Talmud that are construed as independent entities. For example, municipal governments known as “<i>bnei ha-ir</i>” were empowered to address the political, economic, social, and educational matters of the local Jewish community.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 11:23; <i>Bava Batra</i> 8b.</i> The authoritative governing body of this corporate body was the “<i>shiva tovei ha-ir</i>,” i.e., the seven notables of the city who were elected by the local citizenry. For numerous authorities, this panel was viewed as being an independent body with a life of its own, untrammeled by the <i>halakhot</i> that are applicable to private individuals. For instance, in contradistinction to a private agreement, a <i>kinyan</i> (symbolic act of undertaking an obligation) is not required in order to impart validity to a public agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 6:19, 21; <i>Mordekhai Bava Metzia</i> 457–458; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 204:8–9.<br>Nonetheless, if the promise was given without authorization, the promise is unenforceable. For example, if the promise was given without prior approval of the majority of the seven elders or undermined the welfare of the community, the promise is null and void. See <i>Teshuvot Rashbash</i> 666; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>HM</i> 61; <i>PDR</i> 6:166, 173.</i> Therefore, if the municipal body makes a promise, the body is duty-bound to comply with it, even though it is not legally enforceable in a <i>beit din</i>.
A few decades ago, this notion of the <i>tzibur</i>, i.e., the community, was extended beyond the confines of the seven elders of the city to encompass political agreements of political parties in a democratic state. In a case brought to an Israeli <i>beit din</i>, three political parties were running for election for a municipal council under a joint list. The parties executed a written agreement that if only two of the first three candidates were elected, the second would withdraw in favor of the third. As expected, only two were elected, but the second candidate refused to resign. Among the arguments advanced by the plaintiff in <i>beit din</i> was that no proper <i>kinyan</i> was performed, and consequently, the written agreement had no validity. The <i>beit din</i>’s reply was that:<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i>, supra n. 4, at 181. This conclusion is contingent upon the fact that the public promise obligates both parties. However, should the recipient of the promise fail to be obligated, the public may retract its promise. See <i>Teshuvot Be’er Yitzhak</i>, <i>YD</i> 3.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Communal leaders … should not advance the claim that they don’t have to comply with the duties they agreed to because they are not legally binding. Words and promises, in particular those regarding the public, are matters of holiness … The public may not break its pledges …</span>
Pursuant to some <i>Aharonim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Helkat Ya’akov</i> 3:190; <i>Teshuvot Tzofnat Paneach</i> 184; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> (Ettinger) 2:54, 124; <i>Yad Shaul</i>, 47; <i>Teshuvot Zera Avraham</i> (Zemba) 4:21–24.</i> given that Halakha views the <i>tzibur</i> as an independent entity, we similarly ought to recognize a corporation as a separate entity. Just as the public association is governed by its own rules, similarly corporate life has its own practices.
<b>2. The Limited Liability Rule</b>
Regardless of how one construes a corporation as a partnership or as an artificial person, everyone agrees that Halakha validates the limited liability rule. Pursuant to this doctrine, shareholders are immune from liability for corporate torts and debts beyond their investments in the corporation’s stock.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Frank Easterbrook &amp; Daniel Fischel, <i>The Economic Structure of Corporate Law</i> 40 (1991).</i> Even those <i>Poskim</i> who construe a corporation as a general partnership, and as such personally obligate each and every employee for an ensuing liability, they nevertheless invoke the limited liability rule. In other words, despite the fact that a corporation is viewed as a <i>shutafut</i>, generally speaking, directors, officers and shareholders of a corporation are not personally liable for the financial obligations of the corporation. Moreover, even R. Yeshayahu Bloi, who argues that every shareholder is an owner of the corporation because his investment may result in profit or loss,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Brit Yehuda</i> 2, n. 59. Implicit in R. Bloi’s position is that incurring a profit or loss regarding an investment is an indicator of ownership. In other words, should the corporation incur losses, either the corporate profits will be divided among the shareholders, and they will receive less because of the losses; or, should corporate dissolution occur, the shareholders will receive less money than they invested.<br>Whether from a secular legal perspective stock ownership is in fact a species of private property is subject to debate. See Milton Friedman, “The Social Responsibility of Business is to Increase Its Profits,” <i>NY Times</i>, September 13, 1970 (Magazine section); Melvin Eisenberg, “The Conception that the Corporation is a Nexus of Contracts and the Dual Nature of the Firm,” 24 J<i>. Corporate Law</i>, 819, 825 (1999); Ronald Green, “Shareholders as Stakeholders,” 50 <i>Washington</i> and Lee L. Rev. 1409, 1413–1416 (1993); Stephen Bainbridge, <i>Director Primacy: The Means and Ends of Corporate Governance</i>, UCLA School of Law Research Paper No. 02-06.</i> nevertheless admits that barring certain extenuating circumstances, each and every shareholder is shielded by the limited liability rule.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 8.</i>
Various reasons are advanced for recognizing this rule. In monetary matters, “<i>matneh al ma she-katuv batorah, tena’o kayam</i>,” i.e., one can stipulate contrary to what is written in the Torah and establish his own agreements and <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, i.e., commercial custom, or “<i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>,” i.e., the law of the kingship is the law, imparts validity to limiting liability.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Halakhot</i>, supra n. 2; E. Batzri, <i>Dinei Mamonot</i>, vol. 2, 315; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Halva’ah</i> 7:17, <i>Shutafut</i> 1:33; <i>Brit Yehuda</i> 7:25–26; <i>Moadim u-Zmanim</i> 3:269; <i>PDR</i> 6:322, 10:278.</i>
Despite the fact that upon forming a corporation, no individuals or group of individuals sits down and explicitly agrees among themselves to comply with this rule, nevertheless in the words of R. Ezra Batzri, a retired Israeli <i>dayan</i> states,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Dinei Mamonot</i>, supra n. 10; <i>PDR</i> 19:9, 16. It is a subject of debate whether the lack of personal liability for corporate debt is because the concerned did not accept to pay or because the creditor waived the liability. See <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban Bava Batra</i> 126b; <i>Rashba</i>, <i>Shita Mekubetzet</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 56a.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">In spite of the fact that not every individual is knowledgeable in all the facets of secular law, he accepts their norms … and he can apprise himself of the law before executing an agreement [with the corporation].</span>
Since the corporate member can ascertain what the law states regarding liability, the corporate law has validity by dint of <i>minhag</i>, even if no individuals sought legal advice. This <i>minhag</i> requires compliance not from the members of the corporate entity, but also from third parties who engage in business with the enterprise.
Similarly, the late R. Bloi, <i>dayan</i> of the Edah Haredit Beit Din in Yerushalayim, argues that if the <i>minhag</i> is widespread, there is a presumption that the individual acted in accordance with the <i>minhag</i>, even if he was unfamiliar with it.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Sekhirut</i> 7, n. 17; see ch. 4, section 5.</i>
There is a widespread <i>minhag</i> that the limited liability rule applies to a corporation. Prior to the formation of the corporation, the prospective members of the corporation had the ability to afford themselves of legal consultation for the purpose of ascertaining the import of the limited liability rule. Consequently, the limited liability rule is operative.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 42:36; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>Hiddushin</i> 71:25; <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 71:3, <i>Urim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 71:10 disagree and argue that a party must know of the <i>minhag</i>. Therefore, even if others know, he is not obligated to follow the <i>minhag</i>. As such, the limited liability rule would only be applicable if the prospective member of the corporation is familiar with the rule.<br>Nonetheless, as R. Gatinyo notes, “The words of the respected early and later authorities demonstrate that they all concur that we follow the local practice … and it is not dependent on whether they know of the existence of the custom.” See <i>Teshuvot Tzel ha-Kesef</i> 33.<br>For the grounds to impute liability based on the fact that one could have afforded himself legal consultation in order to ascertain his responsibilities, see File no. 1-35-8935, Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, <i>Mosdot Plonim v. Kuf &amp; Vav</i>, November 1, 2004.</i>
<b>3. The Limited Liability Rule and <i>Shi’abud Nekhasim</i> without <i>Shi’abud ha-Guf</i> or <i>Apotiki Meforash</i></b>
In fact, two <i>pesakim</i> (decisions) issued by <i>battei din</i> in Eretz Yisrael echo the same approach. In one <i>din torah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 6:315</i> the <i>beit din</i> examined whether managers and workers bear any personal responsibility for corporate debt. In addressing this question, the panel debated whether Halakha recognizes a <i>shi’abud nekhasim</i> (an encumbrance of assets) in a situation such as an outstanding corporate debt, where there exists no <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i> (personal obligation to pay the debt). Unable to decide whether one should subscribe to the view that Reuven can place a lien on his own assets for the sake of Shimon without Reuven having any personal duty to Shimon, the <i>beit din</i> concluded that, based upon <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> and <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>, these corporate employees were exempt from liability. Though this <i>din torah</i> (<i>beit din</i> proceeding) did not address our scenario of a corporate officer who controlled the corporation, the thrust of their reasoning does not indicate the existence of any distinction between a corporate owner and a corporate manager.
Seven years later, another <i>din torah</i> in Eretz Yisrael dealt with a <i>Tove’a</i> who had commissioned the services of a corporation and claimed an outstanding debt.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 10:273, 288–290.</i> The <i>Nitvaim</i> (defendants) argued that the business’s original owners were deceased, and that the <i>Nitvaim</i> had inherited ownership of the company. The question posed to the <i>beit din</i> was whether the heirs should be considered the <i>nitvaim</i>, in which case debt recovery would be difficult, or whether the <i>Nitva</i> was actually the corporation, which is an independent entity and therefore liable. Endorsing the position of Ramban/Rashba,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 8a–b.</i> R. Shlomo Daichovsky, in a minority opinion, concluded that there can be a <i>shi’abud nekhasim</i> without a <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i>, and therefore, the proper address for debt collection is the company rather than its owners.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Though the majority ruled differently, two other <i>dayanim</i> of the panel denied that the heirs had personal liability for the corporate debt. See <i>PDR</i>, supra n. 15, at 292–294.</i> Arguing like Maharshag, Rav Feinstein and an Israeli <i>beit din</i> equally maintain that the debt is grounded in <i>shi’abud nekhasim</i> without <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharshag</i>, <i>YD</i> 3, 5; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>YD</i> 2:63; <i>PDR</i> 6:315.<br>It would be equally effective based on the fact that it is understood as a <i>kinyan situmta</i> (a transfer based on commercial custom), which will be valid according to some <i>Poskim</i> even for assets which are not in existence (<i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i>). See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 13:20; <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 36. Even according to those <i>Poskim</i> who argue that it would be ineffective for future assets (see <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:278; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i> and <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, 201), it would be valid due to the fact that a corporation has the status of a <i>tzibur</i>. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashbash</i> 546; <i>PDR</i> op. cit., at 323. Obviously, such a conclusion presumes that a corporation is a separate entity rather than a <i>shutafut</i>.</i>
Alternatively, R. Yitzhak Weiss, R. Shmuel Wosner, and Machon Lehoro’ah, a <i>beit din</i> in Monsey, New York, contend<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 10:145; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 5, <i>HM</i> 306; <i>Meishiv be-Halakha</i> 97.</i> that responsibility for debt incurred by a corporation is based upon the institution of “<i>apotiki meforash</i>,” i.e., user’s security interest. In other words, corporate management may establish a lien on the company’s assets without imposing any personal liability upon themselves, the shareholders, and employees.
