In effect, a creditor can recover his debt from the designated asset(s).<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 226:1; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 117:6; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 2.</i> The only manner by which a creditor’s right of recovery from the <i>apotiki</i> is extinguished is by paying the debt.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, the invoking of the institution of <i>apotiki meforash</i> to justify the limited liability rule has its limitations. For example, according to <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 15b, s.v. “<i>ho</i>,” <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i> 15b, <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i> and <i>Ritva</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 16b, the creditor can recover <i>shevach</i> (accrued profits) of <i>apotiki meforash</i> above his actual debt. Clearly, in a corporate context, a creditor may recover his debt and nothing more. Other <i>Poskim</i> disagree.<br>Secondly, according to <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 36b and <i>Rashba</i> (<i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:981), <i>shemita</i> (the seventh year which annuls debts) nullifies an <i>apotiki</i>. Again, within the corporate context that would mean that <i>shemitah</i> will extinguish all outstanding corporate debts! However, if one understands the limited liability rule as recognizing that there can be <i>shi’abud nekhasim</i> without <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i>, then <i>shemita</i> does not nullify corporate debts. See <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 67:25. However, see self-contradictory ruling of <i>Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 66:43, that argues that a <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i> remains.<br>Finally, one may argue that invoking the institution of an <i>apotiki meforash</i> to understand the corporate limited liability rule is unfounded. Whereas, concerning the <i>apotiki meforash</i> we are dealing with debtor who has a <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i>, regarding a corporation, the shareholders have no <i>shi’abud ha-guf.</i></i> Moreover, though <i>apotiki meforash</i> may serve to explain the absence of personal liability for corporate employees, it does not exempt them from complying with <i>issurim</i> such as <i>ribbit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 71a, s.v. “<i>ve-yisrael</i>.” The absence of <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i> does not mean that there is no <i>issur</i> of <i>ribbit</i>. See <i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 169:9–10. Contra <i>Teshuvot Maharshag</i>, <i>YD</i> 5.</i>
Without addressing the various reasons for why one is obligated to pay one’s debt,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 86a; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 175a; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 2:610; <i>Sha’arei Yosher</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 5, <i>perek</i> 2.</i> and whether there is a difference whether we construe corporate debt liability as based on <i>shi’abud nekhasim</i> without <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i> or as an <i>apotiki meforash</i>, it is clear that shareholders and/or members of a corporation and creditors have implicitly agreed to exempt the former from personal liability.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 117:1.</i>
<b>4. The Scope of the Limited Liability Rule</b>
Even if Halakha allows one to benefit from the limited liability rule, is there a distinction between an individual who owns this business enterprise and one who only invests in it? In other words, will the limited liability rule serve as a shield for an individual who owns and controls a corporation? R. Tzvi Yehuda Ben Ya’akov, a <i>dayan</i> in Tel Aviv, addresses the following question: If a corporate stockholder suddenly becomes an <i>aveil</i> (mourner), given that he is proscribed from working during the days of <i>shiva</i>, is there a prohibition upon the corporation to engage in work during the time of his <i>shiva</i>? In other words, does one identify “his work” as the work of the corporation, or do we view his shares as an investment in the labor of others, and the corporation’s work is not considered “his work”?
Initially, R. Ben Ya’akov draws a distinction between two types of shareholders. If a shareholder simply has an investment in the corporation, then any labor performed during his <i>shiva</i> is construed as the work of others in the corporation. However, if the stockholder has a controlling interest in the corporation, then any work engaged by the corporate network during his <i>aveilut</i> is “his work,” and the corporation should be closed during this period. In effect, the litmus test for determining whether the corporation should remain open is whether the <i>aveil</i> has a controlling interest or merely a shareholder investment. Given that R. Ben Ya’akov admits that a corporation is a separate entity, at the conclusion of the <i>psak din</i>, he leaves the question open.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 1: 39 (10).</i> However, subsequently, in the next volume of his <i>teshuvot</i>, he affirms that a shareholder who is in control of a corporation is to be treated differently.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 2:12 (5).</i> Such a distinction has been endorsed by some <i>Poskim</i> regarding issues relating to <i>hametz</i> and <i>ribbit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> (Ettinger) 2:124; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i> 3, <i>YD</i> 63.</i> In our scenario, given that <i>Nitva</i> had a controlling interest in the company and was in control of the day-to-day operations of Rabinowitz Properties, in accordance with R. Ben Ya’akov’s line of reasoning, possibly he should be personally liable for any outstanding corporate debt.
However, it is our understanding that R. Ben Ya’akov’s <i>teshuva</i> is limited to <i>hilkhot aveilut</i> and does not impact upon the issue of a corporate owner’s personal liability for corporate debt. In other words, there are <i>Poskim</i>, who like R. Ben Ya’akov accept the limited liability rule, and yet with regard to <i>issurim</i> such as <i>ribbit</i> and <i>hametz</i>, rule that one must refrain from loaning money to a corporation without a <i>heter iska</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">A business partnership structured such that <i>hilkhot ribbit</i> are not violated.</i> and that an individual cannot buy shares in a Jewish-owned corporation that transgresses Shabbat. The same conclusion ought to apply regarding the <i>issur</i> of engaging work during one’s <i>aveilut</i>.
As R. Menashe Klein states,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mishneh Halakhot</i> 6:277 (p. 171).</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Clearly it is prohibited to lend with interest to a corporation due to the fact that in actuality it is a partnership, akin to any partnership … with the <i>tenai</i> (stipulation) that the corporation is exempt from any <i>shi’budei ha-guf</i> (personal encumbrances) … if the corporation sustains a loss … But this does not remove the owners from their ownership rights … and if they borrow money with interest, it is their monies which were borrowed …</span>
In short, according to R. Klein and others,<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Dinei Mamonot</i> vol. 1, 182; 2, 319–320.</i> the corporate hierarchy, namely the owner, and for that matter every shareholder, officer, and manager, are required to comply with <i>issurim</i> such as <i>ribbit</i>, yet at the same time they are shielded from personal liability for corporate debt based upon the limited liability rule. In short, the recognition of the limited liability rule protects the corporate hierarchy from incurring personal debt, but will not shield them from individual responsibility for compliance with <i>issurim</i> such as <i>ribbit</i>, <i>shemirat shabbat</i>, and the like.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">One would assume that those <i>Poskim</i> who recognize the corporation as an artificial person would argue that the corporation is not a lender, and therefore <i>hilkhot ribbit</i> and/or <i>chametz</i> are inapplicable (see <i>Tzofnat Paneach</i>, supra n. 6; <i>Yad Shaul</i>, supra n. 6; possibly <i>Teshuvot Maharam Schick</i>, <i>YD</i> 158), and those <i>Poskim</i> who recognize it as a <i>shutafut</i> would contend that a corporation is like any lender and therefore <i>hilkhot ribbit</i> are applicable (see <i>Teshuvot Melamaid le-Hoeil</i> 1, <i>OH</i> 9; <i>Teshuvot Har Tzvi</i>, <i>YD</i> 126). But that is not necessarily the case. For example, there are authorities who would construe the corporation as an artificial person and yet <i>hilkhot ribbit</i> would be applicable. See <i>Mahari ha-Levi</i>, supra n. 6.<br>However, the common denominator of the authorities is that corporate debt is to be paid by the corporation rather than by the shareholder. Yet, we must note the problematic opinion of one authority that a shareholder who is a lender may recover outstanding corporate debt from the corporate managers. See <i>Moadim u-Zemanim</i>, supra n. 10, at n. 1.</i> As R. Shternbuch exclaims,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Moadim u-Zemanim</i>, supra n. 10.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If the limited liability rule would mean that ownership is totally nullified from the shareholders … then each husband would establish a corporation with his wife or family members … and we would say from henceforth, his food does not belong to him but to the corporation, and one would be able to keep <i>hametz</i> in one’s home during Pesach … and one would be exempt from affixing a <i>mezuza</i> to his doorpost and keeping Shabbat … !</span>
Though regarding <i>hilkhot aveilut</i>, an individual with a controlling interest in a corporation will define corporate work as “his work” during <i>shiva</i>, nonetheless, such a determination will not mean that this officer is personally responsible for outstanding corporate debt.
Clearly, had <i>Nitva</i> verbally agreed to personally guarantee the outstanding invoices, such an agreement would have been binding.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah cited in <i>Bava Batra</i> 175b.</i> Assuming the <i>Tove’a</i> can demonstrate that he had personally agreed to guarantee payment of the outstanding debt, i.e., <i>arevut</i>, the <i>Nitva</i> would be obligated to pay personally.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 129:2; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 129:8. According to others, this <i>arevut</i> (guarantee) is contingent upon the debtor stating, “I am relying upon you.” See <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 129:7; <i>Teshuvot Shoeil u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura</i> 4, 1:45; <i>Teshuvot Maharash Engel</i> 7:102; <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i> 142.</i> Just as the corporate veil does not shield an individual from the need to abstain from engaging in <i>issurim</i> such as refraining from violating the interdicts against <i>ribbit</i> and <i>hametz</i>, similarly, one must be trustworthy in one’s business commitments. And, should a corporate employee knowingly accept a certain corporate obligation as his own personal duty, he becomes personally liable. Following in the footsteps of R. Yitzhak Weiss and R. Shmuel Wosner,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">See text accompanying n. 19.</i> R. Shlomo Amar, Eretz Yisrael’s former chief rabbi rules,<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Shlomo Amar, “Obligations and Responsibilities of Directors of Financial Institutions” (Hebrew), 33 <i>Tehumin</i> 15, 24 (5773). See also <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, 65–110.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">… Even though practically speaking, a corporation is like an “<i>apotiki m’forash</i>,” and the owners are not personally liable, rather the corporate assets [are the asset-based liability], nevertheless, the director, who is hired as a professional … and is paid in accordance with his expertise, clearly must act responsibly and refrain from being negligent in his work, and any negligence … is construed as <i>peshiah</i> [halakhic negligence], … and an employee is liable at least like a bailee …</span>
However, in our scenario, contrary to <i>Tove’a</i>’s allegations, such a relationship had never materialized, generating negligent conduct on the part of the <i>Nitva</i>. The communication of the <i>Nitva</i>’s message, “You need not worry, our assets are secure,” can easily be interpreted as meaning that the corporate assets are secure and payment will be forthcoming. Possibly, this promise did not envision any future corporate inability to satisfy the debt.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari Weil</i> 80.</i> In fact, if such an exchange would have occurred between two individuals in a private or non-corporate business setting, such an interpretation would be plausible, and one would have to prove that the <i>Nitva</i> was in actuality undertaking to be a guarantor in order to extract money from him.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 131:6.</i> Had our scenario been one in which the corporate entity eventually filed for bankruptcy and failed to satisfy the debt, and the financial condition of the company was known to <i>Nitva</i>, he would have been personally liable for damages as a <i>mazik</i>, i.e., a tortfeasor committing negligent misrepresentation, regardless if the corporation is halakhically construed as an independent entity or as partnership.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 129, 7; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 7–8; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 129:2; <i>Divrei Geonim</i> 78:14; <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i> 9:419, 421.</i> On the other hand, if <i>Nitva</i> were unaware of the pending financial debacle, he would not be personally liable.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 19:9, 20.</i> However, the circumstances surrounding our case did not transpire within the context of any corporate bankruptcy. As such, <i>Nitva</i> is personally exempt from compensating the <i>Tove’a</i>.
In our case, both Fried and Dine signed off on the contract and riders executed between their respective LLCs. In effect, the contract and riders of two corporate enterprises and their signatures accompanied by a contract memorialization of their respective roles as President and Vice President conveys to us that both <i>Tove’a</i> and <i>Nitva</i> are implicitly accepting the limited liability rule.
<b>5. Piercing the Corporate Veil</b>
One of the advantages of incorporating a business is liability protection. As noted, forming a corporation creates what is called a “corporate veil,” a division been the business entity and the personal assets of the shareholders, officers, and directors of a corporation. If challenged in a lawsuit, IRS action, or other action, the veil of liability protection may be pierced and these individuals may be held personally liable for its debts.
Pursuant to section 19 of the rider of the AIA document executed by the parties, the choice of law provision is the law of Maryland in resolving all matters with Rabinowitz Properties. Though the parties to this <i>beit din</i> (arbitration) proceeding have not expressed whether this matter ought to be resolved according to Hoshen Mishpat or Maryland law, we have chosen to resolve this matter of “piercing the veil” both according to Halakha and Maryland law.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Secondly, even in the absence of this choice of law provision, as we noted in the text accompanying n. 10, one of the justifications for accepting the limited liability rule is “<i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>”. Consequently, we are addressing our case based on civil law as well as <i>Hoshen Mishpat</i>.<br>Piercing the corporate veil entails holding an individual such as a shareholder personally liable, whereas enterprise liability offers a mechanism for holding the entire corporation liable. For this distinction, see <i>Walkovsky v. Carlton</i>, 223 N.E. 2d 6 (NY 1966).</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>A. Halakha</i></span>
As we noted, a corporate officer, like any corporate employee, must refrain from transgressing certain <i>issurim</i> such as <i>ribbit</i> and Shabbat. Yet, simultaneously, he is protected by the limited liability rule, and therefore is exempt from personal liability for any outstanding corporate debt. However, should the controlling interest of a corporation reside with one individual, as is our case, the possibility exists that the corporation has either been established or functions as a mere tool or business conduit for the benefit of that individual. Should the major stockholder and one who is in control siphon off corporate assets by failing to report income, failing to comply with corporate formalities, and the like, such actions label him as a <i>gazlan</i> (thief),<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Halakhot</i>, supra n. 29.</i> and he would be personally liable for the corporate debt.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Clearly, other employees of the corporate who would siphon assets and fail to comply with certain corporate rules such as reporting income would equally be personally liable for corporate debt. See supra n. 29.</i>
As a <i>beit din</i> in Yerushalayim rules,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">File No. 379/63, <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i> 9:419, 421.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">In certain instances we attribute the duties and rights of the corporation to the shareholders … One of the situations is if the corporate owner uses the corporation to commit fraud or do an injustice to another individual. In such an instance, we can obligate the owner personally… . and this is like any <i>tenai</i> [stipulation] in monetary affairs, in which we follow the stipulation. This applies when the original intention of the owner was to exploit the corporation. However, if this was not his initial intention, but nevertheless, “down the line,” the assets were not collectible, one cannot collect from the personal assets of the shareholders of the corporation.</span>
As R. Wosner argues, if a corporate officer with a controlling interest dissipates the corporate accounts and funnels the funds into his own account, the corporate shield is lifted and he is personally liable for corporate debts.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i>, vol. 8, <i>HM</i> 306. In the event that there was negligence such as misrepresentation, the shareholders are personally liable for any monetary harm. See <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 10:133.</i>
To put it differently, some of the relevant halakhic<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Whether a particular factor may be legally relevant will vary from one state jurisdiction to another.</i> factors for a <i>beit din</i>’s determination to pierce the corporate veil are as follows<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">A scrutiny of all the facts relating to the affairs of the corporate entity based upon document production and testimony would be required prior to a determination of fraud.</i>: (1) Commingling of corporate funds and other assets with personal financial instruments; (2) An individual’s treatment of the corporation’s assets as his own; (3) An individual holding out that he is personally liable for the corporate debt; (4) Failure to report corporate income; (5) Concealment and misrepresentation of the identity of the corporate ownership and management; (6) Use of the corporate entity to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; (7) Use of a corporation as a subterfuge for illegal transactions; (8) <i>Nitva</i>’s control of the corporation is so complete as to constitute control of policy and finances. Such domination is then used to commit fraud, and the contravention of the duty owed to <i>Tove’a</i> caused injury.
In our scenario, none of the above factors were even raised as ground(s) to pierce the corporate veil, much less proven.
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>B. Maryland Law</i></span>
The grounds for “piercing the veil” may vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. Given the aforementioned provision in the agreement, we will address how courts in Maryland dealt with this matter.
Despite the proclamation that a court may pierce the corporate veil to enforce an equity consideration, arguments that have urged corporate piercing for reasons other than fraud or a necessity to enforce a paramount equity (which has not been defined) have failed in Maryland courts.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Our presentation of Maryland law in part has benefited from the work of John Moye, <i>The Law of Business Organizations</i>, 6th ed., 180–192. See <i>Residential Warranty v. Bancroft Homes Greenspring Valley, Inc.</i> 126 Md. App. Ct. at 307, 728 A. 2d at 789 (1999); <i>Antonio v. Security Services of America</i>, <i>LLC, et al</i>. US District LEXIS 72148 (D. Md. July 16, 2010).</i> In <i>Travel Committee, Inc. v. Pan American World Airways,</i>
Inc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">91 Md. App. 123, 138, 603 A. 2d 1301 (1992).</i> the Court cited a Fourth Circuit South Carolina opinion in <i>DeWitt Track Brokers v. W. Ray Flemming Fruit Co.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">540 F. 2d 681, 685 (4th Circ. 1976).</i> which states:
<span class="poetry indentAll">… When substantial ownership of all the stock of a corporation in a single is combined with other factors clearly supporting disregard of the corporate fiction on the grounds of equity and fairness, courts have experienced “little difficulty” and have shown no hesitancy in applying what is described as the “alter ego” or “instrumentality” theory in order to cast aside the corporate shield and to fasten liability on the individual stockholder.</span>
Invoking the “alter ego theory” which allows one to disregard the corporate fiction where a corporation either is established or functions as a mere tool or business conduit of another individual, the <i>DeWitt Truck Brokers</i> enumerates the factors which establish that the alter ego exists:
<span class="poetry indentAll">These include: whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, the corporation’s failure to observe corporate formalities, non-payment of dividends, the debtor’s corporation’s insolvency, the dominant stockholder’s siphoning off corporate assets, the non-functioning of other officers or directors, the absence of corporate records and the corporation’s status as a façade for the stockholder’s arguments …</span>
Legally, the reasoning is sound. Moreover, this reasoning has been applied in other American courts. But it is only that: a <i>persuasive</i> opinion. It has no binding effect on any of the Maryland courts, because it was applying the law of South Carolina. In fact, Maryland courts have adopted a restrictive approach to corporate veil piercing and limited it to instances of fraud. In fact, in various holdings, the court ruled that even if a sham corporation were set up for the sole purpose of evading legal obligations, no piercing would be permitted.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bart Arconti &amp; Sons, Inc. v. Ames-Ennis, Inc.</i>, 275 Md. at 309, 340 A. 2d, at 233–234 (1976); <i>Dixon vs. Process Corp.</i>, 38 Md. App. at 655, 382 A. 2d at 900 (1978).</i> Based upon the foregoing presentation of Maryland law, there is no basis for invoking the alter ego doctrine.
Even if one would argue that enforcing “a paramount equity,” i.e., the application of the alter ego theory, serves as another reason to pierce the corporate veil, in our instance, based upon the cumulative evidence submitted to this panel, no proof was shown that provided sufficient grounds for disregarding the corporate entity.
In sum, pursuant to both Halakha and Maryland law, in the absence of a demonstration of fraud, a claim for recovery of corporate debt from a corporate officer is without foundation. Based upon the cumulative evidence submitted to this panel, there was demonstration of fraud. In effect, <i>Nitva</i>, while serving as CEO of Rabinowitz Properties, was protected under the limited liability rule.
In short, <i>Tove’a</i>’s discovery attempt to uncover improper behavior such as fraud or total disregard of the corporate entity to satisfy <i>Nitva</i>’s personal agenda in order to impute <i>Nitva</i>’s personal liability lacks foundation.
<b>Decision</b>
1. <i>Nitva</i> is hereby exempt from personal liability for any corporate debts incurred by Rabinowitz Properties.
2. All other claims and applications are hereby denied.
3. Any provision of this decision may be modified with the consent of both parties.

c) Non Compete Agreements

<b>C. Non-Compete Agreements</b><sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">A non-compete agreement or what is sometimes called a restrictive covenant is a contract in which a party agrees to be restricted in some regards as to future conduct.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Moshe Peking vs. Aaron Levy</i></span>
On February 1, 2009, the above parties signed an arbitration agreement empowering this panel to resolve this matter according to applicable portions of Shulhan Arukh and <i>Poskim</i>. Both parties submitted to this <i>beit din</i> their differences and disputes in reference to various claims advanced by Aaron Friedman, the owner of Moshe Peking (hereafter: <i>Tove’a</i>) against Ilan Assaf (hereafter: <i>Nitva</i>). Having given said matters due consideration and having heard all parties testify as to the facts of said disputes and differences; this panel does decide and agree as follows:
<b>Facts</b>
From May 1995 through April 2003, Ilan Assaf was employed as a chef by Aaron Friedman of Moshe Peking, which was located in the orthodox Jewish commercial neighborhood in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Among the terms of the restrictive covenant agreement signed by the parties at the commencement of <i>Nitva</i>’s employment were the following:
1. Employee acknowledges that it is essential to the success of the Employer that the business and the affairs of the Employer be kept in the strictest confidence. Employee shall not at any time disclose to any person any information (financial or otherwise) relating … to the business or relating to any trade secrets of the Employer, including without limiting the generality of the foregoing, customer lists, information relating to costs, information relating to present and contemplated services and products such as menus, recipes, dish presentations etc … Should the employee decide to resign his employment or should he be terminated the aforesaid information remains the proprietary information of the former employer.
2. Employee hereby covenants and agrees that he shall not for a period of five (5) years following departure from Employer’s employ, directly or indirectly, in any manner whatsoever including, without limitation, or in partnership or jointly or in conjunction with any person, as agent or shareholder, or in any other capacity such as independently carry on or be engaged in such a business in the Orthodox Jewish commercial neighborhood of Milwaukee, Wisconsin.
3. In the event that a court of competent jurisdiction finds any restrictive covenant contained in this Agreement to be unenforceable in whole or in part, including without limitation as to duration and/or territory, the parties hereby direct the court to reduce the scope of such provision to that which is reasonable in the circumstances.
4. Any disputes and differences regarding this Agreement shall be resolved by Beit Din Tzedek, Milwaukee, Wisconsin.
In effect, the parties executed two forms of restrictive covenants. In accordance with section one, there is a non-disclosure agreement which prohibits the disclosure of the employer’s proprietary information to a third party during the period of his employment as well as prohibiting the employee to disclose said information to others upon his decision to resign from his job or upon termination. And, in pursuance with section three, there is a non-compete agreement which restricts the employee from working for a competitor or independently establishing his own business in the same trade.
In April 2003, <i>Nitva</i> left <i>Tove’a</i>’s employ and opened his own restaurant in the same neighborhood. In May 2005, Ayala Friedman, chef-owner of Moshe Peking in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, sued her former chef, Ilan Assaf, now chef and part owner of King David’s Restaurant.
<b><i>Tove’a</i>’s Claims</b>
In his complaint, the <i>Tove’a</i> alleged that the <i>Nitva</i> pirated the <i>Tove’a</i>’s menu, recipes, and dish presentations, and such conduct is a flagrant misappropriation of his intellectual property’s rights. According to <i>Tove’a</i>, the <i>Nitva</i> had copied a novel culinary creation (rather than a recipe for a dish already in existence in the culinary public domain such as fettucine alfredo, marinated skirt steak, chicken breast, or apple strudel), which <i>Tove’a</i> maintained was a signature dish at Moshe Peking. Unlike many dishes such as apple pie, which are not original to a chef, our culinary creation is novel. Since cuisine is frequently copied and imitated in the culinary industry, damages should be awarded due to the piracy. Furthermore, <i>Tove’a</i> alleges that <i>Nitva</i>’s opening of a competitive restaurant in his neighborhood immediately after his departure from Moshe Peking was a breach of the terms of the restrictive covenant agreement. In short, the piracy and the absence of geographical separation and market separation have deprived the <i>Tove’a</i> of a livelihood and are paving the way toward his financial ruin.
<b><i>Nitva</i>’s Claims</b>
<i>Nitva</i> admittedly copied the cuisine and the methods of presentation. In reply to <i>Tove’a</i>’s copyright claim, it is his understanding that neither Halakha nor civil law, for that matter, would afford protection to <i>Tove’a</i>’s business investments. Secondly, though <i>Nitva</i> agrees that he signed off on a restrictive covenant agreement, nevertheless, pursuant to section three of said document, the agreement is contrary to public policy and therefore unenforceable.
<b>Discussion</b>
<b>1. Protecting Cuisine and Dish Preparations under the Rubric of Secular Copyright Law</b>
In addressing the protection of a literary or artistic creation, R. Yosef Nathanson, opines:<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i> 1:44.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Let not our perfect Torah be viewed as not being at least equal to their idle conversation; that is something that reason rejects …</span>
Invoking s<i>evara</i>, i.e., halakhic logic, R. Nathanson asserts that if non-Jewish society’s “idle conversation,” i.e., secular law, provides copyright protection for artistic creations, <i>a fortiori</i> Halakha must do no less.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Whereas, American law and other legal systems limit the span of time for copyright protection, R. Nathanson argued that the right was perpetual and transferable.</i> Subsequently, R. Yitzhak Schmelkes contendes that <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>, i.e., the law of the kingdom is the law, propels Halakha to impart recognition to an individual to publish his manuscript.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>YD</i> 2:75; <i>HM</i> 80. However, unlike R. Nathanson’s view, supra text accompanying n. 1, once the secular copyright protection expires, R. Shmelkes argues that one loses one’s entitlement to the work.</i> A similar view was espoused by R. Shimon Sofer.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hit’orerut Teshuva</i> 1:232.</i>
A recent secular legal presentation of our matter has been described in the following fashion,<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Emily Cunningham, “Protecting Cuisine under the Rubric of Intellectual Property Law: Should the Law Play a Bigger Role in the Kitchen?” 9 <i>J. High Technology Law</i> 22, 24, 26–27 (2009). All footnotes for the text of the citation have been deleted.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The culinary industry generally views cooking as a derivative art. Chefs … draw inspiration from a multitude of places, borrowing and expanding on fellow chefs’ ideas and deriving new dishes from them. Many chefs freely admit that they base their dishes on versions that they have previously seen or eaten …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The scope of the law is set forth in section 102 of the Copyright Act of 1976 and extends to literary, musical, dramatic, choreographic, pictorial, graphic, architectural, and sculptural works …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Derivative works, which originate from a preexisting work and recast, transform or adapt that work, require additional considerations for copyrightability. A derivative work that is primarily a new work but incorporates previously registered material is copyrightable … Factors a court examines when considering whether to grant copyright protection for derivative works include whether the underlying work is the public domain and whether the changes or additions made are merely trivial variations on the underlying work …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Copyright laws traditionally have not protected individual recipes. The US Register of Copyrights notes that “mere listings of ingredients as in recipes, formulas, compounds or prescriptions are not subject to protection [unless] [they are] accompanied by substantial literary expression in the form of an explanation … or when there is a combination of recipes, as in a cookbook.” The rationale for this is that an individual recipe is a process of creating something, rather than a creative literary expression …</span>
Given that the culinary industry and secular law<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Feist Publ’ns, Inc. v. Rural Tel Serv. Co</i>., 499 US 340, 345 (1991); <i>Publ’ns Int’l, Ltd. v. Meredith Corp</i>., 88 F. 3d 473, 480 (7th Cir. 1996); <i>Lambing v. Godiva Chocolatier</i>, 142 F. 3d 434 (6th Cir. 1998); 1 Melville B. Nimmer &amp; David Nimmer, <i>Nimmer on Copyright</i>, Section 2.18 {1} (2005).<br>The law would equally fail to afford the <i>Tove’a</i> trademark protection for the cuisine and dish preparations. For the difference between trademark and copyright protection, as well as concluding that these matters are not a protectable trademark, see Cunningham, supra 5, at 28–32.</i> view cooking as a derivative art, the aforementioned <i>Poskim</i> would conclude that there are no grounds for affording copyright protection to the <i>Tove’a</i>’s cuisine and dish presentations.
However, there are a few authorities who claim that there exists a property right of any expression of wisdom, independent of its recognition by civil law. For example R. Shimon Shkop notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei R. Shimon Shkop</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 1.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It is agreed according to the law of the Torah (and the laws of the nations) that any individual who invents [creates] something new in this world, he is its owner in every respect and right.</span>
In another work, R. Shkop argues that if an employee creates a utensil by “the toil of his hands,”<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei R. Shimon Shkop</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 4.</i> this utensil belongs to the employee by dint of the rule <i>yad po’eil ke-yad ba’al habayit</i>, lit. “the hand of the worker is like the hand of the employer.”<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 10a, s.v. “<i>omar.</i>”</i> He concludes that R. Hayyim Soloveitchik of Brisk also espouses this view. Rabbis Naftali Tzvi Berlin, Hayyim Sofer, Elyashiv, Y. Weiss, and Feinstein, have also subscribed to this position.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Meishiv Davar</i>, <i>OH</i> 24; <i>Teshuvot Mahane Hayyim</i> 2, <i>HM</i> 49; Nachum Weisfish, <i>Mishnat Zekhuyot ha-Yotzer</i> (Hebrew), (2002) 115 in the name of R. Elyashiv; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 9:153; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>OH</i> 4:40, <i>HM</i> 19.</i> Adopting this approach, in contrast to secular law, Halakha would extend protection to ideas, procedures, processes, methods of operation, etc. As such, a culinary creation would be afforded protection. Even though this is not a creative literary expression, a new dish is nevertheless a new process of creating something and therefore subject to protection.
However, the majority of <i>Poskim</i> reject the notion that Halakha recognizes copyright as a property right.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 10; <i>Teshuvot Sha’arei De’ah</i> 1:145, 148; <i>Teshuvot Parshat Mordekhai</i>, <i>HM</i> 7–8; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>HM</i> 24; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i> 259; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 41, 79; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Schick</i>, <i>YD</i> 156; <i>Teshuvot Yeshu’ot Malko</i>, <i>HM</i> 22; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Yeshayahu</i> 12; <i>Teshuvot Shem Arye</i> 1, <i>HM</i> 20; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 3:157; <i>Ohr Sameach</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Shabbat</i> 1:8; <i>Teshuvot Seridei Eish</i> 3:129; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 4:202; <i>Teshuvot va-Yeshev Moshe</i> 1:1–3, 5; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:202; <i>Teshuvot Pe’at Sadekha</i> 158; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Zvi</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sehanim</i> 18; R. Zalman N. Goldberg, “<i>Ha’ataka mi-Cassette le-lo Reshut ha-Ba’alim</i>” (Hebrew), 6 <i>Tehumin</i> 185 (5755); <i>PDR</i> 21:297; <i>Teshuvot Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 2:14; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Geneivah</i> 9:11.<br>Cf. Rabbis M. Feinstein, Elyashiv, Y. Weiss, and S. Wosner who argue that Halakha recognizes such a right. See supra n. 10 and Y. Cohen, <i>Emek ha-Mishpat</i>, vol. 4, 2.</i> Firstly, the history of <i>haskamot</i>, i.e., rabbinic approbations given prior to the publication of Jewish books, attests to the fact that the prohibitions on republishing the works invoked in these approbations, as well as the grounds advanced by authorities to protect people’s creative investments, were based on rabbinic legislation, trade guild legislation, custom, civil law, unfair completion, and the like, and not on the idea of copyright.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Haskama</i> to <i>Sha’agat Arye</i>, Brin 1796; <i>Parshat Mordekhai</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i>, <i>HM</i> 57. For additional sources, see Nahum Rakover, <i>Zehut Yotzrim be-Mekorot ha-Yehudim</i> (Hebrew), Yerushalayim, 1991.</i>
Though to the best of our knowledge there is no extant <i>teshuva</i> that addresses the alleged privacy of cuisine and dish preparations, nevertheless, based upon the following two <i>teshuvot</i> we are able to discern how Halakha will address these claims. R. Yehezkel Landau, an eighteenth-century <i>Posek</i>, addressed the following scenario: A scholar paid a publisher to print his commentary alongside the text of the Talmud. Upon completion of the printing process, the publisher kept the typeset characters and used them to print his own edition of the Talmud, without the additional commentary. The scholar argued that since he had paid for typesetting those characters, any accrued profits from this edition should belong to him. On the other hand, the publisher claimed that since he owned the typeset characters, the scholar was unable to recoup the profit from the character layout.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Noda be-Yehuda</i>, supra n. 12.</i>
Relying upon the Talmudic rule that if the publisher derives benefit and the scholar sustained a loss (i.e., <i>zeh nehene ve-zeh haser, hayav</i>), R. Landau argued that since the publisher benefited from the scholar’s payment for the character arrangement, the publisher is obligated to remunerate him for the value of the accrued benefit. In other words, the obligation to provide compensation depends on the fact that one derived benefit from someone’s labor (i.e., the character layout) rather than the fact that it was the publisher’s property.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. R. Barukh Frankel-Te’omim, who claims that the characters belonged to the publisher. See <i>Hagahot Barukh Ta’am</i>, <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i> 2:35b.<br>Others argue that the scholar has either a partial-proprietary right or a right in the creation of the typeset arrangement. See <i>Divrei Malkiel</i>, supra n. 12; <i>Yeshuot Malko</i>, supra n. 11. However, our reading of the <i>teshuva</i> does not bear out these conclusions.</i> Though he is obligated to compensate the scholar for his use of the character layout, nevertheless, should the publisher accrue any profits from utilizing this arrangement, R. Landau does not mandate that the publisher disgorge his profits. Turning to our scenario, if Halakha mandates responsibility for unjust appropriation of someone’s time and effort in developing a process (e.g., a typesetting layout), <i>a fortiori</i>, it obligates an award in a case of piracy of a culinary dish.
Approximately a hundred years later, R. Malkiel Tennenbaum, “the Lomza Rov,” responded to the following situation: An individual received a governmental license to sell his newly created product, namely, sweet and fragrant water, and he sold this water with a governmental seal. Should another person sell a similar water composition with such labels, R. Tennebaum contends that it would be a case of unfair competition, and the competitor would be duty-bound to compensate the original seller for any losses incurred by the marketing of this competing product.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Divrei Malkiel</i>, supra n. 12.</i>
In sum, according to R. Tennenbaum and R. Landau, individuals’ creations and discoveries are protected by indigenous categories of <i>hasagat gevul</i> (unfair economic competition) and <i>zeh nehene ve-zeh haser</i> (loosely translated as “unjust enrichment”) rather than any copyright doctrines such as property rights. Similarly, pirating a novel culinary dish conceptually matches R. Tennebaum and R. Landau’s cases, and would therefore find redress on similar grounds.
At first glance, given that the damage was only indirect (<i>grama</i>), and there is a ruling that “one who causes indirect damage is exempt from responsibility” (“<i>grama be-nezikin patur</i>”),<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Kama</i> 60a; <i>Bava Batra</i> 22b.</i> one might assume that <i>Nitva</i> is exempt from compensating the <i>Tove’a</i> for his losses. According to most authorities, an action is considered to be a direct cause of damage (“<i>garmi</i>”) if the damage caused is instantaneous and inevitable (“<i>bari hezeka</i>”), such as one who destroys someone’s note of indebtedness. However, if the damage is not inevitable or instantaneous, the damage is labeled <i>grama</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 22b; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 9:17. Such a conclusion may be inferred from <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i> 140; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 4, <i>HM</i> 3; <i>Teshuvot le-Horot Natan</i> 3:99.</i>
However, it should be noted that there is an authoritative opinion, albeit in variance with the majority view, that there really is no distinguishing characteristic between <i>garmi</i> and <i>grama</i> actions. According to this view, for punitive purposes, i.e., <i>kenas</i>, Hazal classified usual and frequent injuries as <i>garmi</i>, and unusual and infrequent injuries as <i>grama</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 386:3; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 386:10.</i> The underlying reason for attaching responsibility is to deter individuals from harming their fellow men.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">See supra <i>Rema</i>, n. 12; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 386:20.</i> In this view, the ground for responsibility would be that piracy is an act of <i>hezek</i>, i.e,. damage.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Noda be-Yehuda</i>, supra n. 12; <i>Levush Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 15.</i> Alternatively, deriving benefit from someone else’s asset is akin to theft, and therefore one must pay.<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 371:10.</i>
Given that the panel was unfamiliar with the culinary industry, and pursuant to the requirements of secular arbitration law,<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Domke on Commercial Arbitration</i>, 3rd ed., 29:13.</i> the panel hired an independent investigator of the industry in order to ascertain whether cuisine is frequently copied in the culinary industry or whether our case is an isolated incident. Based upon the testimony of the professional expert, as well as the findings in the trade literature,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">See Cunningham, supra n. 6, at 22–24.</i> the <i>beit din</i> concluded that such occurrences are commonplace. As such, pursuant to this position, we awarded <i>Tove’a</i> damages for the unjust enrichment<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The implicit assumption is that <i>zeh nehene ve-zeh haser</i>, wherein one individual benefits and in the process economically harms another, one is obligated to pay, similar to any <i>mazik</i>. See <i>Noda be-Yehuda</i> in the name of <i>Rambam</i>, supra n. 12; <i>Levush Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 15:8–11.</i> and harm incurred by unfair competition.
<b>2. Protecting a Novel Dish as a <i>Tenai</i> of the Non-Disclosure Agreement</b>
One of the terms of the non-compete agreement is the following non-disclosure provision:
<span class="poetry indentAll">Employee acknowledges that it is essential to the success of the Employer that the business and the affairs of the Employer be kept in the strictest confidence. Employee shall not at any time disclose to any person any information (financial or otherwise) relating … to the business or relating to any trade secrets of the Employer, including without limiting the generality of the foregoing, customer lists, information relating to costs, information relating to present and contemplated services and products such as menus, recipes, dish presentations etc …</span>
Should we view the agreement to preempt the <i>Nitva</i>’s use of the cuisine and/or dish preparations as a <i>tenai</i> (i.e., a condition) of any future employment in the industry, such a condition gives rise to the following issues: (1) <i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i> (something which is not yet in existence); (2) <i>davar she-ein bo mamash</i> (something lacking physical property).
Regarding the new food creation, it did not exist at the time of the signing of this agreement. Consequently, though certain recipes and dish preparations were in existence at the commencement of the <i>Nitva</i>’s employment, and are therefore in the category of <i>davar she-ba la-olam</i>, this new dish, which was developed subsequent to the agreement, would be labeled as <i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i>. On the one hand, such a <i>tenai</i> would be effective only regarding items that existed at the time of the signing of the agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 209:12; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 209:8.</i> On the other hand, the condition would be ineffective regarding the recipe that was developed subsequent to the signing of the agreement. This conclusion is contingent upon the fact that the <i>Nitva</i> would own these recipes and dish preparations. Given that at the time of the signing of the agreement, these items were not in existence, <i>Nitva</i> can therefore never assert ownership over them. However, if he <i>obligates</i> himself to refrain from misappropriating these items, then Halakha recognizes this obligation even regarding instances of items that will surface at a future date.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 95:10 in the name of <i>Rema</i>; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:6; <i>Sma</i>, ad locum 18; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 209:4. For the identical reasoning in validating a promissory note, see <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, 246.</i> Therefore, <i>Tove’a</i> is entitled to receive compensation for his loss.
Clearly, a <i>tenai</i> which entails a new dish meets the tangibility requirements<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">See infra text accompanying nn. 29 and 31. This conclusion is predicated upon two facts: that the word “shall” in the agreement is a term of obligation, and that a <i>kinyan</i> was executed. In the absence of either requirement, the agreement would be validated as a <i>kinyan situmta</i> (a commercial form of undertaking an obligation), which is effective regarding something not yet in existence.</i> and therefore is a <i>davar she-yesh bo mamash</i>. As such, the <i>tenai</i> is valid and <i>Tove’a</i> is entitled to receive compensation for his loss.
<b>3. The Validity of Undertaking an Obligation Not to Compete</b>
According to the Halakha of obligations, i.e., <i>hit’hayivut</i>, in order for an agreement to be legally effective, certain language must be utilized in the agreement. For example, the use of language such as “I obligate myself to pay John Doe such and such,” “I undertake to pay … ,” “I am obligated to pay … ,” or “I admit that I am obligated to pay John Doe such and such,” are all terms of undertaking an obligation.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:6; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:13; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:3; <i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 3:173; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 29.</i> The common denominator of these different terms of accepting a commitment is that the person is being <i>meshabed nafshei</i>, i.e., “committing himself” <i>now</i>, by transforming himself into a debtor now. Consequently, a promise to give an object that entails a future action has no legal validity.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 3a; <i>Rashi</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>kinyan devarim hu</i>”; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 1:3; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 245:1.</i>
One of the terms of the non-compete agreement is the following:
<span class="poetry indentAll">Employee hereby covenants and agrees that he shall not for a period of five (5) years following departure from Employer’s employ, directly or indirectly, in any manner whatsoever including, without limitation, or in partnership or jointly or in conjunction with any person, as agent or shareholder, or in any other capacity, carry on or be engaged in such a business in the Orthodox Jewish commercial neighborhood of Milwaukee, Wisconsin.</span>
The aforesaid provision provides that in the future (“shall”) the <i>Nitva</i> will not open up a competitive business for a period of five years. In terms of <i>hilkhot hit’hayivut</i>, such an undertaking fails to be binding for two reasons. Firstly, in the absence of being <i>meshabed nafshei</i> now, one cannot endow a commitment that will occur in the future with halakhic validity. Moreover, one cannot obligate oneself to refrain from engaging in a certain conduct, i.e., to abstain from opening up a competitive business.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 278; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:87, 3:20; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 1:94; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 3:31; <i>Teshuvot Tosafot Re’em</i> (Taubes) 3:4; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 274; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i> 1, <i>HM</i> 31; <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i> 1:582; <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i> 582; <i>Teshuvot Erek Shai</i> 205; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:18; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 1:6; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 209; Zalman N. Goldberg, “The Definition of Religious in a Contract” (Hebrew), 17 <i>Tehumin</i> 181 (5758).<br>Had the agreement stated, “If I open up a competing enterprise, I obligate myself now to pay you,” the <i>Nitva</i> would have been responsible. See <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 114–115; <i>Sma</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:18; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:24; <i>Divrei Hayyim</i>, op. cit.</i> To effectively undertake an obligation, there must be an immediate <i>halot</i>. Namely, for a <i>hit’hayivut</i> (and, for that matter, for a transfer of ownership) to be effective, it must be predicated upon a <i>davar she-yesh bo mamash</i>, i.e., something that is tangible, possessing height, width, and depth.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>R. Hai Gaon</i>, <i>Mekach u-Memkar</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 2; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 22:13. This rule of tangibility applies equally to undertaking obligations such as partnership agreements or employment agreements. See See <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 1, 3; <i>Rashba</i> and <i>Ra’avad</i>, <i>Shita Mekubetzet</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 3a, s.v. “<i>ve-khi</i>.”</i> Obligating oneself to do something or to refrain from doing something are illustrations of a <i>davar she-ein bo mamash</i>. Hence, this agreement’s provision is ineffective in obligating the <i>Nitva</i> to refrain from opening a business.
Nonetheless, given that the (albeit improperly drafted) non-compete agreement was a condition of his employment, we can speak of “a meeting of the minds” regarding the impermissibility to open a competitive enterprise, and therefore the agreement is effective. And, in fact, in accordance with certain authorities,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 9; <i>Teshuvot Perakh Mateh Aharon</i> 1:14.</i> one Israeli <i>beit din</i> validated a non-compete agreement for this reason.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 3:336.</i> Alternatively, since this condition was a clause ensconced in his former employment agreement and in exchange for his agreement to be employed and carry out this condition (as well as others) he received wages, he is obligated to comply with the condition.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mateh Aharon</i>, supra n. 33, at 13–14; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i> vol. 1, <i>HM</i> 2; <i>PDR</i>, supra n. 33, at 344. Cf. others who contend that one cannot contract a salary with an employee that entails abstaining from an action. See <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sehirut</i> 18.</i> Thirdly, should an individual benefit from what another individual gave him in exchange for refraining from acting in a certatin fashion, he is obligated to comply with this <i>tenai</i> (condition).<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 280. In effect, Rivash agrees with other decisors who claim that one can undertake a personal obligation to abstain from certain behavior. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:6; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:18. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, supra n. 33 who concurs with Rivash’s posture, albeit for a different reason.</i> Finally, assuming civil law will recognize the employment of the word “shall” as denoting an obligation, then Halakha will recognize this agreement as a “<i>kinyan situmta</i>” and it is therefore valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 42; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 42:15; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 61:5.</i>
In short, in addition to infractions in the form of unfair competition and unjust enrichment, the <i>Nitva</i>’s piracy of the cuisine and dish presentations were in violation of a <i>tenai</i> memorialized in the non-compete agreement, which proscribed the <i>Nitva</i> from misappropriating the <i>Tove’a</i>’s cuisine and dish arrangements. As such, damages will be awarded.
<b>4. The Application of <i>Hasagat Gevul</i></b>
Even in the absence of a non-compete agreement, we need to examine whether the <i>Nitva</i> is subject to certain restraints based upon the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>hasagat gevul</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">For a contemporary application, see <i>PDR</i> 3:336, 4:200.</i> As Talmud states,<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 21b.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Rabbi Huna said: If a resident of an alley sets up a hand mill and another resident of the alley wants to set up one adjacent to him, the first has the right to stop him, because he can say to him, “You are interfering with my livelihood.”</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Rabbi Huna ben Yehoshua said: It is quite clear to me … that the resident of an alley cannot prevent another resident of the same alley [from establishing a competing enterprise in his alley].”</span>
In the pursuance of R. Huna ben Yehoshua’s view, many <i>Poskim</i> rule in favor of the right of free entry of the competing business.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 156; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 156:5; <i>Teshuvot Beit Ephraim</i>, <i>HM</i> 26–28; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 156:6–7.</i> Though R. Huna’s opinion is rejected, nevertheless, Aviassaf contends that if a business is situated at the end of a closed alley, a competitor cannot open up a business at the beginning or middle of the alley, lest his positioning in the alley will effectively deprive the other person’s source of income and livelihood whose business is situated at the end of the alley.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Aviassaf</i> cited by <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>BB</i> 516.</i> Subsequent to the Aviassaf, numerous decisors, including Rema, argue that a business that encroaches upon an established firm within an urban neighborhood<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 6:90.</i> (and according to certain authorities, within a town<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, supra n. 12.</i>) and engages in ruinous competition violates <i>hilkhot hasagat gevul</i>, i.e., unfair competition.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ri Megash</i> on <i>Bava Batra</i> 21b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 5:3; <i>Rema</i>, supra n. 11 (Cf. <i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur HM</i> 156:4); <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 132; <i>Teshuvot Mas’at Binyamin</i> 27; <i>Teshuvot Radach</i> 27:3; <i>Teshuvot Ginat Veradim</i> 3:20–21; <i>Levushei Mordekhai</i>, <i>HM</i> 13; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i> 1:18, 2, <i>HM</i> 39–40; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 61, 79, 118; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:38, 2:31.</i> In effect, predatory competition is equivalent to setting up a business in an alley that will impede the business venture located at the end of the closed alley. Others contend, pursuant to R. Yosef Karo’s view, regardless of the scope of the encroachment (whether one diminishes another’s profit margins or causes financial ruin), one is permitted to open up a competing enterprise.<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 156:11; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 156:5; <i>Teshuvot Beit Ephraim</i>, <i>HM</i> 26; <i>PDR</i>, supra n. 42.</i>
Contrary to the <i>Tove’a</i>’s assertion that the <i>Nitva</i>’s opening of a business has laid the groundwork for his financial ruin, a review of the <i>Tove’a</i>’s business records<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">For the reliability of such records for corroborating a claim, see Mishnah, <i>Shavuot</i> 7:5; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 86:1; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 91; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 91:5.<br>Some authorities looked askance at a <i>Tove’a</i>’s entries in his business records, lest his books had been doctored to support his claims (see <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 65; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>HM</i> 15). However, in our scenario, the <i>Tove’a</i>’s records undermined his claim, so we have no reason to challenge their authenticity.</i> clearly indicate that his profit margins have only been diminished. Given that the competitor’s entry into the marketplace merely diminished the <i>Tove’a</i>’s profits, we may refrain from resolving whether we accept the approach of Shulhan Arukh or Rema regarding the parameters of restraint of trade. To put it differently, <i>Nitva</i> has not breached his agreement with the <i>Tove’a</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Given the absence of a breach, we need not address the question whether the non-compete agreement between them promotes the interests of the Torah-observant Jewish community or not. For factoring this concern of the public interest regarding restrictive covenants, see <i>Teshuvot Hessed le-Avraham</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>YD</i> 7; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 1:169.<br>Secondly, given that the b<i>eit din</i> did not state that the action is a restraint of trade, we may refrain from addressing the question of whether such a judgment would be prohibited under anti-trust legislation. See <i>State of Missouri v. National Organization for Women, Inc.,</i> 620 F. 2d 1301 (8th Cir. 1980).</i> Had the <i>Nitva</i> obligated himself, accompanied by a proper <i>kinyan</i>, to refrain from causing consequential damages such as <i>grama</i> and diminishing profits of the <i>Tove’a</i>, he would have been monetarily responsible.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Even though <i>Divrei Hayyim</i> argues that obligating oneself to abstain from a particular course of action is unenforceable, nonetheless, he concludes that obligating oneself to refrain from engaging in <i>hezek</i>, damage, is effective. See <i>Divrei Hayyim</i>, supra n. 30. Additionally, see <i>Aruch ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:13; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Bina</i>, <i>HM</i> 2; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yehuda</i> 1; <i>Mishpatekha le</i>-<i>Ya’akov</i> 2:32, 30; R. Zalman N. Goldberg 11 <i>Yeshurun</i> 602–603 (2002).</i>
<b>5. The Legal Enforceability of the Non-Compete Agreement</b>
One of the provisions of the non-compete agreement is the following:
<span class="poetry indentAll">In the event that a court of competent jurisdiction finds any restrictive covenant contained in this Agreement to be unenforceable in whole or in part, including without limitation as to duration and/or territory, the parties hereby direct the court to reduce the scope of such provision to that which is reasonable in the circumstances.</span>
Since the aforementioned term of the agreement has been mutually agreed upon by the parties, generally a <i>beit din</i> must address whether the agreement which was executed in Wisconsin and deals with a Wisconsin business entity, is legally enforceable in a secular court, or whether it would be as a violation of federal law<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">15 USC section 2.</i> or state law, or contrary to public policy.
Generally speaking, in common law systems, restrictive covenants are unenforceable. Nonetheless, a non-compete agreement is an exception to the rule provided that the agreement mandates the minimal degree of conduct to protect the employer’s business interest, the restraint does not incur undue hardship upon the employee, and the restraint is not contrary to the public interest.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">E. Farnsworth, <i>Contracts</i>, 5.3 (1982).</i> Additionally, Wisconsin law requires that an agreement must provide a reasonable territorial limit and time limit.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Wisconsin Statute, Section 103.465 (2007–2008);</i> These requirements have been examined in Wisconsin case law.<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote"><i>State Arms Gun Co. v. Schmelling</i>, No. 94-2055, 1995 Wisc. App. LEXIS 1132, at *13 (July 20,1995); <i>NSP v. National Gas Co</i>., 2000 WI App 30, 8, 232 Wis. 2d 541, 606 N.W. 2d 613;<i>Heyde Cos. V. Dove Healthcare, LLC</i>, 2002 WI 131,30 n. 2, 258 Wis. 2d 28,654 N.W. 2d 830; <i>Selmer Co. v. Rinn</i>, 2010 WI App 10619, 328 Wis. 2d 263, 789 N.W. 2d 621 (2010); <i>Star Direct Inc. v. Dal Pra</i>, 2009 WI 76, 19, 319 Wis. 2d 274, 767 N.W. 2d 898.</i>
In light of the fact that this panel did not award any monies to the <i>Tove’a</i> relating to <i>Nitva</i>’s entry into the marketplace, we may abstain from deciding whether we need to scrutinize the non-compete agreement from a secular legal perspective and the circumstances serving as the grounds for an arbitration award.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Whether we would examine this matter from a secular viewpoint would be dependent on whether we recognize that <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> is applicable in dealing with non-compete agreements.</i>
<b>Decision</b>
1. <i>Nitva</i> is hereby obligated to pay <i>Tove’a</i> $50,000 for the damages in tort and breach of contract.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">We have refrained from communicating publicly how this figure was calculated.</i>
2. All other claims and applications are hereby denied.
3. Any provision of this decision may be modified with the consent of both parties.
<b>Final Thoughts</b>
For additional authorities who validate a non-compete agreement (i.e., an agreement which entails an obligation to abstain from action), see <i>Teshuvot Darkhei Noam, HM</i> 38; <i>Kesef ha-Kodshin, SA, HM</i> 183:4; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam, HM</i> 274, 370; <i>Teshuvot Maharam mi-Lublin</i> 108; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hessed</i> 228 (Cf. no. 222); <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer, YD</i> 9; <i>Teshuvot Mutzal me-Eish</i> 2:11; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 4:220; <i>Teshuvot Netzah Yisrael</i> 42; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 6:170 (18) in the name of <i>Maharashdam</i>.

d) Promises! Promises! The Validity of a Real Estate Binder Agreement

<b>D. Promises! Promises! – The Validity of a Real Estate Binder Agreement</b>
<b>Facts</b>
A real estate binder agreement was signed by the parties regarding the purchase of a property in New Jersey. As memorialized in the agreement, certain conditions, such as ten-day attorney review, would have to be complied with prior to drafting the real estate contract. The parties agreed that the conditions had been obtained. However, the buyer (hereafter: <i>Nitva</i>) subsequently withdrew his offer to purchase the property. The matter was submitted to <i>beit din</i> for resolution.
<b><i>Tove’a</i>’s Claims</b>
Admittedly, no detailed contract of sale was executed between the parties. Nevertheless, the seller (hereafter: <i>Tove’a</i>) argues that their real estate binder agreement should be viewed maximally as a preliminary agreement where the conditions had been obtained and therefore should be binding. Moreover, upon compliance with the conditions in the agreement, and relying upon <i>Nitva</i>’s readiness to execute the purchase, the <i>Tove’a</i> purchased another piece of real estate that was underwritten by a mortgage. The <i>Tove’a</i> claims that he does not have the financial wherewithal to own two pieces of real estate simultaneously and that he is incurring financial losses. Consequently, <i>Nitva</i>’s decision to withdraw his offer to purchase the property has caused him financial harm, and <i>Nitva</i> should therefore be responsible to compensate for his losses. Finally, unable to purchase some securities due to the breach of the promise, <i>Tove’a</i> contends that <i>Nitva</i> ought to be responsible for <i>Tove’a</i>’s failure to profit from anticipated securities investment.
<b><i>Nitva</i>’s Claims</b>
In reply to <i>Tove’a</i>’s arguments, <i>Nitva</i> claims that the agreement to purchase was at best only a promise that contemplated the signing of a more detailed formal contract. Therefore, even though all the conditions of the agreement were obtained, he nevertheless had the option to withdraw from the deal and lose the earnest money, i.e., the money that serves as a security deposit to hold the property for the purchaser. Moreover, he never thought that the deal would fall through and therefore never contemplated that he would have to pay the earnest money. Furthermore, the fact that <i>Tove’a</i> undertook certain financial commitments that he cannot meet and that <i>Tove’a</i> failed to profit from certain investments is not <i>Nitva</i>’s responsibility.
<b>Discussion</b>
<b>1. Does a Real Estate Binder Agreement Constitute a Halakhically <i>Bona Fide</i> Offer to Purchase Property or Not?</b>
Conventionally, upon reaching an oral agreement regarding the purchase of real estate, both parties sign a broker-prepared real estate binder that is subject to attorney review. The binder specifies the buyer and seller, and describes the property being sold. The agreement is an offer to purchase this real estate under certain conditions under which the seller would be willing to sell the property. These conditions include the specific purchase price, inspection, property conditions, and financing arrangements. These conditions are contingencies that allow the potential purchaser to walk away from the agreement if all of the conditions are not met by the purchase date. The agreement was signed by both parties and was accompanied by earnest money. If the seller accepts the offer, the earnest money is held in escrow. When the transaction is finalized, the deposit is applied to the buyer’s costs. If the offer is rejected, the earnest money is returned to the buyer, since no binding contract has been executed. Should all the conditions be met and the potential buyer withdraw his offer, he loses his deposit. Though the agreement contemplates the possibility of the parties signing off on a formal written contract, nevertheless by signing this retainer agreement, the parties are obligating themselves to finalize the sale contingent upon certain conditions being satisfied. As the real estate binder agreement states, it is “an offer to purchase.”
<b>A. Is it a Halakhically Binding <i>Hit’hayivut</i> in Terms of the <i>Halakhot</i> of <i>Hi’yuvim</i>?</b>
This agreement will be examined from two diametrically opposed perspectives: the offer to purchase as a halakhically binding <i>hit’hayivut</i>, obligation, and as a halakhically binding agreement based upon civil law.
From the perspective of the rules of <i>hit’hayivut</i>, a real estate binder, which entails an offer to purchase, is an obligation between parties to behave in a certain manner in the future, which has been characterized by the Talmud as a <i>kinyan devarim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 3a; <i>Rashi</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 3a, s.v. “<i>kinyan devarim</i>”; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 1:3.</i> For a <i>bona fide hit’hayivut</i>, there is a requirement that the matter be “<i>davar she-yesh bo mamash</i>” (something with substance). An offer to purchase is a promise at a future date rather than a “<i>davar she-yesh bo mamash</i>.” Additionally, one cannot undertake an obligation if it is a “<i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i>,” something not yet in existence.<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 210:1. Though generally one is precluded from transferring ownership of an asset that is not yet in existence, nonetheless, if you employ the words, “I obligate myself to sell” and you execute a <i>kinyan</i>, a symbolic way to undertake a commitment, the agreement is valid. See <i>Sefer ha-Terumot</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 64: 2 (1–3); <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:6; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:24, 26; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:18; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 206:5; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i>, <i>HM</i> 26; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 2:26; <i>Teshuvot Mahara Sasson</i> 133; <i>Imrei Bina</i>, <i>Hilkhot Halva’ah</i> 51. In other words, though ownership of the asset has not been transferred, nevertheless there exists an obligation upon the seller to sell the asset to the buyer, an obligation that is enforceable in a <i>beit din</i>. Consequently, for example, if language of <i>hit’hayivut</i> was employed in an agreement accompanied by the execution of a proper <i>kinyan</i> regarding the purchase of a parcel of land or a house without registering the property as required by secular law, there remains an obligation upon the seller to follow through with the sale of the property by complying with the legal requirements. See <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i> 264; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 2:55.<br>In other words, the seller is not required to articulate a <i>shi’abud ha-guf</i>, to undertake personal responsibility to comply with his duty. In other words, the seller’s assets are not required to serve as a guarantee that should the sale fail to materialize, he would be responsible to pay for breaching the agreement. See <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 39:17, 60:7, 203:6; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 28; <i>Teshuvot R. Bezalel Ashkenazi</i> 11; <i>Imrei Yosher</i>, op. cit.; <i>Teshuvot Avnei Nezer</i>, <i>HM</i> 30. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 2, <i>HM</i> 69, 81; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 203:2, 206:1; <i>PDR</i> 14:334.<br>Whether undertaking an obligation to sell preempts the possibility that the person can sell the property to a third person is subject to debate. See <i>Mahara Sasson</i>, op. cit.; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, op. cit.</i> One cannot transfer ownership of a property that would be purchased in the future. Again, the obligation is predicated upon a <i>halot</i>, a legal status of something that has a physical property. The <i>halot</i> condition is not obtained with a property that is being offered for purchase at a future date.<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 13:20; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 209:6. Others view undertaking an obligation of a <i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i> as expressing the absence of <i>gemirat da’at</i>, firm resolve to undertake the obligation. See <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 66b.</i> In short, even if the conditions as set out in the binder agreement were met, refusal of the <i>Nitva</i> to follow up with the sale of the property cannot be enforced by a <i>beit din</i>.
Nonetheless, <i>Nitva</i> has a halakhic-moral duty to keep his word to purchase the property. The consequences of reneging upon a promise are stated in Shulhan Arukh and Rema in the following fashion:<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 204:7; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 204:11.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">When one conducts and concludes commercial transactions using words only (without a formal act of acquisition), that person should stand by his word, even though none of the purchase price has been taken, nor a buyer’s mark made on the goods … Whoever withdraws from this type of transaction, whether buyer or seller, is deemed a faithless person.</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Rema</i>: a person should stand by his word even though no act of acquisition has been performed, and only mere words have passed between the parties …</span>
Where no payment has been made, and the seller articulates an oral commitment to sell real estate (<i>karka</i>) or chattel (<i>metaltelin</i>) to a prospective buyer, and should either party renege on the agreement of sale, he is stigmatized as a <i>mehusar amana</i> (lit. “lacking trustworthiness”). Given that no <i>kinyan</i>, a symbolic act undertaking an obligation, has been executed between the parties, technically either party may withdraw from consummating the sale. Compliance with the promise is unenforceable. Enforceability depends upon the execution of a <i>kinyan</i>. Nevertheless, the individual who reneges from his commitment may be labeled a transgressor (<i>avaryan</i>) and publicly shamed by the community,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam Mintz</i> 1:160; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 204:11 (in the name of <i>Ranah</i>).</i> and has violated minimally a rabbinic <i>issur</i><sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 1:118. Cf. others who argue that he has violated a biblical <i>issur</i>. See <i>Pnei Yehoshua</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 86a in the name of <i>Rashi</i>; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 451; <i>Sma</i>, <i>HM</i> 204:12; <i>Minhat Pe’tim</i>, <i>HM</i> 204:11.</i> provided that the parties mutually agreed upon the selling price of the item.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 49a, s.v. “<i>gamru</i>”; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 189.</i> This conclusion applies even if the promise is memorialized in a written agreement that does not comply with certain formal requirements,<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">(Not necessarily all of the requirements.)</i> such as a promise to pay for a “<i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i>” (something not yet in existence) or the absence of a <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam Mintz</i> 35; <i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:38; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 209:3; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 4:66; <i>Minhat Pe’tim</i>, <i>HM</i> 209.</i> In short, absent a halakhically enforceable obligation, the <i>beit din</i> will not enforce his halakhic-<i>moral</i> duty to comply with his promise. Consequently, in terms of <i>hilkhot hi’yuvim</i>, <i>Nitva</i> would lose his security deposit.
<b>B. Is This Halakhically Binding as a <i>Kinyan Situmta</i>?</b>
According to the majority of <i>Poskim</i>, a contract that entails the sale of real estate will be recognized by dint of the fact that this is the commercial practice for transferring ownership from one person to another. In halakhic parlance, this is known as a <i>kinyan situmta</i>.
