This type of contract has been recognized for centuries and in contemporary times, provided it is valid and enforceable in the eyes of secular law.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 13:21; <i>Teshuvot Tzmach Tzedek</i> (Schneerson), <i>YD</i> 233; <i>Teshuvot Nehar Afarsemon</i>, <i>HM</i> 15; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i>, vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 26; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Schick</i>, <i>HM</i> 41; <i>PDR</i> 6:202; <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i> 2:53.<br>For the requirement that the agreement must comport with secular law, see <i>PDR</i> 12:279; <i>Ateret Devora</i> 2:40.</i> In the absence of a signed contract, many <i>Poskim</i> have recognized the agreement as “an obligation to sell and purchase,” which would be enforceable by a <i>beit din</i> rather than as a contractual obligation to actually transfer property ownership.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 4:275, 279, 6:202, 216, 14:43, 70, 18:354, 360.</i> In other words, for the property to be transferred, the agreement must be a <i>kinyan situmta</i>, namely, recognized as legally effective by New York law.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sabia v. Mattituck Inlet Mar. &amp; Shipyard, Inc</i>. 24 AD 3d 178 (2005); <i>Bonilla v. Rotter</i>, 2007 NY Slip Op. 449, NY Appellate Div., 1st Dept. 2007.</i>
The question is whether a real estate binder agreement, which is an offer to purchase, is viewed as a halakhically <i>bona fide</i> contract, like a real estate sale contract. If it has the same status as any real estate contract, then if the conditions have been obtained as outlined in the binder agreement, the seller is obligated to sell and the buyer is obligated to purchase. Halakhically, whether a real estate binder agreement is binding upon the parties depends on whether the locale in which this preliminary agreement was entered has a common <i>minhag</i> (custom) of accepting the validity of such documents. If so, one may conclude that it is binding based on <i>kinyan situmta</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 66; <i>Teshuvot Maharasham</i> 6:113; <i>Teshuvot Ahiezer</i> 3:79<i>.</i> The assumption is that a <i>kinyan situmta</i> is effective even <i>for davar she-lo ba la-olam</i>. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 3:153; <i>Teshuvot Shoeil u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 2:39; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Schick</i>, <i>HM</i> 41; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:26; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 66; <i>Teshuvot Sefer Yehoshua</i> 114; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 5:37. Cf. <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i> 201:1; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 201, <i>Hiddushin</i> 5; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i> 134.<br>Whether there is an additional requirement of <i>shi’abud nekhasim</i>, namely that a person’s property serves as a guarantor by the promisor (in our case, the seller) to create a halakhically legal obligation is subject to debate. See supra n. 2. For further discussion, see <i>Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 2:9.<br>Others contend that it is a “<i>hit’hayivut</i>,” i.e., the undertaking of an obligation to finalize the agreement, rather than the actual finalization of an agreement. For an analysis of both viewpoints, see <i>Teshuvot Meishiv Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 36.</i> For the <i>minhag</i> to be efficacious there is a threshold requirement that it must be widespread and practiced at least three times.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 163:3, 331:1; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:1. Others argue that it must transpire on a daily basis. See <i>Teshuvot Hakham Tzvi</i> 61.</i> In effect, frequently the <i>minhag</i> is reflective of the governing civil law.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam Mintz</i> 82; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 3:132; <i>Teshuvot Nediv Lev</i> (David Hazan) 12; <i>Teshuvot Nediv Lev</i> (Eliezer Hazan) 13; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> (Ettinger) 2:111; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Avraham</i> 1:1; <i>Teshuvot Oholei Tam</i> 202; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yisrael</i> (Landau) 172; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 1:10; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 4:143; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Uziel</i> 3:28; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:72, 75.<br>Another (albeit minority) opinion rejects the effectiveness of the commercial practice to legitimate a <i>kinyan</i> for the following reason: Since a binder agreement was signed so that it will be enforceable in civil court, the signing was done involuntarily, and therefore, such a <i>kinyan</i> is invalid. In other words, adoption of a <i>minhag</i> must be undertaken voluntarily. Given that this practice of recognizing a preliminary agreement is grounded in law, and one of the aspects of law is its “coercive nature,” the law cannot serve as the basis of the <i>minhag</i> regarding the recognition of a <i>kinyan</i> grounded in commercial practice<i>.</i> See R. Zalman N. Goldberg’s opinion in <i>PDR</i> 12:279.</i>
Alternatively, R. Hayyim Rapaport observes, the norms of secular law determine the expectations of the parties (i.e., <i>umdana</i>) with respect to the binding nature of an agreement, and if the parties expect an agreement to be binding, then they are bound to its provisions.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mayyim Hayyim</i> cited by <i>Pithei Teshuva</i> HM 207:3. For an identical approach, see <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i>, <i>Likkutim</i> 16:1; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 23:2; Clearly, <i>Hazon Ish</i> would argue that one cannot validate a contractual agreement based upon civil law. See <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i>, <i>Likkutim</i> 16:11.</i>
Finally, in the absence of a <i>minhag</i> or an <i>umdana</i>, Talmud, as well as most authorities, validates a preliminary agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avoda Zara</i> 72a; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 206:1; <i>Rema</i>, ad locum.; <i>Teshuvot Noda be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>YD</i> 48; <i>Tiv Kidushin</i> 50:17; <i>Teshuvot ha-Bah</i> 10; <i>Teshuvot Beit Shmuel Aharon</i>, <i>EH</i> 12; <i>PDR</i> 9:16, 40, 18:29, 31. For additional authorities, see <i>Otzar ha-Poskim</i>, <i>EH</i> 50 (44:3).<br>At first glance, it would seem that this conclusion stands in contradiction to <i>Taz</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 50:12; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, ad locum 15; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>Tinyana</i> 75, and others who argue that the preliminary agreement (referred to in rabbinic Hebrew as “<i>rashei perakim</i>” or in modern Hebrew as “<i>zihron devarim</i>”), similar to the document titled <i>tena’im</i> (conditions) which is signed at the time of an engagement to marry, is subject to a party’s rescission. But in fact, in this instance, the parties’ intention is to bind themselves to the actual document memorializing the <i>tena’im</i> rather than the preliminary agreement to the <i>tena’im.</i> Alternatively, the reason for the <i>tena’im</i> agreement is to remember what was was mutually agreed upon. Consequently, even those authorities would concur that a conventional preliminary agreement with the intent to be bound by the terms is valid.</i>
In our case, the <i>minhag</i> or <i>umdana</i> regarding the expectation of the parties can be ascertained by an inquiry into the common commercial practice and secular law governing the acceptance of preliminary agreements. New Jersey case law validates such preliminary agreements under the following condition: The question is whether the parties intended to be bound at the time they reached an oral or written preliminary agreement, or only at the time the formal contract was signed. Assuming, upon scrutiny of the facts, that the intent of the parties was to be bound with the signing of the real estate binder agreement, the parties are considered to be “under contract” for the real estate sale.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Comerata v. Chaumont, Inc</i>., 52 NJ Super. 299, 305 (App. Div. 1958); <i>Onderbook v</i>. <i>Prebyterian Homes</i>, 85 NJ 171, 183 (1981); <i>Morales v. Santiago</i>, 217 NJ Super. 496, 501–502 (App. Div. 1987); <i>Satellite Entertainment v. Keaton</i>, 347 NJ 268,276 (App. Div. 2002).</i> This reasoning is more fully developed in New York’s Second Circuit and Second Department.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Adjustrite Systems, Inc. v. GAB Business Services</i>, Inc., 145 F. 3d 543, 547 (2d Circuit 1998); <i>Teachers Ins. &amp; Annuity Ass’n of Am. V. Tribune Co.</i>, 670 F. Supp. 491 (SDNY 1987). See also recent case law cited in Alan Schwartz and Robert Scott, “The Law and Economics of Preliminary Agreements,” 120 <i>Harvard L. Rev.</i> 662, 673, n. 34, 674, n. 39 (2007).</i>
To state our conclusion somewhat differently, even though the binder agreement neither comports with the requirements of a <i>hit’hayivut</i> nor complies with the technical requirements that the paper and ink of the agreement must belong to the Seller,<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gittin</i> 20b–21a; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 191:1; <i>Mishkenot Ya’akov</i>, <i>HM</i> 42.</i> nevertheless it is enforceable based upon <i>kinyan situmta</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Should the Seller fail to provide the <i>shtar</i> and the ink, and should civil law fail to enforce the agreement, Halakha will refuse to validate the sale. See <i>PDR</i> 20:71, 76; <i>Pithei Hoshen</i>, <i>Kinyan</i> 122, n. 13.</i>
In our scenario, we are dealing with a binder agreement that is an example of a preliminary agreement regarding a price to purchase a specific piece of property. Given that the conditions of the binder agreement were obtained, the buyer’s decision to renege on his commitment has halakhic as well as legal consequences, namely that <i>Nitva</i> loses his security deposit.
Seemingly, given that <i>Nitva</i> did not expect to pay the security deposit, the transaction lacks the requisite <i>gemirat da’at</i>, a commitment that was made with firm intent to remit the earnest money. To state it differently, this transaction is characterized as an <i>asmakhta</i> – an agreement that lacks a presumption of firm resolve on the part of the obligator. The possibility that the purchase would fail to materialize never entered the <i>Nitva</i>’s mind, thus the contract is void, <i>ab initio</i>.
Nonetheless, if the commercial practice is to establish such a penalty, then we presume that one did intend to follow through and pay the monies should the contract fail to materialize.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 66a; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 50:6; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 61:5; <i>Teshuvot Maharash Enzel</i> 1:12; <i>PDR</i> 5:258, 270, 14:334.</i> For example, in return for a premium payment, an insurance company promises to reimburse the insured for the loss. Given that such an arrangement reflects common commercial practice, <i>asmakhta</i> will not be a factor invalidating the insurance contract.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Beit Ephraim</i>, <i>HM</i> 34.</i> Similarly, the requirement of a security deposit upon signing a binder agreement is common practice in the real estate and therefore does not run afoul of the strictures of <i>asmakhta</i>.
On the other hand, based upon the fact that the agreement was subject to attorney review, the intent of the parties was not to be bound by the real estate binder agreement.
<b>2. <i>Nezikin</i> Claims Due to Reliance upon Promise</b>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>A. </i>Tove’a<i>’s Undertaking the Purchase of a Second Home</i></span>
Relying upon <i>Nitva</i>’s readiness to execute the purchase, the <i>Tove’a</i> purchased another piece of real estate that was underwritten by a mortgage. The <i>Tove’a</i> argues that he does not have the financial wherewithal to own two pieces of real estate simultaneously and is incurring financial losses. Consequently, <i>Nitva</i>’s decision to withdraw his offer to purchase the property has caused him a financial loss and therefore <i>Nitva</i> should be responsible to compensate for his damages.
Rambam states,<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Zekhiya u-Matana</i> 6:24</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">My teachers have ruled that if it is the custom of the land that each man (when betrothed) should make a feast for his friends or distribute money to the religious functionaries of the community, and he follows the custom of all people and then she retracts, she must refund his expenses, because she caused him to spend his money; and whoever causes another to lose money must pay for it.</span>
In a critical annotation on this ruling, Ra’avad demurs,<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">… . I do not concur with his teachers regarding this matter. That indirect causation is akin to seeds in the garden that did not grow, regarding which one pays (only) the expenses. The principle of the matter is: loss of money committed by the owner of the money, even though someone else caused him (to incur the loss), that person is exempt from liability.</span>
In other words, whereas according to Rambam, breach of a promise to marry is actionable, according to the Ra’avad, damages are not recoverable. Consequently, some authorities contend that <i>Tove’a</i>’s ability to recover losses incurred by undertaking to acquire a second home is dependent whether one endorses the view of Rambam or of Ra’avad.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Berakh Moshe</i> (Galante) 5; <i>Teshuvot Rabbi Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 134.</i> While a minority of <i>Poskim</i> agrees with Ra’avad, most authorities, including Shulhan Arukh, concur with the position of Rambam.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 50:3; <i>Otzar ha-Poskim</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 50:3, sections 24–26.</i> Among the reasons for requiring <i>nezikin</i> (tort) liability suggested by the <i>Poskim</i> is the immediacy and direct nature of the harm (<i>bari hezeka</i>) and the injured party’s reliance upon the <i>mazik</i> (tortfeasor).<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>EH</i> 50, s.v. “<i>katav</i>”; <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i> 386:1; <i>Teshuvot Ein Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 68:20; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, supra n. 24; <i>PDR</i> 3:18, 31.</i>
Applying Rambam’s position to our scenario, clearly there is direct link between the <i>Nitva</i>’s failure to keep his promise and the <i>Tove’a</i>’s decision to embark on the purchase of a second property. In fact, <i>Tove’a</i> should have realized that a formal written contract had to be prepared and accepted by <i>Nitva</i> prior to arriving at the conclusion that this was “a done deal.” If someone promises another that he will do something for him, and relying upon this assurance, he expends monies, and subsequently the promisor retracted his offer, Maharik and Sefer ha-Mikneh conclude that the promisee must sustain the loss due to the fact that he should have contemplated that the promisor may change his mind.<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 133:2; <i>Sefer ha-Mikneh</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 50; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 242:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Alsheikh</i> 121.</i> Similarly, in our case, <i>Tove’a</i> should have foreseen the possibility that the deal may fall through, a frequent occurrence in real estate matters.
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>B. </i>“Mevatel Kiso shel Haveiro” <i>–</i> Tove’a<i>’s Inability to Fund a Securities Investment</i></span>
Unable to purchase some securities due to the breach of the promise, <i>Tove’a</i> contends that <i>Nitva</i> ought to be responsible for <i>Tove’a</i>’s failure to profit from anticipated securities investment.
Assuming <i>Nitva</i> undertook the obligation to assume the losses and provided that the obligation does not run afoul of <i>asmakhta</i> by undertaking an obligation that is exaggerated, such an agreement would be valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 104a; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 73b; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ran</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 104a; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 9:4,7; <i>SA</i> and <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 328:1.</i> Some <i>Poskim</i> require that the agreement be in writing.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot Rid</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 104a; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 328.</i>
Absent the <i>Nitva</i> undertaking an obligation, the fact remains that if the <i>Tove’a</i> relied upon the fact that his losses would be covered, <i>Nitva</i> would be responsible. Responding to the <i>Tove’a</i>’s claim, the Talmud Bavli teaches us,<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 73b.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If someone gives money to his friend to serve as his agent to go and purchase wine for him during the season when the price is low, and the servant was negligent and failed to buy it, he must pay him for the wine at the low price.</span>
In our case, the promise (<i>Tove’a</i>) relied upon the promisor (<i>Nitva</i>) and incurred a loss. The Talmud concludes that <i>Nitva</i> is responsible to compensate for the losses that were suffered.
The rationale for compensation expounded upon by Ra’ah is the following:<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva ha-Hadashim</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 73b. Though numerous decisors identify the authorship of this position with R. Yom Tov ben Avraham Ishbili, known by the acronym “Ritva,” in fact Ritva is citing his teacher, Ra’ah. The text identifies the view with “<i>mori ha-rav</i>” (i.e., his rabbinical teacher). Ritva’s use of this appellation refers to Ra’ah. See Yitzhak Brand, “<i>Ha-Nosei ve-Notain be-Devarim</i>: Between Contractual Obligation &amp; Tortuous Reliance” (Hebrew), 24 <i>Mehkarei Mishpat</i>, 55, nn. 107, 122–124 (5768) and this writer’s, “The Role of Detrimental Reliance in the Law of Obligations: A Comparative Analysis,” in Volume in Memory of Menachem Elon (forthcoming).</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Here (Bava Metzia 73b), even though the agent did not contractually agree to assume liability [for failure to fulfill his promise], since the principal gave him money with which to purchase merchandise, and the principal would have either purchased it himself or arranged for another to do so had not the agent promised to do so, and the principal relied upon him and gave him the money based upon the reliance, for that reason the agent is liable to pay the loss caused by the reliance on his promise.</span>
As explained elsewhere,<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">See this writer’s “The Theory of Efficient Breach: A Jewish Law Perspective” in <i>The Oxford Handbook of Judaism and Economics</i>, ed. Aaron Levine, Oxford, 2010, 340, 347–348.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Ra’ah’s position contains four propositions. The first is that one does not require an agreement that explicitly stipulates that consequential damages are recoverable. The second proposition is that in the absence of such agreement, by giving money to the agent to effectuate a wine purchase at a location where the selling price was lower than others, the promisee relied upon the promisor’s compliance. The third proposition is that the words of the promisor serve as the act of inducing reliance by the promise. Moreover, in the context of Ra’ah’s posture more importantly, it is the <i>be-hahi hana’a</i> (i.e., because of the benefit created by the induced reliance that establishes a surety relationship between the two parties) he undertakes the obligation, and therefore the promise becomes halakhically binding upon the promisor and enforceable in a case of breach.”<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Barukh Kahane, <i>Arevut</i>, Yerushalayim, 1998, 78–90. In order to be granted relief, some <i>Poskim</i> require that the profit loss must be clear and definite. See <i>Ra’vyah</i> cited by <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 125; <i>Sefer Ra’vyah</i>, Deblitsky ed., No. 957; <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 69a, s.v. “<i>pirshu</i>”; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 183:1; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 178; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 22:2.</i></span>
It is the halakhic norm of an <i>arevut</i>, i.e., a guarantee, rather that the halakhic norm of promise keeping, which endows validity to the agreement. Conventionally, should the borrower default on his loan, the <i>arev</i> undertakes the obligation to pay the lender. Here, we are applying the institution of <i>arevut</i> in a non-loan transaction in order to transform a promissory obligation into a halakhically-legally enforceable duty. The breach of the promissory obligation is contingent upon the fact that the promisor induced someone to rely on his promise. Just as a guarantor’s obligation to compensate is created by the trust that is engendered by the creditor’s conviction that the guarantor will compensate him in case of a borrower’s default upon a loan, analogously, should an individual be negligent and fail to purchase wine at a lower price for another person as he promised, akin to an <i>arev</i> he is liable to indemnify him for any ensuing loss.<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 6b; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 7a; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 370; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 181; <i>Imrei Yosher</i>, supra n. 2; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 209:32; <i>Derisha</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:2; Kahane, supra n. 35 at 6, 441<i>.</i></i> Since the Ra’ah’s time, there are a few authorities who subscribed to his approach of a promissory obligation based on detrimental reliance grounded in <i>hilkhot arevut</i> and awarded damages for a loss of profits.<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ra’vyah</i>, supra n. 35; <i>Ra’avad</i>, <i>Shita Mekubezet</i> on <i>Bava Metzia</i> 73b; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 176:31, 183:1, 304:2, 306:6, 333:14; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 1:86; <i>Teshuvot Avnei Nezer</i>, <i>EH</i> 407; <i>Teshuvot Even Shetiya</i> 79; <i>Teshuvot Har ha-Carmel</i>, <i>HM</i> 10; <i>Divrei Geonim</i> 96:47; <i>Teshuvot Panim Meirot</i> 1:82; <i>Teshuvot Meishiv Davar</i> 3:15; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 22:1; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 1:85; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 1:93; <i>Dibrot Moshe</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 2:503; <i>PDR</i> 3:18, 30, 17:289, 295.<br>Alternatively, damages for preclusion of profits are grounded in <i>nezikin</i>, i.e., torts. See <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen HM</i> 333:2.</i>
For most authorities, the compensation resulting from reliance upon the promise is due the fact that the <i>Nitva</i> explicitly agreed at the time of the agreement to reimburse the promisee for any harm resulting from failure to finalize the wine purchase. Reliance upon an oral promise without providing such a stipulation does not engender financial ­liability.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 73b; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 5:69; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 114:115; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 308; <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Shomerim</i> 8; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 176:31,183:1, 304:2, 306:6, 333:14; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 22:1; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, <i>HM</i> 176:4.</i> Hence, in our case, <i>Nitva</i> promised to buy the property without agreeing to reimburse for any loss resulting from breaking his promise and therefore should be exempt from any of <i>Tove’a</i>’s losses pertaining to his inability to invest in the securities market.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">This argument would equally apply to <i>Tove’a</i>’s claim for incurring financial losses due to purchasing a second home.</i>
Moreover, for many, where the profit is speculative such as investment in securities, there is no recovery for lost profits.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Ra’vyah</i> 957; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 183:1; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:399; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 151; <i>Teshuvot Maharash ha-Levi</i>, <i>EH</i> 5; <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Gezela</i> 11; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 178; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 5:125.</i> As the Talmud Yerushalmi states,<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yerushalmi</i> 9:3.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Rabbi Yitzhak says: Someone who prevents his friend from making a profit (<i>mevatel kiso shel haveiro</i>) has only a grievance.</span>
Given that the preclusion of profit is illustrative of a case of <i>grama</i>, i.e., indirect harm, and one is exempt for such conduct, the injured party has no grounds for recovery.<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 207:16.</i> Consequently, in our case, <i>Tove’a</i>’s claim to recover lost profits lacks foundation.
Finally, even for those <i>Poskim</i> who would subscribe to the Ra’ah’s position, his view is predicated upon engendered trust that caused the <i>Tove’a</i>, the seller, to rely upon the <i>Nitva</i>’s promise to purchase. But, <i>Tove’a</i> should have foreseen the possibility that the deal may fall through, a frequent occurrence in real estate matters, and he therefore should have refrained from undertaking other financial deals. To state it differently, there were no grounds for the <i>Tove’a</i> to rely upon the <i>Nitva</i>’s promise. It is a case of misplaced trust. Therefore, there is no foundation to the <i>Tove’a</i>’s claims to recoup any financial losses that were caused by his actions rather than driven by the <i>Nitva</i>’s promise.
<b>Decision</b>
1. <i>Nitva</i> loses his security deposit.
2. <i>Nitva</i> is not obligated to pay <i>Tove’a</i> the profit losses incurred by him.

e) Real Estate Brokerage Agreement

<b>E. Real Estate Brokerage Agreement</b>
<b>Facts</b>
In July 5, 2008, Levi Meyer (hereafter: <i>Tove’a</i>), a New Jersey licensed real estate broker, entered into an exclusive brokerage agreement, known professionally as a listing agreement, with Michael Miller (hereafter: <i>Nitva</i>) for the sale of his property located at 9 Meadow Lane, Paramus, NJ. The expiration date of the agreement was January 23, 2009. Pursuant to the agreement, should <i>Tove’a</i> find a buyer, he would be entitled to a six percent commission. <i>Tove’a</i> found a ready, willing, and able buyer for the property, and <i>Nitva</i> accepted an offer from Fred Nevins to purchase the aforesaid property, only to later find out that Nevins withdrew his offer. Unbeknownst to <i>Tove’a</i>, Israel Levy, another broker, showed the property to a third party and subsequently, <i>Nitva</i> sold the property to the third party on February 29, 2009. Though <i>Nitva</i> paid Levy a commission for the sale, <i>Nitva</i> refused to remit a commission to <i>Tove’a</i>.
<b><i>Tove’a</i> Claims</b>
<i>Tove’a</i> argues that he is entitled to his commission for three reasons: (1) <i>Tove’a</i> found a ready, willing, and able buyer for <i>Nitva</i>; (2) Pursuant to the agreement, if said property is sold to a third party by anyone else, <i>Tove’a</i> remains entitled to receive commission; (3) Since the offer from Nevins was accepted by <i>Nitva</i>, and negotiations between the <i>Nitva</i> and Nevins extended beyond the expiration date of the listing agreement, therefore in accordance with the provisions of the listing agreement, the brokerage commitment is extended for an additional three months. Given that the sale to Levy transpired during this three month extension, <i>Tove’a</i> earns his commission.
<b><i>Nitva</i>’s Reply</b>
In reply to <i>Tove’a</i>’s claims, though there was a ready, willing, and able buyer to purchase his property, and Nevins’ offer was signed and accepted, nevertheless, since the prospective buyer failed to execute a contract for sale with <i>Nitva</i>, <i>Tove’a</i> is not entitled to a commission. Secondly, in pursuance of the terms of the agreement, if a third party brokers the sale, the <i>Tove’a</i> fails to receive his commission. Finally, even though Nevins and <i>Nitva</i> admittedly executed an acceptance offer, nonetheless, subsequently, prior to the lapse of the listing agreement, Nevins requested certain modifications concerning the terms of the sale and additions regarding the property, and <i>Nitva</i> notified Nevins that he no longer wanted to sell to Nevins.
<b>Discussion</b>
<b>1. The Validity of the Listing Agreement: A <i>Bona Fide Shtar</i> or a <i>Kinyan Situmta</i>?</b>
The real estate agreement reads as follows:
<span class="poetry indentAll">… In consideration of a Broker’s listing and endeavoring to sell the property, Owner grants to Broker the exclusive right to sell the property at the price and upon the terms set forth herein or at such price or terms upon which Owner may agree …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Upon the procuring of a Purchaser of the property during the term of this listing, Owner agrees to pay a Broker a commission of six per cent of the selling price. Broker’s commission shall be considered earned if the sale of the property is effected by Broker, by Owner, or by any third party during the term of this listing …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The term of this listing shall be extended by the period of time commenced by the date that the Owner accepts any offer presented by Broker for the property and ended by the date that negotiations with respect to such offer terminate. If negotiations with respect to an accepted offer terminate after the listing termination date set forth above, then the term shall be further extended by a period of three months from the date that such negotiations terminate …</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">This Agreement expresses the entire agreement of the parties with respect to the subject matter hereof … shall be governed by New Jersey law …</span>
Both <i>Tove’a</i> and <i>Nitva</i> signed off on the real estate brokerage agreement.
According to the Halakha of obligations, i.e., <i>hit’hayivut</i>, in order for an agreement, including but not limited to a real estate agreement, to be halakhically effective, certain terminology must be utilized in the agreement. For example, the employment of the terminology, “the Owner undertakes to pay,” or “the Owner obligates himself to pay,” are terms of undertaking a financial commitment that would be enforceable in <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:6; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:13; <i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 3:173; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 29.</i> Hence, employment of terminology in the listing such as, “Owner may agree” and “Owner agrees,” which entails a future activity, is in halakhic nomenclature, a “<i>kinyan devarim</i>” and has no enforceability.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 3a; <i>Rashi</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>kinyan devarim</i>”; <i>Teshuvot Rama</i> (Abulafia) 249 found in <i>Orhot Tzadikim</i>, Warsaw, 5662; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 1:3; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 245:1; File no. 288409-5, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, April 10, 2013.</i>
Minimally this listing agreement is an example of a <i>kinyan situmta</i>, i.e., a mode of undertaking an obligation recognized in commercial practice. <i>Kinyan situmta</i> is not only recognized as a vehicle to transfer assets, i.e., <i>hakna’a</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a; <i>Teshuvot Tzmach Tzedek</i> (Schneersohn), <i>YD</i> 233; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:26; <i>Teshuvot Maharam Schick</i>, <i>HM</i> 41; <i>PDR</i> 6:202; <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i> 2:53.</i> such as a real estate contract, but also as a means for undertaking obligations, i.e., <i>hit’hayivut</i>, <sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 66; <i>Kesef ha-Kodshin</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:1.</i> such as an employment contract or a business partnership agreement. A real estate brokerage agreement entails a <i>hit’hayivut</i> and is an example of one of the many contracts that is halakhically recognized.<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 5:45; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, <i>HM</i> 194:2; <i>Teshuvot Ahiezer</i> 3:79; <i>PDR</i> 3:368, 4:279.</i> Its validity is predicated upon the fact that it has been legally drafted properly and is enforceable according to civil law.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 12:279, 291, 18:108, 112; Ron Kleinman, “<i>Kinyan Situmta</i>: Commercial Practices Regarding Modes of <i>Kinyanim</i>” (Hebrew), 24 <i>Mehkarei Mishpat</i> 243, 286 (5768).</i> A review of the terms of this listing agreement shows that it has been written in proper legal form and will be enforceable in civil court.
Moreover, in accordance with this agreement, any questions regarding interpreting its terms are to be resolved by applicable New Jersey law. Lest one challenge the basis for resolving halakhic questions in accordance with civil law, the Talmud instructs us that the operative rule in the context of monetary affairs is that “an individual may stipulate contrary to what is written in the Torah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 19b; <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 38:5; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:17, 305:4; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 344:1.</i> As such, since both the <i>Tove’a</i> and <i>Nitva</i> agreed that any differences regarding the agreement are to be resolved by applying the norms of NJ law, their agreement is a private arrangement that Halakha recognizes. Halakha will therefore resolve the differences between the parties in accordance with the dictates of civil law.
We now proceed to ascertain how NJ law has addressed the issues emerging from this dispute. In our scenario, though the <i>Tove’a</i> had produced a prospective buyer ready, willing, and able to purchase in accordance with the terms set by <i>Nitva</i>, nevertheless, no binding contract of sale between the Owner and the prospective buyer had been finalized. Consequently, <i>Nitva</i> contends that he is exempt from paying a real estate commission to the <i>Tove’a</i>.
In the absence of a broker’s agreement to the contrary, some NJ courts rule that a broker earns his commission by producing a ready, willing, and able buyer.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Marschalk v. Weber</i>, 11 NJ Super. 16 (App. Div. 1950); <i>Blau v. Friedman</i>, 26 NJ 397, 401 (1958); <i>Beckmann Inc. v. Zinke’s Rainbow’s End, Inc.</i>, 40 NJ 193, 196 (App. Div.), certif. denied, 22 NJ 219 (1956); <i>Stanchak v. Cliffside Park</i>, 116 NJ Super. 471 (1971).</i> In the event that there is a provision in the listing agreement that the commission would be “remitted on closing” or “payable when the time passes,” such provision is to be understood as determining the time of the payment of the commission rather than as a prerequisite to the broker’s entitlement to the commission.<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Klipper v. Schlossberg</i>, 96 NJ L 397, 401 (Sup. Ct. 1921); <i>J. R. Tucker, Inc. v. Mahaffey</i>, 6 NJ Misc. 17 (Sup. Ct. 1928).</i>
Accordingly, if a broker produces a ready, willing, and able purchaser who agrees to buy the property on mutually satisfactory terms with the seller and enters into a sales contract with him, the broker is entitled to his commission.
However, the majority of NJ courts endorse the <i>Ellsworth Dobbs, Inc. v. J. Johnson and A. Johnson</i> holding which states,<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ellsworth Dobbs Inc v. J. Johnson and A. Johnson</i>, 50 NJ 528, 548, 236 A. 2d 843 (1967).</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">When a broker is engaged by an owner of a property to find a purchaser for it, the broker earns his commission when (a) he produces a purchaser ready, willing, and able to buy on the same terms, fixed by the owner, (b) the purchaser enters into a binding contract with the owner to do so, and (c) the purchaser completes the transaction by closing the title in accordance with the provisions of the contract. If the contract is not consummated because of the lack of financial ability to perform or because of any other default of his … there is no right to commission against the seller.</span>
To this very day, NJ continues to subscribe to this position.<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kennedy v. Roach</i>, 122 NJ Super. 361 (1973); <i>Rothman Realty Corp. v. Breck</i>, 73 NJ Super. 577 (1977); <i>Feist v. Dockside, et al.</i>, 255 NJ Super. 100 (1992); <i>Banquesource Capital v. Pine Brook, et al</i>., 265 NJ Super. 446 (1992); <i>Van Winkle and Liggett v. GBR Fabrics, Inc. v. Harper, et al.</i> 638 A. 2d 173, NJ Super 152, 169–170 (1993); <i>Atlantic Commercial v. Dunham</i>, 303 NJ Super. 122 (1997); <i>Deforest Investment Co. v. Cushman and Wakefield</i>, No. A-3467-09T2, NJ Super. Ct., App. Div. 2012.</i> Based upon the foregoing, since a sales contract was never consummated between the <i>Nitva</i> and Nevins, <i>Tove’a</i> is not entitled to his commission.
Additionally, based upon his understanding of one the agreement’s provisions, <i>Nitva</i> contends that <i>Tove’a</i> is not entitled to his commission from the sale of the property to Levy by another broker. As the agreement states,
<span class="poetry indentAll">Upon the procuring of a Purchaser of the property during the term of this listing, Owner agrees to pay a Broker a commission of six per cent of the selling price. Broker’s commission shall be considered earned if the sale of the property is effected by Broker, by Owner, or by any third party during the term of this listing …</span>
In other words, <i>Nitva</i> argues that if a second broker introduces the <i>Nitva</i> to a prospective buyer and facilitates the sale of the property, only the second broker earns the commission. Such an interpretation of this provision is predicated upon the contention that the phrase, “if sold to a party who was introduced to the property during the term by broker” is modifying not only the case of a sale “after its termination” but also the case of sale “during the term of the listing.”
Such an interpretation ignores the earlier part of the clause – “if the sale is effected … by any third party” – and the clear intent of the provision to give Broker A, namely the <i>Tove’a</i>, an exclusive brokerage agreement during the term of the signed listing agreement. The fact that the owner, namely the <i>Nitva</i>, was required to pay a commission to Broker B does not reduce his obligation to Broker A, namely the <i>Tove’a</i>. <i>Nitva</i> could have protected himself either by renegotiation with Broker A prior to the sale, or by refraining from selling until the lapse of the brokerage agreement. He did neither.
Such a conclusion would be equally forthcoming according to the canons of halakhic interpretation of agreements. If one has a doubt regarding language employed in an agreement, then if there is an <i>umdana</i>, i.e., common sense meaning, to the benefit of one of the parties, we follow the <i>umdana</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 2:100 cited by <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>HM</i> 42, <i>hagaha</i> 30; <i>Hiddushei R. Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 42:5.<br>Though the choice of law provision stipulates that NJ law governs, whether halakhically that means that we are directed to interpret the actual construction of the provisions of the agreement or only the actual civil law governing brokerage law we leave as an open question. Consequently, we interpreted the construction of the clauses in accordance with both legal systems.</i> In our scenario, clearly it is to the benefit of the <i>Tove’a</i> to negotiate an exclusive brokerage agreement whereby if another broker sells the property to a third party unbeknownst to him, he still earns a commission. Secondly, even if assume that that there are two differing interpretations of this clause, one which benefits the <i>Tove’a</i> and another which benefits the <i>Nitva</i>, <i>yad ba’al ha-shtar al ha-elyona</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 3 cited by <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>HM</i> 42, <i>hagaha</i> 19. However, if the clause cannot be interpreted in two different ways, then the document is construed against the drafter.</i> the document is construed in favor of the drafter, namely the <i>Tove’a</i>.
Given our understanding of the aforementioned clause, the question remains whether the <i>Tove’a</i> is in actuality entitled to his commission on the sale of the property to Levy. <i>Nitva</i> sold the property to the third party on February 29, 2009. The prerequisite for an earned commission is that the sale transpired during “the life of the agreement.” In our instance, the agreement expired on January 23, 2009, so seemingly <i>Tove’a</i> should be denied his commission. Nevertheless, invoking one of the clauses of the agreement, <i>Tove’a</i> argues that he is still entitled to his commission. As the provision states,
<span class="poetry indentAll">The term of this listing shall be extended by the period of time commenced by the date that the Owner accepts any offer presented by Broker for the property and ended by the date that negotiations with respect to such offer terminate. If negotiations with respect to an accepted offer terminate after the listing termination date set forth above, then the term shall be further extended by a period of three months from the date that such negotiations terminate …</span>
Clearly, during the time of the listing agreement, there was an offer by Nevins that was accepted by <i>Nitva</i>. However, subsequently, there is a paper trail corroborating that Nevins had second thoughts regarding his offer. Nevins requested that <i>Nitva</i> add certain additions to the property and requested certain financial accommodations prior to signing the contract for sale. Due to these requests for modification of the original offer, <i>Nitva</i> orally communicated to the <i>Tove’a</i> that he no longer was interested in selling the property to Nevins. <i>Tove’a</i> claims that negotiations between <i>Nitva</i> and Nevins continued. However, he was unable to produce any documentation corroborating his claim. Given that <i>Nitva</i> produced a paper trail indicating that Nevins had retracted from the original offer and the <i>Tove’a</i> was unable to show that negotiations continued, the three-month extension of the listing agreement based upon an accepted offer was inapplicable to our case at hand. Hence, had the listing agreement been extended to April 23, 2009, then <i>Tove’a</i> would have been entitled to a commission based upon the sale on February 29, 2009. Based upon the cumulative evidence that the negotiations had ceased between the <i>Nitva</i> and Nevins prior to the expiration date of the listing agreement, there are no grounds to extend the term of the brokerage agreement. Therefore, there are no grounds for <i>Tove’a</i>’s entitlement to a real estate commission.
<b>Decision</b>
<i>Nitva</i> is hereby not obligated to pay a commission to the <i>Tove’a</i>.
<b>Final Thoughts</b>
Assuming the parties had negotiated the terms of their agreement orally and subsequently there was a dispute regarding the terms, how would Halakha address the current claims advanced by the <i>Tove’a</i> and <i>Nitva</i>? In the absence of a written or verbal agreement to provide services, <i>Rema</i> rules,<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 264:4. See also <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 246:17. Cf. <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 363:10. On the other hand, Rema contends that certain actions, such as expressing a willingness to be an <i>arev</i> (guarantor on a loan) without performing the prescribed <i>kinyan</i> (a symbolic act of undertaking an obligation), are not actions for which one customarily receives compensation. Hence under certain circumstances, a failure to pay the <i>arev</i> will not allow him to recover from the borrower a fee for his services. See <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 129:22. For the reasoning underlying Rema’s view, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 64:3.<br>In civil law, a similar notion of a quasi-contractual recovery is known as <i>quantum merit</i> (“as much as he deserves”) and allows the performing party, in this case the broker, to recoup the reasonable value of services rendered is recognized in NJ law. See NJ case law cited in <i>Weichert Co. Realtors v. Ryan and Saunders</i>, 128 NJ 427 (1992), 608 A. 2d 280.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If one performs an action or benefit for his friend, [the friend] cannot say that it was done <i>gratis</i> since he never told him to do it, and he must compensate him.</span>
Numerous <i>Poskim</i> endorse Rema’s posture,<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">See the list of <i>teshuvot</i> recorded in <i>Teshuvot Maharam Alsheikh</i> 70; <i>Teshuvot Maharitz</i> 2, <i>EH</i> 21; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 345; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 134; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 70:28; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i> 246:1; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 246:5; <i>PDR</i> 11:278, 282–283.<br>Given the contradictory rulings found in <i>Rema</i>, op. cit., some <i>Aharonim</i> view this matter as a halakhic-legal doubt and therefore, one cannot extract money from the beneficiary. See <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 363; <i>Teshuvot Noda-be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>HM</i> 34; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 119; <i>Teshuvot Doveiv Meisharim</i> 1:42.</i> contending that an individual is entitled to a fee for services rendered whether he was duly empowered by another to perform these actions, or whether he performed these services on his own initiative, provided that the beneficiary of the work did not tell him to stop or communicate to him that he would not receive remuneration for his services.<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 101b; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 375:1 (in the name of <i>Rosh</i>); <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 375:1; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 2:151. Cf. <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 101b; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 101b; <i>Teshuvot Pri Tevua</i> 58; <i>Teshuvot Maharash Engel</i> 3:15.</i> The obligation to pay a commission exists regardless of whether the broker incurred actual expenses or not.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Yad Eliyahu</i> (Lublin) 74.</i> His time investment may serve as the sole justification of compensation for his services. As we may infer from Rema’s words, “If one performs an action or benefit for his friend …” Rema’s words clearly inform us that remuneration is based upon “an action or benefit,” rather than linked to an outlay of expenses.
Even if the broker acted on his own initiative or at the behest of a seller, but failed to execute a <i>kinyan</i> to demonstrate that both parties resolve that the broker has been hired to perform certain services, nevertheless, by dint of benefiting from his services, the seller must pay.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharach Ohr Zarua</i> 3; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 476; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 106; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 2:56; <i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 3:66; <i>Teshuvot Maharash</i> 1:37.</i> As Rav Hai Gaon exclaims,<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hemda Genuza</i> 135.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Is it possible that all employees and brokers require a <i>kinyan</i>? Rather, the benefit that [the employer] receives because [the employee] works for his needs, he undertakes to obligate himself.</span>
In fact, according to certain authorities, a broker is viewed as an agent,<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:61, 2:56; <i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 3:66; <i>Teshuvot Ba’i Hayei</i> vol.1, <i>HM</i> 166; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>EH</i> 212.</i> and as such there is no requirement to execute a <i>kinyan</i>.
Moreover, even if the seller expressly states that he does not want a broker or refuses to pay him, if he subsequently benefits from the broker’s work, he is obligated to pay him.<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pri Tevua</i>, supra n. 16.</i> As one <i>beit din</i> states,<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 13:34, 37.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The act of sale was facilitated by the broker they wanted, and they themselves are deriving benefit from it, yet they are unwilling to pay for the brokering efforts … and they must pay the broker his commission even though they refuse to pay …</span>
Alternatively, as contended in a recent Israeli <i>beit din</i> decision, if the <i>minhag</i> as reflected in the prevailing law is to remit compensation for brokerage services, then there is a tacit assumption between the parties that the broker is entitled the market fee for his services.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">File no. 72059, Eretz Hemda-Gazit Beit Din, July 16, 2012. For precedent opinion, see <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 4:125.</i>
The question is at what point is a broker entitled to receive his commission? Assuming that a contract of sale was executed between the parties and subsequently, prior to the closing, the prospective buyer had a change of heart, is the broker entitled to his commission? Addressing this scenario, Rabbi Arye Balchover concludes,<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Shem Arye</i>, <i>HM</i> 32.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Since the actual act [of closing] did not transpire he can change his mind and refrain from the purchase. Therefore he is exempt from paying him … and the assumption is that he did not obligate himself unless the transaction was finalized.</span>
Such an approach, which requires both the execution of a contract for sale as well as an actual closing, resonates in the rulings of others.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Noda-be-Yehuda</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i>, <i>HM</i> 36; <i>Teshuvot Nehar Afarsemon</i>, <i>HM</i> 1; <i>Teshuvot Pe’at Negev</i> 2; <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sekhirut</i> 23; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 154.</i> However, there are others who contend that the actual closing is not determinative of whether the broker earns his commission. For example, if prior to the closing, both parties decide to withdraw from the deal, the broker is entitled to receive his commission.<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rif</i>, Leitner ed., 76; <i>Teshuvot Sha’ar Ephraim</i> 150; <i>Teshuvot Even Hefetz</i> 22.</i> On the other hand, if the change of heart is due to <i>mekach ta’ut</i>, an error in the transaction such as if the foundations of the home are not sturdy, then the broker will not receive his fee.<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Pe’ulat Tzadik</i> 119.</i> Since the broker was unable to finalize the deal due to a defect in the physical integrity of the property, the seller is exempt from paying him a commission. In such circumstances, even if the broker received the commission, he must return the fee to the seller.<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Levush Mordekhai</i> 2, <i>HM</i> 15; <i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i> 2, <i>HM</i> 136; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, <i>HM</i> 185:10; <i>Teshuvot Halikhot Yisrael</i> 66.</i>
Alternatively, the time of a commission payment is dependent upon <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, commercial practice.<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 185:10; <i>Levush</i>, <i>HM</i> 185:10; <i>Beit Shmuel</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 50:23. See also <i>Teshuvot Maharashach</i> 2:229.</i> If the prevailing practice is that the broker’s fee is payable upon closing the deal, then and only then is the seller obligated to pay. However, if the custom is that the fee for services is contingent upon a broker identifying a willing, able, and ready purchaser, then remittance is due upon the execution of a contract for sale. In eighteenth-century Izmir, Turkey, the <i>minhag</i> was that if the broker procured a buyer and the closing was cancelled, absent any mutually agreed imposition of a penalty for the cancellation, the broker is not entitled to his fee. On the other hand, if the agreement stipulated a penalty for withdrawing from a contract for sale, then the broker is entitled to a commission from the party who defaulted on the deal.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i> vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 137; <i>Teshuvot Ruach Hayyim</i> (Palache), <i>HM</i> 185; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 6:54.</i> However, if the agreement between the parties differs from <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, the agreement trumps <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> and the terms of the agreement are determinative.<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, supra n. 29.</i>
In short, in the absence of a written agreement to the contrary, a broker’s fee in NJ is payable upon the execution of a contract for sale either based on <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, which is reflective of state law, or based on the aforesaid rulings that argue that a broker’s job is completed upon the completion of the work, i.e., either the sale of the property or the actual closing.
Finally, there was discussion regarding the varying understandings of a particular clause of the agreement over whether the <i>Tove’a</i> is entitled to his fee if another broker had showed the property to a third party and the party subsequently purchased the property from the <i>Nitva</i> prior to the expiration of the listing agreement. Due to the vagueness of this provision as well as others, <i>Nitva</i> contends that he did not understand some of the terms of the agreement and he therefore should not be responsible to pay any commission to the <i>Tove’a</i>. Relying upon precedent, in a recent NJ case, the court states,<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kislak, Inc. vs. Abraham Schlosser and Hanco Property Management</i>, Superior Ct. of NJ, County of Middlesex Law Division, Docket No. MID-L-3229-10.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The law will not make a better contract for parties than they themselves have seen fit to enter into … The judicial function of a court of law is to enforce a contract as it is written. <i>Kupfersmith v. Delaware Insurance Co</i>., 84 NJL 271 (1913) … Burying one’s head in the sand might be a strategy for signatories to contracts, particularly in the absence of any evidence that was coercion or undue influence in the procurement of defendant’s execution of the agreement.</span>
This civil recognition that “<i>ignorantia legis neminem excusat</i>” (lit. “ignorance of the law does not excuse”) resonates in Halakha. Addressing a scenario of a party who signed off on a document and subsequently advances the plea that he isn’t literate in the language of the document, Rashba rules that his signature obligates him to the agreement’s terms because there is a presumption that he read it prior to signing or that he relied on others to explain to him the terms prior to affixing his signature to the document.<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhosot le-Ramban</i> 77.</i> This approach that ignorance of Halakha is no defense is endorsed by Shulhan Arukh and Rema.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 40:1, 45:3, 61:13; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 66:13, <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 61:13.</i> Under certain extenuating circumstances, such as an individual who, for emotional reasons, cannot relate to what is written, such as a bride regarding a <i>ketuba</i>, the claim that one failed to comprehend or foresee what he was signing is a defense.<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:1156 cited by <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>HM</i> 147:8; <i>Teshuvot Ginat Veradim</i>, <i>EH</i> 4:14; <i>PDR</i> 9:152, 160.</i> In our case, <i>Nitva</i> was neither emotionally distraught nor were the agreement’s terms unforeseeable.
We have concluded that <i>Nitva</i> is not obligated to pay a commission, and therefore <i>Nitva</i>’s claim that the rate of commission is too high is irrelevant to our judgment. Nevertheless, we will reply to <i>Nitva</i>’s contention. Rabbi Ya’akov ha-Levi Ettinger of seventeenth-century Salonika contends that the resolution of this matter is contingent upon the scope of the Talmudic rule <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>, the law of the kingdom is the law.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 28a; <i>Gittin</i> 10b; <i>Bava Kama</i> 113a–b; <i>Bava Batra</i> 44b–45a.</i> The question is whether the regulation of real estate matters can be validated based upon this rule. As Rabbi Ettinger elucidates, this question depends on whether we accept Rema’s view or the Shakh’s position regarding the parameters of this rule.<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> (Ettinger) 2:111.</i> In Rema’s opinion, all matters may be subsumed under the rubric of “<i>le-takanat ha-medina</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 73:14, 369:11.</i> which is understood by Rema as referring to any issues relating to social interaction.<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 369.</i> Vigorously disagreeing with Rema, Shakh contends that if a particular secular law contradicts Halakha, <i>dina de-malkhuta</i> will not govern.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 73:39; <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i>, <i>Likkutim</i> 16:1. Interestingly enough, a number of <i>Rishonim</i> and the majority of <i>Aharonim</i> adopt Rema’s posture. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba ha-Meyuhosot le-Ramban</i> 22; <i>Levush Ir Shushan</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:11; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Emet</i> 12; <i>Teshuvot Zera Avraham</i>, <i>HM</i> 8; <i>Teshuvot Doveiv Meisharim</i> 1:76. Normative Halakha follows Shakh’s position.</i> In our scenario there is no conflict between Halakha and NJ case law regarding this matter. Both legal systems argue that the fee for a broker’s services is reflective of <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashakh</i> 1:79; <i>Teshuvot Ginat Veradim</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:1; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> (Ettinger), supra n. 37, 2:103; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>EH</i> 1:116; <i>Teshuvot Mahane Hayyim</i> 5:15 (in the name of <i>Hatam Sofer</i> and <i>Imrei Eish</i>); <i>Teshuvot Maharam Brisk</i> 1:67; <i>Teshuvot Panim Meirot</i> 2:63.</i> NJ commercial practice is that the fee is negotiable,<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">E. Lank and J. Sobeck, <i>Essentials of NJ Real Estate</i>, 10th ed., 29.<br></i> and the parties agreed upon a six percent commission, a rate that frequently is negotiated for such a property. In fact, throughout the lands of our dispersion, whether it was sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Salonika, seventeenth-century Egypt, nineteenth-century Galicia or twentieth-century Israel, <i>Poskim</i> utilized <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> as the guideline for validating the rate of a brokerage commission.<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maharshakh</i>, supra n. 41; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 2:103; <i>Teshuvot Ginat Veradim</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:1; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, <i>Kuntres Aharon</i>, p. 56; <i>PDR</i> 10:284–285; <i>Dinei Mamonot</i> vol. 2, <i>sha’ar</i> 3, 8:1.</i>

f) Dual Real Estate Commission, Illegal Contracts, and Civil Law

<b>F. Dual Real Estate Commission, Illegal Contracts, and Civil Law</b>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Century Realty Agency v. Aaron Levy</i></span>
<b>Facts</b>
Century Realty Agency (hereafter: <i>Tove’a</i>), a New York licensed real estate brokerage agency located in Monticello, NY that is owned and managed by a Torah observant Jew, entered into an exclusive written brokerage agreement with Simcha Cohen (henceforth: the Seller), whereby <i>Tove’a</i> would show commercial properties for sale by the Seller, and upon procuring a ready and willing buyer, <i>Tove’a</i> would receive a 6% commission from the Seller. Additionally, unbeknownst to the Seller, <i>Tove’a</i> executed a written agreement with Aaron Levy (hereafter: <i>Nitva</i>) whereby, the <i>Nitva</i> would remit a 6% commission to the <i>Tove’a</i> should he, the <i>Nitva</i>, purchase the property from the Seller. Though <i>Tove’a</i> failed to sign off on the real estate commission agreement, <i>Nitva</i> signed off on the agreement.
<i>Nitva</i>’s offer to purchase the property was accepted by the Seller. At the closing, the closing documentation stated that the Seller had remitted the commission to <i>Tove’a</i>. Moreover, at the time, <i>Nitva</i>’s attorney for the closing communicated to the <i>Tove’a</i> that his client would not be paying any additional commission to the <i>Tove’a</i>.
The matter was submitted to <i>beit din</i> for resolution.
<b><i>Tove’a</i>’s Claims</b>
Admittedly, <i>Tove’a</i> failed to sign off on the commission agreement. However, since <i>Nitva</i> signed off on a written agreement that he would remit a second commission regarding the purchase of the property, he is bound to the terms of the agreement, and therefore <i>Nitva</i> is obligated to remit the second commission. Even though <i>Tove’a</i> failed to sign off on the agreement, <i>Nitva</i> is not exempt from paying, because at the time of the agreement, <i>Nitva</i> shook hands with the <i>Tove’a</i>, in effect acknowledging his obligation to pay the commission.
<b><i>Nitva</i>’s Claims</b>
Admittedly, he signed off on the real estate commission agreement. However, given that <i>Tove’a</i> did not sign off, he is not legally bound to remit the commission. Moreover, <i>Nitva</i> argues that he shook <i>Tove’a</i>’s hand out of courtesy, namely, as an acknowledgement to the real estate agency for the brokerage services provided, rather than as a means of acknowledging that he will remit a commission to <i>Tove’a</i>. In addition, at the time of the closing, <i>Nitva</i>’s attorney communicated to the <i>Tove’a</i> that his client would not be paying a second commission.
Finally, since the property was located in New York, New York real estate law applies to the sale. Consequently, dual agency is prohibited under New York law in the absence of written disclosure to the Seller. Therefore, the agreement executed between the <i>Tove’a</i> and <i>Nitva</i> is an illegal contract and is unenforceable.
<b>Discussion</b>
<b>1. <i>Da’at ha-Rov</i> (The Majority Opinion)</b>
The threshold question is whether a Seller who promises to pay a commission above the market rate is obligated to pay. One view is that if the Seller promised to pay above the market rate, he is obligated to pay the promised amount.<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 172 (in the name of R. Simha, <i>Ohr Zarua</i>, and <i>Sefer ha-Hokhma</i>); <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 106a, s.v. “<i>ein</i>”; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 3:20; <i>Teshuvot Mishpat Tzedek</i> 3:71; <i>Teshuvot Lehem Rav</i> 227; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 1:97 in the name of <i>Shevut Ya’akov</i> 2:157 and <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 90.</i> However, others hold that he is obligated to pay the entire amount, provided that he executed a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i> (a symbolic act of undertaking an obligation) or <i>shtar hov</i> (a halakhically valid document of obligation),<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 169:8, 264:4, and 81:4; <i>Orhot Mishpatim</i> vol. 1, <i>Shadhanut</i> 6:7; <i>Teshuvot Mishpetei Shmuel</i> 78; <i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i>, <i>HM</i> 135. See also <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh Kelal</i> 64; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 264:8; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 2:157; <i>Teshuvot Beit Meir</i> 47; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, <i>HM</i> 185; <i>Teshuvot Panim Meirot</i> 1:97.</i> or undertook a <i>shevuah</i> (an oath).<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 264:4 and 81:4; <i>Tashbetz</i>, supra n. 1; <i>Orhot Mishpatim</i>, supra n. 2.</i> A promise to undertake a future action without an accompanying <i>kinyan</i> is a <i>kinyan devarim</i> (a promise),<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 3a; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 7:8.</i> and therefore unenforceable in <i>beit din</i>.
Other <i>Poskim</i>, relying upon the ruling of Maharam, Rema, Shakh, and others, argue that since the client can always allege that he was jesting (“<i>hashata</i>”) and therefore never seriously intended to pay such a rate, the seller is obligated to pay only the prevailing market rate.<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 172 (in the name of <i>Maharam</i>); <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, <i>Hut ha-Meshulash</i> 62; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh Kelal</i> 64:3; <i>Teshuvot ha-Bah</i> 28; <i>Rema</i>, <i>Darkhei Moshe ha-Arukh</i> 264; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 264:7; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rema</i> 86; <i>Teshuvot Hikrei Lev</i> 2:135; <i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 3, 63; <i>Levush</i>, <i>HM</i> 264:7; <i>Panim Meirot</i>, supra n. 2; <i>Beit Meir</i>, supra n. 2; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 264:14–15; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 154, 186; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 58.</i> Therefore, if the seller still retains the funds and has not transferred them to the agent, he can argue that he is relying upon the <i>Poskim</i> who contend that the agent is only entitled to the market rate commission.<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hukot ha-Hayyim</i> (Palache), <i>HM</i> 29; <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>HM</i> 264:4; <i>Teshuvot Ba’ei Hayyei</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:80; <i>Teshuvot Maharashakh</i> 2:80.</i> Even if the seller does not advance the argument in <i>beit din</i>, the <i>beit din</i> can advance this argument for him.<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 81:1.</i> The latter position is corroborated based upon the following Halakha: If the Buyer advances to the agent a portion of the compensation, and after completing his services, refuses to pay the balance because he argues that the balance exceeds the market rate, he is exempt from remitting the balance.<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 81:26; <i>Sma</i>, ad locum 53; <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i> 81:16.</i>
Based upon the foregoing, the panel adopted the position that as long as there was a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i>, the Seller would be duty-bound to pay a commission that exceeded the market rate. Similarly, in our scenario, should the Buyer have promised to pay a commission above the market rate by executing a <i>kinyan</i>, the <i>Nitva</i> would be obligated to remit the funds.
Finally, even if it there was a <i>kinyan</i>, nevertheless when you are still engaged in the matter (i.e., <i>asukim be’oto inyan</i>), one has a right to rescind the offer even though a handshake was executed.<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kesef ha-Kodshin</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 195:1; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 195:14; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 195:5.</i> At the time of the real estate closing (i.e., <i>asukim be’oto inyan</i>), the <i>Nitva</i> and his attorney said no such monies would be forthcoming, and therefore the commitment dissolved.
In light of the cumulative evidence that there is a dispute between the parties whether in fact <i>Nitva</i> shook the <i>Tove’a</i>’s hands acknowledging his obligation to remit the commission, the majority of the panel concluded that in cases where the fact(s) are in doubt, we invoke <i>peshara</i> (compromise)<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 12:5; <i>Urim ve-Tumim</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 12:5.</i> and obligate <i>Nitva</i> to pay one-third of the commission for services provided by the <i>Tove’a</i>.
<b>2. <i>Da’at Me’ut</i> (The Minority Opinion)</b>
<i>Kinyan situmta</i> refers to a <i>kinyan</i> that is effective to undertake a commitment (i.e., <i>hit’hayivut</i>) or transfer of items (i.e., <i>hakna’ah</i>) based upon <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>. Paris in the twelfth century, thirteenth-century Provence, fifteenth-century Algeria, sixteenth-century Spain, and twentieth-century Galicia, as well as other places, a handshake was a method of <i>kinyan</i>, to undertake an obligation.<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">R. Hayyim, <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 5:72; <i>Hiddushim</i> attributed to <i>Ritva</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a; <i>Tashbetz</i> 1:94; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur YD</i> 239:5; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 201:1.</i> Echoing Shulhan Arukh and Rema’s rulings,<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:1; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:2, <i>Rema</i>, ad locum.</i> R. Yisrael Grossman of the twentieth century opines,<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Halikhot Yisrael</i> 8.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If the sale is finalized via commercial practice such as … via <i>situmta</i> or by a handshake accompanied by saying “<i>mazal u-brakha</i>” <i>…</i> the parties are obligated to compensate the broker in accordance with the local practice.</span>
However, today the finalization of an agreement regarding a real estate commission is performed through executing a real estate commission agreement rather than a handshake.
<b>Moreover, even if some people finalize a commission agreement via a <i>tekia’at kaf</i> (handshake), such a <i>kinyan</i> will only be effective if the majority of the residents of the New York community practice this form of <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nimukei Yosef</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i>, beginning of ch. 7 (52a), in the name of <i>Rashba</i> and <i>Ran</i>; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 331:1; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 72; <i>Sdei Hemed</i>, <i>Kelalim</i>, <i>Ma’arekhet ha-Mem</i>, p. 248, s.v. “<i>u-minhag shelo</i>”; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 3:152.</i> And today, most residents do not handshake to finalize a real estate commission arrangement.</b>
Consequently, the fact that there exists a doubt regarding the motivation and circumstances leading up to the handshake is irrelevant. Even assuming that the handshake was executed in order to undertake a commitment to pay a commission, given that it is no longer a legally recognized vehicle to finalize agreements,<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote"><i>PDR</i> 12:279; <i>Teshuvot Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 3:5.</i> it cannot be viewed as a <i>kinyan situmta</i>.
Though, to the best of my knowledge, there is no explicit discussion regarding the propriety of a broker receiving two commissions, one from the Seller and one from the Buyer, nevertheless an inference can be drawn from a dispute amongst <i>Rishonim</i> (early authorities) that deals with two principals who appoint a <i>shaliach</i> (an agent) to purchase an asset. The dispute emerges from the discussion in Bava Metzia regarding two principals who placed their money in a common purse, but the <i>shaliach</i> acquires the property for only one of the principals.<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a.</i> In that case, Rava rules that though the <i>shaliach</i>, in actuality, was working for only one of the principals, nonetheless the property is acquired by both principals. According to R. Meir Abulafia (Rama), Rava’s decision applies even if the <i>shaliach</i> explicitly states prior to becoming involved in the transaction that his intent is to buy for one of the principals. In contrast, Rid contends that Rava’s ruling extends only to a principal who fails to reveal his intent. However, if he explicitly states prior to the execution of the transaction that his intent is to purchase the asset for one principal only, then the asset is only acquired for that that principal.<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 184; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 184:2; H. Zippori, “The Laws of Agency,” Section 17, Israel’s Ministry of Justice.</i> The common denominator of Rava’s position is that both principals knew that each of them appointed the identical <i>shaliach</i>, and there is a dispute regarding whether the property has been acquired by either both principals or only one of them. However, in a scenario in which one principal (the Seller) is unaware of the existence of a second principal, such agency would be invalid. Therefore, in our scenario, where the agent, the <i>Tove’a</i>, did not disclose to the Seller that there is a second principal, there would be no grounds for receiving a second commission from the Buyer, the <i>Nitva</i>.
The outstanding matter to address is the legal and halakhic consequences of the written agreement signed between <i>Tove’a</i> and <i>Nitva</i>. Legally, a real estate broker has a fiduciary relationship to his client and therefore has the duty not to act for a party whose interests are adverse to those of the principal, unless full disclosure has been communicated to the Seller. Accordingly, the broker cannot serve as an agent for both the Seller and the Buyer.<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Matter of Goldstein v. Department of State, Division of Licensing Services</i>, 144 AD 2d 463, 464; <i>Kenneth D. Laub &amp; Co. v. Bear Stearns Cos.</i>, 278 AD 121, 718 NYS 2d 45, NY AD 2000; <i>Queens Structure Corp. v. Jay Lawrence Assoc.</i>, 304 AD 2d 736, 758 NYS 2d 664, NY AD 2003.</i> In particular, in our case, the existence of an exclusive brokerage agreement with the Seller is inherently at odds with any dual brokerage arrangement. There are conflicts inherent in a dual agency. The dual agent owes both the Seller and prospective buyer the same degree of care and duty as he would if he represented each alone. In many real estate dealings this is impossible due to the contrasting motivations of the Seller and Buyer, and the broker’s duty of disclosure.<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">10 P. Rohan, B. Goldstein &amp; C. Bobis, <i>Real Estate Brokerage Law and Practice</i>, section 3.06, at 3–39 (1987).</i> Unlike a dual brokerage arrangement in which the parties agree to a lower standard of fiduciary ties and the broker may be acting in the Buyer’s interests to the detriment of the Seller’s interests, an exclusive brokerage arrangement propels the broker to consider only the Seller’s interests and receives the broker’s undivided loyalty. Adopting this perspective, a broker who has signed off on an exclusive brokerage agreement who decides to receive a second commission from the Buyer is in actuality accepting what amounts to a bribe. The submission of such payments subverts the brokering process and undermines the Seller’s interests. If a broker accepts two commissions, the Seller can claim that had the broker disclosed the second commission, he would have offered him a lower rate. Since the double commission was undisclosed, the Seller is unaware of the option that he could have requested a lower commission from the broker. Finally, legally, the written agreement signed between the broker and <i>Nitva</i> is an illegal contract and therefore unenforceable in a civil court.
Turning to Halakha, the threshold question is whether any <i>issur</i> (prohibition) was violated by signing off on a second commission arrangement. As we know, according to Halakha, “<i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>” (the law of the kingdom is the law). According to most decisors, any matters relating to <i>karka</i> (real property), such as taxation, eminent domain, etc., require an observant Jew’s compliance.<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ohr Zarua</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 3:447; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:895; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 194:2, 369:2, 6.</i> Failure to abide by the law in such instances may entail a violation of a Torah prohibition.<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avnei Miluim</i> 28:2; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314. Cf. <i>Beit Shmuel, SA EH</i> 28:3; <i>Teshuvot Binyan Tzion</i> 2:15.</i> Real estate law, including guidelines for brokerage arrangements, ought to be subsumed under this category of <i>karka</i>, and therefore would require compliance.<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> (Ettinger) 111.</i> Alternatively, pursuant to Rema, accepted by the majority of <i>Poskim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Doveiv Meisharim</i> 1:76.</i> civil law governs all matters that are “<i>le-takanat bnei ha-medina</i>” (for the benefit of the citizenry), understood by <i>Rema</i> as referring to any issues relating to social interaction.<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Darkhei Moshe</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 369; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 73:14, 369:11.</i> As we mentioned, the implementation of a dual brokerage fee without written disclosure means that the Seller has unknowingly given up his right to the agent’s undivided loyalty. As such, his illegal conduct impacts upon social interaction, in addition to falling under the rubric of <i>geneivat da’at</i> (verbal deception).
Though Shakh vigorously disagrees with Rema and contends that if a particular secular law contradicts Halakha, <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> does not apply,<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 73:39.</i> nevertheless, one can infer from <i>hilkhot shelihut</i> involving two principals that the payment of two commissions to a broker is not countenanced by Halakha.
