In Bava Metzia,<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a.</i> Rava addresses the case of principals who place their money in a common purse, but the <i>shaliach</i> acquired property for only one of the principals. Rava concludes that though the <i>shaliach</i> is working for one of the principals, nevertheless the property is acquired by both principals. According to Rama, the <i>psak</i> of Rava applies even if the <i>shaliach</i> explicitly states prior to becoming involved in the commercial mandate that he intends to acquire the property for only one of the principals. In contrast, <i>Rid</i> argues that Rava’s ruling applies to a principal who doesn’t disclose his intent. However, if he explicitly states before the execution of the transaction that he intends to purchase the asset for one principal, then the asset is only acquired for that principal.<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 184; <i>Bi’ur ha-Gra</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 184:2; H. Zippori, Multiplicity of Principals and Agents, Yerushalayim: Ministry of Justice.</i>
Based upon this dispute, in accordance with Rama, payment of two commissions without disclosure to the Seller would be permissible. Rama contends that if the <i>shaliach</i> explicitly states that his intent is to acquire in the name of one principal, the asset is acquired by both. Similarly, in our case, when the broker, as <i>shaliach</i>, is working for the Seller and Buyer, he can exhibit a sense of loyalty to both principals and therefore can receive a commission from both. On the other hand, in accordance with Rid, if the <i>shaliach</i> explicitly states that he is working for one principal only, the asset is acquired by this principal. Consequently, in our scenario, Rid would concur that there are no grounds for a double commission. If, in Rava’s case, intent to work for one principal casts into doubt his loyalty toward the other principal, if the broker fails to disclose the double commission arrangement to the Seller, we would reach a similar conclusion. Various <i>Poskim</i> including Tur and Rema follow the Rid’s opinion.<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, ibid.; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 184:1.</i> Since according to Tur and Rema there is a basis for outlawing the two-commission arrangement, Shakh would concur that one must comply with the secular legislation.
Secondly, the notion that a broker can receive a commission from both the Seller and the Buyer is also contradicted by another <i>sugya</i> (Talmudic discussion), which argues that one person cannot represent two individuals. This is the <i>sugya</i> dealing with the dividing up of a father’s assets amongst orphans. Halakha states that one is required to appoint two <i>apotroposim</i> (guardians) to deal with this transaction. As such, each <i>apotropus</i> would be able to advance the <i>zekhut</i> (right) of each orphan.<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 77b and <i>Ketuvot</i> 100a; <i>Tosafot</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>borerim</i>”; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 33b; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva Kiddushin</i> 43a.</i> Here again, the notion that one person can represent two individuals who may have contradictory interests is rejected by Halakha. Analogously, a broker cannot receive a dual commission from the Buyer as well as a Seller without full disclosure to the Seller, lest the Seller’s interests be subverted. As such, even Shakh would agree that compliance with secular law is required.
Alternatively, we may invoke <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>, relying upon Hatam Sofer’s teaching:
<span class="poetry indentAll">If the matter had been submitted to us, we would have legislated it!<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 44.</i></span>
The backdrop for Hatam Sofer’s statement was the nineteenth-century Eastern European regulation that only licensed wine brokers may sell wine and liquor. Concerned with the monopolistic ramifications of this civil law and the attendant economic harm foisted upon non-licensed wine brokerages, members of the Jewish community approached Hatam Sofer to express his opinion regarding this regulation. In reply, Hatam Sofer argued that it is desirable to regulate economic competition, and that there is precedent in Jewish legal history for protecting the right of people to make a living, and therefore, the civil regulation makes sense. Hatam Sofer concludes that if the Jewish community had been empowered in his time to pass such legislation, they would have done it without hesitation. The notion that “if the matter had been submitted to us, we would have legislated it!” reverberates in the subsequent nineteenth- and twentieth-century rulings of Rabbis Yitzhak Schmelkes, Shlomo Z. Auerbach, Eliezer Waldenburg, Yitzhak Nissim, Yosef Elyashiv, and Shmuel Wosner who ruled in various contexts that <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> is applicable to such scenarios.<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i> 75, 77:3; <i>Teshuvot Hit’orerut Teshuva</i> 232; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 44; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Shlomo</i> 1:87; <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 12:83; <i>PDR</i> 6:382 (R. Elyashiv and R. Nissim’s opinions); <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 10:291.</i>
In the absence of an explicit halakhic prohibition outlawing dual agency without full disclosure to the Seller, and in light of a contrary understanding of Rava’s ruling,<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 184:1 draws other conclusions from Rava’s ruling and therefore would implicitly argue that this Talmudic discussion has no implication for the matter of the propriety of a broker accepting a double commission.</i> we nevertheless invoke Hatam Sofer’s approach that “had the matter been submitted to us, we would have legislated it!”
Common sense dictates that Halakha follow secular law by prohibiting the above type of dual agency in order to promote trust and confidence between the Seller and the broker.
Seemingly, this approach undermines Hazon Ish’s position that “everything is explicit in our Torah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 16:1.</i> According to Hazon Ish, Halakha as a legal system has explicit rules that encompass the entire gamut of human relations. Hatam Sofer’s approach, which embraces secular law, seems to stand in bold contrast to Hazon Ish’s viewpoint. However, perhaps we need to translate the notion of an “explicit rule” loosely, as denoting any rule that can be inferred from Halakha. Therefore, though as we noted, there is no explicit discussion addressing the propriety of a dual agency and a two-commission arrangement, nevertheless, we may infer from the discussion of the aforementioned ruling of Rava and the teaching regarding the appointment of guardians for orphans, that Halakha would disapprove of such an arrangement.
In sum, the teachings relating to <i>shelihut</i> and <i>apotropus</i> implicitly reject the permissibility of an arrangement of dual brokerage commissions. Secondly, the execution of the agreement between <i>Tove’a</i> and <i>Nitva</i> is in contravention of <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> for one of the four forthcoming reasons: (1) Matters of brokerage are to be subsumed in the category of “<i>karka</i>”; (2) issues of brokerage are to be subsumed under the rubric of “<i>le-takanat bnei ha-Medina</i>”; (3) the secular legislation resonates in the teachings of Tur and Rema regarding agency and the discussion dealing with the appointment of guardians for orphans; and (4) secular law prohibiting dual commission fees is an example of equitable legislation and therefore should receive our halakhic stamp of approval.
In short, the agreement executed between the Seller and Buyer is an illegal and unenforceable contract under secular law. Halakhically, this agreement entails an <i>issur</i>, namely failing to comply with secular law, and at first glance, payment of such monies involves the violation of an <i>issur</i>. Hence, seemingly <i>Tove’a</i> is not entitled to these monies. And, in fact, there are some <i>Poskim</i>, notably Rabbis Y. Trani, Y. Rosannes, and K. Zuckerman who arrive at this conclusion.<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharit</i> 2, <i>YD</i> 38; <i>Mishneh le-Melekh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Issurei Mizbei’ach</i> 4:13; <i>Teshuvot Minhat ha-Komeitz</i> 1:117.</i>
However, most authorities rule otherwise. For example, the following agreements which involve the commission of a sin remain enforceable in a <i>beit din</i>: a loan transaction with a <i>ribbit</i> clause,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i> and <i>SA</i>, <i>YD</i> 161:11, <i>HM</i> 52:1. Though the creditor cannot collect the <i>ribbit</i>, he can recover his principal.</i> an agreement to hire false witnesses,<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 9.</i> a matchmaker who introduced a <i>kohen</i> to a divorcee for the sake of marriage is entitled to a commission,<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">See ibid.</i> an agreement to litigate a matter in civil court,<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashbash</i> 331; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 22:15; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:11.</i> and an agreement to engage in an illicit affair.<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ohr Zarua Bava Kama</i> 157; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 2:136; <i>PDR</i> 9:16, 37–38.</i> In all these instances, though a sin was committed, nevertheless by dint of the fact that the individual obligated himself to pay for a certain service, he is duty-bound to compensate for the service rendered. As R. Y. Bassan teaches us,<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari Bassan</i> 84.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If somebody says to his friend, please do this and this for me, and his friend did what is required, he is obligated to give him what he said he would give even though it involved a matter of sin …</span>
Translating this rabbinic formulation into legalese, Professor Moshe Silberg, a renowned twentieth-century Israeli jurist observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Moshe Silberg, <i>Talmudic Law and the Modern State</i>, New York: Burning Bush, 1973, 82.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We see clearly that Jewish law does not establish a causal connection between the commission of an offense and the voiding of a civil contract … The violation of the law or morality is one thing, and the legal validity of the contract is another – to the extent that the fulfilling of the contract itself does not activate the offense … Precisely because Jewish law does not distinguish between law and morality, and that practically every performance of an obligation is at the same time a fulfillment of a religio-moral commandment – as “the commandment” of repaying a debt of monetary obligation – the non-fulfillment of a contract entered into through a violation of law will only turn out to be an additional offense to supplement the original one committed by the transgressor.</span>
In other words, though, for example, there is a prohibition against the taking of <i>ribbit</i>, of submitting false testimony, of a <i>kohen</i> marrying a divorcee, of litigating one’s case in civil court, and of engaging in an illicit affair, nevertheless, as long as the actual agreement between to the parties (involving these <i>issurim</i>) complies with the norms of the halakhic law of obligations, monies are to be remitted. The illegality arises from the act of <i>issur</i> itself (e.g., taking <i>ribbit</i>, submitting false testimony) and therefore does not impact the fact that an agreement was executed that entails payment of money for undertaking the act of <i>issur</i>. Seemingly, based upon the foregoing, the <i>Nitva</i> should pay the commission. Given that the element of illegality involved in a dual brokerage fee does not invalidate the agreement, <i>Nitva</i> ought to remit the monies owed to <i>Tove’a</i>.
Nevertheless, despite the foregoing, halakhic policy is to refuse to validate such a monetary payment, because such a stance would compromise the role of a <i>beit din</i> to be vigilant in <i>afrushei me-issura</i> (preventing improper conduct).<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tashbetz</i> 2:98–99; <i>Teshuvot Mahane Hayyim</i> 2:21; <i>Yeshuot Yisrael</i>, <i>HM</i> 22.</i>
However, upon a closer reading of these rulings, we find that our scenario is readily distinguishable from the others. In the cases of an agreement to hire false witnesses, a matchmaker who introduced a <i>kohen</i> to a divorcee, an agreement to litigate a matter in civil court, and an agreement to engage in an illicit affair, although the agreement is prohibited, the payment is not tainted. The prohibition does not affect the monetary obligation. On the other hand, in our case, both the actual payment of the double commission and the execution of the agreement are halakhically (and legally) improper. And in such a situation, Halakha will not validate a tainted remittance of monies. For example, if there is legislation that the sale of a bottle of wine cannot exceed fifty dollars, and a Jew sold a bottle for fifty-five dollars, the seller must return five dollars to the buyer.<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharam Alsheikh</i> 75; <i>Teshuvot Maharitz</i> 16; Eliav Shochetman, <i>Illegality of an Act</i> (Hebrew), Yerushalayim, 1981, 232–233.</i> In effect, this is similar to how Halakha deals with a loan transaction that has a provision for <i>ribbit</i>. Namely, the borrower can recover the principal, but the <i>ribbit</i> cannot be collected, and if he collected <i>ribbit</i>, he must return it to the lender.
Similarly, if a broker received a second commission from the Buyer, he is obligated to return the monies to the Buyer. And therefore, in our case, should we mandate that the Buyer remit a commission to the broker, it would be halakhically prohibited due to the fact that it is a violation of civil law.
Finally, there is a rule, either in accordance with the <i>din</i>, black-letter Halakha,<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Yashar</i>, <i>Helek ha-Hiddushim</i> 112.</i> or as a penalty,<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ra’avad</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hovel u-Mazik</i> 4:16.</i> that a sinner cannot benefit from his wrongdoing.<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 92b.</i> Therefore, since a double commission given to the broker is halakhically prohibited due to its non-disclosure to the Seller, which is a violation of civil law as well as minimally the interdict against <i>geneviat da’at</i>, Halakha does not permit him to benefit from his improper conduct.
Based upon the foregoing, the <i>Nitva</i> is not obligated to pay a commission to the <i>Tove’a</i>.
<b>Final Thoughts</b>
Finally, during the <i>dayanim</i>’s deliberations among themselves, the argument was raised that possibly if <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> demonstrated that real estate agents engaged in such a practice, we should direct the <i>Nitva</i> to remit the outstanding commission to the <i>Tove’a</i>. Upon review of <i>teshuvot</i> of <i>Rishonim</i> and <i>Aharonim</i>, one finds that the majority, and perhaps the overwhelming majority, of <i>Poskim</i> endorse the following approach of R. Moshe Feinstein:<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:75.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">It is clear … that in the situation of any law related to a local practice … there is no requirement that this decision be in pursuance with that of Torah scholars … Even if the custom was established by non-Jews who are the majority in that city, that custom is binding according to Torah law. It is assumed that when an agreement is executed, the inference is that the agreement conforms to local practice … and clearly, secular law is not inferior to custom …</span>
This notion that <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> is reflective of civil law resonates with many <i>Poskim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Divrei Yosef</i> 21; <i>Teshuvot Nediv Lev</i> 13; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 2:111; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Avraham</i> 1:1; <i>Teshuvot Ateret Shlomo</i> 1:88 (5) in the name of <i>Hazon Ish</i>; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 2:86; <i>PDR</i> 8:162, 164 (Rabbis Goldschmidt, Elyashiv and Zolty’s opinions). For additional <i>teshuvot</i>, see D. Frimer, “The Influence of Israeli Law upon Jewish Law” (Hebrew), 39 <i>Jewish Studies</i> 134 (5759).</i> Adopting this approach leads one to the conclusion that Halakha recognizes a commercial practice that imbibes the norms of civil law.
In other words, there is an acknowledgement that there can be a <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> that emerges from the business community. The question is whether this practice will be halakhically legitimate even if it is in variance with the law. Addressing the <i>minhag</i> amongst providers of child care services that pay their employees certain social benefits which are below what civil law mandates, R. Ya’akov Eliezrov, a <i>dayan</i> on the Yerushalayim Regional Beit Din, rules that such payments are halakhically appropriate.<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Y. Eliezrov, “An Employee who Deviates from the National Practice” (Hebrew), 20 <i>Tehumin</i> 71, 72–73 (5760).</i> On the other hand, this practice is labeled a “<i>minhag garu’a</i>” (a bad practice, due to the fact that it discriminates in comparison to the other provider networks) by R. Sherman, and he therefore rules that the providers have to pay the social benefits as prescribed by civil law.<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">A. Sherman, “National Practice in Labor Relations” (Hebrew), 18 <i>Tehumin</i> 236, 240–241 (5758). For further discussion, see ch. 4 of this monograph.</i> Consequently, should we accept the former position, then a commercial practice of dual agency with a commission paid by Seller and Buyer without disclosure to the Seller would be valid. In contrast, adopting the latter approach, such a practice would be invalid because it was a “bad custom,” since the Seller loses the undivided loyalty of the broker.
However, I will refrain from addressing my position regarding whether a <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> can be in variance with civil law, since there is a threshold question as to whether such a practice actually exists. To obtain the status of a <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, the practice must be adopted by the majority of the real estate brokerages dealing in residential sales in a given locale,<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nimukei Yosef</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i>, beginning of ch. 7, in the name of <i>Rashba</i> and <i>Ran</i>; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 331:1.</i> have occurred at least three times, and be widespread throughout the locale.<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, ibid.</i> Additionally, R. Yitzhak bar Sheshet and R. Yair Bachrach add, the commercial custom must transpire every day. In other words, whenever a real estate commission agreement is finalized, there is a provision that both the Seller and Buyer must remit commission fees to the broker.<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 475 and <i>Teshuvot Hakham Tzvi</i> 61.<br>The actual <i>psak din</i> of the majority opinion which was neither signed off by the <i>dayanim</i> nor was given to the parties, stated that the <i>Nitva</i> is obligated to pay the <i>Tove’a</i> one-third of the commission for services rendered by <i>Tove’a</i>. As occurs frequently, absent from the majority opinion is a rendition of the facts, the parties’ claims, and the panel’s reasoning. The reconstruction of the facts, parties’ claims, and the majority opinion was authored by this writer; the author of the minority opinion. This writer’s reconstruction of the majority opinion has not been reviewed by his colleagues. Prior to the issuance of the <i>psak din</i> accompanied by the minority opinion, at the request of the <i>Tove’a</i>, <i>Nitva</i> agreed to pay the award in installments.<br>Generally speaking, there is a prohibition to divulge which <i>dayan</i> ruled in favor of the <i>tove’a</i> and which <i>dayan</i> ruled in favor of the <i>nitva</i>. Therefore, the issuance of a dissenting opinion is at variance with Halakha. See <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 19:2. Nonetheless, if the d<i>ayanim</i> agree that their names be publicized, then the issuance of a minority opinion is permissible. See B.Z. Nesher, “Publicizing the names of dayanim in <i>beit din</i> rulings” (Hebrew), 6 <i>Divrei Mishpat</i> 382, 390 (5760). In fact, the <i>minhag</i> amongst <i>dayanim</i> serving on the <i>battei din</i> under the aegis of Israel’s Chief Rabbinate is to publicize their names. And in our case, the other <i>dayanim</i> on the panel agreed to disclose the author of the minority view. As mentioned, the <i>psak din</i> was not given to the parties.</i>
Addressing whether there exists in New York City a commercial practice whereby a broker receives two commissions, various real estate agencies and one attorney submitted documentation to this panel in order to ascertain the prevalence of such a practice. The submissions indicate that “it may occasionally happen,” “it is quite rare for a broker to have a dual agency … and receive two commissions,” “it occurs sometimes when there are a few potential buyers who are jumping to purchase the home,” and “commissions can, and are occasionally paid both sides.” In light of the submitted professional opinions, it is clear that dual agency coupled with two commissions occurs infrequently and therefore cannot be labeled a <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>.

g) Mekach Ta'ut, the Role of Gemirat Da'at in Undertaking Obligations in Transferring Property and Promise Keeping

<b>G. <i>Mekach Ta’ut</i>, the Role of <i>Gemirat Da’at</i> in Undertaking Obligations in Transferring Property and Promise Keeping</b>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Jardin Estates vs. Venetian Lanes</i></span>
On July 1, 2009, the above parties signed an arbitration agreement empowering this panel to resolve this matter according to applicable portions of Shulhan Arukh and <i>Poskim</i>. Both parties submitted to this <i>beit din</i> their differences and disputes in reference to various claims advanced by <i>Jardin Estates vs. Venetian Lanes</i>. Having given said matters due consideration and having heard all parties testify as to the facts of said disputes and differences; this panel does decide and agree as follows:
<b>Facts</b>
On September 29, 2008, Jardin Estates (hereafter: <i>Tove’a</i>), owned by Avraham and Sara Cohen, sold a bungalow colony located in Elizaville, New York to Venetian Lanes (hereafter: <i>Nitva</i>). At the time of the sale, a deed was issued to the <i>Tove’a</i> that granted them title to the bungalow colony. Subsequently, in exchange for the sale of the bungalow colony, a conveyance agreement assigning exclusive ownership, use, and occupancy of a bungalow unit known as “Avraham’s Tent,” was given to Mr. and Mrs. Avraham Cohen, who held the controlling interest for the <i>Tove’a</i>. The conveyance agreement reads as follows:
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Agreement between Jardin Estates and Venetian Lanes, dated September 29, 2008.</i></span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Whereas, Venetian Lanes has this date purchased from Jardin Estates, the bungalow colony known as Jardin Estates located in Elizaville, New York, and</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Whereas, as part of the consideration Avraham and Sara Cohen shall have the exclusive ownership and use of one of the bungalows located at Venetian Lanes</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Now therefore in consideration of the mutual covenants hereinafter set forth the parties agree as follows:</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">1. Avraham and Sara Cohen, their heirs and assigns shall have the exclusive use, ownership and occupancy of the bungalow located in the main house in the front called “Avraham’s Tent”.</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">2. Venetian Estates shall have the right of first refusal in the event the Cohens, their heir(s) or assigns wish to sell their interest in the bungalow, said right of first refusal shall be exercised in within 30 days after written notice is given by the Cohens to Venetian Estates.</span>
Said agreement was signed by Venetian Estates and Avraham and Sara Cohen. In reply to our questioning, Mr. Cohen confirmed that the conveyance agreement was executed after the closing. And in fact, the text of the agreement supports this admission. To date, <i>Tove’a</i> has been denied access to this bungalow unit.
<b><i>Tove’a</i>’s Claims</b>
<i>Nitva</i> paid <i>Tove’a</i> $500,000 for the purchase of the bungalow colony. In addition, <i>Nitva</i> made an oral commitment to pay <i>Tove’a</i> an additional $100,000 as a finder’s fee for the <i>Tove’a</i>’s services in brokering deals with the co-shareholders of the bungalow to enable him to sell the colony to the <i>Nitva</i>. As of today, said monies were not paid to the <i>Tove’a</i>.
Additionally, <i>Tove’a</i> is claiming $40,000 for the loss of use of the bungalow unit for four years (2008 through 2011) and the recouping of lost rental revenue due to his inability to occupy the unit.
In reply to <i>Nitva</i>’s argument that he only became aware of the problems with the sewer and pool after the purchase, <i>Tove’a</i> contends that pursuant to the sales agreement there is a general disclaimer of liability for defects, and therefore <i>Tove’a</i> is not responsible to compensate for <i>Nitva</i>’s outlay of expenses relating to the plumbing and pool repair.
<b><i>Nitva</i>’s Claims</b>
<i>Nitva</i> claims, with the corroboration of the President of Jardin Estates of 2007–2008, Tova Wahrman, that <i>Nitva</i> only became aware of the non-functioning sewer system and the pool after the September 29, 2008 purchase of the colony. Consequently, <i>Nitva</i> advances claims for $58,000 for pool repairs and $18,000 for sewerage repairs.
Though <i>Nitva</i> admits that an agreement was signed that transferred ownership of the bungalow unit to the <i>Tove’a</i>, nevertheless this agreement was halakhically invalid, and therefore <i>Nitva</i> retains ownership of the unit. Even if this <i>beit din</i> panel validates the transfer, <i>Nitva</i> claims that since the remainder of the bungalow colony is owned by <i>Nitva</i>, the <i>Tove’a</i> does not have a right of way to access his bungalow. Since an easement was not granted by the <i>Nitva</i> to the <i>Tove’a</i>, <i>Tove’a</i> cannot access his unit.
<b>Discussion</b>
Generally speaking, for an agreement between parties to be legally enforceable, one must determine whether the parties involved have resolved to finalize their arrangement. In Halakha, this is known as <i>gemirat da’at</i>. This condition must be obtained both in undertaking obligations, such as hiring an employee and agreeing to pay money for a service, and in transferring property such as a bungalow colony or a bungalow unit.
Our case addresses both types of <i>gemirat da’at</i>. Regarding transfer of property, we will first address the question: Given that the buyer became aware of the defective sewer system and pool after his purchase of the colony, did the buyer have <i>gemirat da’at</i> when he executed his purchase? Second, was the conveyance agreement a <i>bona fide</i> method to transfer the bungalow unit from the buyer to the seller? Finally, in terms of undertaking obligations, was the buyer’s promise to pay the seller additional monies above the selling price memorialized in the actual sales agreement halakhically enforceable?
<b>1. The Sale of the Bungalow Colony: Recovery of Costs for Sewage Problems and Non-Functioning Swimming Pool</b>
In our scenario, the buyer is entitled to purchase the bungalow colony relying upon the assumption that the seller’s representations are true. His <i>gemirat da’at</i> is obtained, in part, by receiving a bungalow colony free of defects. As Rashi aptly notes, a buyer can claim: “I did not intend to purchase an item with a defect.”<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 80a. See also <i>Tosafot Ketuvot</i> 47b, s.v. “<i>she-lo</i>”; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 15:6; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 40.</i>
In fact, any misrepresentation by the buyer involves <i>geneivat da’at</i> (lit. “stealing of the mind”), which entails either a violation of deception or of theft.<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Hullin</i> 94a; <i>Sha’arei Teshuva</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 3; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 403; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 228:6.<br>According to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ona’a</i> (price fraud), one is prohibited to sell an item at a price different from the market price, and when the differential between the purchase price and the market price is more than one-sixth, the sale is void. Given that both the colony and the unit are categorized as “<i>karka</i>,” immovable property, the interdict against <i>ona’a</i> is inapplicable, and therefore any misrepresentation of the properties does not entail the violation of this prohibition. (However, should there have been excessive overcharging involving a sale twice the market price, the <i>ona’a</i> interdict would have been applicable even to <i>karka</i>. See <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 1:7; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 227:29; <i>Sma</i>, ad locum 50–52; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 17. Cf. <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 227:29.)<br>Though the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ona’a</i> are inapplicable, nevertheless the <i>issurim</i> (prohibitions) regarding fair representation are operative.</i> If it is determined that there is a discrepancy in the sale, under certain conditions the sale is void (<i>mekach ta’ut</i>).
Due to the fact that the bungalow swimming pool was inoperative and the plumbing system was non-functioning in some of the bungalow units, <i>Nitva</i> argues that he has a right to rescind the sale. Should the <i>beit din</i> deny him that right, he should be compensated by the <i>Tove’a</i> for repairing the sewage system and bungalow pool.
At first glance, seemingly this issue may be resolved by focusing on the rulings of Shulhan Arukh and Rema. Addressing the <i>halakhot</i> of sales, Shulhan Arukh states:<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:5</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Reuven sold Shimon homes that he had in another city. Prior to the finalization of the sale, some gentiles entered the homes and vandalized them, caused smoke damage to the walls, and dismembered doors and windows. Shimon wants to rescind the sale and Reuven says that since the defect is of a temporary nature (it is repairable), he would deduct the amount of money to restore the houses to their original condition and the sale would be final. The Halakha is with Reuven.</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Rema: For after all, Reuven sold a house and it may still properly be called a house. Similarly, any defect that is not structurally connected to the house (<i>be-guf ha-bayit</i>), such as an easement to access the property, or drainage pipes, which can be removed, the sale of the house is final. However, if there is a structural defect in the house, such as if the seller said that a wall was sound and it actually was crumbling, the seller is proscribed from reconstructing the wall, and anything of the like.</span>
A reading of Shulhan Arukh’s ruling would lead one to the conclusion that if the defect cannot be repaired, then the seller has a right to rescind the sale. However, should the defect be repairable, regardless of the extent and cost of the repair, then the seller’s right is limited to receiving a deduction from the purchase price.
However, the consensus of authorities is that Shulhan Arukh’s decision is based upon a decision of Rosh, who conveys to us a different understanding of this ruling. According to Rosh,<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 96:6, which is cited by <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:5.</i> one must distinguish between whether after discovery of the defect it is still called a house or not. In our instance, ought one view an inoperative pool and non-functioning plumbing in some units as temporary defects which can be repaired, and therefore the buyer should merely receive a deduction from the purchase price, or should we say that Venetian Lanes is to be viewed as a piece of property with living units, and therefore the right of rescission of the sale exists? In explaining this position, one authority contends that the determining factor is the external appearance of the property. In other words, if it looks like a bungalow colony, it is a bungalow colony, even if it has a structural defect. Based upon this understanding of Shulhan Arukh, it would seem that Venetian Estates remains a bungalow colony, and these are temporary defects that can be remedied and paid for by the seller. However, the retention of the appearance of a bungalow is only one of the reasons to validate the sale. If it the colony would need a tremendous amount of repair, it would lose its identity as a bungalow, and therefore, there would be a right of rescission of the sale.<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Perisha</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:5. For other interpretations of Rosh’s and ultimately SA’s view, see <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 232 and <i>Ohr Sameach</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 17:9.</i>
Rema, as we read above, disagrees and argues that if there is a structural defect, for example, if the wrong construction materials were used or if there is a tottering wall, the sale is invalid. In the words of Netivot ha-Mishpat,<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 232:7.</i> by replacing a tottering wall with a sound wall, does the house receive “<i>panim hadashot</i>” (lit. “a new face”)? Moreover, Netivot Ha-Mishpat contends that if the property cannot be used, it is equivalent to a defect in the “<i>guf ha-bayit</i>,” the physical integrity of the bungalow colony, and therefore rescission is permitted.<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 233:4. Cf. <i>Magen Elef</i> on <i>Makor Hayyim</i>, <i>OH</i> 437:7.</i> On the other hand, if there are defects that are external to the property, such as bad drainage, the sale is valid and any repairs for these types of defect are to be paid by the seller. Consequently, according to Rema, the inability to use certain bungalow units due to plumbing problems and a non-operative pool is to be viewed as a defect relating to the <i>guf ha-bayit</i>, and therefore the sale is invalid.
In short, according to Shulhan Arukh, the sale would be valid, but Rema would disagree. Without addressing the issue of whether this panel should follow Shulhan Arukh’s position or Rema’s view, endorsed by Netivot ha-Mishpat and others,<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:10; <i>Minhat Pe’tim</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:5.</i> our foregoing presentation assumes that there was an obligation upon the seller to disclose the defects, and that the buyer was exempt from initiating on his own an inspection prior to his purchase. Based upon these premises, we investigated what type of defect will invalidate a sale and we demonstrated that this is a subject of another controversy between Shulhan Arukh and Rema.
But in fact, as we will presently show, there was never any obligation upon the seller to disclose these particular problems, and there was a duty upon the buyer to check the colony. To put it differently, this is a case of “<i>caveat emptor</i>” – “let the buyer beware”. Given the particular circumstances of our case, as will be demonstrated, the onus of all inquiries and inspection regarding the property rests squarely upon the shoulders of the buyer, namely the <i>Nitva</i>!
The question is whether the buyer had <i>gemirat da’at</i> to purchase the bungalow colony with the attendant defects. In a situation in which the buyer could have inspected the property,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rif</i> 153; <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 15:3; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:10; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1206 (136). According to this position, even prior to purchasing the colony, if a buyer refrains from inspection, he has waived his right and therefore cannot rescind the sale. Contra <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 385; <i>Teshuvot Maharitz</i> 225; <i>Teshuvot Ranah</i> 1:40; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:5.<br>For others, only upon purchasing the colony would failure to inspect the property be construed that the buyer waived his right to inspection. See <i>Mishneh la-Melekh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, op. cit.; <i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ona’a</i> 3; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i> 3:38.</i> either by himself or via the services of a third party,<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 3:223.</i> and he refrained from such inspection, it is a debate whether he can subsequently rescind the sale if defects emerge.<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">See supra n. 7.</i> Given the debate, one cannot extract money from the seller.<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 232:4; <i>Mahari ha-Levi</i>, supra n. 8.</i> This assumes that the buyer had already purchased the property. However, if the buyer became aware of the defects prior to transferring the money to the seller, he can rescind the sale.<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh la-Melekh</i>, ibid., supra n. 7; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 232:5; <i>Teshuvot Maharitz</i> 225; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, supra n. 7. Cf. <i>Maggid Mishneh</i> and <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> supra n. 7.<br>Cf. <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 232:1 who argues that only a buyer’s use of the property will extinguish his right to rescind the sale.</i> In our scenario, the buyer became aware of the defects after the sale and paying the purchase money.
However, on the basis of the clause in the sales agreement that specifically states that the colony was being sold “as is,” <i>Tove’a</i> argues that <i>Nitva</i> has no right to advance claims for his construction and repair costs. In reply to <i>Tove’a</i>’s contention, most <i>Poskim</i> argue that such a clause cannot serve as grounds for rescinding a sale (i.e., <i>mekach ta’ut</i>). In order to be shielded from pleas of <i>mekach ta’ut</i>, it is the seller’s duty to specify the actual <i>mumim</i> (defects) in the property.<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 16:6 (and <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 11:16); <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:7; <i>Sma</i>, ad locum 16; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 4; <i>Teshuvot ve-Shav ha-Kohen</i> 45; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 2:166. Cf. <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 232; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 4:136.</i> A general disclaimer of liability for defects will not be binding upon the buyer.
Moreover, <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, commercial practice, dictates that there are certain assets for which a buyer customarily does perform an inspection.<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 42b; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ramban</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>mekhdei</i>” (Ramban’s second answer).</i> Therefore, if the <i>minhag</i> is not to inspect a prospective buy, then if defects are found after the sale, the seller is liable.<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tzedaka u-Mishpat HM</i> 36; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 3:622.</i> For example, in certain times and places, the prevailing <i>minhag</i> was not to inspect courtyards and homes, and therefore Radvaz of sixteenth-century Egypt and Maharsham of twentieth-century Poland ruled that if subsequent to the purchase defects were discovered, the right of rescission is available.<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Radvaz</i>, supra n. 16; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 3:128.</i> However, today where the <i>minhag</i> is to inspect real estate prior to an anticipated purchase, including the plumbing and pool of a bungalow colony, if the buyer fails to perform his due diligence, the right of rescission does not exist.<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Clearly, if inspection is impractical, such as checking the plumbing system and/or a pool in the winter months, the seller has an obligation to inform the buyer of any defects and the buyer has not waived his right to an inspection. See <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, supra n. 7.</i>
Such a conclusion is equally forthcoming regarding the seller’s duty of disclosure. Not only is the seller prohibited from deceiving or misleading the buyer, but if the seller is aware of any defect, he is obligated to disclose it to the buyer prior to the sale. Generally speaking, there is a duty upon the seller to disclose any defects to the prospective buyer. However, in the absence of the seller’s disclosure of plumbing and pool problems, if the buyer has the opportunity to perform an inspection, or if he refrains from asking whether there are problems, should a sale take place and he subsequently becomes aware of defects, the right of rescission does not exist.<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Ma’akhalot Assurot</i> 8:14; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>YD</i> 1:31. Contra <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 228:6.</i>
Furthermore, even if prevailing practice does not indicate that prospective buyers inspect real estate prior to a sale, as we mentioned, if a buyer who can easily inspect the asset fails to implement such an inspection, there is a controversy whether the buyer has a right to rescind the sale.<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh la-Melekh</i>, supra n. 7; <i>Rif</i>, supra n. 7; <i>Teshuvot Maharit Zahalon</i> 225.</i> In this case, the buyer could have easily inspected whether the plumbing and pools were functional. And in cases of <i>safek</i> (doubt) one cannot mandate the seller to return the money.<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpat Shalom</i>, supra n. 11; <i>Mahari ha-Levi</i>, supra n. 8.</i>
Finally, even if the buyer was unaware of the problems prior to the purchase and even if <i>minhag ha-makom</i>, local practice, did not indicate that inspection is in place, if the buyer utilizes the property after he is aware of the problems, he loses his right to rescind the sale.<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 15:3; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:3; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, supra n. 11.</i> Moreover, though there is an opinion that if he used the property knowing that there were problems prior to payment,<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mahane Ephraim</i>, <i>Hiddushim</i> on <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mekhira</i> 15:3.</i> he could still rescind the sale, most <i>Poskim</i> disagree.<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 232:3; <i>Teshuvot Galya Masekhet</i> 10.</i> Once payment was made, the buyer’s decision to refrain from inspection is construed as <i>mehila</i> (i.e., a waiver).<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh la-Melekh</i>, <i>Mahane Ephraim</i> and <i>R. Akiva Eiger</i>, supra n. 7.</i> And in our situation, the buyer made the seller aware of these problems and requested remuneration for the repairs after the property was used and bought.
In sum, given that <i>Nitva</i> had adequate opportunity to inspect the pool and other plumbing matters during the month of September, and since there is an established practice to check these matters prior to purchase, and given that there was no duty upon the seller to disclose these defects, there existed <i>gemirat da’at</i> of the buyer upon executing his purchase. In effect, the buyer purchased the bungalow colony with its attendant non-functioning pool and plumbing knowing that he would be paying for these repairs. Consequently, there are no grounds for the <i>Nitva</i> to advance a claim for recovery of the costs of these repairs. Therefore, <i>Nitva</i>’s claim for construction costs and repairs are hereby denied. If the buyer could not advance a claim of <i>mekach ta’ut</i> years ago, there are no grounds now for asking remuneration for repairs.
<b>2. The Conveyance Agreement – A <i>Bona Fide</i> Halakhic Transfer of Ownership, a Lease, or <i>Haspa be-Alma</i>?</b>
Optimally, for an agreement to convey property or lease it to another individual, one must utilize language of <i>hit’hayivut</i>, <i>hak’naah</i>, or <i>sekhirut</i> (an obligation to transference/lease) such as “I obligate myself now to assign exclusive use, ownership, and occupancy of the bungalow.” Generally, an agreement is to be interpreted according to <i>lashon bnei adam</i> (common usage),<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 207; <i>Teshuvot Maharival</i> 2:21.</i> and common usage of the word “shall” does not denote an obligation.<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Webster’s Unabridged Dictionary</i>.</i> Consequently, at first glance, one may conclude that the terminology “… the parties agree as follows: Avraham Cohen … shall have the exclusive use …” is a <i>kinyan eitan</i> (i.e., undertaking a future event). Though Tur, Beit Yosef, and Rema cite both views regarding whether <i>kinyan eitan</i> is an effective mode to transfer assets,<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 105; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 157:2, 245:4; <i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 195 and 245; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 51, <i>HM</i> 157:4, 203:1.</i> numerous <i>Aharonim</i> reject its effectiveness as a <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Rashbash</i> 70; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 245:1; <i>Sma</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 245:2; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, ad locum 1; <i>Arukh ha-Shulhan</i>, <i>HM</i> 245:1–2; <i>Teshuvot Havot Yair</i> 80 cited by <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 245:3; <i>PDR</i> 4:275, 10:363; <i>Teshuvot Yabia Omer</i>, vol. 5, <i>HM</i> 5.</i> There must be language of <i>hit’hayivut</i> accompanied by a <i>kinyan</i>.
Nevertheless, in drafting contracts, should the <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> employ the word “shall” as denoting an obligation, then Halakha would accept the <i>minhag ha-soharim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 68:13; <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 42; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 42:15; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 61:5.</i> and conclude that this agreement utilized proper language of <i>hit’hayivut</i>. However, it is unclear whether employing the word “shall” in drafting contracts necessarily is to be interpreted as an obligation.<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">See excerpt below from Nora and Seth Tillman, “A Fragment on Shall and May,” 50 <i>American Journal of Legal History</i>, 453, 455, n. 6 (2010); <i>Black’s Law Dictionary</i> 1499 (9th ed. 2009) (defining “shall” as “will,” a future tense verb: “The corporation shall then have a period of 30 days to object.”); infra n. 8 (collecting authorities); cf. Bryan A. Garner, “A Dictionary Of Modern Legal Usage,” 939-41 (2nd ed. 1995) (discussing generally “words of authority” and noting that “shall” is inherently ambiguous); Kenneth A. Adams, “The New Rules of Drafting (Part Two),” <i>Mich. Bar J</i>., Aug. 2002, at 40, 40 (“<i>Shall</i> has a tortured history that gave rise to exception-ridden rules about when <i>shall</i> conveys simple futurity and when it conveys compulsion.”); Akhil Reed Amar, “Intratextualism,” 112 <i>Harvard L. Rev</i>. 747, 759-60 (1999) (“Are the words ‘shall be vested’ to be understood as a kind of prediction, or as a mandate? Is ‘shall’ here a future-tense verb or an imperative verb?”); Michele M. Asprey, “Shall <i>Must Go</i>,” 3 <i>Scribes J. Legal Writing</i> 79, 82 (1992) (“The reason why it is difficult to replace <i>shall</i> with a word that has all these subtle meanings is that <i>shall</i> never did it in the first place.”); Steven G. Calabresi &amp; Kevin H. Rhodes, “The Structural Constitution: Unitary Executive, Plural Judiciary,” 105 <i>Harv. L. Rev</i>. 1155, 1179 n. 125 (1992) (“Another possible construction is that the word ‘shall’ in the Vesting Clauses of Articles II and III is a present tense ‘performative’ that acquires force from its self-proclaimed status in a constituting document.”); Peter M. Goodloe, “Simplification – A Federal Legislative Perspective,” 105 <i>Dick. L. Rev.</i> 247, 254 (2001) (“The reason given is that ‘shall’ has dual functions. In addition to expressing the mandatory, it has the alternative construction of expressing the future tense.”); John F. O’Connor, “The Emoluments Clause: An Anti-Federalist Intruder in a Federalist Constitution,” 24 <i>Hofstra L. Rev</i>. 89, 118–19 (1995) (“The Emoluments Clause [also known as the Ineligibility Clause] refers to the act of appointment in the future tense, ‘shall … be appointed,’ while referring to increased emoluments in the future perfect tense, ‘shall have been increased.’”); Dru Stevenson, “Special Solicitude for State Standing, <i>Massachusetts v. EPA</i>,” 112 <i>Penn. St. L. Rev</i>. 1, 53 n. 273 (2007) (“As if this were not confusing enough, ‘shall’ is also used in a future temporal sense, somewhat interchangeably with ‘will’ …”); Nick Horn, “A Dainty Dish to Set before the King: Plain Language and Legislation,” <i>in Plain Language Ass’n Int’l Fourth Biennial Conference Proceedings</i> (Sept. 27, 2002) (unpublished manuscript) (distinguishing <i>shall</i> from <i>must</i>), available at http://www.plainlanguagenetwork.org/conferences/2002/dish/dainty.pdf.</i> Even if one would argue that “shall” denotes an obligation, in this agreement it clearly is to be understood as future-oriented. Upon a closer reading of the agreement, the word that attempts to create the obligation is “agrees” rather than “shall.” In other words, the agreement is to be understood as saying that the “… the parties agree Avraham Cohen … shall have the exclusive use …” As such, the agreement is stating that in the future, <i>Nitva</i> agrees that <i>Tove’a</i> will receive exclusive use, ownership, and occupancy of the bungalow. Such a provision of the agreement is a “<i>kinyan devarim</i>.” Employment of the word “agrees” is future-oriented; it does not denote obligation.<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Rama</i> (R. Meir Abulafia) 249, found in <i>Ohr Tzadikim</i>, Warsaw, 5662; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:17; File no. 1-35-8935, Regional Beit Din, <i>Mosdot Plonim v. Aaron, Yoel, &amp; Bela K</i>; <i>Mishpat ha-Tzava’ah</i> 2:25; File no. 288409-5, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, April 10, 2013. Cf. Mishmeret Shalom who is unsure whether this language is a “<i>kinyan devarim</i>.” See <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 207:7.<br>However, should a <i>kinyan</i> be performed relating to an agreement that fails to employ language of <i>hit’hayivut</i>, the agreement would be valid. See Rama and Rashba; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 212:1.</i>
However one cannot simply focus on the terminology “Mr. and Mrs. Avraham Cohen … shall have the exclusive use …” One must address the entire conveyance agreement. Among the provisions, it states the following:
<span class="poetry indentAll">Whereas, Venetian Lanes has this date purchased from Jardin Estates, the bungalow colony known as Jardin Estates located in Elizaville, New York, and</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Whereas, as part of the consideration Avraham and Sara Cohen shall have the exclusive ownership and use of one of the bungalows located at Venetian Lanes</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Now therefore in consideration of the mutual covenants hereinafter set forth the parties agree as follows:</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll">1. Avraham and Sara Cohen, their heirs and assigns shall have the exclusive use, ownership and occupancy of the bungalow located in the main house in the front called “Avraham’s Tent.”</span>
The essence of <i>Nitva</i>’s argument is that the legitimacy of the property transfer is based upon <i>“be-hahi hana’ah gamar u-mesha’bed nafshei</i>.” In other words, because of the benefit of being able to buy the bungalow colony, transfer of ownership of one of the units takes effect.
However, invoking “<i>be-hahi hana’ah gamar u-mesha’bed nafshei</i>” is only effective if stipulated at the time of the actual sale of the bungalow colony.<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 16b–17a; <i>Rashbam</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 123b; <i>Avodah Zara</i> 63b; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 18b; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 291:16. Whether “<i>be-hahi hana’ah gamar u-mesha’bed nafshei</i>” is a variation of a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i>, a physical act of acquisition similar to <i>kinyan kesef</i> or <i>halifin</i>, or that the expression of benefit brings the parties to <i>gemirut da’at</i> (firm resolve of the parties) and is a substitute for a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i>, is subject to controversy. See <i>Teshuvot Nahal Yitzhak</i> 40, in particular <i>anafim</i> 3–4.<br>Such barter would be valid even without a <i>kinyan</i> or the presence of witnesses provided that at the time of the agreement each party has the item in his possession. See <i>PDR</i> 6:248–249.<br>The invoking of <i>Nitva</i>’s argument is predicated upon that “<i>be-hahi hana’ah gamar u-mesha’bed nafshei</i>” is effective for transference of assets as well as undertaking an obligation. See <i>Bava Batra</i> 106b.</i> In other words, the <i>Nitva</i> would have had to stipulate at the time of the actual sale of the colony that in consideration of purchasing the colony, <i>Nitva</i> is assigning ownership of one unit to the <i>Tove’a</i>. Such a stipulation was absent from the sales agreement. In our case, the conveyance agreement was executed <i>after</i> the sale, and consequently, “<i>be-hahi hana’ah gamar u-mesha’bed nafshei</i>” is inapplicable.
What actually transpired here? Conventionally under NY law, parties execute a conveyance agreement wherein in consideration for ten dollars and covenants and promises, a deed will convey the property. To put it differently, to transfer property or a lease requires <i>gemirat da’at</i> that is expressed in utilizing a language of <i>hit’hayivut</i> accompanied by <i>a kinyan</i>. Here, the parties chose to execute an agreement that, “in their eyes,” they were <i>gomeir da’atam</i> (firmly resolved) without employing a language of <i>hit’hayivut</i> and without the issuance of a deed required by law or any <i>kinyan</i> recognized by Halakha.
In the absence of language of <i>hit’hayivut</i>, one requires the performance of an act of <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>Hilkhot Zekhiya u-Matana</i> 8:6; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 207:2.</i> In our case, such an action never transpired. The question is, in the absence of a <i>kinyan</i>, can one argue that such an agreement is binding? According to many <i>Poskim</i>, where there is clear evidence of <i>gemirat da’at</i>, the <i>kinyan</i> is obtained by the <i>gemirat da’at</i>, and therefore, such an arrangement is valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Aliyot de-Rabbeinu Yona</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 84b; <i>Rashbam</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 123b, s.v. “<i>hakhi garsinan</i>” (as understood by <i>Rashash</i>, ad locum; R. Yosef Engel, <i>Tziyunim la-Torah</i>, <i>kelal</i> 39); <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>hakha</i>” (as understood by <i>Kovetz Shiurim</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 374); <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 17b, s.v. “<i>ak’nuyei</i>”; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 1:46, 2:46, 113; <i>Teshuvot Maharshal</i> 36, 135; R. Shlomo Kluger, <i>Teshuvot Tuv Ta’am ve-Da’at</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i>, 265, 269, <i>Mahadura</i> 3, 2:146; <i>Hokhmat Shlomo</i>, <i>OH</i> 434:10; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314 (as understood by <i>Teshuvot Shem Arye</i>, <i>YD</i> 48 and <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 4:48:1. Cf. <i>Teshuvot Dvar Avraham</i>’s understanding in 1:1, <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314 and <i>HM</i> 12); <i>Rashash</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 18b; <i>Teshuvot R. Akiva Eiger</i>, <i>pesakim</i> 37; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hakhamim</i> 1, <i>HM</i> 32; <i>Pnei Yehoshua</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 77b; <i>Teshuvot Hemdat Shlomo</i>, <i>YD</i> 33; <i>Avnei Miluim</i> 30:3 (in the name of <i>Ran</i>); <i>Teshuvot Ohel Moshe</i> 2:138; <i>Kuntres Minhat Asher</i> 2.<br>Some of these sources as well as some of the sources cited infra, at n. 34–58 have been culled from Ron Kleinman, “Merchant Customs Relating to Methods of Acquisition in Jewish Law” (Hebrew), unpublished doctoral dissertation (Ramat Gan: Israel 2000), and “<i>Kinyan Situmta</i>” (Hebrew), 24 <i>Mehkarei Mishpat</i> 243 (5768).<br>R. Farbstein’s interpretation of this view that should parties discover that they erred and their act of <i>kinyan</i> was halakhically invalid, “clearly the buyer did not acquire the item” lacks foundation in the aforementioned approach. See <i>PDR</i> 22:282, 287.<br>Moreover, even according to this perspective, given the fact, as we noted, that the conveyance agreement was executed after the sale rather than during the time of the sale, there is no evidence of <i>gemirut da’at</i> that would affirm the transfer of ownership.</i> However, this position, albeit Talmudically grounded, is based on a <i>shitat yahid</i> (a minority view)<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meiri</i> in the name of “<i>Gedolei Olam</i>,” <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 28b, <i>Bava Batra</i> 75; <i>Ra’avad</i>, <i>Shita Lo Noda Le-me le-Massechet</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 28b. Cf. <i>Ra’avad</i>, <i>Katuv Sham</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 84b.<br>For the Talmudic basis for this view, see (1) <i>Ketuvot</i> 102a–b: “These are the matters that can be acquired via the medium of speech.” See <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Ketuvot</i> 102b, s.v. “<i>a’libai</i>.” (2) <i>Bava Batra</i> 142b; acquiring for the benefit of an embryo, see <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 210:1. (3) <i>Bekhorot</i> 18b, transferring ownership of a first-born animal to a <i>kohen</i>. See <i>Teshuvot R. Akiver Eiger</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 37 in the name of <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 18b, s.v. “<i>ak’neuyei</i>.” (5) <i>Bava Kama</i> 102b, someone dedicates his assets to the <i>Beit ha-Mikdash.</i> See <i>Sefer ha-Terumoth</i>, <i>sha’ar</i> 1, 1:5 in the name of <i>Ra’avad</i>. (6) <i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a, <i>situmta</i>. <i>Rashash</i>, ibid.; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 194:2. (7) <i>Bava Metzia</i> 94a. A paid <i>shomer</i> (bailee) may change his status to that of a <i>sho’el</i> (borrower) by means of an oral stipulation rather than executing a formal <i>kinyan</i>. (6) <i>Bava Batra</i> 123b. The transfer of priestly gifts to <i>makire kehuna</i> (acquaintances of the <i>kohanim</i>). See <i>Rashash</i>, ad locum. (7) <i>Bava Batra</i> 173b. An <i>arevut</i>, a suretyship agreement undertaken at the time of the creation of a debt, can be effectuated orally without a <i>kinyan</i>.</i> that people can stipulate contrary to what is written in the Torah (<i>“matneh al ma sha-katuv ba-torah”</i>) and decide on their own how to transfer property, as <i>Tove’a</i> and <i>Nitva</i> did when executing this conveyance agreement. Consequently, it is unsurprising to find that <i>Poskim</i> will either explicitly state that this view is contrary to the weight of Halakha, or will only rely on this view as a “<i>senif </i>” which will support other halakhic reasoning to advance a particular <i>psak</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">For those decisors who employ it as a <i>senif</i> (a supporting argument), see <i>Teshuvot Rabbi Akiva Eiger</i> 37; <i>Sdei Hemed</i>, <i>Ma’arekhet Daled Minim</i> 3:6.<br>For others who explicitly state that this position cannot be applied <i>Halakha le-ma’aseh</i> (in practice), see <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 3:318; <i>Teshuvot Avnei Tzedek</i>, <i>YD</i> 133 in the name of <i>Imrei Bina</i>.</i> Most <i>Poskim</i> disagree and minimally will validate an agreement devoid of language of <i>hit’hayivut</i> such as “the parties agree,” only if there was a <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushei ha</i>-<i>Ramban</i>, <i>ha</i>-<i>Rashba</i>, <i>ha</i>-<i>Ran</i>, <i>Nimukei Yosef</i> (in name of <i>Ritva</i>), <i>Kiddushin</i> 28b; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 25b, s.v. “<i>beheima</i>”; <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 76a, s.v. “<i>sefina</i>”; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 198:10.<br>For the effectiveness of an agreement accompanied by a <i>kinyan</i> that is devoid of language of <i>hit’hayivut</i>, see <i>Rama</i>, supra n. 30; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:17; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 212:1.</i> In the words of Meiri,<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit ha-Behira</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i>, supra n. 34.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Where do <i>hedyotot</i> [laymen] have permission to nullify the Halakha of <i>kinyanim</i>!</span>
Remarking on the view that accepts such agreements without a <i>kinyan</i>, R. Yehoshua Ehrenburg exclaims, “These words are astonishing!”<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 4:48:1. Even though R. Ehrenburg argues that an act of <i>kinyan</i> is grounded in <i>gemirut da’at</i> (see <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 3, <i>HM</i> 19), nevertheless, his position is that it must be a recognized <i>kinyan</i> rather than the subjective <i>gemirut da’at</i> of the parties.</i>
And in the words of R. Zalman Nehemiah Goldberg,<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">“The Validity of Obligating to Sell Based upon a Preliminary Agreement” (Hebrew), 12 <i>Tehumin</i> 279, 298 (5751).</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We have not found that a seller and buyer can create a <i>kinyan</i> that is not grounded in <i>din torah</i>!</span>
Moreover, even Beit Yosef and Rema, who allow parties to execute an agreement without the prescribed <i>kinyan</i>, stipulate that only a recognized <i>kinyan</i> may be utilized. For example, both Beit Yosef and Rema will permit <i>metaltelin</i> (chattel) to be transferred with <i>kinyan kesef</i> though <i>min ha-din</i>, <i>metaltelin</i> cannot be transferred with <i>kesef</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yosef</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 195; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 195:5. See also <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 198; <i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, <i>HM</i> 198:3.<br></i> In other words, minimally parties must implement a recognized <i>kinyan</i> even if it is not the one prescribed for the particular object. And other <i>Poskim</i>, among them Derisha and Shakh, take issue with this position and argue that a transfer of ownership requires the prescribed <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Derisha</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:3; <i>Shakh</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 195:10.</i> The consensus is that a recognized <i>kinyan</i> must be utilized.<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, there are numerous <i>Poskim</i> who will validate a property transfer provided that the proper <i>kinyan</i> was employed. See <i>Yam shel Shlomo</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 1:22; <i>Teshuvot Ramatz</i> 5; <i>Teshuvot Helkat Ya’akov</i> 2:104; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Moshe</i> 2:77; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Emet</i> 12; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 142; <i>Teshuvot Binyan Tzion</i> 1:2; <i>Erekh Shai</i>, <i>HM</i> 194; <i>PDR</i> 6:378 (R. Shlomo Urbach’s opinion).</i>
Thirdly, should a gentile accept Halakha and purchase with a <i>bona fide kinyan</i> from a Jew, such an agreement would be valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketzot ha-Hoshen</i>, supra n. 40.</i> Again, it is valid agreement because a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i> was employed.
Moreover, let’s assume that our Hakhamim nullified the recognized <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i>. Can parties then stipulate between themselves that the halakhically recognized <i>kinyanim</i> are to be effective? The reply is that such private stipulation will be invalid.<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 198:5; <i>Shakh</i>, ad locum 10.</i>
Furthermore, in contradistinction to a private agreement, a <i>kinyan</i> is not required in order to impart validity to a public agreement.<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 6:19, 21; <i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 457–458; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 204:8–9.<br>Nonetheless, if the promise was given without authorization, the promise is unenforceable. For example, if the promise was given without prior approval of the majority of the seven elders or undermined the welfare of the community, the promise is null and void. See <i>Teshuvot Rashbash</i> 666; <i>Teshuvot Beit Yitzhak</i>, <i>HM</i> 61; <i>PDR</i> 6:166, 173.</i> Therefore, if a communal institution, such as a municipal body, a yeshiva, or a synagogue, makes a promise, the body is duty-bound to comply with it. However, one of the exceptions to this rule is when dealing with the sale of land. For a land sale to be effective, the communal institution must execute a <i>kinyan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Beit Yitzhak</i>, supra n. 45.</i> Certainly in our case, dealing with the affairs of private individuals, a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i> must accompany the land transfer!
Finally, the <i>Tove’a</i> assumes that parties can create their own <i>kinyan situmta</i>, a mode of undertaking an obligation that is rooted in their own <i>gemirat da’at</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 380; <i>Teshuvot Tuv Ta’am ve-Da’at</i>, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 74, 269; <i>Minhat Asher</i>, <i>Bereishit</i> 208–209.</i> but most <i>Poskim</i> argue otherwise. For many <i>Poskim</i>, <i>kinyan situmta</i> is based on either minhag,<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:268, 3:17, 4:125; <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>YD</i> 314.</i> “<i>kinyan halifin</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Dvar Avraham</i>, supra n. 33, <i>anaf</i> 1.</i> or grounded in “<i>kinyan meshikha/hazaka</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piskei Halakhot im Bi’ur Yad David</i>, <i>Ishut</i> 1, 228–229.</i> To put it differently, there is a requirement of an “objective act” that creates the <i>gemirut da’at</i> of the parties.
For the conveyance agreement to be viewed as a <i>kinyan situmta</i>, it must be reflective of <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>, and such a <i>minhag</i> must be based upon the requirements of what secular law mandates for property transfer. There are numerous <i>Aharonim</i> who mandate that an agreement comply with <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 194:2; <i>Teshuvot Oholei Tam</i> 202; <i>Teshuvot ha-Mabit</i> 1:145; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 2:66; <i>Teshuvot Shev Ya’akov</i>, <i>HM</i> 14; <i>Teshuvot Tzemach Tzedek</i> (Lubavitch), <i>HM</i> 38; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 1:10; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Moshe</i> 2:62; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 4:143; <i>Teshuvot To’afot Re’eim</i>, <i>HM</i> 13; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:31; <i>Teshuvot Maharit</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:66; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Yitzhak</i> 5, <i>HM</i> 3; <i>Teshuvot Maharash Engel</i> 5:27; <i>Teshuvot Mahari ha-Levi</i> 2:60; <i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:62.</i> Should a deed be required by secular law, <i>gemirat da’at</i> will only be obtained by filing a deed.<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharitz HM</i> 2:66; <i>Teshuvot Torat Hayyim</i> 1:19; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Malkiel</i> 4:143; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 2:31. For a list of over 30 <i>Aharonim</i> who concur with this position, see <i>Ma’adanei Aretz Shevi’it</i> 18:11.<br>Such an arrangement clearly does not absolve the parties from complying with the legal requirement of issuance of deed. It simply means that the parties are free to execute an agreement with a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i>. And, subsequently, it becomes their duty to receive a deed to attest to the property transfer.</i> Secular law requires the issuance of a deed as a prerequisite for property transfer, and that is not provided for in this conveyance agreement. Absent the parties’ agreement to execute a transfer without title registration, Hazon Ish and R. Shlomo Z. Auerbach recognize a property transfer utilizing a halakhically recognized <i>kinyan</i> unaccompanied by a deed,<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Ma’aserot</i> 10 reprinted later as <i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>HM</i> 16; <i>Ma’adanei Aretz</i> 18:2. And many have endorsed their approach. See <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 6:170-22; <i>Teshuvot Pri Eliyahu</i> (Zlotnick) 3:106; <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i> 9:306; <i>Teshuvot Mishkenot le-Yisrael</i> 33:11.</i> but subsequently, there must be title registration in order to comply with secular law.<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hazon Ish</i>, <i>Ma’aserot</i> 10:1, 3, 7; <i>Ma’adanei Aretz</i>, supra n. 52. Cf. the positions of Rabbis Moshe Harari of Aleppo and Moshe Abulafia of Damascus, Syria. See <i>Pnei Yitzchak</i>, infra n. 55.</i> Even those nineteenth-century <i>Poskim</i> and contemporary authorities who recognize a transfer of ownership without a deed, require that a bona fide <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i> with language of <i>hit’hayivut</i> be utilized.<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Pnei Yitzhak</i> 5, <i>HM</i> 2–3 (R. Moshe Harari and R. Y. Moshe Abulafia); <i>Ma’adanei Aretz</i>, supra n. 52; <i>Shevet ha-Levi</i>, supra n. 53; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 6:170.</i> In other words, the parties may execute a <i>kinyan</i> prior to title registration and it will be valid.<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Dvar Moshe</i>, <i>To’afot Re’eim</i>, <i>Torat Hayyim</i>, and <i>Maharsham</i>, supra n. 52.</i> The common denominator is that there must be a <i>ma’aseh kinyan</i> that is known by the business community.
In other words, <i>Poskim</i> have recognized a <i>kinyan situmta</i> based upon <i>minhag ha-soharim</i> such as placing a seal on an item, a handshake, a coin transfer, etc., or based upon secular law.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a; <i>Rashi</i>, ad locum; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 12:39 in the name of <i>R. Hayyim ha-Kohen</i>; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 74a.</i> However, a <i>kinyan situmta</i> based upon the <i>subjective kavana</i> (intent) of the parties, as we find in our case, was recognized by only a few <i>Poskim</i>. As such, the weight of halakhic opinion is to reject this conveyance agreement as a <i>bona fide kinyan situmta</i>.
Given that <i>Poskim</i> recognize our modern-day contract as a <i>kinyan situmta</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharashdam HM</i> 280; <i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 3:8; <i>Teshuvot Tzemach Tzedek</i> (Lubavitch), <i>YD</i> 233; <i>Kesef ha-Kodshin</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 201:1; <i>Teshuvot Maharshag</i> 3:113; <i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 5:45; <i>PDR</i> 3:363, 4:193, 275, 6:202, 14:43.</i> the question is whether the conveyance agreement generates a lease and/or use in the bungalow unit. Pursuant to NY law,<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Huggins v. Castle Estates</i>, 36 NY 2d 427, 430, 369 NYS 80 (1975); <i>Millbrook Hunt v. Smith</i>, 249 AD 2d 281, 670 NYS 2d 907 (2d Dept. 1998).</i> ownership remains in the possession of the <i>Nitva</i>. However, in consideration of the purchase of the bungalow colony, <i>Nitva</i> agreed to convey a property interest akin to a valid negative easement to the <i>Tove’a</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">17 NY Jur, Easements &amp; Licenses, Section 14, pp. 265–266; <i>Manhasset Bay Assoc. v. Town of N. Hempstead</i>, 150 AD 2d 533, 541 NYS 2d 119 (2nd Dept. 1989).</i> which means that the owner granted the <i>Tove’a</i> use of this parcel of land in the colony. Unlike a license, which is revocable, this easement is not revocable.<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Todd v. Krolick</i>, 96 AD 2d 695, 466 NYS 2d 788 (3d Dept. 1983).</i> As such, by dint of an easement, <i>Tove’a</i> has been granted exclusive use of the unit. Alternatively, we view this conveyance agreement as granting the <i>Tove’a</i> a perpetual lease of rent-free space.<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Seemingly, this conclusion violates the rule against perpetuities that prohibits property transfer for an unreasonable period of time. Given that the interest granted was a present grant of a lease, the rule against perpetuities is inapplicable due to the fact that this rule deals with contingent future interests. In other words, the rule applies to a legal right to property that does not include the right to present possession or enjoyment of the property. See John Gray, “The Rule against Perpetuities,” Sec. 230 (4th ed. 1942); <i>Camerlo v. Howard Johnson Co</i>., 710 F. 2d 987, Court of Appeals, Third Circuit, 1983; <i>Bleecker Street Tenants Corp. v. Bleeker Jones LLC</i>, NY Court of Appeals, No. 12, February 24, 2011.</i>
Given that NY law will validate this conveyance agreement, Halakha will recognize this agreement conveying use and occupancy of this unit as a <i>kinyan situmta</i>.
In sum, the foregoing shows that the requirement of employing certain language and mandating a <i>kinyan</i>, must “objectively” demonstrate <i>gemirat da’at</i>. Though most <i>Poskim</i> will invalidate <i>kinyan situmta</i> grounded in the subjective intentions of the parties, nevertheless, given that secular law recognizes this agreement, Halakha also validates it.
<b>3. The Conveyance of the Ownership of the Bungalow Unit: Is it a <i>Tenai</i> of the Sale of the Colony?</b>
The question is whether there is a basis for concluding that the <i>Tove’a</i> actually owns the unit. R. Dovid Babad, a famed nineteenth-century <i>Posek</i> of Galicia, communicates to us a <i>mesorah</i> (tradition) that he received:<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Havatzelet ha-Sharon</i> 2:28. This approach was adopted by some <i>Poskim</i> in areas of <i>ishut</i> (family Halakha) questions. See <i>Teshuvot Helkat Ya’akov</i>, <i>EH</i> 56; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Yitzhak</i> 9:150.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">I heard from ha-Gaon R. Barish Rapaport … that he had a <i>mesorah</i> from his Rav, ha-Gaon Noda be-She’arim, <i>Av Beit Din</i> of Lublin, that upon receiving a question to address, he would first weigh in his mind the truthfulness of the matter according to what human reason dictates and if in his estimation human reason the matter is true, then he would delve into Halakha to arrive at a decision.</span>
Even if Halakha and secular law invalidate this conveyance agreement in terms of transferring ownership from the <i>Nitva</i> to the <i>Tove’a</i>, reason dictates that there was an agreement of property transfer consummated verbally between the parties. In fact, we have a signed agreement that memorializes this arrangement. So the question before this panel is whether this arrangement was finalized <i>verbally</i> prior to the sale of the colony, and there actually was a <i>tenai</i> to consummate the sale, or was it only initially discussed and finalized after the closing? Obviously, both possibilities exist and the question is: How do we determine when the verbal agreement actually transpired? Addressing our dilemma, R. Yosef ibn Lev addresses a <i>kashrut</i> question posed to him. A <i>halef</i> (knife) for <i>shehita</i> (slaughtering) must be free of nicks. Consequently, prior to <i>shehita</i>, the <i>shohet</i> (ritual slaughterer) must have his <i>halef</i> inspected by a rabbi. In this case, the rabbi ruled that the knife was <i>pasul</i> (invalid) and therefore could not be used for <i>shehita</i>. However, another individual, unaware of the rabbi’s ruling, showed the <i>halef</i> to another rabbi who declared it kosher, and the knife was used to slaughter meat. After the animal was slaughtered, the knife was examined for a third time, and again it was ruled to be <i>pasul</i> for <i>shehita</i>.
The question is: What is the status of meat slaughtered with a <i>halef</i> that was <i>pasul</i>, but prior to the slaughtering, was found to be kosher? At first glance, we should conclude that the meat is kosher because we may assume that the knife had been repaired prior to the <i>shehita</i>. Moreover, if a <i>halef</i> is known to be kosher and subsequently is discovered to be nicked, any meat that was slaughtered with the <i>halef</i> is kosher because we may assume that the nick occurred after the meat was slaughtered. Such reasoning would lead one to conclude that the meat is kosher. However, in this case, this reasoning would have to be predicated upon the following facts: The <i>halef</i> was repaired between the first and second inspection, but was subsequently nicked before the third inspection. In light of the low degree of probability that the events occurred in that fashion, R. Yosef Ibn Lev refrained from declaring the meat kosher.<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Marharival</i> 1:57.</i>
The implications of his position are that if there is a high degree of probability that a certain chain of events transpired, then a <i>dayan</i> can invoke <i>umdana de-mukhah</i> (sound inference/common sense) and conclude that the events in actuality happened. To apply this ruling to our case, it is highly unlikely that the parties initially discussed an arrangement of transferring the unit after the closing and then prepared and executed the conveyance document.
