The more likely sequence of events is that this matter was discussed and finalized verbally <i>prior</i> to the closing. In other words, in consummating a real estate deal (or for that matter, any commercial transaction) concerned parties stipulate any and all of their conditions to the sale prior to the sale. There is an <i>umdana de-mukhah</i> that our parties, as experienced and astute businessmen, conducted themselves according to <i>minhag ha-soharim</i>. Based upon the cumulative evidence submitted to this panel, no facts exist to rebut this presumption. It is evident that the sale of the colony was contingent (i.e., a <i>tenai</i>) upon receiving ownership of the bungalow unit. And relying upon an <i>umdana de-mukhah</i>, one can be “<i>motzi mamon</i>” (extract money) from a <i>Nitva</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i>, <i>kelal</i> 69; <i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, 1:84, 3:289; <i>Teshuvot Rashbash</i>, 387; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 99:8; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>,15:2; <i>Teshuvot Mahara Sasson</i> 45; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 5; <i>Teshuvot Maharit ha-Hadashot</i> 19, 42; <i>Teshuvot Darkhei Noam</i>, <i>HM</i> 52; <i>Teshuvot Ezrat Kohen</i> 41; <i>PDR</i> 9:341, 17:321, 21:148; File No. 813075/1, Supreme Beit Din, <i>Plonit v. Ploni</i>. Additionally, see <i>Rishonim</i> and <i>Aharonim</i> cited by <i>Teshuvot Maharam Alsheich</i> 40, <i>Sdei Hemmed</i>, <i>Ma’arechet Aleph</i>, 187 (p. 100), <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>HM</i> 1:15, <i>Hagahot Beit Yosef</i> 20; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>HM</i> 15:9.<br>Cf. <i>Alfasi on Ketuvot</i> 43b; <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sanhedrin</i> 24:2; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 15:5; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:287, 3:551; <i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 129; <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 15:2; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i> 3, <i>Mahadura Kama</i> 152; <i>Even ha-Ezel</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hovel u-Mazik</i> 8:14.<br>According to some <i>Poskim</i>, in cases in which the <i>Nitva</i>’s submissions are grounded in lies, one can invoke an <i>umdana de-mukhah</i> and extract money. See <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 99:8; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i>, 3:142; <i>PDR</i> 12:75.<br>Implicit in our position is that the invoking of <i>umdana de-mukhah</i> is not limited to appraising the intent of the parties, but equally extends to assessing whether an event actually transpired. See <i>Sefer Kovetz Shiurim</i> (Wasserman) 1:580, 2:38.</i> based upon a signed <i>shtar borerut</i> (arbitration agreement).<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shevut Ya’akov</i>, supra n. 65; <i>Teshuvot Mishpatekha le-Ya’akov</i> 3:32; <i>Piskei Din Yerushalayim</i> 1:209; <i>PDR</i> 9:331, 19:106; File no. 1-35-8935, supra n. 30; File no. 826201-2, Netanya Regional Beit Din, <i>Ploni v. Plonit</i>, July 4, 2013.</i>
Lest one challenge this conclusion due to the fact that NY law requires title transfer and issuance of a deed. In the absence of a deed, we are dealing with an illegal contract. And, in fact, according to NY law, a party to an illegal contract cannot request a civil court to help him carry out his illegal act.<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sabia v. Mattituck Inlet Mar. &amp; Shipyard, Inc</i>. 24 AD 3d 178 (2005); <i>Bonilla v. Rotter</i>, 2007 NY Slip Op. 449, NY Appellate Div., 1st Dept. 2007.</i>
Moreover, to conclude that the <i>Tove’a</i> now owns the property without a title is seemingly a violation of Halakha. As we know, the consensus is that with regard to matters of <i>karka’ot</i> (land), there is an imperative to follow the laws enacted by the civil authority (“<i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i>”).<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ohr Zarua</i>, <i>Bava Kama</i> 447 (in the name of R. Eliezer of Metz); <i>SA</i>, <i>Rema</i>, <i>HM</i> 369:8; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:29; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Rivot</i> 83<i>.</i></i> Consequently, transferring ownership without a deed entails non-compliance with the dictates of the government, and therefore, such conduct is halakhically proscribed.<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i>, 2:239; <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i> 50.</i>
However, in bold contrast to NY law, Halakha views an illegal contract very differently. Professor Moshe Silberg, a renowned twentieth-century Israeli jurist observes,<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">Moshe Silberg, <i>Talmudic Law and the Modern State</i>, New York: Burning Bush, 1973, 82.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">We see clearly that Jewish law does not establish a causal connection between the commission of an offense and the voiding of a civil contract … The violation of the law or morality is one thing, and the legal validity of the contract is another – to the extent that the fulfilling of the contract itself does not activate the offense … Precisely because Jewish law does not distinguish between law and morality, and that practically every performance of an obligation is at the same time a fulfillment of a religio-moral commandment – as “the commandment” of repaying a debt of monetary obligation – the non-fulfillment of a contract entered into through a violation of law will only turn out to be an additional offense to supplement the original one committed by the transgressor.</span>
To put it differently, the agreement is illegal only if the essential terms of the agreement are illegal. In other words, one must distinguish between the conduct that is prohibited and the actual agreement. For example, if a husband tells his wife, “I will give you your <i>get</i> (Jewish divorce) on the condition that you consume non-kosher meat,” and she eats it, she is divorced.<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gittin</i> 84b.</i> Or if party agrees to hire witnesses who are deceitful, the agreement is valid. Though the actual testimony is prohibited, nevertheless the agreement to hire such witnesses does not entail an <i>issur</i>, and one is obligated to comply with his duty to abide by the agreement and must remit the monies for the hiring.<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 9:1.</i> Similarly, if an individual executes an agreement with a prostitute to engage in an illicit affair, though the affair is prohibited, nevertheless, one must fulfill one’s commitment and therefore comply with the agreement and remit money for her services.<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>EH</i> 87:25; <i>Teshuvot Sho’el u-Meishiv</i>, <i>Mahadura Revia’a</i> 3:39.</i>
In our situation, one must differentiate between the parties’ decision to transfer ownership without the issuance of a deed, which involves a halakhic violation of failing to comply with the dictates of civil law, and the undertaking of the actual agreement between the parties. In other words, though the parties are engaging in an <i>issur</i>, i.e., non-compliance with the law of the state of NY, nevertheless, <i>Nitva</i> has an obligation to fulfill the terms of the conveyance agreement, including but not limited to the transfer of ownership.
In short, the bungalow unit belongs to the <i>Nitva</i> with the <i>Nitva</i> having granted an irrevocable right to the <i>Tove’a</i> to occupy and use the unit. Therefore there are grounds for his claim for recouping lost rental revenue due to being unable to occupy the unit for a period of years.
<b>4. A Promise: Is it a Halakhically Enforceable Obligation?</b>
At some juncture in time prior to the execution of the sale of the colony, the parties agreed to the amount of the purchase, which would be paid at the closing, and <i>Nitva</i> orally promised to pay an additional $100,000 in cash for the purchase of Jardin Estates. Is such a promise a halakhically enforceable obligation?
According to the <i>din</i>, there are two components required in the undertaking of an obligation: effectuating a <i>kinyan</i> (i.e., symbolic act of acquisition) and <i>gemirat da’at</i> (i.e., a concrete articulation of the parties’ firm resolve to undertake the obligation). The act of promising reflects the absence of <i>gemirat da’at</i>, either because a promise entails executing an obligation in the future (e.g., a promise to sell goods) or a promise is in respect to transferring title of something that is not yet in existence (i.e., <i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i>), such as an item that has not been produced or is not in his possession (i.e., <i>eino bi-reshuto</i>), and therefore such promises are unenforceable in a <i>beit din</i>. <i>Nitva</i>’s promise is an example of a <i>davar she-lo ba la-olam</i> because it entails the commitment to remit a sum of money in the future, i.e., upon the consummation of the purchase of a bungalow colony
The consequence of reneging upon a promise is stated in Shulhan Arukh and Rema in the following fashion:<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 204:7; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 204:11.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">When one conducts and concludes commercial transactions using words only (the negotiation and agreement not being completed by a formal act of acquisition), that person should stand by his word, even though none of the purchase price has been taken, nor a buyer’s mark made on the goods … Whoever withdraws from this type of transaction, whether buyer or seller, is deemed a faithless person.</span>
<span class="poetry indentAll"><i>Rema</i>: A person should stand by his word even though no act of acquisition has been performed, and only mere words have passed between the parties …</span>
Where no payment has been made, and the seller articulates an oral commitment to sell realty or personalty to a prospective buyer and the deal is finalized,<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meiri</i>, <i>Beit ha-Behira</i>,<i>Bava Metzia</i> 49a, s.v. “<i>gamru</i>.”</i> should either party then renege on the agreement of sale, he is stigmatized as a <i>mehusar amana</i> (lit. “lacking faith”). Given that no act of acquisition (i.e., <i>kinyan</i>) has been executed between the parties, technically either party may withdraw from consummating the sale. The noncompliance with the promise is unenforceable. Enforceability depends upon the execution of a <i>kinyan</i>.
According to the Halakha of obligations, i.e., <i>hit’hayivut</i>, the promisor (in this case the <i>Nitva</i>) must obligate himself rather than promise to pay “X” number of dollars. For example, the use of language such as “I obligate myself to pay Abraham Doe such and such,” “I undertake to pay … ,” “I am obligated to pay … ,” or “I admit that I am obligated to <i>Tove’a</i> such and such” are all <i>leshonot</i> (language) of obligation.<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:6; <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:13; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 60:3; <i>Teshuvot Maharshakh</i> 3:173; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>HM</i> 29.</i> The common denominator of these different terms of accepting a commitment is that with this language, one transforms himself into a debtor <i>now</i>. Consequently, <i>min ha-din</i> – in accordance with Halakha – a promise to remit only entails a future action and therefore has no legal validity.<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 3a; <i>Rashi</i>, ad locum, s.v. “<i>kinyan devarim hu</i>”; <i>Piskei ha-Rosh</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 1:3; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 245:1.</i> In fact, in response to actual instances of individuals making promises in commercial matters, <i>Poskim</i> have ruled that these promises are beyond the pale of enforceability by a <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharik</i>, <i>shoresh</i> 133:2; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Rivot</i> 278; <i>Teshuvot Berakh Moshe Galante</i> 5; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Yitzhak</i> (Abulafia) 6:6.</i>
Nonetheless, despite the absence of the mention of the aforementioned monies in the closing statement, there is an <i>umdana de-mukhah</i>, i.e., it is objectively evident, that he did not waive his right to these monies. For example, Reuven sells real estate to Shimon and during the negotiations Reuven informs Shimon that he is selling the land because he is moving to Eretz Yisrael. Should Reuven cancel his move, the sale is null and void. Despite the fact that there was no <i>tenai kaful</i>, a double condition, it is objectively evident that the sale was contingent upon Reuven’s move.<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 49b, s.v. “<i>devarim</i>”; <i>Hiddushei ha-Rashba</i>, <i>Kiddushin</i> 49b; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 34:1; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 207:4; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 207:1; <i>Teshuvot Mishpat Shoham</i> 60. For additional <i>Poskim</i> who endorse applying an <i>umdana de-mukhah</i> in contemporary times, see <i>Teshuvot Ba’ei Hayyei</i> 1, <i>HM</i> 41.<br>Even if one would argue that one cannot invoke an <i>umdana de-mukhah</i> in contemporary times to extract monies, pursuant to the arbitration agreement that this matter is resolved in accordance with the <i>din</i> or <i>peshara</i>, a <i>beit din</i> panel is empowered to extract money from the <i>Nitva</i>. See <i>Shevut Ya’akov</i>, supra n. 65.<br>Given that we are dealing with a <i>tenai</i> that is communicated verbally, according to many <i>Poskim</i> there is no need to utilize a <i>tenai kaful</i>. See <i>PDR</i> 6:97, 99–100, 102–103.</i>
In fact, one could advance the argument that even if the <i>Tove’a</i> had not conditioned the sale upon receipt of the monies, the condition would be valid. As Rosh states,<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 81:1; <i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 207:4; <i>Knesset ha-Gedola</i>, <i>HM</i> 207 in the name of <i>Rivash</i>.</i> “if the situation is such that his intentions are clear, even if he does not indicate the sale is under these conditions, the conditions are binding.” And this conclusion would be applicable even if the condition were not reiterated at the time of the closing.<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 207:1. Cf. <i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i> 207:19.</i>
Lest one challenge this conclusion and argue that the <i>tenai</i> is only binding provided that it is reiterated at the time of the closing,<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netivot ha-Mishpat</i>, supra n. 81.</i> based upon the facts it is clear that without receiving such monies, the <i>Tove’a</i> would have not sold the colony to <i>Nitva</i>. Consequently, given that there exists an <i>umdana de-mukhah</i> (sound inference) that can serve as grounds for rescission of the transaction (<i>mekach ta’ut</i>), there is no evidence that <i>mehila</i> (waiver) transpired prior to the closing.<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 207: 4; <i>Sha’ar Mishpat</i>, <i>HM</i> 68:1, 98:1.</i>
If a person makes an oral commitment regarding a condition of the sale and fails to have this condition incorporated in the sales agreement, there is a controversy about whether this is an indication that he has waived this condition. Nevertheless, everyone would agree in our situation, where the sale was consummated <i>without</i> a written sales agreement, the condition remains.<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rema</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 207:1; <i>Teshuvot Pnei Yehoshua</i> 2:100; <i>Mishpat Shalom</i> 207:1.</i> As such, even though the formal purchase price was $500,000, the earlier promise to pay an additional $100,000 was never waived.
In sum, in construing the promise as a <i>tenai</i>, <i>Nitva</i> is obligated to pay $100,000 to the <i>Tove’a</i>.
<b>Decision</b>
1
A. Avraham’s Tent is owned by Venetian Lanes
B. The <i>Tove’a</i> has exclusive occupancy and use of Avraham’s Tent in the form of a negative easement and is granted an easement, a right of way to access Avraham’s Tent. <i>Nitva</i> shall hereby immediately publicly record the two easements.
2. <i>Nitva</i> is obligated to pay $100,000 to the <i>Tove’a</i>.
3. All other applications and claims are hereby denied.
4. The obligations set forth herein shall be enforceable in any court of competent jurisdiction.
5. Any provision of this decision may be modified with the consent of both parties.
There is a <i>da’at me’ut</i> (a minority opinion) that disagreed with portions of the above decision.
<b>Final Thoughts</b>
<b>Access to the Bungalow Unit</b>
Does the fact that the contract fails to grant the <i>Tove’a</i> a right of way to his bungalow preclude him from accessing his bungalow? Does a person who has occupancy and use of a house fly in the air in order to access his home?<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">A similar type of argument was set forth in <i>Bava Batra</i> 64b.</i> Shulhan Arukh states,<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 214:2 (end).</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If someone sells a pit or a cistern, the buyer does not have to acquire a right of way to the pit or cistern. The buyer may enter the seller’s house to go the cistern and draw water.</span>
Similarly, in our situation, upon receiving occupancy and use of the bungalow unit, the <i>Tove’a</i> does not have to formally acquire a right of way from the <i>Nitva</i>. Rather, <i>Tove’a</i> can access his home via the road of the bungalow colony that belongs to the <i>Nitva</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Whether the right of way belongs to the <i>Tove’a</i> or he simply has use of the access road is beyond our discussion. However, some <i>Rishonim</i> view the right as strictly a <i>shi’abud</i> in the form of an easement. See <i>Rashbam</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 82a; <i>Hiddushei ha-Ritva</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 64b.</i>
Should the <i>Nitva</i> refuse to grant the <i>Tove’a</i> a right of way, R. Greineman argues,<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hiddushim u-Bi’urim</i>, <i>Bava Batra</i> 64a.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">When the seller refuses to sell him the access road, seemingly the buyer can nullify the sale … What is the value of a pit and cistern which have no access to them?</span>
If the buyer cannot make use of his purchase there was no purpose to his acquisition of the property. Without citing Netivot ha-Mishpat,<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">Supra n. 7.</i> R. Greineman ascribes to the approach that non-use of the property purchased is equivalent to a defect in the “<i>guf ha-bayit</i>,” and therefore rescission is permitted. Similarly, in our scenario, the right to occupy/use the property implicitly assumes that the <i>Tove’a</i> has access to the road(s) leading to the bungalow unit.

h) A Wayward Torah Heir

<b>H. A Wayward Torah Heir</b>
<b>Facts</b>
A father authorized his attorney to prepare a last will and testament in accordance with NJ estate law. Among the terms of the testamentary disposition was a provision that his son (hereafter: <i>Tove’a</i>) and his daughter (hereafter: <i>Nitva’at</i>) would share equally in their father’s estate.
Upon the father’s demise, <i>Tove’a</i> filed an action in civil court alleging that though the will stated that the <i>Nitva’at</i> was the executor of the estate, nevertheless, subsequently, their father changed his mind and wanted the <i>Tove’a</i> to be the executor. In accordance with the terms of the civil will, the executor was to receive remuneration for his services. Based upon the submission of cumulative evidence, the court determined that the <i>Tove’a</i> was the executor of the estate and in fact was to receive compensation for his past services. Subsequently, <i>Tove’a</i> summoned the <i>Nitva’at</i> to appear in <i>beit din</i> for the purpose of challenging the halakhic validity of the civil will.
<b><i>Tove’a</i>’s Claims</b>
Given that according to Torah law, when the heirs are a son and a daughter, the entire estate of their father is to be transferred to the Torah heir, namely the son, the <i>Tove’a</i> is entitled to the entire inheritance.
<b><i>Nitva’at</i>’s Reply</b>
In reply to <i>Tove’a</i>’s claim, <i>Nitva’at</i> claims that there are various halakhic justifications for affirming a civil will. Moreover, the <i>beit din</i> should disinherit the <i>Tove’a</i> due to his decision to proceed to court to resolve the matter of the executor of the estate and then to proceed to <i>beit din</i> to deal with the halakhic propriety of the civil will. Apparently, concerning the issue of the executor, <i>Tove’a</i> believed that a civil judgment would be handed down in his favor. After receiving a civil ruling in his favor, and knowing that contesting a civil will in court would fail, <i>Tove’a</i> promptly proceeded to <i>beit din</i> to challenge the halakhic propriety of the civil will. Such forum shopping, argues <i>Nitva’at</i>, ought to be discredited by the <i>beit din</i>. Finally, <i>Nitva’at</i> advanced the claim to recoup her expenses incurred by having to appear in civil court at the <i>Tove’a</i>’s request.
<b>Discussion</b>
Without addressing the halakhic merits of affirming a civil testamentary disposition<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">See Chapter Two.</i> and assuming that <i>Tove’a</i> is entitled to the entire estate as the Torah heir, we will demonstrate that he should receive only the share of the inheritance that has been earmarked for him in the testamentary disposition.
<b>1. Litigation in Secular Court</b>
The <i>Tove’a</i>’s initial decision to address this matter in a secular court is a violation of Halakha. The Torah states “<i>ve-eleh ha-mishpatim asher tasim lifneihem</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shemot</i> 321:1.</i> from which the Talmud expounds “<i>lifneihem – ve-lo lifnei akum</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gittin</i> 88b.</i> As such, the Talmud understands that there is an <i>issur</i> against adjudicating one’s claims in a non-Jewish court. According to the Midrash Tanhuma,<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishpatim</i> 3.</i> subsequently codified in Mishneh Torah and Shulhan Arukh,<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Sanhedrin</i> 26:7; <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:1.</i> one who litigates his dispute in a civil jurisdiction “has cursed and raised a hand against the Torah of Moses.” As R. Dovid ben Zimra notes, appearance before a civil tribunal demonstrates that the <i>Tove’a</i> believes that the halakhic system is false and contributes to the removal of the <i>Shekhinah</i> (Divine presence) from the Jewish community.<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 4:1190.</i> According to many <i>Poskim</i>, this is an <i>issur de’oraita</i>, a biblical prohibition.<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 2:290; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:172; <i>Birkei Yosef</i>, <i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:3; <i>Hukot Hayyim</i>, <i>HM</i> 1. Others argue that the prohibition is rabbinic in nature. See, for example, <i>Sefer Mekor Barukh</i> 32.</i>
Even if a decision would not be handed down by the secular tribunal, the <i>issur</i> of litigating in a civil court has been committed. As Shulhan Arukh states, “It is forbidden to adjudicate”<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:1.</i> – the mere appearance in a civil court activates the <i>issur</i>. Even if an individual plans to resolve the matter in <i>beit din</i> and simply wants to place pressure upon the defendant by commencing an action in court, such behavior violates the prohibition.<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">B.T. Wosner, “Litigating in Civil Court” (Hebrew), 3 <i>Divrei Mishpat</i> 195 (5758).</i> Similarly, attempting to forge a compromise does not allow a plaintiff to commence a claim in civil court.<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Minhat Asher</i>, <i>Devarim</i> 3:1.</i> Consequently, <i>Tove’a</i>’s commencement of a claim in civil court entails a transgression of “<i>lifneihem – ve-lo lifnei akum</i>.”
<b>2. “A Sinner Should Not Benefit”</b>
Addressing the civil court’s ruling that <i>Tove’a</i> is the executor of the estate, <i>Tove’a</i>’s conduct is at variance with the rule that a sinner ought not to benefit from the fruits of his improper behavior. In the words of the Talmud, “a sinner should not profit” from his sin.<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 92b.</i> For example, though a sale of property on Shabbat will be final and deemed valid, nevertheless, if the purchaser accrued a profit from the sale, then he should donate his profits to the poor rather than benefit from his sin of negotiating a sale on Shabbat.<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mordekhai</i>, <i>Shabbat</i> 258 in the name of <i>Rabbeinu Gershon</i>.</i> Or, generally speaking, if I appoint a <i>shaliach</i> (agent) to perform an act, I am obligated to pay compensation for the <i>shaliach</i>’s efforts. Based upon what we have explained, the same is true for a <i>shaliach</i> who performs an act that is in contravention of Halakha on my behalf. However, in light of the principle that a sinner cannot profit from his sin, should the <i>shaliach</i> advance a claim for recovery of his fee for services rendered, <i>beit din</i> will penalize him and deny him any monetary relief.<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Ma’arkhei Lev</i> 113.</i> Addressing the halakhic rule that the profits earned by a professional dice player do not have to be returned,<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote"><i>SA</i>, <i>HM</i> 370:7.</i> should he regularly engage in such conduct, Radvaz concludes that he should be penalized and the profits should be returned to the losers.<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:517.</i> Such conclusions were endorsed by others.<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:551, 962, 2:148; <i>Teshuvot Shevut Ya’akov</i> 1:145.</i>
In fact, the rule that “he should not profit from his sinning” has been applied in <i>yerusha</i> matters. For example, dealing with a Torah heir who is a <i>mumar</i> (apostate), as well as a <i>yoresh</i> (heir) who murders his father in order to receive his inheritance, Rambam rules that he may be disinherited.<sup class="footnote-marker">400</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rambam</i>, Blau ed., 275; Rabinowitz-Teomim, <i>Hukat Mishpat</i>, <i>perek</i> 2, <i>se’if</i> 11.</i> Obviously, the act of homicide does not impact upon his status as a <i>yoresh</i>. However, to allow a <i>yoresh</i> to receive his <i>yerusha</i> after murdering his father is a vivid illustration of a sinner benefiting from “the fruits of his sin,” and as we know Halakha disapproves of a sinner profiting from his sin.<sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 92b; Eliav Shochetman, <i>The Illegality of an Act</i> (Hebrew), Yerushalayim, 1981, 250.</i>
Whether this rule of “he should not profit from his sinning” operates <i>min ha-din</i>, in accordance with black-letter Halakha,<sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Yashar le-Rabbeinu Tam</i>, <i>Helek ha-Hiddushim</i> 112.</i> or as a penal measure for one who is exploiting the halakhic process – akin to the principle “since he acted improperly, therefore, we will act improperly towards him”<sup class="footnote-marker">403</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ra’avad</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Hovel u-Mazik</i> 4:16. For further discussion of this rule, see infra text accompanying nn. 21–49.</i> – is a subject of debate.
In our scenario, given that <i>Tove’a</i> engaged in improper behavior by proceeding to civil court, he should not potentially profit from his sin by receiving remuneration for past services as mandated by the civil court.
<b>3. The Rule “Since He Acted Improperly, We Act Improperly Towards Him”</b>
Regarding <i>Tove’a</i>’s decision to initially proceed to civil court in order to resolve the dispute and then to appear in <i>beit din</i> to adjudicate another matter, <i>Tove’a</i>’s conduct is reminiscent of the various <i>teshuvot</i> of Rosh dealing with fraudulent conveyances, i.e., the debtor attempts to prevent the creditor from collecting his debt by assigning his assets to a third party. In one of them, Reuven was obligated to Shimon on an oral loan, so he gave all his property to Levi in order to defeat Shimon’s claim. In reply, Rosh concludes that the transfer to Levi was a sham and we must invalidate this legal transaction. The fact that he transfered all of his assets to a third party clearly indicates that his intent was to defraud Reuven of the money entitled to him. Can one imagine, <i>Rosh</i> exclaims, that a person who is bereft of his assets would need to beg from door to door in order to receive his daily subsistence? Obviously, the transaction was a sham in order to evade his duty to repay the loan. As Rosh himself states, if one swears that he will sell his assets in order to avoid repaying his debt, it is akin to “swearing to nullify a <i>mitzva</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">404</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 8:2.</i>
As Rosh notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">405</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 78:1.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">Whenever anyone sought to scheme against his fellow, the Sages of the Talmud stood against him to frustrate his plan. And we shall draw inferences and reach conclusions by analogy from one case to another, for the Sages of the Talmud were unable to specify everything that would happen in the future.</span>
Consequently, on the basis of a <i>hekesh</i> (reasoning by analogy) from the facts and the ruling of Rosh (and others<sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:942; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ritva</i> 187; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ran</i> 44; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rivash</i> 387; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>YD</i> 133; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 2:170. For the role of <i>hekesh</i> in the halakhic process, see this writer’s <i>Rabbinic Authority</i>, 53–57.</i>), as well as the various passages in the Talmud that state “since he acted improperly, therefore, we will act improperly with him,”<sup class="footnote-marker">407</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 110a; <i>Ketuvot</i> 86a; <i>Bava Batra</i> 48b; <i>Gittin</i> 40a.</i> we conclude that in our situation <i>Tove’a</i> acted improperly by commencing an action in civil court. A Torah-observant Jew must bring all claims to a <i>beit din</i> rather than bifurcate one’s claims between <i>beit din</i> and civil court so as to exploit each institution for the sake of generating the optimum in financial profits. Such forum shopping is halakhically unconscionable.
In short, invoking both rules “since he acted improperly, therefore, we will act improperly with him” and “he should not profit from his sinning” leads this panel to the conclusion that the <i>Tove’a</i>’s behavior ought to impact upon the amount he should receive from his father’s estate.
In fact, we have a case of <i>yerusha</i> (inheritance) dating back to Mishnaic times in which Torah heirs were deprived of their rightful share due to acting improperly. <i>Tove’a</i>’s pattern of behavior is remindful of the Mishnah that recounts the story of Bnei Rokhel. The Mishnah states:<sup class="footnote-marker">408</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 9:7.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">If someone distributes his property verbally, R. Eliezer states: whether he is healthy or critically ill, the properties which can be subject to a lien are acquired through money … Those which cannot become subject to a lien are acquired by <i>meshikha</i> [“pulling” – a form of acquisition]. They said to him: It occurred with the mother of the sons of Rokhel that she was ill and she said, “Give my veil to my daughter; it is worth twelve <i>maneh</i>,” and she died, and they upheld her words. He said to them: As to the sons of Rokhel, their mother should bury them.</span>
In the Mishnah, a dispute is recorded between the Hakhamim (Scholars) and R. Eliezer whether the gift of a dying man (<i>matnat shekhiv mera</i>) can be effected solely by word of mouth, or whether one requires the execution of a <i>kinyan</i>. Challenging R. Eliezer’s position, Hakhamim invoke the story of the mother of Bnei Rokhel (the name of the mother) who while dying, gifted verbally an asset to her daughter. Obviously, a verbal instruction is sufficient! In response to the challenge, R. Eliezer informs us that the Bnei Rokhel were sinners, and therefore the Scholars penalized the sons and validated the gift even though no <i>kinyan</i> was performed.<sup class="footnote-marker">409</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rabbeinu Gershon</i>, <i>Rashbam</i>, and <i>Meiri</i> on <i>Bava Batra</i> 156b; <i>Bah</i>, <i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 228:1.</i> In other words, in the absence of the execution of a <i>kinyan</i>, the sons should have inherited the asset, but since the sons were sinners who planted <i>kilayim</i>, a forbidden mixture of seeds, the Scholars penalized them by disinheriting them due to their improper behavior.<sup class="footnote-marker">410</sup><i class="footnote">Their improper behavior was the fact that they planted <i>kilayim</i>. See <i>Bava Batra</i> 156b.<br>In other words, even though their improper conduct was unrelated to their monetary entitlement to the asset of <i>yerusha</i>, nonetheless, the Scholars felt empowered to penalize them with regard to the <i>yerusha</i> due to improper behavior unrelated to the <i>yerusha</i>.</i>
In accordance with the <i>din</i>, the strict Halakha, the wicked sons should have retained their inheritance. Firstly, as the Mishnah instructs us, the ensuing punishment of violating the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>kilayim</i> entails a confiscation of the field itself.<sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shekalim</i> 1:2.</i> Moreover, Shmuel’s instructions, which state “keep away from inheritance transfers from a bad to a good son, much more so when they are from a son to daughter,” <sup class="footnote-marker">412</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 133b.</i> ought to propel this panel to the conclusion that the sons of Rokhel should have retained their <i>yerusha</i> as memorialized in their father’s will. Nonetheless, the Mishnah teaches us that we are empowered to disinherit Torah heirs due to their engagement in a sin that our authorities want others to refrain from emulating (as we will explain below).
If our Hakhamim in the Mishnah or Talmud penalized a person who transgressed the <i>issur</i> of <i>kilayim</i>, a man who forced a woman to consent to <i>kiddushin</i> (halakhic betrothal), or who snatched a girl for the sake of marriage,<sup class="footnote-marker">413</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 48b; <i>Yevamot</i> 110a.</i> <i>a fortiori</i>, in our situation in which the <i>Tove’a</i> transgressed an <i>issur</i> of litigating in secular court, he ought to be penalized! Lest one challenge that Mishnah’s position ought to be limited to an individual who engages in the transgression of the <i>issur</i> of <i>kilayim</i>, Pnei Mavin argues that the rabbinic penal powers extend to any <i>issurim</i> transgressed.<sup class="footnote-marker">414</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pnei Mavin</i> 1:233 (140b).</i> In fact, as we pointed out, Talmud itself invokes this penal authority regarding the transgression of other prohibitions. Such empowerment was not limited to the period of the Tannaim (scholars of the Mishnah), but was also implemented by the Amoraim (sages of the Talmud),<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 110a; <i>Bava Batra</i> 48b; <i>Gittin</i> 40a; <i>Ketuvot</i> 86a.</i> Rishonim (medieval authorities<i>)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 1:942; <i>Teshuvot ha-Rosh</i> 78:1–2; <i>Teshuvot ha-Ran</i> 44.</i> and Aharonim (later authorities).<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 3:873; <i>Teshuvot Maharashdam</i>, <i>YD</i> 133; <i>Teshuvot Imrei Yosher</i> 2:170.</i>
In fact, interestingly enough, though unaware of a <i>beit din</i>’s penal capacity and relying upon Turkish law, R. Yehoshua Ehrenburg of twentieth-century Eretz Yisrael concludes that Halakha should follow secular law and should disinherit a Torah heir who is a murderer.<sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 1:100.</i> Given that there is an oft-cited NY case, <i>Riggs v. Palmer</i>, in which an heir was deprived of her inheritance due to killing her father,<sup class="footnote-marker">419</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Riggs v. Palmer</i>, 115 NY 506 (1889).</i> contrary to Ohr Sameach’s view,<sup class="footnote-marker">420</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ohr Sameach</i>, <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, <i>Hilkhot Mamrim</i> 7:14. See also, <i>Teshuvot Tzitz Eliezer</i> 17:18.</i> R. Ehrenburg would argue that NY law ought to be applicable in our case. In effect, <i>dina de-malkhuta dina</i> is to be determinative in a case of a <i>yoresh</i> who acted improperly! To state it differently, had our case involved <i>Nitva</i>’s infraction of civil law, a <i>beit din</i> would have been empowered to disinherit him.
In fact, this conclusion is reminiscent, as tenuous as the connection may seem, of Hatam Sofer’s reply to the governmental legislation enacted that regulated the sale of wine and liquor in nineteenth-century Hungary. As R. Moshe Sofer notes,<sup class="footnote-marker">421</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>HM</i> 44. In fact, <i>Hatam Sofer</i> disinherited a son who assaulted his mother. See infra text accompanying n. 37.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">The legislation that was enacted … is not contrary to the <i>din</i> of the Torah, rather in accordance to the Torah. And if we had the opportunity to legislate we would have legislated in this fashion.</span>
The <i>beit din</i>’s authority is not limited to a case of a <i>mumar</i> or a murderer. Exercise of such authority was invoked in various instances in disinheriting a Torah heir.<sup class="footnote-marker">422</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot va-Yeshev Moshe</i> 2:13 (such an individual is aptly described in the Torah’s words as “<i>va-yishman yeshurun va-yiv’at</i>,” “and the nation fattened and bolted the Torah.”) See <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>EH</i> 2:158 cited by <i>Pithei Teshuva</i>, <i>HM</i> 276:1 (a son who batters his mother).</i>
Possibly, R. Feinstein’s <i>psak</i> is applicable to our case. R. Feinstein argues if a son believes in <i>Hashem</i>, is meticulous regarding his observance of <i>mitzvot</i> between man and <i>Hashem</i>, and educates his children in Torah and <i>mitzvot</i>, he will receive his Torah portion. However, in a situation in which the Torah heir engages in <i>aveirot</i> between <i>Hashem</i> and man, R. Feinstein rules that he may be deprived of his portion.<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggerot Moshe</i>, <i>HM</i> 2:50 (3) who argues that Hatam Sofer concurs with him.</i> Given that litigating in civil court is an example of an <i>issur</i> between man and God and according to some <i>Poskim</i>, entails an <i>issur de’oraita</i>, therefore R. Feinstein would conclude that he may be deprived of a portion of his <i>yerusha</i>.
As such, this <i>beit din</i> should use its authority<sup class="footnote-marker">424</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i> 2:148; <i>Sdei Hemed</i>, <i>Asifat Dinim</i>, <i>Ma’arekhet</i> 5, <i>siman</i> 3.</i> and penalize <i>Tove’a</i> for litigating in secular court, and his share of the <i>yerusha</i> should therefore be diminished.
We are ruling that the <i>Tove’a</i> receive only a partial share in his father’s estate. Admittedly, upon death, Halakha rather than compliance with a contractual obligation informs us that estate assets belong to the Torah heir. As the Talmud states, one’s inheritance comes from <i>Hashem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 47a.</i> Yet, as pointed out, Halakha empowers a <i>beit din</i> to penalize a Torah heir for acting improperly, i.e., for engaging in <i>issur</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sdei Hemed</i>, <i>Asifat Dinim</i>, <i>Ma’arekhet</i> 5, s<i>iman</i> 3, 388. Such penal authority is predicated upon the capacity of a <i>beit din</i> to not only divest the propriety rights of an owner, namely the <i>bekhor</i>, but affects a valid transfer of the estate to third parties, namely the sisters. See <i>Sdei Hemed</i>, ibid., p. 387; <i>Sdei Hemed</i>, <i>Kelalim</i>, <i>Ma’arekhet Heh</i>, s<i>iman</i> 59, 176–181.</i> However, one might contend that <i>beit din</i> is perverting justice, as Rambam rules,<sup class="footnote-marker">427</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Mitzvot</i>, <i>mitzvat lo ta’ase</i> 278.</i>
The <i>dayan</i> is warned to refrain from perverting the Halakha regarding one of the litigants if he knew he was wicked and sinful, Hashem has warned us to refrain from punishing him by denying him his [monetary] entitlement.
Perversion of justice is not limited to rendering a decision that favors one party, but equally extends to a <i>Posek</i> or a <i>dayan</i> who misrepresents the grounds for his ruling. Engaging in such behavior compromises the arbiter’s integrity and may entail the transgression of <i>bal tosif</i>, adding to the Torah and/or lying.<sup class="footnote-marker">428</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer ha-Hinukh</i>, <i>mitzvat a’se</i> 465 (Chavel ed.); Zvi Chajes, <i>Darkei Ho’roah</i>, <i>siman</i> 6; <i>Teshuvot Dvar Yehoshua</i> 1:19:6 (addendum); <i>Arukh le-Ner</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 65b. For additional sources and discussion, see A. Frimer and D. Frimer, “Women’s Prayer Groups – Theory and Practice,” 32 <i>Tradition</i> 5, 63–69 (1998).</i> For example, a rabbi cannot claim that the commission of a particular action is a biblical violation when in actuality it is only a rabbinic infraction. Or one cannot prohibit a particular activity in order to promote peace when Halakha doesn’t recognize this rationale for proscribing this behavior.
Invoking Pnei Mavin’s words,<sup class="footnote-marker">429</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pnei Mavin</i>, supra n. 29.</i> R. Hezekiah Medini’s teachings regarding the responsibility of a <i>dayan</i> are instructive:<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sdei Hemed</i>, supra n. 41 at 387.</i>
<span class="poetry indentAll">A <i>dayan</i> should not penalize by perverting justice due to the fact that he is a wicked individual and transgressor. Even if he is wicked and a transgressor, one must judge a truthful <i>din</i> … And even though a <i>beit din</i> is authorized to mete out punishment in variance with the <i>din</i> [<i>hora’at sha’ah</i>] … it is because we want the sinner to repent … or for people to know and fear and not continue to sin … and all this applies when we do it as punishment and revenge. What is wrong is perverting justice if he does not know and he thinks Halakha obligates such action …</span>
In other words, as elucidated by R. Eliav Shochetman, the prohibition of perversion of justice applies only when the <i>beit din</i>’s judgment that is in variance with the <i>din</i> will be perceived by the public as reflecting the <i>din</i>. However, if upon deliberation a <i>beit din</i> arrives at the decision to penalize someone, then the <i>beit din</i> must clearly explain the grounds for its <i>psak din</i>. In its decision, the <i>beit din</i> must state that, in accordance to the din, he may have been entitled to receive his portion as a Torah heir, however, due to his religious impropriety in engaging in forum shopping, <i>Tove’a</i> will be penalized by diminishing his <i>yerusha</i>. It is within the province of <i>beit din</i> to employ its penal authority in order that others do not emulate his improper behavior, in this case, forum shopping.<sup class="footnote-marker">431</sup><i class="footnote">Shochetman, supra n. 18, at 242.</i> Such an approach has been invoked in a case by R. Avraham Sherman, a Yerushalmi <i>dayan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote">A. Sherman, “The Prohibition against Perversion of the Verdict of a Wicked Individual In Order to Punish Him” (Hebrew), 8 <i>Shurat ha-Din</i> 70 (5763).</i>
Hence, given the halakhic precedent for invoking a <i>beit din</i>’s penal authority, we argue that such punitive measures be enforced in our scenario of a <i>Tove’a</i> who initially attempted to find relief by engaging in forum shopping for the purpose of depriving his sister of portions of an estate gifted by their father. As such, though the <i>Tove’a</i>, as a Torah heir, may have been entitled to the entire <i>yerusha</i>, due to his forum shopping, the <i>Tove’a</i> should receive only half of his <i>yerusha</i>.
<b>4. Recovery of Court and Legal Fees</b>
Finally, in reply to <i>Nitva’at</i>’s claim to recover court and legal costs incurred in secular court, generally speaking, <i>Tove’a</i> is obligated to reimburse the <i>Nitva’at</i> for such costs.<sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tur</i>, <i>HM</i> 26:7, in the name of <i>Rosh</i>; <i>Teshuvot ha-Radvaz</i> 1:172; <i>Teshuvot Divrei Hayyim</i> vol. 2, <i>HM</i> 1.</i> And, if for example, the parties agreed to revisit the matter of resolving who is the estate’s executor prior to his appearance in <i>beit din</i>, <i>Tove’a</i> would have been obligated to pay for <i>Nitva’at</i>’s court and legal fees which were incurred in civil court.<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Divrei Hayyim</i>, supra n. 48.</i>
Nonetheless, despite <i>Tove’a</i>’s right to revisit the case, said conclusion is predicated upon the fact that the <i>Nitva’at</i> attempted to summon the <i>Tove’a</i> to a <i>beit din</i> to determine the issue of the estate’s executor and the <i>Tove’a</i> refused to appear.<sup class="footnote-marker">435</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Maharsham</i> 1:89; <i>Teshuvot ve-Hanhagot</i> 5:364.</i> The filing of a <i>hazamana</i>, summons to appear in <i>beit din</i>, never happened. In the absence of initiating a suit in beit din, the <i>Nitva’at</i> acquiescene to appear in civil court prempts the possibility of revisiting the claim in <i>beit din</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">436</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Teshuvot Tashbetz</i> 3:68.</i>
However, if the <i>Nitva’at</i> failed to summon him to <i>beit din</i>, such inaction is construed as a waiver for recovery of court and litigation fees.<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Levush</i> in the name of <i>Divrei Hayyim</i> 2:46; <i>Teshuvot Teshurat Shai</i>, <i>Mahadura Tinyana</i> 164; <i>Teshuvot Minhat Shai</i> 2:60.</i> Hence, in our case, the <i>Nitva’at</i> failed to summon the <i>Tove’a</i> to a <i>beit din</i>, and therefore, the claim for recovery of said fees is without foundation.
<b>Decision</b>
1. <i>Tove’a</i> shall receive half of the estate distribution as memorialized in the civil will.
2. The <i>Nitva’at</i>’s claims for recovery of court and legal fees are hereby denied.
